Prime Coat:   Primer, galvanized, water based, Dunn-Edwards, Ultra-Grip Premi-
um UGPR00-1, MPI #134. 
b. 
Intermediate Coat:  Latex, interior, matching topcoat. 
c. 
Topcoat:   Latex, interior, semi-gloss, Dunn-Edwards, Spartazero SZRO50, 
(Gloss Level 5), MPI #54. 
 
D. 
Gypsum Board Substrates, except where noted for ‘Epoxy Coating’: 
 
1. 
Premium Architectural Coating System: 
 
a. 
Prime Coat:  Primer sealer, latex, interior, Dunn-Edwards, Vinylastic Select 
VNSL00, MPI #50. 
b. 
Intermediate Coat:  Latex, interior, matching topcoat. 
c. 
Topcoat:   Latex, interior, eggshell, Dunn-Edwards, Spartazero SZRO30, (Gloss 
Level 3), MPI #52. 
                        END OF SECTION  
SECTION 099600                                                                                               HIGH-PERFORMANCE COATINGS 
PART 1 - GENERAL 
PART 1 - GENERAL 
1.1 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
A. 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and 
Division 01 Specification Sections, apply to this Section. 
1.2 
SUMMARY 
A. 
Section includes surface preparation and the application of high-performance coating systems 
1. 
Interior Substrates: 
a. 
Concrete surfaces. 
b. 
Steel. 
c. 
Galvanized metal. 
d. 
Aluminum (not anodized or otherwise coated). 
e. 
Gypsum board. 
B. 
Related Requirements: 
1. 
Section 051200 "Structural Steel Framing for shop priming of structural steel with primers 
specified in this Section. 
2. 
Section 055213 "Pipe and Tube Railings" for shop painting pipe and tube railings with coatings 
specified in this Section. 
3. 
Section 099123 "Interior Painting" for general field painting. 
1.3 
DEFINITIONS 
A. 
MPI Gloss Level 5: 35 to 70 units at 60 degrees, according to ASTM D523. 
B. 
MPI Gloss Level 6: 70 to 85 units at 60 degrees, according to ASTM D523. 
C. 
MPI Gloss Level 7: More than 85 units at 60 degrees, according to ASTM D523. 
1.4 
ACTION SUBMITTALS 
A. 
Product Data: For each type of product. Include preparation requirements and application instructions. 
1. 
Include printout of current "MPI Approved Products List" for each product category specified, 
with the proposed product highlighted. 
2. 
Indicate VOC content. 
B. 
Samples for Initial Selection: For each type of topcoat product indicated. 
 
 
1. 
Submit Samples on rigid backing, 8 inches square. 
2. 
Apply coats on Samples in steps to show each coat required for system. 
3. 
Label each coat of each Sample. 
4. 
Label each Sample for location and application area. 
D. 
Product List: Cross-reference to coating system and locations of application areas. Use same designations 
indicated on Drawings and in schedules. Include color designations. 
1.5 
MAINTENANCE MATERIAL SUBMITTALS 
A. 
Furnish extra materials, from the same product run, that match products installed and that are packaged 
with protective covering for storage and identified with labels describing contents. 
1. 
Coatings: 5 percent, but not less than 1 gal.  of each material and color applied. 
1.6 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
A. 
Mockups: Apply mockups of each coating system indicated to verify preliminary selections made under 
Sample submittals and to demonstrate aesthetic effects and set quality standards for materials and 
execution. 
1. 
Architect will select one surface to represent surfaces and conditions for application of each 
coating system. 
a. 
Wall and Ceiling Surfaces: Provide samples of at least 100 sq. ft. 
b. 
Other Items: Architect will designate items or areas required. 
2. 
Final approval of color selections will be based on mockups. 
a. 
If preliminary color selections are not approved, apply additional mockups of additional 
colors selected by Architect at no added cost to Owner. 
3. 
Approval of mockups does not constitute approval of deviations from the Contract Documents 
contained in mockups unless Architect specifically approves such deviations in writing. 
4. 
Subject to compliance with requirements, approved mockups may become part of the completed 
Work if undisturbed at time of Substantial Completion. 
1.7 
DELIVERY, STORAGE, AND HANDLING 
A. 
Store materials not in use in tightly covered containers in well-ventilated areas with ambient temperatures 
continuously maintained at not less than 45 deg F. 
1. 
Maintain containers in clean condition, free of foreign materials and residue. 
2. 
Remove rags and waste from storage areas daily. 
1.8 
FIELD CONDITIONS 
A. 
Apply coatings only when temperature of surfaces to be coated and ambient air temperatures are between 
 
 
B. 
Do not apply coatings when relative humidity exceeds 85 percent; at temperatures less than 5 deg F above 
the dew point; or to damp or wet surfaces. 
C. 
Do not apply exterior coatings in snow, rain, fog, or mist. 
PART 2 - PRODUCTS 
2.1 
MANUFACTURERS 
A. 
Manufacturers: Subject to compliance with requirements, available manufacturers offering products that 
may be incorporated into the Work include, but are not limited to, the following: 
1. 
Benjamin Moore & Co. 
2. 
Carboline/Dunn Edwards 
3. 
Sherwin-Williams Company (The). 
 
B. 
Products: Subject to compliance with requirements, [provide product] [provide one of the products] 
[available products that may be incorporated into the Work include, but are not limited to products] listed 
in the Exterior High-Performance Coating Schedule or Interior High-Performance Coating Schedule for 
the coating category indicated. 
2.2 
HIGH-PERFORMANCE COATINGS, GENERAL 
A. 
MPI Standards: Products shall comply with MPI standards indicated and shall be listed in its "MPI 
Approved Products Lists." 
B. 
Material Compatibility: 
1. 
Materials for use within each paint system shall be compatible with one another and substrates 
indicated, under conditions of service and application as demonstrated by manufacturer, based on 
testing and field experience. 
2. 
For each coat in a paint system, products shall be recommended in writing by topcoat 
manufacturers for use in paint system and on substrate indicated. 
3. 
Products shall be of same manufacturer for each coat in a coating system. 
C. 
Colors: Match Architect's samples. 
2.3 
SOURCE QUALITY CONTROL 
A. 
Testing of Coating Materials: Owner reserves the right to invoke the following procedure: 
1. 
Owner will engage the services of a qualified testing agency to sample coating materials. 
Contractor will be notified in advance and may be present when samples are taken. If coating 
materials have already been delivered to Project site, samples may be taken at Project site. 
Samples will be identified, sealed, and certified by testing agency. 
2. 
Testing agency will perform tests for compliance with product requirements. 
3. 
Owner may direct Contractor to stop applying coatings if test results show materials being used do 
not comply with product requirements. Contractor shall remove noncomplying coating materials 
 
 
from Project site, pay for testing, and recoat surfaces coated with rejected materials. Contractor 
will be required to remove rejected materials from previously coated surfaces if, on recoating with 
complying materials, the two coatings are incompatible. 
PART 3 - EXECUTION 
3.1 
EXAMINATION 
A. 
Examine substrates and conditions, with Applicator present, for compliance with requirements for 
maximum moisture content and other conditions affecting performance of the Work. 
B. 
Maximum Moisture Content of Substrates: When measured with an electronic moisture meter as follows: 
1. 
Concrete: 12 percent. 
2. 
Fiber-Cement Board: 12 percent. 
3. 
Masonry (Clay and CMUs): 12 percent. 
4. 
Wood: 15 percent. 
5. 
Gypsum Board: 12 percent. 
6. 
Plaster: 12 percent. 
C. 
Gypsum Board Substrates: Verify that finishing compound is sanded smooth. 
D. 
Plaster Substrates: Verify that plaster is fully cured. 
E. 
Verify suitability of substrates, including surface conditions and compatibility, with existing finishes and 
primers. 
F. 
Proceed with coating application only after unsatisfactory conditions have been corrected. 
1. 
Application of coating indicates acceptance of surfaces and conditions. 
3.2 
PREPARATION 
A. 
Comply with manufacturer's written instructions and recommendations in "MPI Architectural Painting 
Specification Manual" applicable to substrates and coating systems indicated. 
B. 
Remove hardware, covers, plates, and similar items already in place that are removable and are not to be 
painted. If removal is impractical or impossible because of size or weight of item, provide surface-applied 
protection before surface preparation and painting. 
1. 
After completing painting operations, use workers skilled in the trades involved to reinstall items 
that were removed. Remove surface-applied protection if any. 
C. 
Clean substrates of substances that could impair bond of coatings, including dust, dirt, oil, grease, and 
incompatible paints and encapsulants. 
1. 
Remove incompatible primers and reprime substrate with compatible primers or apply tie coat as 
required to produce coating systems indicated. 
 
 
D. 
Concrete Substrates: Remove release agents, curing compounds, efflorescence, and chalk. Do not coat 
surfaces if moisture content or alkalinity of surfaces to be coated exceeds that permitted in manufacturer's 
written instructions. 
1. 
Clean surfaces with pressurized water. Use pressure range of 1500 to 4000 psi at 6 to 12 inches. 
2. 
Abrasive blast clean surfaces to comply with SSPC-SP 7/NACE No. 4. 
E. 
Masonry Substrates: Remove efflorescence and chalk. Do not coat surfaces if moisture content, alkalinity 
of surfaces, or alkalinity of mortar joints exceeds that permitted in manufacturer's written instructions. 
1. 
Clean surfaces with pressurized water. Use pressure range of 100 to 600 psi at 6 to 12 inches. 
F. 
Steel Substrates: Remove rust, loose mill scale, and shop primer if any. Clean using methods 
recommended in writing by paint manufacturer but not less than the following: 
1. 
SSPC-SP 7/NACE No. 4. 
2. 
SSPC-SP 11. 
3. 
SSPC-SP 6/NACE No. 3. 
4. 
SSPC-SP 10/NACE No. 2. 
5. 
SSPC-SP 5/NACE No. 1. 
G. 
Shop-Primed Steel Substrates: Clean field welds, bolted connections, and areas where shop paint is 
abraded. Paint exposed areas with the same material as used for shop priming to comply with SSPC-PA 1 
for touching up shop-primed surfaces. 
H. 
Galvanized-Metal Substrates: Remove grease and oil residue from galvanized sheet metal by mechanical 
methods to produce clean, lightly etched surfaces that promote adhesion of subsequently applied coatings. 
I. 
Aluminum Substrates: Remove loose surface oxidation. 
3.3 
APPLICATION 
A. 
Apply high-performance coatings according to manufacturer's written instructions and recommendations 
in "MPI Architectural Painting Specification Manual." 
1. 
Use applicators and techniques suited for coating and substrate indicated. 
2. 
Coat surfaces behind movable equipment and furniture same as similar exposed surfaces. Before 
final installation, coat surfaces behind permanently fixed equipment or furniture with prime coat 
only. 
3. 
Coat backsides of access panels, removable or hinged covers, and similar hinged items to match 
exposed surfaces. 
4. 
Do not apply coatings over labels of independent testing agencies or equipment name, 
identification, performance rating, or nomenclature plates. 
B. 
Tint each undercoat a lighter shade to facilitate identification of each coat if multiple coats of the same 
material are to be applied. Tint undercoats to match color of finish coat but provide sufficient difference 
in shade of undercoats to distinguish each separate coat. 
C. 
If undercoats or other conditions show through final coat, apply additional coats until cured film has a 
uniform coating finish, color, and appearance. 
 
 
D. 
Apply coatings to produce surface films without cloudiness, spotting, holidays, laps, brush marks, runs, 
sags, ropiness, or other surface imperfections. Produce sharp glass lines and color breaks. 
3.4 
FIELD QUALITY CONTROL 
A. 
Dry Film Thickness Testing: Owner may engage the services of a qualified testing and inspecting agency 
to inspect and test coatings for dry film thickness. 
1. 
Contractor shall touch up and restore coated surfaces damaged by testing. 
2. 
If test results show that dry film thickness of applied coating does not comply with coating 
manufacturer's written recommendations, Contractor shall pay for testing and apply additional 
coats as needed to provide dry film thickness that complies with coating manufacturer's written 
recommendations. 
3.5 
CLEANING AND PROTECTION 
A. 
At end of each workday, remove rubbish, empty cans, rags, and other discarded materials from Project 
site. 
B. 
After completing coating application, clean spattered surfaces. Remove spattered coatings by washing, 
scraping, or other methods. Do not scratch or damage adjacent finished surfaces. 
C. 
Protect work of other trades against damage from coating operation. Correct damage to work of other 
trades by cleaning, repairing, replacing, and recoating, as approved by Architect, and leave in an 
undamaged condition. 
D. 
At completion of construction activities of other trades, touch up and restore damaged or defaced coated 
surfaces. 
3.6 
INTERIOR HIGH-PERFORMANCE COATING SCHEDULE 
A. 
Concrete Substrates, Vertical Surfaces: 
1. 
Epoxy, High-Build System MPI INT 3.1P: 
a. 
Prime Coat: High-build epoxy, matching topcoat (reduced). 
b. 
Intermediate Coat: High-build epoxy, matching topcoat. 
c. 
Topcoat: High-build epoxy, low gloss [, MPI #108]. 
1) 
S-W Macropoxy 646-100, B58-600 Series, 5.0-10.0 mils dry, per coat. 
B. 
Steel Substrates: 
1. 
Epoxy-Modified Latex System: 
a. 
Prime Coat: Primer, rust-inhibitive, water based: 
1) 
S-W Pro-Cryl Universal Primer, B66-310 Series, at 2.0 to 4.0 mils dry, per coat. 
 
 
c. 
Topcoat: Epoxy-modified latex, interior, eggshell:  
1) 
S-W Pro Industrial Waterbased Catalyzed Epoxy Eggshell, B73-300 Series, at 2.0 to 
4.0 mils dry, per coat. 
d. 
Topcoat: Epoxy-modified latex, interior, gloss: 
1) 
S-W Pro Industrial Waterbased Catalyzed Epoxy Gloss, B73-300 Series, at 2.0 to 
4.0 mils dry, per coat. 
C. 
Gypsum Board Substrates: 
1. 
Epoxy System: 
a. 
Prime Coat: Primer sealer, latex, interior: 
1) 
S-W ProMar 200 Zero VOC Interior Latex Primer, B28W2600, at 1.0 mils dry, per 
coat. 
b. 
Intermediate Coat: Epoxy, gloss matching topcoat. 
c. 
Topcoat: Epoxy, semi-gloss: 
1) 
S-W Macropoxy 646-100, B58-600 Series, at 5.0 to 10 mils dry, per coat. 
 
2. 
Pre-Catalyzed Waterbased Epoxy (Dunn Edwards/Carboline) 
a. 
Prime Coat:  Primer sealer, latex, interior, Dunn-Edwards, Vinylastic Premium VNPR00. 
b. 
Intermediate Coat:  Pre-catalyzed waterbased epoxy matching topcoat. 
c. 
Topcoat:  Waterbased epoxy, interior, semi-gloss, Dunn-Edwards, Enduracat ENPX50, 
(Gloss Level 5). 
 
 
 
 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
 
 
 
 
Division 11 
Equipment 
SECTION 110010 
EQUIPMENT GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
SUMMARY 
 
This specification indicates the general technical requirements for packaged and custom-built process equipment 
and applies to all equipment specified in the attached specification package. 
 
In case of discrepancies or conflicts between documents, immediately notify the Owner or Owner’s 
Representative in writing. The written correspondence shall include a description of the discrepancy or conflict, 
the recommended resolution and any cost or schedule implications. The Manufacturer shall proceed after 
receiving written confirmation from the Owner or Owner’s representative. 
 
Components shall be sized and provided as specified. Where such specification is not included, sizing shall be 
supplied by the Manufacturer to be consistent with the stated application of the equipment. The Manufacturer 
shall be responsible for supplying components that meet the performance requirements indicated in this and all 
attached specifications and data sheets. Like components among like systems shall be by a single manufacturer. 
The Manufacturer shall be responsible for the proper operation and performance of the system. 
 
The Manufacturer may submit any proposed deviations that would improve design, delivery, or decrease cost 
without affecting quality. Any proposed deviation, including resultant impact on schedule and / or cost, shall be 
submitted in writing to the Owner or Owner's representative for approval. If no such deviations are submitted, it 
 
Substitutions after contract award will only be allowed with due cause (such as lead time, quality, or Owner 
preference) and only with approval of Owner or Owner's representative. Any requested modification to contract 
amounts due to substitution shall be submitted with a written Substitution Proposal. 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide functional, assembled package system(s) that incorporate the specific equipment 
and components indicated in the equipment specification. The bid proposal will add to the project definition 
provided herein but shall not in any way replace any conditions of the specification unless specific written 
exceptions are approved by the Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
1.2. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
This specification section defines technical definitions and code requirements as part of an equipment 
specification package. Commercial requirements are defined elsewhere in the Request for Proposal (RFP) 
document.  
 
1.3. 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
This section indicates the Quality Assurance requirements for the design, fabrication, testing, documentation, 
shipment, and installation of the equipment for which this specification pertains. The requirements indicated 
under this section are in addition to any requirements indicated on attached specifications. The manufacturer is 
required to have an internal QA program. 
 
1.3.1. 
Definitions 
 
Critical Systems 
 
A critical system is any system that comes in direct contact with product. Additionally, any system whose 
conveyance ultimately contacts product or are incorporated into such product, shall be considered a critical 
system. Critical systems include: 
 
• 
Product – All product contact piping, including media, buffer, process acids and bases, and other systems 
as indicated on the drawings and in this specification. 
• 
Compressed Air – Low dewpoint filtered air, free of oil and particulates. 
• 
Clean-In-Place (CIP) – System used to clean product piping, components, and equipment in-situ. 
• 
Reverse Osmosis Water (RO) – Water meeting the requirements as defined by the USP. 
• 
Water for Injection (WFI) – Water meeting the requirements as defined by the USP. 
 
Critical Materials 
 
A critical material is any component that comes in direct contact with product. Any component that contacts 
liquids or gases (including Clean Steam), which ultimately contact product or are incorporated into such product, 
shall be considered critical materials. 
 
Critical Surfaces 
 
A critical surface is any surface of a critical material that is exposed to the product. 
 
Sanitary Clamp Fitting 
 
A sanitary clamp fitting is any fitting produced by various manufacturers that is capable of interchanging with 
and mating to a sanitary style ferrule (TriClover “Tri-Clamp” or other) using a standard gasket and either a hinged 
or bolted clamp. 
 
 
 
1.3.2. 
Codes, Ordinances and Regulations 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide equipment and components that comply with all current applicable national, state 
and local codes and standards, inclusive of all applicable supplements. Critical systems equipment shall conform 
to applicable cGMP guidelines as endorsed by the FDA. The following codes, standards and guidelines, in 
addition to those indicated on attached specifications, may be applicable to the design, manufacture and testing 
of each specified piece of equipment. These include, but are not limited to, the following: 
 
• 
AGA – American Gas Association 
• 
AISI – American Iron and Steel Institute 
• 
ANSI - American National Standards Institute 
                                F2.1, Food Drug and Beverage Equipment 
• 
API – American Petroleum Institute 
• 
ARI – American Refrigeration Institute 
• 
ASHRAE – American Society of Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers 
• 
ASME - American Society of Mechanical Engineers 
 
     Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Div. 1 
               Bioprocessing Equipment Standard BPE, current edition with all applicable supplements  
              B31.3, Chemical Plant and Petroleum Refinery Piping 
• 
ASTM - American Society of Testing and Materials (Standards A269-94a and A270-95) 
• 
AWS - American Welding Society, Welding Handbook 
• 
CFR - Code of Federal Regulations Title 21 
          Part   11:  Electronic Records, Electronic Signatures 
           Part 211:  Current Good Manufacturing Practices for Finished Pharmaceuticals (cGMPs) 
• 
EMA - European Medicines Agency 
• 
EPA - U.S. Environmental Protection Agency 
• 
FDA - Food and Drug Administration 
• 
FM – Factory Mutual 
• 
GAMP - Good Automated Manufacturing Practices 
• 
HIS - Hydraulic Institute Standards 
• 
IEC – International Electrotechnical Commission 
• 
IEEE - Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers 
• 
ISA – The International Society of Automation 
• 
GAMP – Good Automated Manufacturing Practice 
• 
MSS - Manufacturers Standardization Society of the Valve and Fittings Industry 
• 
NBIC - National Board Inspection Code 
• 
NEC - National Electrical Code 
• 
NEMA – National Electrical Manufacturers Association 
• 
NFPA - National Fire Protection Association 
• 
NIH/CDC - National Institutes of Health / Center for Disease Control Guidelines 
• 
NIST – National Institute of Science and Technology 
• 
OSHA – U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration 
• 
SPC  - Society for Protective Coatings 
• 
TEMA – Tubular Exchanger Manufacturers Association 
• 
UL – Underwriter's Laboratories 
• 
USP – US Pharmacopeia 
• 
Local Building Codes 
 
1.3.3. 
Inspections 
 
The Manufacturer shall allow the Owner or Owner’s Representative to inspect the Manufacturer’s shop and work 
related to this project at any time during fabrication or testing of the equipment. 
 
1.4. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
1.4.1. 
General 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide submittals indicated as required in the attached equipment specifications.  
 
The English language and USCS units of measurement shall be used on all documents and drawings produced, 
except that the SI units of liters and °C are allowable when referring to critical systems. All correspondence, 
drawings, instructions, etc., shall be in the English language. All submittals shall display the Owner’s equipment 
tag number. Submittals shall be legible with sufficient space for comments. 
 
All dimensioned and scalable submittal drawings shall be supplied in AutoCAD 2002 or later version DWG 
format. All other documents shall be supplied in Microsoft Word, Excel, Project, or Adobe PDF format. 
 
All documentation indicated as required in the equipment specification shall be compiled as part of an Electronic 
Turnover Package (ETOP). The Manufacturer shall make at least one complete ETOP package available for 
review at FAT. 
 
1.4.2. 
Acceptable Manufacturers 
 
Where specific manufacturers are listed in the specifications they are to be recognized as the approved 
manufacturers. If no manufacturers are indicated, any product or material that complies with the specification for 
the intended application may be submitted for approval.  
 
1.4.3. 
Submittal Procedures 
 
Refer to the accompanying commercial documentation for the procedural requirements concerning the 
production, schedule, review, actions, and responsibilities of submittals.  
 
Allow sufficient time so that design and fabrication will not be delayed because of the time required to process 
submittals, including time for re-submittals. 
 
Allow ten (10) working days for initial review. Allow additional time if processing must be delayed to permit 
coordination with subsequent submittals. The Owner or Owner's Representative will advise the Manufacturer 
when a submittal being processed must be delayed for coordination. 
 
No extension of contract time will be authorized because of failure to transmit submittals sufficiently in advance 
of the work to permit processing or for rejected submittals. 
 
1.4.4. 
VDR Definitions 
 
The items defined below shall be provided as indicated in the VDR. 
 
CODE                                     DESCRIPTION 
 
A-1: 
GENERAL ARRANGEMENT DRAWINGS 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Equipment dimensions and weights (total assembled and operating) 
2. Equipment centerline  
3. Elevations referenced to finish floor elevation. 
4. Piping/electrical connections shall indicate type of connections, sizes, and locations including 
dimensions with reference points.  
5. Foundation requirements/plans 
 
7. Clearances required for component removal. 
8. Leveling instructions or tolerances, and special handling instructions, if any 
 
A-2: 
FLOW DIAGRAMS OR PIPING & INSTRUMENTATION DIAGRAMS (P&IDs) 
 
Process/Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) shall be provided for the main equipment 
package and any subsystems that comprise part of the overall equipment system. P&IDs shall follow 
ISA conventions as much as practical and possible, and a lead sheet indicating all symbology used on 
the P&IDs with descriptions shall be provided. P&IDs shall indicate the following as a minimum: 
 
1. Single line interconnection diagram of all pieces of equipment 
2. Equipment description blocks for each piece of equipment on the drawing indicating, at a 
minimum, capacity, size, manufacturer, model number. 
3. List of all plant/facility services required including sizes, capacities, temperatures, pressures, 
flow rates, etc. 
4. Instrumentation and valves 
5. Directions of flow/slope 
6. Identification letters for all connection points to the equipment 
7. Equipment, instrument, and valve tag numbers 
8. Size, material specification, service, insulation, and line number for all piping 
9. A basic level of control system interconnects for all sensors, transmitters, and automated valves 
10. Set points for relief valves, regulators, and control valves shall be indicated. 
11. All hygienic clamp connections on critical system piping 
12. Notation necessary to adequately explain unique functions of specific items or subsystems, as 
required, and to add general clarity to the drawing. 
 
A-3: 
SCHEMATIC PIPING DIAGRAMS 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Materials of construction 
2. Bill of materials 
3. Type of connections with pipe sizes 
4. Special requirements such as slope 
5. Directions of flow 
6. Identification letters for all connection points to the equipment. 
 
A-4: 
FOUNDATION DIAGRAMS, LOADING REQUIREMENTS, AND SEISMIC DESIGN 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Dimensions 
2. Loading requirements w/relation to a reference point. 
3. Seismic design information 
 
A-5 : 
CATALOG INFORMATION OF SUPPLIED COMPONENTS  
 
 
Information shall include:  
1. Cut sheets for all items for which design drawings will not be supplied. These must include 
dimensions, locations of piping/electrical connections, types of piping/electrical connections, 
material of construction, etc. 
2. All sub-vendor's applicable mechanical, electrical, and instrumentation cut-sheets. 
3. Bill of materials  
 
 
 
 
A-6: 
DETAIL/SHOP DRAWINGS FOR COMPONENTS 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Plan and elevation drawings for all components, which are assembled to achieve a completed, 
functional piece of equipment and are not shown in adequate detail on the general arrangement 
type drawings. 
2. Bill of Materials for component or detail drawing 
 
A-7: 
AS-BUILT AND CERTIFIED EQUIPMENT DRAWINGS 
 
 
Provide certified drawings that reflect the as-built status for all drawings previously issued for review 
and approval. All drawings shall indicate the Owner's purchase order number, equipment item number, 
project number, description, National Board number when applicable, and manufacturer's serial number. 
Certified drawings shall be signed and dated by an authorized representative of the manufacturer of that 
component or system. 
  
 
 
 
  
A-8: 
MECHANICAL SEAL CROSS SECTION 
 
 
Drawings are required for all mechanical seals included in the scope of equipment package. 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Identified parts list. 
2. Bill of materials 
 
A-9: 
VARIABLE FREQUENCY DRIVE (VFD) DATA SHEET 
 
 
Information required for all VFDs used on the equipment. 
 
  
 
Information shall include: 
1. Driver manufacturer's name 
2. Driver model number, catalog number, etc. 
3. Design characteristics including: 
a. Efficiencies, hp, rpm, voltage, amperage, cycles, phase requirements  
b. Dimensions 
4. Bill of materials 
5. Driver tag number (if applicable) 
 
A-10: 
POWER & CONTROL PANEL DRAWINGS  
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Plan and elevation drawings for all components, with dimensions 
2. Interior view including component layout information. 
3. Wiring and pneumatic raceways 
4. Bill of Materials 
5. Nameplate schedules 
 
 A-11: 
POWER AND CONTROL WIRING & PNEUMATIC DIAGRAMS AND SCHEMATICS 
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Terminal strip/wiring numbering 
2. Starters, overloads, protective devices 
3. Transformers 
4. All electrical components 
5. Instrumentation (electrical/pneumatic connections) 
 
7. Legend defining all abbreviations, components, & symbols 
8. Grounding 
9. Panel Layout 
10. Intra-Panel wiring detail. 
11. Drawings shall differentiate between manufacturer and field installed wiring. 
 
 A-12: 
INSTRUMENT SPECIFICATIONS 
 
 
Provide ISA style data sheets for every instrument supplied and include as a minimum: 
1. Purchaser assigned instrument tag numbers. 
2. Instrument type/service description 
3. Manufacturer/model number 
4. Range and units of measurement 
5. Reference P&ID number 
6. Original equipment manufacturer’s specification 
7. Field bus/devicenet device address, as applicable. 
 
A-13: 
ASSEMBLY AND/OR ARRANGEMENT DRAWINGS 
 
 
  
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Detailed drawings indicating the shipping configuration of each equipment package or system. 
If the piece of equipment will be shipped in sub-sections, the drawings shall clearly indicate 
the boundaries, dimensions and weights of the sections. 
2. Location and type of all rigging points. 
3. Indication of how all sub-sections will be re-joined, including all mating points and types of 
connections between systems.  
4. Bill of materials for assembly and/or arrangement drawings 
5. Sequence of assembly if not shown elsewhere. 
 
Provide dimensioned plan, elevation and section drawings, and isometric drawings as needed to 
clearly indicate this information. 
 
A-14: 
INSTRUMENT LOCATION DRAWINGS     
 
 
Drawings shall include: 
1. Location in both plan and elevation, of instrumentation installed on/around equipment. 
2. Purchaser assigned instrumentation tag numbers. 
 
A-15: 
INSTRUMENT LOOP DRAWINGS  
 
 
Provide loop drawings indicating information for each instrument loop containing all electrical and 
pneumatic piping connections: 
1. Purchaser assigned instrument tag numbers. 
2. Instrument type/service description 
3. Reference P&ID number 
4. Original equipment manufacturer’s specification 
5. I/O address, as applicable 
6. Field bus/devicenet device address, as applicable. 
7. Description of test 
8. Test results 
 
One drawing shall be provided per loop. The drawings shall conform to ISA S5.1, S5.3, S5.4 and S5.5 
standards. 
 
 
A-16: 
SYSTEM (SKID) INTERCONNECTION DETAILS 
 
 
Where equipment is supplied in multiple pieces/skids, drawing shall detail: 
1. Piping interconnections 
2. Electrical interconnections 
3. Instrument interconnections 
4. Piece numbers for components requiring assembly. 
  
A-17: 
SPRAY DEVICE MAP 
 
After the spray device(s) are fabricated and successfully tested, provide the spray device map for each. 
 
B-1: 
PRODUCTION SCHEDULE 
 
A preliminary schedule, supplied with Quotation, shall include major fabrication milestone dates based 
upon Vendor's workload, understanding of scope of work, drawing review cycle, and requested delivery 
date. 
 
 
As a minimum, schedule shall include: 
1. Start date. 
2. Start of engineering design. 
3. Proposed drawing cycle. 
4. Completion of fabrication 
5. Inspection and/or testing schedule. 
6. Estimated shipping time to jobsite. 
 
 
The production schedule shall be maintained and updated throughout the project. 
 
B-2: 
WEIGHT LIST OF FABRICATED PARTS FOR ERECTION, UNIT SHIPPING WEIGHT, ERECTED 
WEIGHTS 
 
 
Include: 
1. Individual assembly weights (items, which are to be set in place as one entity). 
2. Individual units shipping weights.  
3. Fully assembled erected weight of the completed assembly. 
 
B-3: 
INSTALLATION & START-UP SCHEDULE 
 
1. 
Installation and Start-up dates & duration 
2. 
Copy of the procedures shall be delivered to the customer prior to the date of shipment to the 
customer. 
 
C-1: 
UTILITY REQUIREMENTS 
 
 
Information to include: 
1. All utilities required by equipment. 
2. Utility operating parameters including: 
a. 
pressure requirements  
b. pressure differentials and drops. 
c. 
peak and average flows 
d. temperature requirements 
e. 
total volume required per cycle. 
f. 
minimum quality requirement of utility 
g. heat dissipation from equipment 
 
i. 
drain requirements, flow, type, and size. 
j. 
biowaste drain requirements. 
k. humidity requirements and tolerances 
l. 
electromechanical and radio frequency interference (EMI/RFI) requirements 
m. all other environmental requirements, tolerances, and specifications 
 
C-2: 
ALLOWABLE FORCES AND MOMENTS ON NOZZLES 
 
 
Include information for all axis for all nozzles. 
 
C-3: 
ASME CODE CALCULATIONS 
 
 
Include: 
1. 
Complete set for each individual pressure vessel. 
2. 
Reference Purchaser nozzle designations and services in calculations. 
3. 
Seismic zone calculations   
 
C-4: 
SEISMIC CALCULCATIONS 
 
Provide seismic calculations performed to meet requirements where equipment will be installed. 
Calculations shall be sealed by a PE registered in that state. 
 
C-5: 
EQUIPMENT CALCULATIONS AND PERFORMANCE CURVES 
 
 
Provide calculations for instruments, equipment and specialty devises (if applicable) including: 
1. Pump sizing 
2. Heat transfer and heat exchanger sizing 
3. Pressure drop. 
4. Agitator sizing 
5. Pressure vessel 
6. Atmospheric vessels (API calculations) 
7. Refrigerant relief devices 
8. Control valves 
 
 
Provide curves (if applicable) for: 
1. Pumps 
2. Blowers 
3. Fans 
4. Agitators 
5. Vacuum Systems 
6. Centrifuges 
7. Motors with special starting or speed, torque or starting requirements. 
8. Other equipment typically supplied with curves. 
 
C-6: 
COMPLETED SPECIFICATION DATASHEETS 
 
Complete all fields identified as VS* (Vendor Specified), as well as indicating any fields where the 
specified data differs from the Manufacturer's offering. This work shall be done by hand directly on the 
data sheets in a legible and easily understood manner. 
 
The final data sheets which will become part of the final turn over package. 
 
 
 
 
D-1: 
RECOMMENDED SPARE PARTS LIST  
 
 Provide recommended spare parts list for five (5) years normal maintenance: 
Include items to be purchased and recommended to be kept in stock in the manufacturing facility. 
These items are consumables such as fuses, gaskets, lamps, switches, belts, filters, etc., which need 
replacement on a frequent basis. The recommended spare parts list should also include items, which 
cannot be delivered to the manufacturing facility within 24 hours of verbal telephone order to the 
supplier. 
 
 
Information required: 
1. Correct nomenclature to match drawings. 
2. Part numbers to match drawing’s/bill of materials. 
3. Quantity required. 
4. Material of construction 
5. Manufacturer’s part number and nomenclature, when different (if a buyout item) 
6. Individual item/part's delivery time from date of order placement. 
 
D-2: 
BILL OF MATERIALS (PARTS LIST W/PART NUMBERS) 
 
 
Include items installed to complete the purchased unit(s). 
 
 
Information required: 
1. Correct nomenclature to match drawings. 
2. Part numbers to match drawings. 
3. Quantity required. 
4. Material of construction 
5. Manufacturer’s part number and nomenclature, when different 
 
D-3: 
DRAWING LIST 
 
Provide a drawing list or index for all mechanical, electrical, instrumentation, P&ID, and misc. drawings, 
which will be issued / utilized for this PO. The list is to be a numbered list. Index should list all drawings, 
by title, in sequential order by drawing number, and indicate applicable document code identifier. Correct 
revision numbers shall also be included for all documents. 
 
D-4: 
INSTRUMENT LIST 
 
Provide an instrument list for all instrumentation. The list shall be in sequential order by tag number. The 
list shall include the tag number, data sheet number with current revision and date, instrument service 
description, P&ID number, line number, manufacturer, model number, part number, serial number (as 
applicable), maximum, minimum and tolerance. 
 
D-5: 
EQUIPMENT LIST 
 
Provide an equipment list for all major components. The list shall be in sequential order by tag number. 
The list shall include the tag number, data sheet number with current revision and date, service description, 
P&ID number, manufacturer, model, part number and serial number. 
 
D-6: 
VALVE LIST 
 
Provide a valve list for all valves. The list shall be in sequential order by tag number. The list shall include 
the tag number, data sheet number with current revision and date, service description, P&ID number, line 
number, manufacturer, model number, serial number (as applicable), 
 
 
D-7: 
I/O SCHEDULE 
 
 
Include: 
1. Input/Output device name 
2. Input/Output module tag numbers 
3. Input/Output devices' tag numbers 
4. Input/Output hardware addresses 
5. Wire numbers for input/output modules 
6. Drawings 
7. Bill of materials including manufacturer’s model and serial numbers, where applicable 
 
D-8: 
ALARM AND INTERLOCK LIST 
 
Provide a list for all alarms and interlocks. The list shall be in sequential order by description as shown on 
the screen. The list shall include all states of condition, trigger points and actions initiated. 
 
D-9: 
LIST OF SPECIAL TOOLS FOR MAINTENANCE AND/OR OPERATION 
 
Provide a list of any special tools required to perform any startup production, and/or maintenance 
operations on the equipment being supplied on this PO.  
 
D-10: 
MATERIAL CERTIFICATION DATA 
 
Provide itemized parts list and materials of construction for all critical material items. 
 
Provide material inspection reports, shipping receipts, Certificates of Compliance, Mill Test Reports and 
other documents used in the execution of critical material handling. 
 
E-1: 
INSTALLATION, OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE MANUALS 
 
Manuals for each system shall be consolidated into an electronic file and shall include:  
1. All final approved drawings 
2. All current equipment, instrument, and motor data sheets. 
3. Vendor data for all sub-vendor furnished equipment, valves, instrumentation, electrical 
components, etc. 
4. Detailed operating instructions with operating ranges, durations, settings, checklists, etc. for all 
supplied components. 
5. Step by step startup, operating and shutdown procedures. 
6. Safety precautions during operation and/or maintenance of the equipment. 
7. List of all routine, repetitive preventative maintenance procedures and frequencies.  
8. List of all major preventative maintenance procedures and frequencies. 
9. Step by step maintenance procedures for all required maintenance and/or repairs. 
10. Complete spare parts and detailed parts list. 
11. Lubrication schedules for all individual pieces of equipment, which are being supplied on the 
PO. 
12. List of all different types of acceptable lubricants, where used, and special handling and storage 
precautions. 
 
E-2: 
LEAK TEST REPORTS 
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of equipment component being tested. 
2. Test date 
3. Start time.  
 
5. Pressure at start 
6. Pressure at end 
7. Test results 
8. Company information 
9. Performed by signatures.  
 
E-3: 
 
ASME CODE CERTIFICATES/STAMPS/REPORTS 
 
Provide all applicable ASME forms (U-1, U-1A, U-2, U-3, and U-4), marking, weld inspection, and 
certification reports for all equipment and auxiliaries required to meet ASME codes and standards. 
Provide DIERS or ASME data and calculations of all temperature or pressure safety relief devices 
furnished with equipment or auxiliaries. 
 
E-4: 
INSPECTION REPORT 
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of equipment component being inspected. 
2. Inspection date 
3. Company information 
4. Performed by signatures.  
5. Inspection results 
 
E-5: 
TESTING AND CALIBRATION EQUIPMENT DATA 
 
Provide calibration procedures and current NIST traceable calibration certifications for all instruments 
used for calibration or testing of systems, including pressure gauges used for hydrostatic tests. 
 
E-6: 
PASSIVATION PROCEDURE 
 
Provide Vendor’s passivation procedure. These procedures shall include, as a minimum: the chemical 
composition of the detergents and passivation solutions to be used; the cleaning, passivation and rinse 
steps; test procedures to determine completeness of these steps; and a typical inspection and test reports. 
 
E-7: 
RIBOFLAVIN PROCEDURE 
 
Provide Vendor’s riboflavin procedure. These procedures shall include, as a minimum: the concentration 
of riboflavin solutions to be used; the riboflavin application and rinse steps; test procedures to determine 
completeness of these steps; and a typical inspection and test reports. 
 
E-8: 
CLEANING PROCEDURE 
 
Provide Vendor’s cleaning procedure. These procedures shall include, as a minimum: the chemical 
composition of the cleaning solutions to be used; the cleaning and rinse steps; procedures to determine 
completeness of these steps; and a typical inspection and procedure reports. 
 
E-9: 
VENDOR QA/QC PLAN 
 
 
Provide Vendor’s QA/QC Plan document 
 
E-10: 
VIDEO BOROSCOPE INSPECTION REPORT AND VIDEO DOCUMENTATION OF HYGENIC 
WELDS  
 
 
Refer to section 230500 “Piping Materials and Methods” 3.3.2 Weld/Brazing Inspections for borescope 
inspections and video requirements. 
 
1. Company information 
2. Date inspection performed. 
3. Signature of person performing inspection. 
4. Signature of person witnessing inspection. 
5. Description of equipment component inspected. 
6. Percentage level of inspection  
7. Results of inspection. 
8. Model and serial number of inspection scope used. 
9. Calibration date of inspection scope 
 
E-11 : 
SURFACE FINISH REPORT 
 
 
Provide Inspection Report that includes the following: 
1. Company information 
2. Date inspection performed. 
3. Signature of person performing inspection. 
4. Signature of person witnessing inspection. 
5. Description of equipment component inspected. 
6. Location and number of test points measured.  
7. Results of surface finish measurements. 
8. Model and serial number of test instrument used. 
9. Calibration date of test instrument. 
 
E-12: 
ELECTROPOLISH REPORT 
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of electropolished equipment component  
2. Electropolishing date 
3. Start and finish times. 
4. Electropolishing settings 
5. Method of electropolishing contact, i.e., filled, submerged, swab, etc. 
6. Inlet water pH and final rinse water pH 
7. Performed by and witnessed by signatures with dates. 
8. Company information 
 
E-13: 
PASSIVATION REPORT   
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of equipment component being passivated. 
2. Passivation date 
3. Start and finish times. 
4. Passivation temperature 
5. Passivation solution and solution strength 
6. Method of passivation solution contact, i.e., filled, submerged, swab, circulation. 
7. Inlet water pH and final rinse water pH 
8. Performed by and witnessed by signatures with dates. 
9. Company information 
 
E-14: 
CALIBRATION INSTRUCTIONS WITH INSTRUMENT RANGES, ACCURACIES AND 
TOLERANCES 
 
 
Include: 
1. Copies of manufacturer's calibration instructions. 
2. Required frequency of calibration (weekly, monthly, quarterly, yearly, etc.). 
 
3. List of calibration instrumentation and/or tools necessary to perform the required calibrations. 
(Instrumentation utilized to perform this function shall be NIST traceable) 
 
E-15: 
CLEANING REPORT 
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of equipment component being cleaned. 
2. Cleaning date 
3. Start and finish times. 
4. Cleaning temperature 
5. Cleaning solution and solution strength 
6. Method of cleaning solution contact, i.e., filled, submerged, swab, circulation. 
7. Inlet water pH and final rinse water pH 
8. Performed by and witnessed by signatures with dates. 
9. Company information 
 
E-16: 
AGITATOR SHAFT RUN-OUT REPORT 
 
 
Provide reports that include the following: 
1. Description of agitator being tested. 
2. Test date 
3. Company information 
4. Performed by signatures.  
5. Test results 
 
E-17: 
FILTER CERTIFICATIONS: 
 
Provide manufacturer certification documentation (or C of C) for each filter provided with the equipment 
or system. 
 
E-18: 
VFD CONFIGURATION  
 
Provide all VFD configuration parameters (including parameters remaining as default). Parameter files can 
be electronic listing. 
 
F-1: 
WELD RECORDS 
 
Equipment records shall include the equipment description (name), manufacturer's name, part or model 
numbers, serial numbers and other relevant source identification information. Provide documentation per 
ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-2: 
WELD PROCEDURE SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-3: 
PROCEDURE QUALIFICATION RECORD 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-4: 
WELDER PERFORMANCE QUALIFICATION 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
 
 
F-5: 
PURGE GAS CERTIFICATES 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-6: 
WELD MACHINE CALIBRATION REPORTS 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-7: 
WELDING OPERATOR PERFORMANCE QUALIFICATION 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-8: 
MATERIAL TEST REPORT 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-9: 
WELD COUPONS/LOGS 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-10: 
WELD WIRE/ROD MATERIAL DATASHEETS 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
F-11: 
WELD EXAMINER/INSPECTOR QUALIFICTIONS 
 
 
Provide documentation per ASME BPE Latest Edition 
 
G-1: 
SITE SPECIFIC SUPPORT PLAN 
 
Provide specific information regarding the manufacturer’s capability to respond to emergency service 
calls. Provide the quantity of available service technicians, including their discipline and their location 
and costs for warranty and non-warranty support. 
 
G-2: 
FUNCTIONAL DESIGN SPECIFICATION (FDS) 
 
Provide detailed information on the control system functionality including sequences, set points, 
interlocks, alarms, user interfaces, component interfaces, reporting, security, data handling, recipe 
handling, control hardware and software, and any other information required to describe and configure 
the overall control system. The FDS shall be written in accordance with the latest GAMP (Good 
Automated Manufacturing Practice) guidelines. 
 
G-3: 
HARWARE DESIGN SPECIFICATION (HDS) 
 
Provide a control system HDS that includes a basic system description, memory type and capacity, I/O 
capacity, communications protocols, report generation, storage devices, and peripherals. Provide 
hardware specifications that include model numbers, part numbers, communication ports, memory and 
storage capacities, operating temperature and humidity ranges, power requirements, memory protection, 
environmental requirements, voltage spike protection, and RF protection. Also include the following: 
 
• 
Programmer and User Interfaces 
• 
Equipment Change Control and Compatibility 
• 
Redundancy effects of component failures or power failures 
• 
Component, wiring and terminal labeling. 
 
G-4: 
SOFTWARE DESIGN SPECIFICATION (SDS)  
 
Provide a control system SDS that includes information on the programming software, system 
architecture, a detailed description of the system programming (including ladder logic if PLC based), all 
interlocks, alarms and control set points, I/O and memory addresses, test procedures, and any other 
information required to review and evaluate the design, as well as provide adequate direction for the 
development of the system programs. 
 
G-5 : 
SOFTWARE SOURCE CODES 
 
 
Provide source code documents including: 
1. Printouts of documented, commented, source code. Comments are to include point, rung, 
and program level annotations. 
2. Electronic copies of source code listed above. 
3. Application source code including file name, version, date generated, and serial number, 
where applicable. 
 
G-6: 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TEST PROTOCOLS AND TESTING PROCEDURES 
 
 
The protocol defines the details of the individual procedures and tests that will be performed. Vendor shall 
submit a listing of standard tests performed with a brief description of the testing. Vendor shall submit a 
detailed FAT protocol developed specifically for the purchased equipment for Purchaser’s review and 
approval prior to FAT testing.  
 
G-7: 
EXECUTED FAT PROTOCOL 
 
Provide all FAT documentation, including signed reports and test results. As applicable, provide the 
results for CIP spray device coverage tests for each piece of equipment, including test procedure and 
CIP conditions during tests. Document any test failures and subsequent correction steps.  
 
G-8: 
COMMISSIONING PLAN 
 
Provide Manufacturer’s recommended commissioning plan to support start-up and validation. 
 
G-9: 
VALIDATION PROTOCOLS 
 
Provide Manufacturer’s proposed installation qualification (IQ) and operational qualification (OQ) 
protocols for critical system equipment. 
 
1.5. 
DELIVERY, STORAGE, AND HANDLING 
 
Deliver products, materials and equipment marked with product names, model numbers, types, grades, and 
compliance labels, and other information needed for identification. Inspect items for shipping damage and refuse, 
return, or refurbish items to the satisfaction of the Owner. Crosscheck delivery records with project schedule to 
eliminate work stoppages due to material shortages. 
 
Store products, materials, and equipment in a manner to prevent damage and degradation. Store items on skids or 
pallets, elevated above the floor or grade. Store items subject to moisture damage in a dry location. Retain 
protective shipping covers, crates, and cartons during storage. Protect items from contamination by job site dirt, 
debris, and other foreign matter. Segregate items into groups of like type for job site storage. Provide a secure, 
fenced, and lighted area for outside job site storage. 
 
Handle products, materials, and equipment in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations and recognized 
industry standards. Utilize lifting lugs, and designated lift points when hoisting equipment. In all cases, carefully 
 
handle, transport, and position items to prevent damage during construction. After placement or installation, cover 
items with tarps or sheeting where required to protect from damage during construction. 
 
 
PART 2. - DESIGN REQUIREMENTS 
 
2.1. 
GENERAL 
 
All materials that will be incorporated into the final equipment package shall be new, unused, and undamaged 
unless otherwise specifically permitted in the specifications or authorized by the Owner. 
 
Refer to the main equipment specification and attachment drawings and specifications for the detailed design 
requirements for each equipment package. 
 
Equipment specifications for custom built equipment packages may be provided with varying levels of 
specification documentation, such as P&IDs, layout drawings, component data sheets, piping and instrumentation 
specifications and data sheets, equipment data sheets, etc. These documents are complementary. Where conflicts 
exist between these documents and this specification, the manufacturer shall submit a request for clarification. 
 
2.2. 
NAMEPLATE 
 
Manufacturer shall provide each piece of equipment with a nameplate, permanently attached to the exterior of the 
equipment in an accessible location. Where required, nameplate shall be affixed to a bracket to allow it to be 
positioned in front of insulation. This nameplate is in addition to any nameplate required by applicable codes or 
certifications (e.g., ASME B&PV code, UL listing, etc.). As a minimum, the following information shall be 
included on the nameplate: 
 
• 
Owner’s Equipment Number 
• 
Manufacturer’s name, model, and serial number 
• 
Year built. 
• 
Other information as indicated in the equipment specification. 
• 
Other information that the Manufacturer includes as standard. 
 
Nameplates on metal tanks, vessels, hoppers, IBCs, etc. shall be constructed of the same material as the external 
surface of the equipment and welded to the exterior of the equipment. Nameplates on critical process equipment 
shall be continuously welded. If the equipment is painted, the nameplate shall also be painted. 
 
2.3. 
TAGGING AND IDENTIFICATION 
 
All equipment, valves, instrumentation, and electrical/I&C enclosures shall be tagged or labeled to indicate the 
tag number assigned to it on the P&ID or elsewhere in the specifications. All tags shall be visible and readable 
from outside the skid boundary, by an operator standing on the floor. 
 
Refer to the attached Section 200553 “Tagging and Identification” for tagging and labeling requirements. 
 
2.4. 
ELECTRICAL HAZARD CLASSIFICATION 
 
All electrical and electronic devices, enclosures and equipment shall comply with the code requirements for 
installation in an area with an electrical hazard classification, as indicated in the equipment specification. 
 
2.5. 
LUBRICATION 
 
Lubricants shall be food grade and FDA compliant where there is any risk of incidental product (critical system) 
contact. Lubricants utilized shall be listed in the Manufacturer’s submittal documentation. 
 
Sealed for life bearings are preferred. 
 
All critical system components must be protected against machine lubricant contamination. No lubrication points 
are allowed above an open product/component handling area. 
 
The use of centralized lubrication systems may be considered in multiple lubrication applications and the charging 
chamber shall be located in an easily accessible part of the machine. Automatically operated systems are preferred. 
 
The equipment design shall demonstrate minimum lubrication requirement. 
 
All pneumatic components must be non-lube type. 
 
2.6. 
MECHANICAL 
 
2.6.1. 
General 
 
Each piece of equipment shall be designed to facilitate ease of maintenance and provide access for inspection, 
adjustment, and sampling points. 
 
Sharp edges and burrs shall be removed from all surfaces. 
 
2.6.2. 
Piping Systems 
 
General 
 
Piping systems shall be designed, assembled, and tested to comply with applicable sections of the ASME B31 
Pressure Piping (non-critical piping systems) and ASME BPE (critical piping systems) codes and standards. 
Welding procedures and welder qualification shall comply with applicable AWS requirements. 
 
Piping Applications 
 
Refer to Section 230500 Piping Systems Application Table. 
 
All piping systems exposed to clean process areas shall be stainless steel, and the transition shall occur prior to 
exposure. 
 
Piping Accessories 
 
At a minimum, pressure gauges shall be provided on each utility line, and temperature gauges on each hydronic 
line as close as possible and practical to where the facility connections are made, and for each piece of equipment 
on an equipment skid or package that uses these utilities. Pressure gauges shall be provided with a ball isolation 
valve, and temperature gauges installed using a thermowell. Pressure gauges on plant steam lines shall be installed 
using a pig tail siphon. 
 
A strainer with a blow down ball valve shall be installed immediately upstream of all plant steam and hydronic 
control valves, as well as upstream of plant steam drip traps (if not incorporated into the trap body, which is the 
preferred design). The strainers shall be oriented such that both branches are parallel to level to prevent the 
accumulation of condensation and promote drainability. 
 
Balancing valves shall be provided on hydronic lines to allow the maximum flows to be set based upon actual 
pressure conditions at the facility connections. 
 
Steam traps on drip legs for plant steam condensate lines shall be thermodynamic style, and clean steam drip traps 
shall be sealed thermostatic design. 
 
Piping Arrangement 
 
Route piping at right angles or parallel to the skid, free of sags or bends, and grouped together wherever possible. 
Locate groups of pipes parallel to each other, spaced to permit applying full insulation and servicing of valves 
and components. 
 
Arrange piping to allow for ease of access to components that will be serviced regularly as part of the intended 
operation of the equipment, including the removal of filter housings, the pull space for heat exchanger tubes or 
plates and the calibration of instrumentation. 
 
Arrange supports and piping directional changes to allow for thermal expansion in the piping systems due to 
normal temperature changes. Avoid creating, even temporarily, undue loads, forces, or strains on valves, 
instrumentation, equipment connections, supports, structural framing caused by piping connections or supports. 
 
Install drains at low points in wetted piping systems, and air vents at high points of hydronic systems for system 
air venting. 
 
Install final piping and fittings at connections to all equipment in such a manner that will permit the removal of 
serviceable components of the equipment (e.g., tube bundles on shell-in-tube heat exchangers, pump casings, etc.) 
without cutting pipelines. Provide unions or comparable fittings where necessary to facilitate the removal or 
service of piping components and instrumentation. 
 
Facility Connections 
 
All non-critical piping system facility connections shall be 150 lb. RF ANSI flange, except for the instrument air, 
which shall be NPT or compression style. Critical piping system facility connections shall be hygienic clamp with 
bolted clamps. Isolation valves shall be provided on each utility line. 
 
2.6.3. 
Pipe Supports 
 
Piping shall be adequately supported to prevent sagging and meet slope requirements, using piping supports 
specifically designed for this application. Supports shall provide rigidity or flexibility where required to allow for 
thermal expansion without transmitting loads to connected equipment. Sanitary stainless steel pipe supports shall 
be used were exposed in clean manufacturing areas. 
 
2.6.4. 
Insulation 
 
The vendor shall design the system for insulation of all piping and components indicated as requiring insulation 
on the drawings and data sheets.  
 
All hot and cold surfaces exposed to personnel shall be insulated to provide personnel protection as a minimum, 
unless otherwise specified, and to improve thermal efficiency.  The maximum allowable surface temperature shall 
be 125°F (51°C) for surfaces where personnel protection is required.  The insulation shall be asbestos free, 
moisture-proof, fire retardant and non-settling.  Insulation on cold systems shall incorporate a vapor barrier to 
prevent the formation of condensation.  Insulation applied to stainless steel/alloy surfaces shall be chloride-free. 
 
All pipe insulation inserts for pipe supports are to be affixed to prevent falling. 
 
2.7. 
ELECTRICAL 
 
2.7.1. 
Code Compliance 
 
All electrical equipment, systems and components shall be designed and constructed in compliance with 
applicable UL and NEC standards and requirements. All electrical and control components shall be UL listed, 
 
shall coordinate an inspection by an approved independent national testing agency of the completed system, after 
installation, in order to receive a UL approval for the overall system, as required and stated in the attached 
equipment specifications. The equipment is to be UL labeled after inspection and approval of the system. The 
Manufacturer shall be responsible for the cost of this effort, including any necessary rework of the system to pass 
inspection. 
 
2.7.2. 
Power Distribution 
 
Refer to Specification 260660 (Electrical Requirements Packaged Equipment) and Equipment Specification for 
additional detail.  
 
2.8. 
INSTRUMENTATION AND CONTROLS 
 
2.8.1. 
General 
 
The instrumentation and control system supplied with each piece of equipment shall meet the specific 
requirements indicated in the equipment specification and Specification 409010 (Basic Instrumentation and 
Controls Requirements) and Specification 409020 (Basic I&C Requirements for PAC-controlled Equipment) or 
Specification 409021 (Basic I&C Requirements for PCS-controlled Equipment) as provided with the equipment 
specification. 
 
2.8.2. 
Control System 
 
The control system, consisting of the controller, operator interface(s), software, and programs/recipes shall meet 
the requirements indicated in the equipment specification. 
 
Unless otherwise specified in the equipment specification, the Manufacturer shall be responsible for supplying 
the necessary software programming to provide for a fully automated system capable of executing recipe-based 
operations, and otherwise meet the operational requirements of the equipment. Programming structure shall 
comply with current GAMP requirements and recommendations. 
 
A copy of the programming software shall be provided to the Owner for each type of control system supplied by 
the Manufacturer (i.e., if several pieces of equipment are provided with common control system software, only a 
single copy of the programming software need be supplied). An electronic copy of each software program shall 
also be provided for each equipment package control system. 
 
2.8.3. 
Instrumentation 
 
General 
 
Exposed portions of instruments and transmitters shall be constructed of materials and coatings suitable for the 
operating environment in which they will be installed. Units for exposed outdoor installation shall be 
weatherproof and corrosion resistant. Units for exposed installation in clean manufacturing areas shall be 
constructed of stainless steel, aluminum, or plastic, and otherwise provided as corrosion resistant, and shall be 
suitable for wash down activities. 
 
The fluid service contact materials of construction for all instruments shall be compatible with and appropriate 
for the system on which they are installed. The pressure and temperature ratings of instruments shall exceed the 
maximum operating limits of the system on which they are installed. The connection type and ratings of 
instruments shall match that of the piping systems in which they are installed. 
 
2.9. 
STRUCTURAL 
 
Refer to specification 230241 (Vibration and Seismic Controls) for additional requirements. 
 
The structural framing of the equipment or skid shall be sized and designed to adequately support all the 
components that will comprise the piece of equipment or skid, loaded to full capacity, meeting the requirements 
for the building code required for the job site location.  
 
This shall include vessels, pumps, heat exchangers and other components if they will be mounted on the framing. 
Framing members shall be added wherever necessary to provide additional support of all piping, instrumentation, 
valves, and other components on the structural frame. Structural framing shall also be sized to resist any 
perceptible vibration that may be induced by any mounted rotating equipment. 
 
Pumps, motors, and gear motors shall be mounted on smooth rolled plates welded to the framing unless vibration 
isolation is required. The plates shall be sized to adequately support the pumps, motors, and gear motors, both 
statically and dynamically throughout their respective operating ranges. Plates shall be stainless steel for critical 
systems or if mounted in clean classified spaces. The design shall provide adequate clearance underneath the plate 
to enable cleaning. 
 
All skid components, including piping, flow meters, valves, filter housings, pumps, in-line monitoring 
instruments, heat exchangers, etc., must be fully supported without interfering with disassembly for regular 
maintenance. All components of the equipment or skid shall reside as much as possible within the boundaries of 
the structural framing. Any components that extend beyond the framing shall be capable of being easily removed 
and stored separately when the equipment or skid is transported. 
 
Each piece of equipment or skid shall have a footprint and height no greater than the maximum external 
dimensions indicated in the equipment specification. This footprint shall include the structural framework. The 
Manufacturer shall provide the actual overall equipment dimensions on the shop drawings for approval by the 
Owner or Owner’s representative. 
 
Suitable lifting points or forklift lift points shall be furnished on the structural frame. Lifting points shall be 
capable of supporting the entire piece of equipment as a unit and shall be clearly identified and precisely located 
on the equipment shop drawings. 
 
If applicable, the structural frame shall be equipped with leveling pads at appropriate support points. The leveling 
legs of clean room equipment shall not have any exposed threads. The equipment data sheet may indicate the unit 
is portable. If so indicated, the wheels for portable equipment shall be stainless steel/polyurethane non-marking 
casters, two swivel type and two fixed, all with locking capability. In addition to casters, each unit shall be 
provided with jack style leveling feet (a minimum of four) that can be used to lift the entire unit up off of the 
casters when it is located in its operational position. 
 
2.10. SAFETY 
 
The manufacturer shall document all safety features and provide a detailed list of safety interlocks in English. 
All moving parts that can form a pinch point or trap, or cause injury to personnel must be adequately guarded 
with either fixed or interlocked guards. It is not sufficient to display written warnings. Use Table 10 in OSHA 
Standard 29 CFR part 1910.217 for maximum width openings. Noncompliance must be reviewed with Owner or 
Owner’s representative. 
 
The safety interlock system (E-stops and electrical interlocks) shall be hardwired. The system shall pass through 
a safety relay, which will remove all output voltages and cause an “air dump” in power down, E-stop, and guard 
open conditions. 
 
All safety interlocks shall be subject to Safety Integrity Level (SIL) determination establishing the probability of 
failure on demand (PFD) and spurious trip rate (STR) functions as well as being wired in series and brought to a 
terminal block in the main control panel. 
 
Interlock bypasses (guards, etc.) are prohibited without express permission from the Owner. 
 
Emergency Stops (E-stops) shall be positioned for easy access, and in locations that will insure both operator and 
machine safety. At a minimum, an E-Stop shall be mounted on each operator interface enclosure, location to be 
approved during submittal process. 
 
E-stop switches must be red, of mushroom design and latch when depressed. All E-stop switches shall be lockable. 
They must be capable of bringing the machine to a “Zero energy” state. Zero energy means that all machine 
motion must come to a controlled stop and all residual energy must be dissipated from the system where the 
removal of such energy shall not cause additional machine movement. 
 
During normal operation, the machine shall not exceed a noise level of 80 DBA at three feet from major surfaces 
of the machine and at five feet above the floor. Any deviation from this specified noise level must be approved 
by Owner. Noise levels are subject to verification during the FAT. 
 
The installation or operation of the system shall not affect the safety devices already in place in the area where 
the equipment will be installed. 
 
Tool-less guards/doors that are used to access the machine must stop the machine cycle and release any energy 
source, potential or kinetic, when opened. 
 
Equipment shall meet the OEL (Occupational Exposure Limit) capability indicated in the equipment specification 
under normal operation with the process materials indicated in the specifications. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
GENERAL 
 
The Owner shall have access to the Manufacturer's shop where any activity occurs related to the fabrication and 
testing of the system. The Owner  
 
3.2. 
PREPARATION 
 
All openings of the equipment shall be kept closed or capped during shipping and throughout all fabrication and 
testing activities, unless actual work is being performed on that opening. All components of the packaged 
equipment shall be kept as clean as possible at all times to protect the packaged equipment and components from 
contamination from other fabrication activities. 
 
3.3. 
CLEANING AND PASSIVATION 
After the equipment has been completely fabricated and pressure tested, all critical surfaces shall be detergent 
cleaned then passivated prior to inspection by the Owner or Owner's representative, unless indicated otherwise in 
the equipment specification. The cleaning and passivation procedure shall be that which was reviewed and 
approved by the Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
3.4. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
Refer to the FAT section of each equipment specification for FAT requirements for that piece of equipment that 
will be in addition to those indicated in this section. 
 
As a minimum, the Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and indicated 
in this section. FAT is in addition to the ASME pressure tests and other tests required by code. All costs for FAT 
and code related tests shall be included in the Manufacturer’s quoted cost for the equipment. Refer to the Test 
Responsibilities Matrix in each Equipment Specification for protocol development and execution responsibilities 
of the Vendor, Owner, Systems Integrator, etc. if applicable. The Manufacturer shall submit his standard FAT 
procedures to the Owner or Owner's representative for review and approval at least 4 weeks prior to the test dates. 
 
All supplies, equipment and utilities required to complete all Factory Acceptance Tests shall be supplied by the 
Manufacturer, unless otherwise indicated in writing by the Manufacturer and approved by the Owner. The 
Manufacturer shall also make available all necessary personnel required to assist and perform FAT activities in a 
timely manner. The utilities provided by the Manufacturer for FAT activities shall match those indicated as 
available at the installation site for the equipment, including pressure, temperature, flow rate, and quality. 
 
Water used for any test that will contact the wetted surfaces of critical systems and components shall be purified 
DI water with a composition which has approved by the Owner or Owner's representative. The test water shall 
leave no mineral or chemical residues on any critical surfaces. City water is acceptable only for the testing of heat 
transfer jackets and other non-critical systems. 
 
Compressed air shall be generated by oil free compressors or shall be filtered using an appropriate coalescing 
filter. Upstream of the point of use, the air shall be filtered with a 0.2 µm or better filter to remove particulates. 
 
Only clean steam generated by stainless steel equipment shall be allowed to contact critical systems, unless an 
alternative steam source is submitted by the Manufacturer and approved by the Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
Manufacturer shall provide temporary UPS for the 120VAC control system power supply to prevent disruption 
of system during power loss and/or brown outs. 
 
Each FAT shall be designed to test the full range of operating conditions of each piece of equipment and its 
associated accessories. No test shall require any components to operate in a manner which voids or reduces the 
original component manufacturer's or equipment Manufacturers' warranty. Responsibility for delays caused by 
damaged or unavailable equipment shall lie with the Manufacturer. 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform the approved FAT, in advance of the official FAT that will be witnessed by the 
Owner or Owner's representative and shall correct and document all test failures. The results of this pre-FAT and 
subsequent corrections (if any) shall be submitted to the Owner or Owner's representative for review and approval 
no later than five (5) working days prior to the scheduled FAT. If the equipment fails FAT and requires re-testing 
at a later date, the Manufacturer shall pay all costs associated with this re-testing, including time and travel 
expenses incurred by the Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
Witnessing and acceptance of the actual FAT by the Owner or Owner’s representative shall indicate that the unit 
is ready for shipment to Owner’s facility, but not Owner acceptance of the equipment. 
 
FAT may include, but is not limited to the following General Verification Tests: 
 
• 
A thorough review of all manufacturer documentation packages as indicated in the Submittal Table 
to confirm compliance with the specification and datasheets. This includes review of the approval 
drawing, including P&IDs for order of take-off, instrumentation placement, slopes, tagging, etc. 
Also, included in this review is a check for system dimensions – tie-in points, footprint, dimensional 
tolerances, and height. 
• 
Review of the turnover package for accuracy and completeness.  
• 
Verification of compliance with project documentation verification of piping and fitting heat 
numbers. 
• 
Physical inspection of the packaged equipment components, piping and structural frame weld 
quality, including internal and external finish testing using a profilometer.  
• 
Check for correct “fit-up”. Sanitary clamp connections shall be disassembled and reassembled to 
confirm reasonable construction of the system.  
• 
Piping shall be checked for proper support during operation and its shipping configuration. 
• 
Physical inspection of installation of components, such as valve angles and proper installation of 
flowmeters. 
• 
Inspection of electrical instrument enclosures, panel penetrations, wireways, terminal strips, and 
components 
 
• 
Wiring checkout with electrical drawings 
• 
I/O checkout 
• 
Operating functional check of all phase logic operations 
• 
Power failure test 
• 
Hydrostatic Pressure Test of piping 
• 
Shutdown challenge, if applicable. The system shall be shut down using the emergency stop located 
on the human machine interface (HMI), and the system will be evaluated to see if it has assumed a 
fail-safe condition. 
• 
Utility challenge. Utility services shall be connected, and performance of utility related operations 
assessed. Utility consumptions shall be compared with Manufacturer supplied utility consumption 
data. 
• 
Process specific tests defined in the equipment technical specification. 
 
3.5. 
STORAGE, SHIPPING AND INSTALLATION 
 
Storage 
 
All equipment, valves, instrumentation, enclosures, and other components shall be stored under cover and out of 
the weather. They shall be protected from contamination by moisture and dirt, and from any other damage by 
foreign objects or from mishandling. This shall also apply to components after being manufactured (e.g., 
platforms, stairs, equipment bases, etc.) and to the finished equipment itself. When not in use, all openings in 
piping, valves, instrumentation, and equipment shall be covered and otherwise sealed against dirt and 
contamination. Proper storage needs to be arranged to allow the equipment to reach the client site during the 
agreed upon window in the purchase contract. 
 
Shipping 
 
Each system shall not be prepared for shipment until all FAT is successfully completed as determined by the 
Owner or Owner's representative. Components subject to corrosion shall be properly protected prior to crating 
and other preparations for shipping to the Owner's facility. Agitators and seals shall be removed from vessels and 
shipped in separate crates. Each system and all sub-components shall be adequately secured, crated, skidded and 
covered to prevent damage during shipment. If piping is cut to allow for shipment where re-welds will be done 
in the field during installation, a spool piece of the proper pipe is to be provided by the manufacturer to allow re-
welding of the line. Appropriate material certifications for these spool pieces must be provided if required. 
Shipping crates and containers shall be properly identified with the project name, purchase order number, Owner’s 
equipment number, complete packing list and shipping information. Crating shall be designed to allow for outside 
storage of each skid for up to one month. Prior to installation, items will be inspected for shipping and storage 
damage, and may be refused and returned if the condition of the items does not meet the satisfaction of the Owner 
or Owner’s representative. 
 
Installation
