PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. PREPARATION 
 
Surface Preparation:  Clean, dry, and remove foreign materials such as rust, scale, and dirt from surface.  Clean 
and dry surface per insulation manufacturer’s recommendation. 
 
Install insulation after testing and acceptance of systems.  Keep insulation materials dry during application and 
finishing. 
 
Mix insulating cements with clean potable water.  Mix insulating cements contacting stainless-steel surfaces with 
de-mineralized water. 
 
3.2. INSTALLATION, GENERAL 
 
Apply insulation material, accessories, and finishes according to the manufacturer's printed instructions, and in 
accordance with recognized industry practices to ensure that insulation thermal and vapor barrier properties are 
maintained.  Apply adhesives and coatings at the manufacturer's recommended coverage-per-gallon rate. 
 
Install insulation with smooth, straight, and even surfaces.  Insulate with full-length units of insulation, with single 
cut piece to complete run.  Do not use cut pieces or scraps abutting each other.  Apply insulation with a minimum 
number of joints.  Stagger joints on double layers of insulation. 
 
Tightly butt longitudinal seams and end joints.  Ensure complete and tight fit over surfaces to be covered.  Bond 
with adhesive. 
 
Seal joints, seams and ends to maintain vapor or waterproof barrier on insulation requiring them.  Seal 
penetrations for hangers, supports, anchors, and other projections in insulation. 
 
3.2.1. Gray Space 
 
Hangers and Supports:  Apply insulation continuously through hangers and around anchor attachments.  Install 
saddles, shields, and inserts as specified in Division 230140 Section "Hangers and Supports".  For cold surface 
piping, extend insulation on anchor legs a minimum of 12 inches and taper and seal insulation ends. 
 
Walls, Floors, and Partitions Penetrations:  Apply insulation continuously through walls and partitions.  Seal 
around penetration with fire-rated or non-fire-rated sealant as applicable.  Refer to Section 230050 "Basic 
Mechanical Materials and Methods." 
 
3.2.2. Clean Space/Critical Systems 
 
Clamps:  Unless otherwise indicated apply insulation between pipe clamps. Insulation and jacket to stop at each 
pipe clamp, end of insulation to be sealed with a pre-molded, precut cap. Cap to be same material and thickness 
as adjacent pipe jacket. Do not seal insulation jacket to pipe clamp.  
 
Walls, Floors, and Partitions Penetrations:  Insulation to stop at escutcheon mounted at the ceiling/wall panel.  
The insulation jacket to extend to the ceiling/wall panel and sealed with caulk to the panel. 
 
Protection:  Provide protection for insulation work during remainder of construction period, to avoid damage and 
deterioration. 
 
3.3. INSTALLATION JACKETS, GENERAL 
 
Pull jacket tight and smooth. 
 
Cover circumferential joints with butt strips, at least 3-inches wide, and of same material as insulation jacket.  
Secure with adhesive. 
 
Longitudinal Seams:  Overlap seams at least 1-1/2 inches.  Apply insulation with longitudinal seams at bottom of 
pipe.  Clean and dry surface where jacket overlaps.  Secure with adhesive. 
 
Fill and seal voids, openings, punctures, and breaks at penetrations in jackets with vapor barrier coating. 
 
Cover hanger inserts and shields with jacket material matching adjacent pipe insulation. 
 
3.4. INSTALLATION OF PIPING SYSTEM INSULATION 
 
Apply insulation continuously over system piping, fittings, and components including valves, unions, strainers, 
devices, and specialties, except as otherwise indicated.  Coat pipe insulation ends with vapor barrier coating.  
Apply pre-molded, precut, or field-fabricated segments of insulation around flanges, unions, valves, and fittings.  
Use same material and thickness as adjacent pipe insulation.  Apply materials with adhesive, fill voids with 
mineral fiber insulating cement.  Secure with wire or tape. 
 
Items Not Insulated:  Unless otherwise indicated, do not apply insulation to: 
 
Flexible connectors 
Vibration control devices 
Chrome-plated pipes and fittings (except for handicapped fixtures) 
 
Roof Penetrations:  Apply insulation for interior applications to a point even with the top of the roof flashing.  
Apply insulation for exterior applications butted tightly to interior insulation ends.  Extend metal jacket for 
exterior insulation outside roof flashing at least two (2) inches below top of roof flashing.  Seal metal jacket to 
roof flashing with vapor barrier coating. 
 
For roof drain piping insulate the piping from the roof drain including the roof drain body, the drop from the body 
to the horizontal run, and all horizontal piping to and including the first downturn elbow. 
 
3.5. INSTALLATION OF DUCTWORK INSULATION 
 
Items Not Insulated:  Unless otherwise indicated, do not apply insulation to: 
 
Factory-insulated flexible ducts 
Flexible connectors 
 
Access panels and doors in air distribution systems 
 
Corner Angles:  Install corner angles on external corners of insulation on ductwork in exposed spaces before 
covering with jacketing. 
 
Pin Covers:  Install plastic pin covers on exposed stab-on pins to prevent injury to personnel working around 
ductwork. 
 
3.6. INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT INSULATION 
 
Items Not Insulated:  Unless otherwise indicated, do not apply insulation to:  Factory-insulated plenums, casings, 
terminal boxes, and filter boxes and sections; Flexible connectors; Vibration control devices; Testing laboratory 
labels and stamps; nameplates, ASME stamps, information and data plates; manholes, hand holes, and inspection 
ports. 
 
Do not apply insulation to equipment, breechings, or stacks while hot. 
 
Insulation Thicknesses Greater than Two (2) Inches:  Install insulation in multiple layers with staggered joints. 
 
Protect exposed corners with corner angles. 
 
Removable Insulation:  Install insulation on components that require periodic inspecting, cleaning, and repairing 
for easy removal and replacement without damage to adjacent insulation. 
 
Unless otherwise indicated apply removable insulation covers to: 
 
CIP Skid Heat Exchangers 
Steam and Condensate Valves, Strainers and Check Valves 
Steam Pressure Reducing Valves 
Steam Traps, Float and Thermostatic, Inverted Bucket, and Pump 
 
3.7. EXISTING INSULATION REPAIR 
 
Repair damaged sections of existing mechanical insulation, where indicated on the plans, or damaged during this 
construction period.  Use insulation of same thickness as existing insulation, install new jacket lapping and sealed 
over existing. Insulation repair of AHU A-008 shall occur after existing ductwork has been repaired and sealed.  
 
Repair damaged insulation jackets, by applying jacket material around damaged jacket.  Adhere, and seal.  Extend 
patch at least two (2) inches in both directions beyond damaged insulation jacket and around the entire 
circumference of the pipe. 
 
Replace damaged insulation that cannot be repaired satisfactorily, including units with vapor barrier damage and 
moisture-saturated units. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Industrial Insulation Group (A John’s Manville Co.) 
 
Temperature Rating: 
80°F to 1200°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic hydrous calcium silicate, non-asbestos fibrous reinforcement, 
noncombustible, ASTM C 533, Type I, insulation. 
 
Form: 
Molded flat block, curved block, and grooved block sections as appropriate for 
surfaces applied to. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.54 Btu-in/hr.•ft2•°F at 500°F. 
 
Density: 
Dry density of maximum of 15 lbs./ft3 
 
Compressive Strength: 
100 psi minimum at 5% deformation. 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM B 209, Aluminum jacketing, 3003 Alloy, H-14 temper, 0.016” thickness 
for indoor use, 0.024” thickness for outdoor use, smooth finish, with heat 
laminated vapor barrier, roll stock ready for shop or field cutting and forming to 
insulation. 
 
Adhesive: 
Noncombustible, non-asbestos, silicate-based.  Adhesive shall be Industrial 
Insulation Group CalBond Gold High Temperature Glue for bonding calcium 
silicate insulation. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Aged Water Vapor Permeance, 1.0 
perm maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 200°F. 
 
Corner Angles: 
Install corner angle on external corners of insulation under wires and bands. 
 
Coat insulated surfaces with layer of insulating cement, troweled smooth, leaving smooth continuous surface.  
Fill in scored block, seams, chipped edges, and depressions, and cover over wire netting and joints with cement 
of sufficient thickness to remove surface irregularities. 
 
Install materials with a minimum dimension of 12" and a maximum dimension of 48".  Stagger end joints.  
Bevel insulation edges for cylindrical surfaces for tight joint. 
 
Secure insulation with wire or bands spaced 9” centers.  Cover insulated surfaces with jacketing. 
 
 
 
 
 
END OF C6 
 
 
R 
  
Spec. by 
JY

1. These pipe insulation thicknesses meet all the requirements of the 2018, 2015, 2012, 2009 and 2006 International 
Codes, the 2019, 2016, 2013 and 2010 ASHRAE 90.1 standard, the 2019, 2016 and 2013 California Title 24 codes, 
condensation control and personnel protection.  They are based on the thermal conductivity as listed in specification 
230250 datasheets.                                                                           . 
If the Contractor is proposing materials with higher conductivity, then greater thicknesses may be required, and the 
Contractor shall provide calculations to the Engineer for review and approval.   
2. Index temperature ranges for piping are not necessarily the actual fluid temperature, but rather they are the 
temperature ranges selected by the Engineer upon which to base insulation thickness.  Differences between actual 
fluid temperature and chosen index temperature may account for factors such as transient room temperature and 
humidity situations.  See the Piping Systems Application Table in specification 230500 for required index 
temperatures for each fluid type.   
3. Do not use calcium silicate insulation on piping with fluids colder than 80F in any location, or on piping with fluids 
60F or below where it is located outdoors in humid climates, unless approved by the Engineer.   
4. For thermal conductivities different than the values in specification datasheets, the minimum thickness (T) shall 
be determined as follows:  
T = r{(1 + t/r)K/k – 1}, where  
T = minimum insulation thickness (in.),  
r = actual outside radius of pipe (in.),   
t = insulation thickness listed in this table for applicable index temperature and pipe size,  
K = thermal conductivity of proposed insulation material at mean rating temperature between the applicable index 
temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]); and  
k = thermal conductivity listed in the applicable insulation datasheet for the same mean temperature between the 
applicable index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F])

R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Johns Manville 
Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation 
Knauf Insulation 
 
Temperature Rating: 
0°F to 850°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic, non-chloride, glass fibers, bonded with a thermosetting resin, ASTM 
C547, ASTM C795, Type 1, rigid pipe insulation. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.25 Btu-in/hr•ft2•°F average at 100°F mean temperature. 
 
Density: 
Maximum of 10 lb/ft3 average. 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM B209, Aluminum jacketing, 3003 Alloy, H-14 temper, 0.016” thickness 
for indoor use, 0.024” thickness for outdoor use, smooth finish, factory cut and 
rolled or roll stock ready for shop or field cutting and forming to insulation. 
 
Moisture Barrier: 
3-mil Dupont Surlyn. 
 
Jacket Bands: 
Aluminum, 0.007" thick minimum, ¾" wide. 
 
Adhesive: 
Non-flammable, solvent-based.  Service Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F.   
Produced under the UL Classification and Follow-up service.  
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.08 perm 
maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Fastening and Adhesive: 
As recommended by insulation manufacturer for full vapor barrier installation. 
 
 
END OF F2 
 
 
 
R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Johns Manville 
Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation 
Knauf Insulation 
 
Temperature Rating: 
0°F to 850°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic, non-chloride, glass fibers, bonded with a thermosetting resin, ASTM 
C547, ASTM C795, Type 1, rigid pipe insulation, jacketed, non-
weatherproofed. 
 
Thermal Conductivity:  
Maximum of 0.25 Btu-in/hr.•ft2•°F average at 100°F mean temperature. 
 
Density: 
Maximum of 10 lb/ft3 average. 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM C921, Type I - full vapor barrier type.  PVC jacketing, high-impact, 
ultraviolet-resistant, 20-mils thick, roll stock ready for shop or field cutting and 
forming to indicated sizes, fastened as recommended by manufacturer.  
Jacketing shall be provided as a totally sealed system by using Zeston Perma-
Weld solvent welding adhesive or equivalent. 
 
Adhesive: 
Non-flammable, solvent-based.  Service Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F.  
Produced under the UL Classification and Follow-up service. 
 
PVC Fitting Covers: 
Factory-fabricated fitting covers manufactured from 20-mil-thick, high-impact, 
ultraviolet-resistant PVC. 
 
Fastening and Adhesive: 
As recommended by insulation manufacturer for full vapor barrier installation. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.08 perm 
maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Seal all joints of PVC jacketing not permanently welded with white silicone caulking.

R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Johns Manville 
Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation 
Knauf Fiberglass 
Certain Teed Corporation 
 
Temperature Rating: 
0°F to 450°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic glass fibers, bonded with a thermosetting resin, ASTM C 553, Type 2 
or 3, flexible blanket insulation, minimum 1.5 lb/ft3 density, jacketed. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.31 Btu-in/hr.•ft2•°F average at 75°F mean temperature. 
 
Jacket: 
FSK:  Factory-applied FSK jacket conforming to ASTM C1136, consisting of 
aluminum foil bonded to kraft paper, reinforced with laminated glass-fiber-mat. 
 
Adhesive: 
Non-flammable, solvent-based.  Service Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F.  
Produced under the UL Classification and Follow-up service. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.04 perm 
maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Corner Angles: 
Install corner angle on external corners of insulation on ductwork in exposed 
spaces. 
 
Secure insulation to ducts with longest side or diameter less than 24" with bonding adhesive applied in 6" wide 
transverse strips on 12" centers. 
 
Secure insulation to ducts with longest side or diameter 24" and larger with anchor pins spaced 12" apart each 
way.  Apply bonding adhesive to prevent sagging of the insulation. 
 
Outdoor Weatherproofing: 
Polyguard Alumaguard All-Weather.  Multi-ply rubberized bitumen, aluminum 
foil faced vapor barrier, weather barrier, and UV barrier membrane designed 
specifically to stick to insulation jackets.

R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Johns Manville

Knauf Fiberglass 
Certain Teed Corporation 
 
Temperature Rating: 
0°F - 450°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic, non-chloride, glass fibers, bonded with a thermosetting resin, ASTM 
C 612-Type 1A, ASTM C 795, semi-rigid, jacketed, board insulation. Density; 
Minimum 3.0 lb/ft3 where concealed and 6.0 lb/ft3 where exposed. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.26 Btu-in/hr•ft2•°F average at 75°F mean temperature. 
 
Jacket: 
FSK:  Factory-applied FSK jacket conforming to ASTM C1136, consisting of 
aluminum foil bonded to kraft paper, reinforced with laminated glass-fiber-mat. 
 
Adhesive: 
Non-flammable, solvent-based.  Service Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F.  
Produced under the UL Classification and Follow-up service.

maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Corner Angles: 
Install corner angle on external corners of insulation on ductwork in exposed 
spaces. 
 
Secure board insulation with speed washers and welded pins.  Space anchor pins 18 inches apart each way and 
3 inches from insulation joints. 
 
Outdoor Weatherproofing: 
Polyguard Alumaguard All-Weather.   Multi-ply rubberized bitumen, aluminum 
foil faced vapor barrier, weather barrier, and UV barrier membrane designed 
specifically to stick to insulation jackets.

R 
  
Spec. by 
S. Nagel 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Johns Manville  
Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corporation  
Knauf Fiberglass 
Certain Teed Corporation 
 
Temperature Rating: 
0°F - 450°F 
 
Material: 
Inorganic, non-chloride, glass fibers, bonded with a thermosetting resin, 
ASTM C 612-Type 1A, ASTM C 795, semi-rigid, jacketed, board 
insulation. Density; Minimum 3.0 lb/ft3 where concealed and 6.0 lb/ft3 
where exposed. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.26 Btu-in/hr•ft2•°F average at 75°F mean temperature. 
 
Jacket: 
Aluminum, ASTM B209, 3003 Alloy, H-14 temper,0.016” thickness for 
indoor use, 0.024” thickness for outdoor use, smooth finish, roll stock 
ready for shop or field cutting and forming to insulation.   
 
Adhesive: 
Non-flammable, solvent-based.  Service Temperature Range, -20°F to 
180°F.  Produced under the UL Classification and Follow-up service. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.02 
perm maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Waterproofing Mastic Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive, weatherproofing mastic coating.  Water 
Vapor Permeance, ASTM E-96, procedure B, 2.0 perms.  Temperature 
Range, -40°F to 180°F deg F. 
 
Corner Angles: 
Install corner angle on external corners of insulation on ductwork in 
exposed spaces. 
 
Secure board insulation with speed washers and welded pins.  Space anchor pins 18" apart each way and 3" 
from insulation joints. 
 
Exterior Ductwork Installation:  
Insulation seams shall be sealed with vapor barrier tape.  Encase ductwork 
insulation with vapor barrier with aluminum jacketing.  Horizontal 
jacketing seams shall overlap 3" with seam on the side of duct and overlap 
from above.  Perimeter jacketing seams shall overlap 3".  All seams shall 
be sealed with waterproofing mastic. 
 
END OF F14

Piping Insulation Notes: 
1. These pipe insulation thicknesses (not including the two “Plumb” columns) meet all the requirements of the 2018, 
2015, 2012, 2009 and 2006 International Codes, the 2019, 2016, 2013 and 2010 ASHRAE 90.1 standard, the 
2019, 2016 and 2013 California Title 24 codes, condensation control and personnel protection.  They are based 
on 
the 
thermal 
conductivity 
as 
listed 
in 
specification 
230250 
datasheets.  
The “Plumb 40 to 60” column can be used where the code in force doesn’t have a thickness requirement.   
The “Plumb 61 to 104” column can be used for a) service water heating where the 2009 or 2006 IECC or 2019 
or 2016 California Title 24 codes do not apply and where the applicable code in force allows these thickness 
values, and b) for other services where the code in force allows these thickness values.  Refer to the Piping 
Systems 
Application 
Table 
for 
required 
insulation 
thicknesses 
for 
specific 
piping 
services.                    
If the Contractor is proposing materials with higher conductivity, then greater thicknesses may be required, and 
the Contractor shall provide calculations to the Engineer for review and approval.   
2. Index temperature ranges for piping are not necessarily the actual fluid temperature, but rather they are the 
temperature ranges selected by the Engineer upon which to base insulation thickness.  Differences between actual 
fluid temperature and chosen index temperature may account for factors such as transient room temperature and 
humidity situations.  See the Piping Systems Application Table in specification 230500 for required index 
temperatures for each fluid type.   
3. Do not use fiberglass insulation on piping with fluids colder than 40F in any location, or on piping with fluids 
60F or below where it is located outdoors in humid climates, unless approved by the Engineer.   
4. For thermal conductivities different than the values in specification datasheets, the minimum thickness (T) shall 
be determined as follows:  
T = r{(1 + t/r)K/k – 1}, where  
T = minimum insulation thickness (in.), r = actual outside radius of pipe (in.),   
t = insulation thickness listed in this table for applicable index temperature and pipe size,  
K = thermal conductivity of proposed insulation material at mean rating temperature between the applicable 
index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]); and  
k = thermal conductivity listed in the applicable insulation datasheet for the same mean temperature between the 
applicable index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F])

Ductwork and Equipment Insulation Notes: 
1. Refer to specification 230250 for the insulation category and location of duct systems and equipment where 
insulation is required on this project.   
2. Insulation thicknesses listed are for information only.  The R-value is the actual requirement.  Insulation 
thicknesses listed are nominal and uncompressed.  Per codes, actual installed conditions include 25% compression 
for duct wrap insulation.  Compression does not apply to board and liner insulation.   
 
R 
  
Spec. by 
JY 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Industrial Insulation Group, MinWool-1200, or approved equal 
 
Temperature Range: 
0ºF to 1200ºF 
 
Material: 
Inorganic basalt with a thermosetting resin binder, noncombustible ASTM 
C547, Type II, preformed pipe insulation. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.48 Btu-in/hr•ft2•°F at 500°F. 
 
Recovery After 10% Compression: 100% 
 
Shrinkage: 
0% at 1,050°F (566°) 
 
<2% at 1,200°F (649°C) 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM B 209, Aluminum jacketing, 3003 Alloy, H-14 temper, 0.016” 
thickness for indoor use, 0.024” thickness for outdoor use, smooth finish, 
with heat laminated vapor barrier, factory cut and rolled or roll stock ready 
for shop or field cutting and forming to insulation.

Vapor Barrier Compound:

perm maximum.  Temperature Range, -20°F to 180°F. 
 
Provide extended legs for traced pipe lines.

Piping Insulation Notes: 
1. These pipe insulation thicknesses meet all the requirements of  the 2019, 2016, 2013 and 2010 ASHRAE 90.1 
standard, the 2019, 2016 and 2013 California Title 24 codes, condensation control and personnel protection.  They 
are 
based 
on 
the 
thermal 
conductivity 
as 
listed 
in 
specification 
230250datasheets.                 
If the Contractor is proposing materials with higher conductivity, then greater thicknesses may be required, and the 
Contractor shall provide calculations to the Engineer for review and approval.   
2. Index temperature ranges for piping are not necessarily the actual fluid temperature, but rather they are the 
temperature ranges selected by the Engineer upon which to base insulation thickness.  Differences between actual 
fluid temperature and chosen index temperature may account for factors such as transient room temperature and 
humidity situations.  See the Piping Systems Application Table in specification 230500 for required index 
temperatures for each fluid type.   
3. Do not use mineral wool insulation on piping with fluids colder than 40F in any location, or on piping with fluids 
60F or below where it is located outdoors in humid climates, unless approved by the Engineer.   
4. For thermal conductivities different than the values in specification datasheets, the minimum thickness (T) shall 
be determined as follows:  
T = r{(1 + t/r)K/k – 1}, where  
T = minimum insulation thickness (in.),  
r = actual outside radius of pipe (in.),   
t = insulation thickness listed in this table for applicable index temperature and pipe size,  
K = thermal conductivity of proposed insulation material at mean rating temperature between the applicable index 
temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]); and  
k = thermal conductivity listed in the applicable insulation datasheet for the same mean temperature between the 
applicable index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F])

insulation is required on this project.   
2. Insulation thicknesses listed are for information only.  The R-value is the actual requirement.   
R 
  
Spec. by 
CLS 
 
Manufacturers: 
 
Accessible Products Co. 
 
Temperature Rating: 
-40°F - 350° F 
 
Material: 
Flexible, expanded foam, pre-formed tubular Melamine insulation conforming to 
ASTM C 1410 with open-cell structure, smooth skin on both sides. Tested in 
accordance with ASTM C-871 for maximum leachable chloride content of 95 
ppm. Tested in accordance with ASTM C795 for use in contact with austenitic 
stainless steel. Self-extinguishing and non-toxic. 
 
Conductivity Thermal: 
Maximum of 0.25 BTU-in/hr-ft2-°F average at 75°F maximum temperature. 
 
Density: 
0.5 to 0.62 lbs./ft3 
 
Jacket Material: 
Factory applied high impact, high gloss, washable 0.020” PVC conforming to 
ASTM E-84 for a flame spread rating of 25 or less and a smoke developed rating 
of 50 or less. Insulation shall be sealed longitudinally with a self-adhesive lap seal 
and sealed around the circumference with color matched sealing tape. Jacket shall 
be white. Fittings shall have factory manufactured fitting covers. Surface 
temperature rating from 0°F - 140°F. 
 
Fittings: 
Precut, factory manufactured fitting insulation. Factory-fabricated fitting covers 
manufactured from 20-mil-thick, high-impact, ultraviolet-resistant PVC. 
 
Fastening and Adhesive: 
As recommended by insulation manufacturer for full vapor barrier installation. All 
seams, both straight lap joints and circumferential lap joints, shall be glued with 
factory supplied solvent based adhesive. In below ambient piping applications and 
severe wash down environments, all seams shall be over-sealed with a factory 
approved RTV sealant to guarantee a positive vapor barrier seal. 
 
 
END OF MM2

Notes: 
1. These pipe insulation thicknesses meet all the requirements of the 2015, 2012, 2009 and 2006 International Codes, 
the 2013 and 2010 ASHRAE 90.1 standard, the 2013 California Title 24 codes, condensation control and personnel 
protection. They are based on the thermal conductivity as listed in specification 230250 datasheets. 
If the Contractor is proposing materials with higher conductivity, then greater thicknesses may be required and the 
Contractor shall provide calculations to the Engineer for review and approval.   
2. Index temperature ranges for piping are not necessarily the actual fluid temperature, but rather they are the 
temperature ranges selected by the Engineer upon which to base insulation thickness.  Differences between actual 
fluid temperature and chosen index temperature may account for factors such as transient room temperature and 
humidity situations.  See the Piping Systems Application Table in specification 230500 for required index 
temperatures for each fluid type.   
3. For thermal conductivities different than the values in specification datasheets, the minimum thickness (T) shall 
be determined as follows:  
T = r{(1 + t/r)K/k – 1}, where  
T = minimum insulation thickness (in.),  
r = actual outside radius of pipe (in.),   
t = insulation thickness listed in this table for applicable index temperature and pipe size,  
K = thermal conductivity of proposed insulation material at mean rating temperature between the applicable index 
temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]); and  
k = thermal conductivity listed in the applicable insulation datasheet for the same mean temperature between the 
applicable index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]) 
 
R 
  
Spec. by 
 JY 
  
Manufacturers: 
 
 
Dyplast Products. 
ITW - Insulation Systems 
Elliott Co. 
 
Temperature Rating: 
-297°F to 300°F 
 
Material: 
Polyisocyanurate (modified polyurethane) ASTM C-591, pre-formed tubular 
insulation Grade 2. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.19 Btu-in/hr.•ft2•°F average at 75°F maximum temperature. 
 
Density: 
Minimum 2.0 lb./ft3 and 4.0 lb./ft3 at supports. 
 
Moisture Barrier: 
Factory-applied, vapor retarder film having self-sealing lap. Insulation shall 
be sealed longitudinally with a self-adhesive lap seal and sealed around the 
circumference with vapor retarder tape.  Maximum .01 perm. Saran 560 or 
approved equivalent. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.08 perm 
maximum ASTM F1249.  Temperature Range, -170°F to 300°F. 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM B 209, Aluminum jacketing, 3003 Alloy, H-14 temper, 0.016” 
thickness for indoor use, 0.024” thickness for outdoor use, smooth finish, 
factory cut and rolled or roll stock ready for shop or field cutting and 
forming to insulation. 
 
Jacket Bands: 
ASTM B 209 Aluminum bands, 0.007" thick minimum, 3/4" wide. 
 
Adhesive: 
3/4" wide fiberglass-reinforced plastic adhesive tape applied to pipe on 9" 
centers.  Service Temperature Range, -170°F to 300°F. 
 
Joint Sealer: 
Seal joints and butt ends with permanent plastic material, Foster 95-44 or 
approved equivalent. 
 
Installation shall be per manufacturer’s installation guidelines. 
 
 
END OF P2

ITW - Insulation Systems 
Elliott Co. 
 
Temperature Rating: 
-297°F to 300°F 
 
Material: 
Polyisocyanurate (modified polyurethane) ASTM C-591, pre-formed tubular 
insulation Grade 2. 
 
Thermal Conductivity: 
Maximum of 0.19 Btu-in/hr.•ft2•°F average at 75°F maximum temperature. 
 
Density: 
Minimum 2.0 lb./ft3 and 4.0 lb./ft3 at supports. 
 
Moisture Barrier: 
Factory-applied, vapor retarder film having self-sealing lap. Insulation shall be 
sealed longitudinally with a self-adhesive lap seal and sealed around the 
circumference with vapor retarder tape.  Maximum 0.01 perm. Saran 560 or 
approved equivalent. 
 
Vapor Barrier Compound: 
Water-based, fire-resistive composition.  Water Vapor Permeance, 0.08 perm 
maximum ASTM F1249.  Temperature Range, -170°F to 300°F. 
 
Jacket: 
ASTM C 921, Type I - full vapor barrier type.  PVC jacketing, high-impact, 
ultraviolet-resistant, 20-mils thick, roll stock ready for shop or field cutting and 
forming to indicated sizes, fastened as recommended by manufacturer.  Jacketing 
shall be provided as a totally sealed system by using Zeston Perma-Weld solvent 
welding adhesive or equivalent. 
 
Adhesive: 
3/4" wide fiberglass-reinforced plastic adhesive tape applied to pipe on 9" 
centers.  Service Temperature Range, -170°F to 300°F. 
 
Joint Sealer: 
Seal joints and butt ends with permanent plastic material, Foster 95-44 or 
approved equivalent. 
 
PVC Fitting Covers: 
Factory-fabricated fitting covers manufactured from 20-mil-thick, high-impact, 
ultraviolet-resistant PVC. 
 
Fastening and Adhesive: 
As recommended by insulation manufacturer for full vapor barrier installation. 
 
Installation shall be per manufacturer’s installation guidelines. 
 
Seal all joints of PVC jacketing not Perma-Welded with white silicone caulking.

Piping Insulation Notes: 
1. These pipe insulation thicknesses meet all the requirements of the 2018, 2015, 2012, 2009 and 2006 International 
Codes, the 2019, 2016, 2013 and 2010 ASHRAE 90.1 standard, the 2019, 2016 and 2013 California Title 24 
codes, condensation control and personnel protection.  They are based on the thermal conductivity as listed in 
specification 230250 datasheets.                                                                                  .  
If the Contractor is proposing materials with higher conductivity, then greater thicknesses may be required, and 
the Contractor shall provide calculations to the Engineer for review and approval.   
2. Index temperature ranges for piping are not necessarily the actual fluid temperature, but rather they are the 
temperature ranges selected by the Engineer upon which to base insulation thickness.  Differences between actual 
fluid temperature and chosen index temperature may account for factors such as transient room temperature and 
humidity situations.  See the Piping Systems Application Table in specification 230500 for required index 
temperatures for each fluid type.   
3. For thermal conductivities different than the values in specification datasheets, the minimum thickness (T) shall 
be determined as follows:  
T = r{(1 + t/r)K/k – 1}, where  
T = minimum insulation thickness (in.),  
r = actual outside radius of pipe (in.),   
t = insulation thickness listed in this table for applicable index temperature and pipe size,  
K = thermal conductivity of proposed insulation material at mean rating temperature between the applicable 
index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]); and  
k = thermal conductivity listed in the applicable insulation datasheet for the same mean temperature between the 
applicable index temperature and the room temperature, (Btu-inch./[h•ft2•°F]) 
SECTION 230275 
PRESSURE SAFETY RELIEF DEVICES 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
SUMMARY 
 
This specification indicates the requirements for relief, safety, pressure relief, and safety relief valves, heretofore 
referred to pressure safety relief valves, as well as sentinel or warning valves.  This specification also indicates 
the requirements for rupture disks and fusible plugs.  Attached to and part of this specification are data sheets for 
each valve, disk and plug. 
 
1.2. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
In addition to the drawings and general conditions specifications for the project, applicable sections of the 
following documents apply to and comprise part of this specification section: 
 
Section 230010 Basic Mechanical Requirements 
Section 230050 Basic Mechanical Materials and Methods 
 
1.3. 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
The manufacture, testing and installation of valves shall comply with the applicable requirements of the most 
recent edition of the following codes and standards: 
 
ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code 
API 
 
1.4. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
Provide submittal documents in compliance with requirements indicated in Section 230010 Basic Mechanical 
Requirements. 
 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
VALVES 
 
Provide valves as indicated on the attached data sheets.  Valves shall have a permanently mounted tag indicating 
manufacturer, model number, serial number, and relief set pressure.  Provide each valve with a certification form 
indicating conformance to applicable codes and standards. 
 
2.2. 
DRIP PAN ELBOWS 
 
Drip pan elbows shall match the material of construction of the upstream valve and downstream piping, and 
otherwise shall be compatible with the relieving fluid.  The inlet ports shall be sized to match the discharge size 
and type of the upstream valves.  Where an exact size match is not available, the next larger size drip pan elbow 
shall be used. 
 
2.3. 
FUSIBLE PLUGS 
 
Provide fusible plugs as indicated on the attached data sheets.  Plugs shall have a permanently mounted tag or be 
stamped on the body, indicating manufacturer, model number, melt temperature, and serial number.  Plugs shall 
be stainless steel. 
 
Plugs shall be installed in stainless steel tees connected directly to the vessel jacket.  The plug body must not be 
covered by pipe or vessel insulation and must be mounted on the side of the pipe, parallel to the floor. 
 
Acceptable fusible plug manufacturers: 
 
Sigma Enterprises 
 
2.4. 
RUPTURE DISKS 
 
2.4.1. 
Disks 
 
Provide rupture disks as indicated on the attached datasheets.  Rupture disks shall have a permanently mounted 
tag indicating manufacturer, model number, serial number, size, burst pressure and coincident temperature, 
reorder lot number, and direction of flow.  All rupture disks shall be provided with a certificate indicating 
conformance to applicable codes and standards. 
 
Rupture disks in hygienic service shall be of non-fragmenting reverse buckling type with a smooth, crevice free 
construction on the process side. 
 
Rupture disks located upstream of relief valves shall be non-fragmenting and certified for combination operation 
with a relief valve. 
 
Disks shall be BS&B, Fike, Continental, Oseco, ZOOK Enterprises (graphite disks only), or approved equivalent. 
 
Three (3) additional rupture disks shall be provided for each four (4) rupture disks of identical size, rating, and 
specification, to be used as spares during construction, commissioning, and validation. 
 
2.4.2. 
Disk Holders 
 
A disk holder shall be provided where indicated on the attached datasheets.  A rupture disk holder specifically 
designed for and supplied by the rupture disk manufacturer shall be used to secure the rupture disk to its 
connection point.  The holder shall be permanently marked with the rupture disk tag number. 
 
 
Holders shall be BS&B, Fike, Continental, Oseco, ZOOK Enterprises (graphite disks only) or approved 
equivalent. 
 
2.4.3. 
Burst Sensors 
 
A disk burst sensor shall be provided where indicated on the attached datasheets.  Sensors shall be suitable for 
operation at temperatures of 0-300°F.  Sensors shall be designed for normally closed output and be compatible 
with +5VDC loop power from a control system.  Burst sensor lead length shall be 25 feet minimum or as 
coordinated with the controls contractor, and shall incorporate quick connect type fittings at the sensor to allow 
for removal and replacement without installing new leads to control system. 
 
Burst Sensors shall be BS&B, Fike, Continental, Oseco, ZOOK Enterprises (graphite disks only) or approved 
equivalent. 
 
2.4.4. 
Pipe End Covers 
 
Provide Enviro Guard, Continental Disc Corporation, pipe end covers where indicated on the attached datasheets.  
Covers shall be constructed of PTFE coated/impregnated fiberglass fabric material, blue in color, and designed 
to fit vent piping with either a 90o or 45° angle cut.  Provide covers with a stainless steel identification tag, Nomex 
drawstring and Nomex retrieval rope. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
Provide and install devices as indicated on the drawings, where required to meet the design intent of the system, 
and to comply with applicable codes and standards.  Install devices in accordance with the manufacturer's 
instructions and recommendations.  Install and configure devices in a location and manner to make them readily 
accessible for maintenance and inspection. 
 
Install drip pan elbows where indicated on the drawings, and wherever the discharge piping from a valve is routed 
vertically to the exterior of the building.  Install elbows as close as possible and practical to the discharge port of 
the valve, according to the manufacturer's recommendations.  Route a drain line from the drain port of the drip 
pan elbow to a safe location.  Do not use the drip pan elbow to support the downstream piping. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
VS * - Vendor/Manufacturer to Supply Information

by 1”x1-1/2” relief valve.

NOTES 
(1) 
All units shall have the proper ASME and National Board of Boiler and Pressure Vessel 
Inspectors  stamps, OSHA data, manufacturer’s name, model number and serial number on a 
stainless steel tag affixed to unit. 
(2) 
Actual maximum coincident temperature is 185 °F. Coincident temperature of 250 °F is used to 
match site standard. 
(3) 
Vessels V101, V102, and V103 cannot be overpressurized in a CIP cycle scenario, the system 
volume for CIP fluids is less than the total volume of the vessels. This is primarily sized for the 
coincidence that vessel V201, V202, or V203 is overfilled with CIP fluids. In an overfill scenario 
for vessels V101, V102, and V103, we would see compressed air overpressurization at a 
maximum of 50 psig and a required relief area of less than 4.91 sqin. 
SECTION 230480 
HYGIENIC SYSTEM SPECIALTIES 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1 
SUMMARY 
 
The specification indicates the requirements for specialty components installed on hygienic systems. These 
systems are identified as hygienic on the piping system application table. The components described herein are 
generally used in the following systems. 
 
CIP – Clean in Place 
RO – Reverse Osmosis Water 
WFI – Water for Injection 
P – Product/process systems 
CA –Compressed Air (downstream of sterile filtration) 
 
These components may be specified for installation on other systems as indicated on the drawings and the attached 
component schedules. 
 
Attached to and part of this specification are schedules for the components required for the project and specified 
herein, which provide additional information for each component.  The tag numbers for the components correlate 
to those indicated on the drawings. 
 
For each product used in a hygienic system, the owner shall verify that absorption, adsorption, and permeability 
of the product and possible contaminants are known, and provide evidence that the process contact material is not 
reactive, additive, or absorptive. The product contact materials must not alter the safety, identity, strength, quality, 
or purity of the product beyond the official or established requirements. 
 
All surfaces in contact with hygienic process streams shall be smooth, continuous, non-pooling, and crevice-free. 
 
1.2 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
In addition to the drawings and general conditions specifications for the project, applicable sections of the 
following documents apply to and comprise part of this specification section: 
 
 
230050 – Basic Mechanical Materials and Methods 
 
1.3 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
The manufacture and installation of components shall comply with the applicable requirements of the most recent 
edition of the following codes and standards: 
 
ANSI 
ASME BPE – BioProcess Equipment 
ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1 
ASTM 
AWS 
USP Class VI, 
FDA CFR 177.2600 
FDA CFR 211.94 
ISO 10993 
European Pharmacopoeia 
3-A standards 
 
1.4 
SUBMITTALS 
 
Provide submittal documents in compliance with requirements indicated in specification section 230010. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1 
BACK PRESSURE REGULATOR 
 
Provide self-contained type with adjustable pressure ranges and positive shutoff; stainless steel forged and spring 
chamber investment cast body with sanitary end connections.  All wetted parts shall be 316L stainless steel, 
polished to a minimum of 25 µ-inch Ra.  Valve shall be self-draining and designed for a working pressure of 150 
psig with a maximum operating temperature of 300°F.  Unit shall be capable of being cleaned-in-place and 
steamed-in-place. 
 
2.2 
FLEXIBLE HOSES 
 
2.2.1 
General 
 
Flexible hoses shall have a smooth, drainable interior and a readily cleanable exterior.  The process contact 
materials shall meet USP Class VI requirements for elastomers.  All hoses shall be fully autoclavable.  End 
connections shall be installed in an integral manner with the hose and provide a 360° seal at the internal and 
external junction points with no visible crevices or areas where wicking can occur.  Hose barb type connections 
are prohibited.  End connections shall be hygienic clamp type constructed of the same material and with the same 
interior surface finish as that of the equipment/systems to which they will be connected, unless indicated 
otherwise.  When an end connection is required with a larger size than the nominal size of the hose (step up), the 
connection shall utilize an integral interior taper to promote cleanability and drainability. 
 
Verify that the flexible hose types and sizes indicated in the flexible hose schedule are compatible with the media 
being transferred, pressure, temperature, chemistry, bend radius, effect of elevated temperatures on working 
pressure and vacuum ratings.  Also, comply with the need for conductive materials to dissipate electrostatic 
charges where noted in the drawings and hose schedules. 
 
The hose lengths indicated in schedule are approximate, and shall be field verified to assure ease of installation, 
without undue stress on the hose, and junction points both internally and externally.  Eliminate low points or 
 
determined by field measurements after the equipment and systems which the hose will connect to are installed, 
but shall not be less than 12 inches unless approved by the Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
2.2.2 
Type "A" Hose 
 
Type "A" hose shall be constructed of translucent platinum cured silicone reinforced with a Polyester or Nomex® 
fiber braid.  Hoses shall have a minimum working temperature rating of -80°F to 400°F, with working pressures 
dependent upon on size.  Nominal hose inside diameters shall be 1/4" to 1".  Type "A" hose shall not be used for 
continuous steam or vacuum service. 
 
Sani-Tech West SBP type or approved equivalent. 
 
2.2.3 
Type "B" Hose 
 
Type "B" hose shall be constructed of translucent platinum cured silicone reinforced with a multiple plies of 
Nomex® fiber braid or Polyester fabric and 316L stainless steel helical wire.  Hoses shall have a minimum 
working temperature rating of -80°F to 400°F, with working pressures dependent upon on size, and full vacuum 
at 70°F.  Nominal hose inside diameters shall be 1/2" to 4". 
 
Sani-Tech West SVP type or approved equivalent. 
 
2.2.4 
Type "C" Hose 
 
Type "C" hose shall be constructed of FEP, PTFE, or PFA fluoropolymer liner natural or static conductive (black) 
as noted in the hose schedules. 
 
C1:  Shall be reinforced with a multiple layers of polyester reinforcement and high tensile strength carbon steel 
wire, and an EPDM cover with a readily cleanable surface.  Hoses shall have a minimum working temperature 
rating of -20°F to 300°F, with working pressures dependent upon on size, and full vacuum at 70°F.  Nominal hose 
inside diameters shall be 1/2" to 4". 
 
Hoses shall be Saint-Gobain Versilon™ WTLCTPFA type or approved equivalent. 
 
C2:  Extremely flexible reinforced with 316L stainless steel helical wire and stainless-steel braid with an extruded 
EPDM cover over the braid.  Inside diameters of ¼” to 2”, a minimum working temperature rating of -80°F to 
400°F, with working pressures dependent on size. 
 
Hoses shall be Bioflex Ultra GPSSRC or ASSSRC (static conductive) or approved equivalent.
