Product data:  Manufacturer's detailed technical materials, fabrication, and installation data, including 
technical bulletins, drawings, guides, and manuals, as applicable to the work of this Project. 
C. 
Certifications:  Manufacturer's certification that pipe and fittings have been inspected and tested at the 
point of origin and are in compliance with specified requirements. 
PART 2 - PRODUCTS 
2.01 
MATERIALS 
A. 
Pipe and fittings: 
1. 
Chlorinated Polyvinyl Chloride (CPVC) pipe and fittings for pipelines 15 inches and smaller:  
Conform to ASTM D 3034, Schedule 80 DWV. 
a. 
Manufacture pipe from approved, Type 1, Grade 1, CPVC conforming to ASTM D 1784 and 
meeting requirements of ASTM D 2122 and ASTM D 2412. 
b. 
Pipe shall have integral wall thickened bells or extruded couplings with gasket seals.  Solvent 
weld joints will not be permitted. 
c. 
Pipe joints shall be gasket push-on type complying with ASTM D 3212 and ASTM F 477. 
d. 
Pipe shall be UL/FM approved. 
e. 
Fittings shall conform to the same specifications as pipe in which they are to be installed. 
f. 
Pipe shall be identified on the exterior of the pipe with the following information: 
1) 
Nominal pipe size and o.d. base. 
2) 
Material code designation number (12454C). 
3) 
Pipe Stiffness Designation (PS46). 
4) 
ANSI/ASTM Designation (D3034). 
5) 
Pipe manufacturer's name and production code. 
 
 
PART 3 - EXECUTION 
3.01 
INSTALLATION/PERFORMANCE 
A. 
Excavating, trenching, backfilling, and compacting:  In accord with Division 31 Section "Excavation and 
Fill for Utilities". 
B. 
Pipe laying:  Lay pipe as indicated on Drawings, as specified herein, and in compliance with applicable 
portions of ASTM D 2321. 
1. 
Grade trench bottom to indicated elevation of pipeline and shape bottom to fit lower quadrant of 
pipe.  Excavate holes at each bell hub such that pipe will be uniformly supported along entire 
length of barrel only. 
2. 
Pipe installation and jointing shall be in accord with pipe manufacturer's specifications and 
instructions for type of pipe used and applicable requirements specified herein.  All pipe having a 
defective joint, bell, or spigot is unacceptable, shall be rejected, removed from site, and replaced 
with an acceptable unit. 
3. 
Commence pipe laying in finished trench at lowest point, or from a point designated by Owner, 
and lay upgrade from point of connection with all bell ends forward. 
4. 
Install pipe to homing mark on spigot.  On field cut pipe, provide a homing mark on spigot end in 
accord with manufacturer's recommendations. 
5. 
Maintain pipe alignment and joint closure until sufficient haunching and backfill is in place to 
adequately hold pipe in position. 
6. 
Prevent foreign materials from entering pipe while it is being placed in trench.  Do not place 
debris, tools, articles of clothing, or other materials in pipe at any time. 
7. 
As each length of pipe is placed in trench, assemble joints and bring pipe to intended line and 
grade.  Bed and secure pipe in place. 
8. 
When pipe laying is delayed for 10 min. or more, close open ends of pipe using a watertight plug 
or other approved means to ensure that absolute cleanliness is maintained inside pipe. 
9. 
At penetrations of manhole and similar structures, smoothly cut penetrating ends of pipe parallel 
to interior surface of structure.  Maximum interior protrusion of pipe shall be the minimum 
necessary for proper sealing of pipe connection to structure.  Use resilient connector when 
indicated on Drawings. 
C. 
Pipe jointing: 
1. 
Pipe installation and jointing shall be in accord with pipe manufacturer's specifications and 
instructions for type of pipe used and applicable requirements specified herein. 
2. 
Ensure that interior of pipe and jointing seal is free of sand, dirt, trash, or other foreign materials 
before installation.  All pipe or fitting that has been installed containing dirt or other deleterious 
material shall be removed, cleaned, and re-laid.  Extreme care shall be taken to keep bells of pipe 
free from sand, dirt, or rocks so that joints may be properly assembled without overstressing bells. 
3.02 
FIELD QUALITY CONTROL 
A. 
Alignment:  Inspect sanitary sewerage lines to determine if displacement of pipe has occurred during 
backfilling and compaction. 
B. 
Correct, at no additional cost, sections of piping that are deficient in material, alignment, grade, or joints. 
                                                                    END OF SECTION 
 
 
 
 
Division 40 
Instrumentation and Controls 
SECTION 409010 
BASIC INSTRUMENTATION AND CONTROL REQUIREMENTS 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and Division 
01 Specification Sections, apply to this and the other Sections of Division 40.   
 
The requirements of this section apply to all other Division 40 Sections. 
 
Contract Drawings are in part schematic, intended to convey the scope of work and indicate the general layout, 
design, and arrangement.  
 
Follow Contract Drawings in laying out the work.  Check and be familiar with Shop Drawings and Coordination 
Drawings affecting spaces in which the work will be installed.  
 
Related Sections:  The following sections contain requirements that relate to this section: 
 
Division 40, Section 409050 - Basic Instrumentation and Controls Materials and Methods, for materials 
and methods common to the remainder of Division 40, plus general related specifications. 
 
1.2. 
SCOPE OF WORK 
 
See Section 011100 Summary of Work. 
 
1.3. 
JOB CONDITIONS 
 
Maintain a superintendent or foreman for each trade at the jobsite when work is being performed and when 
required for coordination between trades.   
 
Coordinate installation of instruments, final control devices, and enclosures and routing of conduit and tubing 
with others to allow unobstructed routing, operation, and service access.  Refer conflicts to the Owner or Owner's 
Representative for final decisions as to right-of-way. 
 
 
 
 
 
1.4. 
CODES, ORDINANCES, STANDARDS AND REGULATIONS 
 
Comply with applicable national, state, and local codes, ordinances, standards, and regulations, including but not 
limited to the following: 
 
ANSI 
Applicable American National Standards Institute Standards 
ASTM Applicable American Society of Testing and Materials Standards 
BOCA Building Officials and Code Administrators Building Code 
CFR 
Code of Federal Regulations, 21CFR 210 and 211 - cGMPs  
EPA 
US Environmental Protection Agency Regulations 
ISA 
International Society of Automation 
NEC 
National Electrical Code 
NEMA National Electrical Manufacturers Association 
NFPA National Fire Protection Association Standards 
NIST 
National Institute of Standards and Technology 
OSHA Occupational Safety and Health Association Regulations 
SBC 
Southern Uniform Building Code 
UBC 
Uniform Building Code 
UL 
UL Compliance 
 
1.5. 
DEFINITIONS 
 
Owner:  Takeda Pharmaceutical Company Limited or authorized representative. 
 
Engineer:  CRB Consulting Engineers, Inc. 
 
Instrument - A device used directly or indirectly to measure, monitor, record or control a variable.  The term 
includes primary elements, transmitters, analyzers, controllers, recorders, transducers, final control elements, 
signal converting or conditioning devices, computing devices, and electrical devices such as annunciators, 
switches, and pushbuttons.  The term does not apply to parts (e.g.; receiver bellows or a resistor) that are internal 
components of an instrument.  
 
Field - The areas where production occur (e.g.; the plant floor) exclusive of control rooms, administration areas, 
and welfare areas.  
 
Instrument Piping / Tubing - All piping, tubing, tubing bundles, tube track and channel, valves, air supply filters 
and regulators, fittings, supports, hardware, supplies required for capillary lines and process connections, for 
pneumatic signals and interconnections, and for air supplies shall constitute the instrument piping / tubing system.  
 
Remote Mounted Instruments - Instruments or components of instruments which are not mounted directly into 
the process or utility piping systems e.g.; remote transmitters/totalizers, and analyzers.  
 
Except as otherwise defined in greater detail, the terms "provide", "furnish" and "install" as used in Division 40 
contract documents shall have the following meanings: 
 
 
 
"Provide" or "provided" shall mean "furnish and install". 
 
"Furnish" or "furnished" shall mean to supply to the project site but does not include installation. 
 
"Install" or "installed" shall mean to mount and connect but does not include furnishing. 
 
1.6. 
ADJUSTMENT, START-UP AND DEMONSTRATION 
 
Adjust all systems and equipment to provide proper operation as indicated and described on the drawings and 
specified herein.   
 
 
 
 
Prior to final acceptance, operate systems and equipment for a minimum of 72 continuous hours and until normal 
operating conditions are achieved, as approved by the Owner.  Clean systems and equipment. 
 
Demonstrate the proper operation of all systems and equipment to the Owner.   
 
1.7. 
WARRANTIES AND GUARANTEES 
 
In addition to warranties called for in other sections of these specifications, work shall be guaranteed against 
defect due to faulty installation.  Warranties and guarantees shall be for a period of not less than one year, 
beginning on the later date of final acceptance by Owner, or equipment start-up. 
 
Upon written notice from the Owner or Owner’s Representative, promptly remedy, without cost to the Owner, 
any defects occurring or discovered during the guarantee period.   
 
1.8. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
General 
 
Provide submittals of material or equipment in accordance with the Submittal Requirement Schedule at the end 
of this specification section.  Some sections have very specific submittals, not indicated in this section, and 
therefore are indicated in a specific specification section.  Additional submittals are required if an "X" is indicated 
for that column and item. 
 
Acceptable Manufacturers 
 
Subject to compliance with the requirements of the individual specification sections, provide materials and 
equipment from the indicated manufacturers only.  Submittals of material or equipment manufactured by other 
than those indicated may be returned. 
 
Procedures 
 
Coordination:  Coordinate preparation and processing of submittals with performance of construction activities.  
Transmit each submittal sufficiently in advance of performance of related construction activities to avoid schedule 
delays. 
 
Coordinate each submittal with fabrication, purchasing, testing, delivery, other submittals, and related 
activities that requires sequential activity. 
 
Coordinate transmittal of different types of submittals for related elements of the work so processing 
will not be delayed by the need to review submittals concurrently for coordination. 
 
The Owner or Owner's Representative reserves the right to withhold action on a submittal requiring 
coordination with other submittals until related submittals are received. 
 
Processing:  Allow sufficient review time so that installation will not be delayed as a result of the time required 
to process submittals, including time to resubmit. 
 
Allow two weeks for initial review.  Allow additional time if processing must be delayed to permit 
coordination with subsequent submittals.  The Owner or Owner's Representative will promptly advise 
the Contractor when a submittal being processed must be delayed for coordination. 
 
If an intermediate submittal is necessary, process the same as the initial submittal. 
 
Allow two weeks for reprocessing each submittal. 
 
 
 
No extension of contract time will be authorized because of failure to transmit submittals to the Owner 
or Owner's Representative sufficiently in advance of the work to permit processing. 
 
Preparation:  Place a permanent label or title block on each submittal for identification.  Indicate the name of the 
entity that prepared each submittal on the label or title block. 
 
Provide a space approximately 4" x 5" on the label or beside the title block on Shop Drawings to record 
the Contractor's review and approval markings and the action taken. 
 
Provide a space approximately 4" x 5" on the label or beside the title block on Shop Drawings to record 
the Owner's or Owner's Representative review and approval markings and the action taken. 
 
Include the following information on the label or title block for processing and recording action taken. 
 
Project name 
Date 
Name and address of Owner 
Name and address of Engineer 
Name and address of Contractor 
Name and address of subcontractor 
Name and address of supplier 
Name of manufacturer 
Number and title of appropriate Specification Section 
Drawing number and detail references, as appropriate 
 
Transmittal:  Package each submittal appropriately for transmittal and handling.  Transmit each submittal from 
Contractor to Owner or Owner's Representative using a transmittal form.  Submittals received from sources other 
than the Contractor will be returned without action. 
 
Quantity:  Submit electronic Portable Document Format (PDF) of each required submittal.  The Owner will mark 
and return electronic copy with action taken and corrections or modifications required. 
 
Submittals shall be printed to .pdf, not printed as hard copy and scanned to .pdf.   Annotations to .pdf to clarify 
information, such as indicating specific options on an instrument cut sheet, should be done using editing tools in 
Adobe, Bluebeam, or comparable program, not hand-marked and scanned.   The Engineer or Owner reserves 
the right to reject submittals without review if the .pdf is not readable or if pixelation occurs on zooming in, 
rendering enlarged content unreadable. 
 
Schedules:  Project schedules indicating proposed work phases and sequences.  Include in schedule as a minimum, 
approvals, equipment release, delivery, fabrication, equipment setting, startup, punch, and cleanup.  Prepare and 
submit a complete schedule of submittals.  Coordinate the submittal schedule with the Contractor's construction 
schedule.  Prepare the schedule in chronological order.  Provide the following information: 
 
Scheduled date for the submittal 
Related Section number 
Submittal category 
Name of subcontractor 
Description of the part of the work covered 
Scheduled date for resubmit 
Anticipated date for Engineer's final release or approval 
 
Distribution:  Following response to initial submittal, print and distribute copies to subcontractors and other 
parties required to comply with submittal requirements. 
When revisions are made, distribute to the same parties.  Delete parties from distribution when they have 
 
 
 
Updating:  Revise the schedule after each meeting or activity, where revisions have been recognized or made.  
Issue the updated schedule to all parties involved. 
 
1.8.1. 
Review Action 
 
The Contractor is responsible for all data and information on submittals, including quantities, sizes, dimensions, 
and compliance with the Drawings and Specifications.  Checking by the Owner or Owner's Representative is only 
for general conformance with the design concept of the project and general compliance with the information given 
in the Contract Documents.  Any action shown is subject to the requirements of the Drawings and Specifications.  
Contractor is responsible for dimensions and quantities that shall be confirmed at the jobsite, and the fabrication 
process and techniques of construction. 
 
1.8.2. 
Shop Drawings 
 
Submit information, drawn to accurate scale.  Highlight, encircle, or otherwise indicate deviations from the 
Contract Documents.  Do not reproduce Contract Documents or copy standard information as the basis of Shop 
Drawings.  Standard information prepared without specific reference to the Project is not considered Shop 
Drawings. 
 
Shop Drawings include fabrication and installation drawings, setting diagrams, schedules, patterns, templates, 
and similar drawings.  Include as a minimum the following information on drawings or diagrams: 
 
Dimensions 
Identification of products and materials included 
Compliance with specified standards 
Notation of coordination requirements 
Notation of dimensions established by field measurement if applicable 
Clearances for access and service 
 
1.8.3. 
Product Data 
 
Collect Product Data into a single submittal for each element of construction or system. 
Where Product Data must be specially prepared because standard printed data is not suitable for use, submit as 
Shop Drawings. 
 
Product Data Information:  includes catalog cuts, sketches, or bulletins indicating performance characteristics, 
features of equipment, controls, instrumentation, equipment dimensions, materials of construction, estimated 
weights, heat rejection load when operating, auxiliaries, specialties, or accessories furnished, roughing-in or 
anchor diagrams and templates, manufacturer's installation instructions, service clearance requirements, standard 
color charts, and wiring diagrams. 
 
Mark each copy to show applicable choices and options.  Where printed Product Data includes information on 
several products, some of which are not required, mark copies to indicate the applicable information.  Include the 
following information with above product data: 
 
Manufacturer's printed recommendations 
Compliance with recognized trade association standards 
Compliance with recognized testing agency standards 
Application of testing agency labels and seals 
Notation of dimensions verified by field measurement 
Notation of coordination requirements 
 
Do not submit Product Data until compliance with requirements of the Contract Documents has been confirmed. 
 
 
 
 
Instrument Product Data and Format: shall meet the following guidelines: 
 
1. Cover sheet for each submittal, identifying the name of the client, name of the project, Vendor’s 
submittal ID, Vendor’s contact information, date, and purchase order number. 
2. Submittals shall include the whole instrument assembly, for example, elements and transmitters, 
or valves, actuators and position switches.  Multiple unrelated instrument types shall not be 
provided in the same document. 
3. Instruments will be grouped by model number and will not contain more than one model number 
in a grouping. 
4. A table for each group will contain the following fields at a minimum, tag number, P&ID, and any 
other optional important information such as line size, line specification, failure position, wetted 
elastomers, description, surface finish, etc.  This table shall be sorted by Tag Number. 
5. A model number code schedule that identifies each character in the model number and describes 
what the character represents, or a copy of the instrument cut sheet with each character in the 
model number highlighted on the order section. This must be provided for each unique model 
number.  Any special characters that are not published by the manufacturer but exist in the model 
number shall be accompanied by a clear description as provided by manufacturer.  Documentation 
of this description shall be provided in the form of official communications with manufacturer 
such as email or printed literature.  
6. Instrumentation such as diaphragm valves, multiport valves, and RTD/thermowells, where the 
orientation and dimensions are more clearly described using a drawing, shall be provided with the 
appropriate drawings.  This drawing shall document sizes and label port numbers, weir numbers, 
tag numbers or any information that helps clarify what is being purchased. 
7. All control valves and flow meters shall be provided with process data, sizing calculations, and/or 
flow curves that identify each process condition on the curve.  This information shall follow item 
number 5 in the submittal document but is not required if the exact model being purchased 
matches the model and sizing provided by the Engineer. 
8. A full copy of the instrument cut sheet for the specific model series. 
 
Schematic Drawings: shall include elevation and plan views, and indicate all connections, attachments, and details 
to indicate field required general details of assembly, etc. 
 
Wiring Diagrams: shall detail wiring for signal, control, and power, differentiating between manufacturer-
installed wiring and field-installed wiring. 
 
1.8.4. 
Record Documents 
 
General:  Do not use record document sets for construction purposes; protect from deterioration and loss, by 
keeping them in a secure, fire-resistive location; provide access of record documents for the Owner's reference 
during normal working hours. 
 
Record Drawings:  Upon completion of the work, provide a complete set of record drawings and documents for 
all submittals previously submitted for review.   Where required by the Owner, drawings and documents shall be 
provided in native file (AutoCAD, Word, Excel, etc.) as well as in .pdf.   
 
Maintain a clean, undamaged set of blue or black line prints of Contract Drawings and Shop Drawings.  Mark the 
set to show the actual installation where the installation varies from the work as originally shown.  Mark 
whichever drawing is most capable of showing conditions fully and accurately; where Shop Drawings are used, 
record a cross-reference at the corresponding location on the Contract Drawings.  Give particular attention to 
concealed elements that would be difficult to measure and record at a later date. 
 
Mark record sets in red; use other colors to distinguish between variations in separate categories of the work. 
Mark new information that is important to the Owner, but was not shown on Contract Drawings or Shop 
Drawings. 
 
 
 
Note related Change Order numbers where applicable. 
 
Organize record drawing sheets into manageable sets, bind with durable paper cover sheets, and print suitable 
titles, dates and other identification on the cover of each set. 
 
1.8.5. 
Manuals 
 
Maintenance Manuals:  Organize operating and maintenance data into suitable sets of manageable size.  Bind 
properly indexed data in individual heavy-duty 2", 3-ring vinyl-covered binders, with pocket folders for folded 
sheet information.  Mark appropriate identification on front and spine of each binder. Electronic format is also 
acceptable. Include the following types of information: 
 
Manufacturer name, Model number, and Serial number 
Shop Drawings and Product Data 
Wiring diagrams 
Copies of warranties 
Inspection procedures 
Troubleshooting instructions 
Parts list 
Recommended spare parts list 
 
Prepare maintenance manuals to include the following information for equipment and all auxiliary items: 
 
Description of function, normal operating characteristics and limitations, performance, engineering data 
and tests, control system documentation, and complete nomenclature and commercial numbers of 
replacement parts. 
 
Instructions for installation 
 
Manufacturer's printed operating procedures to include start-up, break-in, and routine and normal 
operating instructions; regulation, control, stopping, shutdown, and emergency instructions; and summer 
and winter operating instructions. 
 
Maintenance procedures for routine preventative maintenance and troubleshooting; disassembly, repair, 
and reassembly; aligning and adjusting instructions; instrument calibration and test procedures. 
 
Servicing instructions and lubrication charts and schedules. 
 
Parts list shall be furnished listing all parts for equipment.  Indicate part number and generic description 
of equipment part manufacturer.  List(s) shall include parts for all peripheral equipment (i.e., vacuum 
pumps, microprocessor package, auxiliary equipment, etc.). 
 
Before Substantial Completion, when each installation that requires submittal of operating and 
maintenance manuals is nominally complete, submit two draft copies of each manual to the Owner or 
Owner's Representative for review.  Include a complete index or table of contents of each manual. 
 
The Owner will return one copy of the draft with comments within 15 days of receipt. 
 
Submit one copy of data in final form at least 15 days before Contractor's request for final observation.  
This copy will be returned within 15 days after final observation, with comments. 
 
After final observation make corrections or modifications to comply with the Owner's comments. Submit 
(8) eight copies of each approved manual to the Owner within 15 days of receipt of the Owner's 
comments. 
 
 
 
1.9. 
DELIVERY, STORAGE AND HANDLING 
 
Deliver products, materials and equipment marked with product names, model numbers, types, grades, and 
compliance labels, and other information needed for identification.  Inspect items for shipping damage and refuse, 
return, or refurbish items to the satisfaction of the Owner.  Maintain delivery records for inventory control and 
for use in processing payment request vouchers.  Crosscheck delivery records with project schedule so as to 
eliminate work stoppages due to material shortages. 
 
Store products, materials, and equipment in a manner to prevent damage and degradation.  Store items on skids 
or pallets, elevated above the floor or grade.  Store items subject to moisture damage in a dry location.  Retain 
protective shipping covers, crates, and cartons during storage.  Protect items from contamination by jobsite dirt 
and debris and other foreign matter.  Segregate items into groups of like type for jobsite storage.  Provide a secure, 
fenced, and lighted area for outside jobsite storage. 
 
Handle products, materials, and equipment in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations and recognized 
industry standards.  Utilize lifting lugs, and designated lift points when hoisting equipment.  Carefully handle, 
transport, and position items to prevent damage during construction.  After placement or installation, cover items 
with tarps or sheeting where required protecting from damage during construction. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS – NOT APPLICABLE 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
INSTALLATIONS 
 
General:  Sequence, coordinate, and integrate the various elements of instrumentation, control systems, materials, 
and equipment.  Comply with the following requirements: 
 
Install systems, materials, and equipment to conform with approved submittal data, including coordination 
drawings, to the greatest extent possible.  Conform to arrangements indicated by the Contract Documents, 
recognizing that portions of the work are shown only in diagrammatic form.  Where coordination requirements 
conflict with individual system requirements, refer conflict to the Owner.

SECTION 409021 
BASIC I&C REQUIREMENTS FOR PCS CONTROLLED PACKAGED EQUIPMENT 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Refer to main equipment specification for all contractual document requirements. 
 
For complete electrical specifications and requirements, refer to Section 260660 Electrical Requirements for 
Packaged Equipment.  For tagging and labeling requirements of instruments and other control related components 
on the packaged equipment, refer to Section “Tagging and Identification”.  
 
In the event of a conflict between this specification and the main equipment specification, the main equipment 
specification shall take precedence.  Where this specification conflicts with specifications other than the main 
equipment specification, this specification shall take precedence. 
 
 
 
1.2. 
SCOPE OF WORK 
 
Manufacturer shall furnish all labor, equipment, and materials, and perform all work necessary for, or incidental 
to, the complete installation of all sensors, final control elements, control systems, and power requirements 
furnished as an integral part of process and mechanical equipment packages. 
 
Manufacturer shall provide a control system Instrument Index and datasheets (ISA type instrument data sheet for 
each instrument) in electronic format.   This database shall be provided to the owner/owner’s engineer 
electronically.  Microsoft Excel is preferred for the Instrument Index and Instrument data.  It is acceptable to 
provide the instrument data sheet data in tabular form in Excel.   
  
Manufacturer shall provide a control system I/O database detailing instrument tag number, manufacture, model 
number, serial number, PID drawing number, instrument range, I/O channel, and I/O assignment.  I/O addressing 
will be provided by Owner and incorporated into Manufacturer’s documentation.  This database shall be provided 
to the owner electronically, in Excel format.   
 
Manufacturer shall provide all sensors, final control elements, control system, and power requirements within the 
physical boundaries of process and mechanical equipment packages. 
 
Manufacturer shall perform testing and make documented adjustments as necessary to ensure proper performance 
of the sensors, final control elements, control system, and power requirements provided as part of process and 
mechanical packages. 
 
For all electrical, instrumentation, and power wiring furnished with the mechanical package, the Manufacturer 
shall provide wiring details depicting terminations at the instruments, terminations at the control system (if 
provided with the package), terminations at power distribution equipment, terminations for Owner connections, 
and cabling information such as wire color and cable number per applicable ANSI/ISA standards. Drawings shall 
clearly designate who provides raceway or wiring components, or who is responsible for termination and testing 
for field installations or reassembly.  
 
Installation of sensors and final control elements, as an integral part of a process or mechanical equipment 
package, but outside the physical boundaries of the package, will be by others. 
 
Where required by the main equipment specification, provide all design documentation for the instrumentation 
and control system, including but not limited to, the control Functional Requirement Specification (FRS), Detailed 
Design Specification (DDS), factory acceptance test (FAT) plan, and site acceptance test (SAT) plan.     
 
Refer to main equipment specification for additional requirements. 
 
1.3. 
DEFINITIONS 
 
Instrument:  A device used directly or indirectly to measure, monitor, record, or control a variable.  The term 
includes primary elements, transmitters, analyzers, controllers, recorders, transducers, final control elements, 
signal converting or conditioning devices, computing devices, and electrical devices such as enunciators, 
switches, and pushbuttons.  The term does not apply to parts (e.g., receiver bellows or a resistor) that are internal 
components of an instrument.  
 
Field:  The areas where production occur (e.g., the plant floor) exclusive of control rooms, administration areas, 
and welfare areas.  
 
Instrument Piping / Tubing:  All piping, tubing, tubing bundles, tube track and channel, valves, air supply filters 
and regulators, fittings, supports, hardware, supplies required for capillary lines and process connections, for 
pneumatic signals and interconnections, and for air supplies shall constitute the instrument piping / tubing system.  
 
 
Remote Mounted Instruments:  Instruments or components of instruments that are not mounted directly into the 
process or utility piping systems, e.g., remote transmitters/totalizers, and analyzers.  
 
Except as otherwise defined in greater detail, the terms "provide", "furnish" and "install" shall have the following 
meanings: 
 
 
 
"Provide" or "provided" shall mean "furnish and install". 
 
"Furnish" or "furnished" shall mean to supply to the project site but does not include installation. 
 
"Install" or "installed" shall mean to mount and connect but does not include furnishing. 
 
1.4. 
ADJUSTMENT, START-UP, AND DEMONSTRATION 
 
Adjust all systems and equipment to provide proper operation as indicated and described on the drawings and 
specified herein.   
 
Prior to final acceptance, operate systems and equipment for a minimum of 72 continuous hours and until normal 
operating conditions are achieved, as approved by the Owner.  Systems and equipment shall be cleaned prior to 
shipment to job site. 
 
Demonstrate the proper operation of all systems and equipment to the Owner.   
 
1.5. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
General 
 
Provide submittals of material or equipment in accordance with the main equipment specification.   
 
1.5.1. 
Documentation 
 
Standard Symbols and Legends shall detail all symbology used in design documents and drawings including a 
description of what each symbol represents.  These shall conform to Owner’s plant standards if such standards 
exist. 
 
1.6. 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
A Quality Control Plan shall be required for equipment falling under this specification. 
 
Where the Manufacturer is providing the development of custom software configuration and programming, 
provide documented qualifications of proposed personnel for review by the Owner / Owner’s representative. 
 
Inspections:  After the installation of the instruments and tubing is complete, the Manufacturer shall visually 
check each component for conformance to the drawings, specification, and manufacturer's recommendations. 
 
All materials and workmanship shall be subject to inspection and examination by the Owner or Owner designee.  
Any defective material, defective workmanship, and instruments installed inaccessibly or in violation of cGMP 
guidelines or the manufacture’s installation guidelines or in violation of this document shall be replaced, 
reworked, or relocated to the satisfaction of the Owner at no additional cost. 
 
Testing:  The Manufacturer must ensure that all instruments, elements, pressure seals, filters, relief valves, and 
other items for which the maximum permissible cold test pressure is lower than the hydrostatic test pressure are 
removed or blanked off from the piping during hydrostatic testing of the piping systems. 
 
As a minimum, the Manufacturer shall verify the functional and safe operation of all devices installed, tubed, or 
piped by the Manufacturer.  Manufacturer will be required to perform continuity checks from the instrument panel 
 
termination or control system I/O to each individual instrument and a loop check for each instrument loop.  This 
requirement shall include the energizing of pneumatic and electronic/electric instruments and the stroking of 
valves from the instrument panel termination or control system I/O.  All instrument loops shall be verified to have 
the correct scale throughout the loop.  Manufacturer shall also perform a visual check of all indicators and gauges.  
Manufacture shall configure and verify that all programmable instrumentation has been setup and scaled properly.  
Manufacturer shall provide full documentation of all testing results.  Loop check procedures and documentation 
shall be reviewed and approved by Owner and testing witnessed by an Owner representative or designee.   
 
Where control system is furnished by Owner, Owner will supply control system hardware and software for factory 
acceptance testing.  Manufacturer shall be responsible for providing floor space and engineering and technician 
labor for assisting in this task on a full-time basis.  Manufacturer shall also be responsible for providing 
engineering and technician labor for a two week period prior to factory acceptance testing for the purpose of 
staging the process control system and testing control system hardware and software.  The Manufacturer shall be 
responsible for control wiring connections to the Owner supplied control system.  On completion of factory 
acceptance testing, the Manufacturer shall disconnect, package and ship the Owner supplied control system to a 
location designated by the Owner. 
 
All test equipment required for this work shall be furnished and retained by Manufacturer. 
 
Calibration procedures and current NIST traceable calibration certifications shall be provided for equipment used 
for calibration of instruments or testing of systems. 
 
1.7. 
STORAGE AND HANDLING 
 
Store products, materials, and equipment in a manner to prevent damage and degradation.  Store items on skids 
or pallets, elevated above the floor or grade.  Store items subject to moisture damage in a dry location.  Retain 
protective shipping covers, crates, and cartons during storage.  Protect items from contamination by jobsite dirt 
and debris and other foreign matter.  Segregate items into groups of like type for jobsite storage.   
 
Handle products, materials, and equipment in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations and recognized 
industry standards.  Utilize lifting lugs, and designated lift points when hoisting equipment.  In all cases, carefully 
handle, transport, and position items to prevent damage during construction.  After placement or installation, 
cover items with tarps or sheeting where required to protect from damage during construction. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
All equipment and material furnished by the Manufacturer shall be new and suitable for operation in the electrical 
and environmental area classification as defined in the equipment data sheet.  Unless field conditions require 
otherwise, enclosures located in classified production areas shall be NEMA 4X brushed stainless steel, enclosures 
located in mechanical areas/chases shall be NEMA 12, and enclosures located in mechanical areas/chases where 
humid or wet conditions are expected shall be NEMA 4.  Enclosures in classified production areas shall have 
sloped tops where suitable for the installation.  All enclosures shall be Hoffman or approved equal. 
 
Sensors and transmitters located in production areas shall be housed in NEMA 4X SS housings, sensors and 
transmitters located in non-production areas shall be housed in NEMA 4X housings.  Instrument enclosures shall 
either be manufactured from corrosion resistant materials or be protected by a resilient epoxy or enamel paint.  
Minimize painted surfaces in classified areas. 
 
All instruments shall be furnished with a securely attached durable stainless steel nameplate with the following 
information as a minimum: 
 
1. Manufacturer 
2. Model 
 
3. Unique Serial Number 
4. Date of Manufacture 
5. Location of Manufacturer 
 
The instrument tag number shall not be engraved on the manufacturer’s standard attached nameplate.  Instrument 
tag number identification shall be by wire on tags as outlined in Section “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
In sterile/hygienic applications, sensors must be of hygienic design with minimum dead legs and crevices.   In-
line sensors and control elements shall be designed and installed such that the instrument completely drains when 
not in service.  Wetted parts of instruments in contact with product fluids must be either 316L stainless steel with 
a final finish no greater than 20 μ-inch Ra max electropolished or a polymer such as USP Class VI PTFE or 
EPDM. All O-rings seals etc. in contact with product fluids shall be made of USP Class VI platinum-cured silicone 
rubber or EPDM rubber. 
 
Any alternative instrumentation provided by the Manufacturer not in compliance with this specification must be 
approved by the Owner in writing. 
 
All instruments cut into the panel shall be designed and sealed to maintain the NEMA rating of the panel. 
 
Accuracy and reproducibility of the instrument shall match or be greater than the requirements of the process to 
be controlled.  The Manufacturer’s instrument data sheets must specify the proposed control range and acceptable 
control tolerance for the process.  
 
Provide control products, components, and installation accessories as required for complete operational 
installation.  
 
2.1. 
WIRE 
 
Power wiring (dedicated power enclosures) shall be sized for the load with #12 AWG being minimum size. 
Control wiring (dedicated control enclosures) shall be #14 AWG.  Power and control wire shall be stranded copper 
wire type THWN or THHN, as an alternate, wiring inside of control panels can be type MTW.  
 
Stranded copper #16 AWG wire type THHN with PVC insulation shall be used for discrete signal wiring unless 
otherwise stated on the drawings.  
 
Stranded, tinned copper #18 AWG, twisted, shielded pair (or three-conductor), with PVC insulation shall be used 
for instrument signal wiring. 
 
Thermocouple couple extension wire shall be of the appropriate type as determined by the thermocouple type. 
(See Section 2.6.2 below for restricted use of thermocouples) 
 
The wire color code shall be as shown below.  Refer to specification 260660 Electrical Requirements for Packaged 
Equipment for wire service types not shown below. 
 
 
Type  
Color  
 
120VAC hot 
Black 
 
120 VAC neutral 
White 
 
24 / 120VAC control signal hot 
Red 
 
24 / 120VAC control signal neutral White 
 
Grounds 
Green, Green w/Yellow stripe 
 
24+ VDC 
Blue 
 
24- VDC 
Blue w/White Strip 
 
24 VDC Analog (shielded) 
Red (+), Black (-) preferred  
 
 
Black (+), Clear (-) permitted 
 
 
RTD (excitation) 
Black, Red, or White 
 
 
RTD (compensation) 
(matches excitation color) 
 
Intrinsically safe 
Light Blue (shall be segregated from non-IS) 
 
Interlocks (Safety Interlocks) 
Yellow (Safety Instrumented Systems -SIS– wiring shall be 
segregated from non-SIS dictated by Safety Integrity Level - SIL) 
2.2. 
CABLE 
 
All communications cable shall have a minimum insulation rating of 300V. 
 
All intrinsically safe cables shall have (intrinsic safety) light blue color insulation jacket. 
 
Single pair instrument cables shall be twisted, shielded 16 gauge minimum, seven (7) strands, with 300 volt 
insulation, nominal thickness 0.015 in. with a 0.020 in. thick polyethylene overall jacket.  Color code: black & 
white. 
 
Single triad instrument wiring shall be twisted, shielded, 18 gauge minimum, seven (7) strands, with 300V 
insulation, nominal thickness 0.015 in. with a 0.020 in. thick polyethylene overall jacket.  Color code: black, 
white, & red. 
 
Cable for Ethernet networks shall be 4 twisted pairs, F/UTP-Foil Shielded, Riser-CMR, Premise Horizontal 
Cable, 23 AWG solid bare copper conductors, polyolefin insulation, overall foil shield (100% coverage), 24 AWG 
stranded tinned copper drain wire, industrial grade PVC jacket, 350MHz Category 6, gigabit Ethernet, RJ-45 
compatible.  Belden # 1351A.  Turck premanufactured cable systems for Ethernet cabling shall be used in clean 
spaces where cabling is exposed and intended for connect/disconnect of portable equipment.  Connectors shall 
have stainless steel connections. 
 
Single-and multi-mode optical fiber cables shall meet all of the requirements delineated within the specifications 
of ANSI/TIA/EIA-568-B.3 and ISO/IEC 11801.   
 
Cable for motor leads for Variable Frequency Drives to motors shall be a shielded drive cable; Belden #2590x 
series cable or equivalent.   Refer to specification 260660, ‘Electrical Requirements for Packaged Equipment’ for 
complete requirements on electrical and power cabling and wire. 
 
DeviceNet™: See Table 2.3.1 for cable requirements. 
 
FOUNDATION Fieldbus: See Table 2.3.2 and Table 2.3.3 for cable requirements. 
 
2.3. 
FIELDBUS NETWORK 
 
2.3.1. 
DeviceNet 
 
All assembled components shall be rated NEMA 4 and IEC IP67 that are not in enclosures.  This includes 
Cordsets, Connectors, Glands, Couplers, Terminators, Bricks, and Tees.  DeviceNet segments will use 
components manufactured by Turck or Stonel unless indicated otherwise on design documents, this specification 
or approved by Owner/Engineer. 
 
For Class 1, Division 2 installations, all field devices must be non-incendive and FM approved for Class 1, 
Division 2 locations. 
 
Allowable Devices 
 
Only devices with DeviceNet interface shall be allowed to be connected to the DeviceNet network.  The maximum 
number of nodes per network is 64. 
 
 
Distance Limitations 
 
Data Rate (Kbits/s) 
Trunk Distance 
Max. Drop Length 
Cumulative Drop Length 
125 
500M (1,640 ft.) 
6M (20 ft.) 
156M (512 ft.) 
250 
250M (820 ft.) 
6M (20 ft.) 
78M (256 ft.) 
500 
100M (327 ft.) 
6M (20 ft.) 
39M (128 ft.) 
 
Trunk Distance is the length of the trunk line between terminating resistors.  Cumulative drop length is the sum 
of all the drops from the trunk tee to the end device.   
 
Project documentation will list all devices and calculated distances.  If distances are found to exceed allowed 
limits, contractor is to notify owner or owner’s representative immediately.  
 
Connectors 
 
All male connectors specified come with external threaded connectors.  All female connectors specified come 
with internal threaded connections. 
 
Sealed connectors can be either mini or micro style depending on project documentation.  Sealed connectors are 
only to be used with thick or mid-sized round cable. 
 
Open connectors can be plug-in or fixed screw terminals depending on project documentation. 
 
Multi-Port Taps 
 
Multi-Port Taps or Bricks shall be the primary connection for DeviceNet devices.  Bricks shall have female quick 
connect spur connectors and a Grounding Lug.  Multi-port taps come in two, four, or six device ports.   
 
Terminators 
 
Termination of the DeviceNet trunk in the field shall be a 120 ohm resistor that is sealed into a T-port tap when 
round cable is used, the terminating resistor shall be UL and FM certified. 
 
Power Supplies 
 
DeviceNet devices require a 24 VDC power supply for the devices to operate.    The power supply shall have a 
UL approval rating of UL-508.  Power supplies shall have current limiting protection per NEC Article 725.  Power 
supplies shall comply with the Open DeviceNet Vendor Association (ODVA) power supply specifications and 
NEC/CE Code Class 2 characteristics. 
 
2.3.2. 
Foundation Fieldbus 
 
All assembled components shall be rated NEMA 4 and IEC IP67 that are not in enclosures.  This includes 
Cordsets, Connectors, Glands, Couplers, Terminators, Bricks, and Tees.  Foundation Fieldbus segments will use 
components manufactured by Turck unless indicated otherwise on design documents, this specification or 
approved by Owner/Engineer.  
 
Allowable devices: 
 
Only devices rated for Foundation Fieldbus shall be allowed to be connected to a Foundation Fieldbus network.   
The maximum number of devices allowable on a fieldbus segment depends on the type of devices. 
 
 
 
DEVICE TYPE 
MAXIMUM DEVICES 
PER SEGMENT 
Bus Powered and FISCO (110mA max) 
5 
Bus Powered through FISCO Multibarrier 
10 
Bus / Non Bus Powered and Non-Intrinsically safe 
16 
 
FISCO segments shall be designed for a maximum 4 devices to allow for future expansion. 
 
FISCO Multibarrier segments shall be designed for a maximum 8 devices to allow for future expansion. 
 
Distance Limitations:   
 
For general purpose Foundation Fieldbus, maximum available segment length is limited to 1,900 M (1.18 miles).  
This is the summation of the trunk line and all spurs.  Individual spurs can measure from 1M (3.28ft.) to 120M 
(394ft.) depending on the number of devices on the segment. 
 
For FISCO, maximum available segment length is limited to 1,000 M (3280ft.).  This is the summation of the 
trunk line and all spurs.  Individual spurs can measure from 1M (3.28ft.) to 60M (196ft.) depending on the number 
of devices on the segment. 
 
Foundation Fieldbus and cables are shielded to minimize noise due to inductive coupling.  Installation of cables 
shall maintain suitable separation from cables and equipment emitting noise.  Cables shall be physically 
separated from power cables, transformers, variable frequency drives and drive cables, rotating equipment and 
other high power machinery.  The minimum separation distance between signal cables and power lines shall be 
as follows: 
 
 
VOLTAGE 
CURRENT 
MINIMUM SEPARATION DISTANCE 
(INCHES) 
0 – 125 VOLTS 
0 – 10 A 
12 INCHES 
125 – 250 VOLTS 
1 – 50 A 
15 INCHES 
250 – 440 VOLTS 
0 – 200 A 
18 INCHES 
 
Signal wiring and AC power cable separated by the recommended distances should not run parallel for more than 
20 ft.  If longer parallel runs are needed, increase the separation distance by 12 inches for each additional 30 ft. 
in length. 
Signal cable shall be separated from devices that generate magnetic fields (motors, variable frequency drives, 
power cables, etc.) by a minimum of five (5) feet; ten (10) to fifteen (15) feet separation is recommended. 
 
All Non-Incendive, Intrinsically Safe, and FISCO cables shall be physically separated from general purpose 
cables by utilizing Non-IS and IS dedicated cable trays, conduits, and panduit (within panels) in accordance with 
NEC Article 504. 
 
Cables 
 
Cables shall be specific to the fieldbus type selected and conform to related standards with regard to cable types, 
routing, and distance.   
 
 
For services installed above fire protection use black-jacketed plenum cable containing 2/20 AWG White 
TC/White BC data conductors with an overall braid and foil shield.  (Belden 89207) Cable shall meet ISA-SP50 
Standard for Type B and shall be UL-910 and CMP rated. 
 
 
 
 
Connectors 
 
All male connectors specified come with external threaded connections.  All female connectors specified come 
with internal threaded connections.  Cordsets shall be prepared with (1) male and (1) female Minifast connector.     
 
Cable lengths may not be increased by connecting cables together; it is desired to use as few cables as possible to 
minimize the number of connections.  Cables are to be installed without excess slack, except at the instrument 
end to facilitate field calibration. 
 
The use of field-wired connectors on one end used to field finish cable, which has not been factory terminated 
shall be used subject to the approval of the owner.   When approved, field-wireable connector shall not be used 
on instrument end of the cordset. 
 
For FISCO cables, each connector shall be installed with a tooled locking mechanism to mechanically prevent 
separation.   
 
Receptacles and Glands 
 
All male gland receptacles specified come with external threaded connections.  Male gland receptacles shall be 
installed in all Foundation Fieldbus field instruments such as transmitters and valve positioners.  In general, they 
shall be factory installed.  However, these may also be field installed by the I&C Contractor or Skid Vendor if 
not supplied with the instrument.    Glands shall be installed in a ½ inch – 14 NPT conduit connections.    
 
The use of female gland receptacles for instrument connections shall be prohibited. 
 
Terminators 
 
Termination of the Foundation Fieldbus Cable in the field requires a 100 ΩRC network-terminating resistor with 
a male Minifast connector.  Two terminators are required for each segment and are to be located at the beginning 
and end of the segment trunk line.  The I&C Sub-Contractor will provide the terminator at the end of each field 
segment as indicated on the project drawings. 
 
Termination of the Foundation Fieldbus Cable in the PCS control cabinet shall be through the built in terminating 
resistor of the fieldbus power supply.  The unit shall be approved for IEC 61158-2 and ISA-SP50.2 installations. 
 
Multi-port Junctions 
 
Multi-Port Junctions shall be the primary connection for Foundation Fieldbus devices.  Multi-port shall have 
female Minifast spur connectors and a Grounding Lug.  The brick shall provide short circuit protection on each 
spur connection: 
 
Power Supplies 
 
Foundation Fieldbus are powered bus networks requiring a power supply for the devices on the segment and to 
carry the Manchester Encoded Signal.  The power supply shall be rated at least 400mA at 24 VDC and have a 
built in terminating resistor.  The power supply shall have a FM approval rating for Class 1, Div. 2, in an 
appropriate enclosure and be approved for IEC 61158-2 and ISA-SP50.02 installations.  Redundant power 
supplies shall meet IEC/ISA physical layer standards.  Paralleling two power supplies to obtain redundancy shall 
not be permitted if stated standards are not adhered to.   Power supplies shall provide diagnostic capability unless 
specifically approved otherwise by the Owner. 
 
Power supplies used in FISCO segments shall be designed for supplying power to segments with devices that are 
installed Class 1, Division 1 areas. 
 
 
Polarity 
 
Foundation Fieldbus signals are polarized.  Connecting the fieldbus cables with reverse polarity will cause the 
device to not communicate properly with the fieldbus interface module.  Fieldbus signals shall be connected so 
they all see the proper polarity.  
 
Voltage Drop 
 
Voltage drop shall be considered when installing a fieldbus network.  Refer to project documents for estimated 
distances and voltage available at each fieldbus device.  Verify trunk and spur lengths prior to installation and 
adjust cable route accordingly.  Minimum voltage allowable at the terminals of a fieldbus device is nine (9) VDC. 
If device locations cannot meet voltage requirements, notify owner or owner’s representative immediately. 
 
Intrinsic Safety 
 
Fieldbus segments used in a potentially flammable atmosphere shall meet the applicable requirements of the 
National Electric Code.  Refer to project drawings for definition of electrical area classification.  Special fieldbus 
barriers and terminators are required for intrinsically safe installations.  Separation and identification requirements 
for IS wiring shall be adhered to. 
 
Connection to High Speed Networks 
 
31.25kbit/s fieldbus networks cannot be directly connected to a higher speed fieldbus network.  When connecting 
to a higher speed network, a special bridge or linking device must be used.  The bridge will be counted as one of 
the 32 field devices on the network. 
 
2.4. 
ELECTRICAL RACEWAYS 
 
2.4.1. 
Rigid Steel Conduit 
 
Rigid Steel Conduit and Fittings:  ANSI C80.1 
 
2.4.2. 
PVC Externally Coated Rigid Steel Conduit and Fittings 
 
ANSI C80.1 and NEMA RN 1. 
 
2.4.3. 
Electrical Metallic Tubing and Fittings 
 
ANSI C80.3. 
 
2.4.4. 
Stainless Steel Conduit 
 
U.L. Listed 316 Stainless Steel 
 
2.4.5. 
Nonmetallic Conduit 
 
Where flexibility is required:  PVC Flexible Conduit and Fittings:  NEMA TC 3; match to conduit or 
conduit/tubing type and material. 
 
2.4.6. 
Liquidtight Flexible Metal Conduit and Fittings 
 
Where flexibility is required and connection to vibrating equipment: UL 360.  Fittings shall be specifically 
approved for use with this raceway.  Use is restricted to 18” lengths.  See use below. 
 
 
2.5. 
RACEWAY INSTALLATION METHOD 
 
Outdoors:  Use the following wiring methods: 
 
Exposed Above Grade:  Rigid metal conduit. 
 
Concealed Above Grade:  Rigid metal conduit. 
 
Connection to Equipment:  Including transformers and hydraulic, pneumatic, or electric solenoid or 
motor-driven equipment:  Liquidtight flexible metal conduit (but restricted to 18” in length). 
 
Indoors:  Use the following wiring methods: 
 
Exposed:  Electrical metallic tubing up to 4" or rigid metal conduit for sizes larger than 4". 
 
Exposed in Clean Rooms:  Stainless steel conduit or gray PVC coated rigid metal conduit. 
 
Concealed (above grade):  Electrical metallic tubing up to 4" or rigid metal conduit for sizes larger than 
4". 
 
Wet or Damp locations:  Stainless Steel or gray PVC Coated Rigid metal conduit. 
 
Connection to Equipment:  Including transformers and hydraulic, pneumatic, or electric solenoid or 
motor-driven equipment:  Liquidtight flexible metal conduit (but restricted to 18” in length). 
 
2.6. 
PNEUMATIC ACCESSORIES 
 
All pneumatic accessories required for conditioning and routing of instrument air supply shall be provided in a 
control panel. 
 
When equipment requires both process (product contact) and instrument air, they shall be supplied to the 
equipment by separate systems and connections and shall be routed in dedicated systems. 
 
Air Preparation 
 
An integral air preparation system shall be used to set individual instrument air feeds to a control panel.  The 
system, at a minimum shall consist of the following components: 
 
• 
Self-Contained Coalescing Filter Regulator w/ pressure gauge 
• 
Isolation Valve 
 
A self-contained pressure regulator with integral coalescing filter shall be used to set instrument air pressure to 
that required for normal operation of downstream pneumatic valve actuators.  It shall be rated for 125 psig supply 
air and be capable of regulating downstream air pressure to as low as 5 psig.  A manual hand operator shall be 
employed for downstream pressure adjustment and shall have an integral locking ring.  The body material shall 
be plastic with plastic and stainless steel internals.  Pneumatic and gauge connections shall be ¼” FPT or larger. 
 
Each regulator shall be provided with an integral pressure gauge that will display downstream pressure.  The 
range of the gauge shall be 0-100 psig.  A pressure gauge shall also be supplied and installed upstream of the 
regulator to measure supply pressure and shall have a range of 0-150 psig. 
 
Integral coalescing filters shall be 5 microns with a clear polycarbonate debris bowl to remove particulates that 
may be in the air stream.  The debris bowl shall be provided with a bottom mounted drain valve to blow down 
debris. 
 
An inline shutoff valve shall be upstream of the regulator.  The valve shall be plastic body with a knife gate 
operator and downstream relief capability. 
 
If air pressure is critical to the operation of the equipment, a pressure switch must be provided which will interlock 
the equipment operation. 
 
Air preparation systems for panels installed in clean process areas shall be installed inside of control panels with 
a breather vent installed in panel for exhaust. 
 
Air Distribution Manifolds 
 
Air distribution within a control panel shall be made with aluminum pre-manufactured blocks.  Each individual 
air feed from a distribution block shall have a quarter-turn plug valve for isolation. 
 
2.7. 
INSTRUMENT TUBING 
 
The following definition of exposed and non-exposed shall be used to determine the type of tubing that will be 
used for a particular installation:  All tubing installed outside wall cavities in production spaces shall be considered 
exposed.  Non-exposed tubing shall include all tubing installed in spaces other than production spaces and tubing 
installed in wall cavities of production spaces.  If tubing inside wall cavities is to be routed through wall into 
production space, tubing material shall change to match specification for the space being entered. 
 
2.7.1. 
Stainless Steel Tubing 
 
Control air tubing in clean production areas shall be ASTM A269 seamless, annealed 316L stainless steel (without 
manufacturer’s printed information).  Minimize fittings and joints in all spaces to conform to all applicable 
sanitization requirements. 
 
 
1/4" O.D., 0.035" wall. 
 
3/8" O.D., 0.035" wall. 
 
1/2" O.D., 0.035" wall. 
 
2.7.2. 
Copper Tubing 
 
Control air tubing in other areas shall be rigid, hard drawn, copper tubing, Type L, ASTM B-88; with cast bronze 
solder joint fittings, ANSI B16.18; or wrought-copper solder-joint fittings, ANSI B16.22; except brass 
compression type fittings at connections to equipment.  Tubing shall have minimum 500 PSIG pressure rating. 
 
 
1/4" O.D., 0.030" wall 
 
3/8" O.D., 0.035" wall 
 
1/2" O.D., 0.040" wall 
 
Control air tubing in other areas shall be rigid, hard drawn, copper tubing, Type L, ASTM B-75; with cast bronze 
solder joint fittings, ANSI B16.18; or wrought-copper solder-joint fittings, ANSI B16.22; except brass 
compression type fittings at connections to equipment.  Tubing shall have minimum 500 PSIG pressure rating. 
 
For HVAC & Refrigeration applications, seamless soft-annealed coiled copper, Type L, ASTM B-75 may be used 
with approval by the Owner. 
 
2.7.3. 
Plastic Tubing 
 
Provide plastic tubing where required for flexible connections to equipment or in process areas if contained in 
stainless tubing.  Exposed flexible connections in process areas shall be limited to less than or equal to three (3) 
feet.   
 
Plastic tubing shall be UV-resistant seamless extrusion molded high density polyethylene (HDPE) tubing.   HDPE 
tubing shall have a minimum working pressure of 300 PSIG and a minimum burst pressure of 1200 PSIG, with 
an operating temperature range of -80°F to 175°F or better at rated pressures.  HDPE tubing shall meet 
NSF/ANSI-51 and FDA requirements for food contact.  
 
1/4" O.D., 0.040" wall, black   Parker HDPE-43 series or approved equal. 
3/8" O.D., 0.062" wall, black   Parker HDPE-64 series or approved equal. 
 
2.7.4. 
Thread Sealant 
 
Minimize use of threaded connections in classified areas.   Where threaded connections are use, provide PTFE 
Teflon 0.0035" thickness Mil Spec A-A-58092 tape for fitting thread sealant.  Liquid or paste type thread sealants 
are prohibited. 
 
2.8. 
INSTRUMENTATION 
 
Unless specifically instructed otherwise, the Manufacturer shall provide control products, components, and 
installation accessories from a manufacturer listed in specification 409100 - Appendix A.  The manufacture listed 
in specification 409100 marked with “*” is the Owner’s preferred manufacture.   Others listed are acceptable 
alternates with approval by owner.  If the approved instrument manufacturers list does not cover the instrument 
type in question, the Manufacturer may employ a suitable instrument of the manufacturer of the Manufacturer’s 
choice with prior approval from the Owner before employing the instrument.   
 
All instruments shall have male minifast connectors installed. 
 
Weigh transmitters/controllers shall be configured as Ethernet I/O or DeviceNet signals. Where Ethernet I/O or 
DeviceNet is not available, weigh signals shall be configured as conventional 4-20mA analog signals and 24VDC 
conventional discrete inputs and outputs. 
 
Valve manifolds shall be Festo Type 32 MPA with Ethernet I/O communications.  The solenoids shall be used 
for automated on/off valve actuator control.  Valve manifolds shall be installed in dedicated enclosures.  Power 
for the manifold(s) shall be prewired to field terminal strips within the enclosure.  All pneumatic instruments and 
tubing for the manifolds shall be assembled to bulkhead fittings mounted on side of the enclosure.  All bulkhead 
fittings shall be tagged to identify the valve or instrument it is serving.  
 
Where HARTsmart devices are utilized, sensor signals shall be configured as 4-20 mA signals.  If no digital 
communications are available, standard instrument signals shall be used and connected via conventional I/O cards.   
 
Discrete inputs and outputs shall be 24VDC 120VAC. 
 
Four wire instrument transmitters and skid mounted electronic components shall use 24 VDCpower if available.   
 
Transmitters shall be capable of withstanding process temperatures either inherently or via mounting 
configuration. 
 
Where possible, transmitters shall be mounted locally to the sensor to minimize the length of uncompensated 
signal cable.  Mounting of transmitter must facilitate frequent operator access for calibration and maintenance.  
 
All sensors and final control elements employed in sanitary applications shall be designed for steam sterilization 
using 30 psig saturated steam to a temperature of 130 °C for one (1) hour, every six (6) hours.  Manufacturer shall 
state anticipated life of sensors under stated operating conditions. 
 
All switch contacts shall be Form "C" (SPDT) rated for 3A at 24 VDC 120VAC, minimum.  Two (2) Form "C" 
contacts are required.  All contacts shall close to confirm position (i.e., valve limit switches).  Where switches are 
 
used for alarm or shutdown purposes, these contacts shall be closed during normal operating conditions and shall 
open to alarm or shutdown.  Electronically controlled switches shall be configured for Fail Safe operation on 
failure or power loss. 
 
For temperature, pressure, flow, and analytical instruments, the installation contractor/manufacture shall add a 
minimum of 6 feet of cable at the instrument end, coiled neatly and secured from touching process line or 
vessel.  The contractor shall verify and add if needed, additional length based on instrument location relative to 
floor or platform level. 
 
2.8.1. 
Flow Element / Transmitter 
 
Sterile Liquid Flow Applications:  Magnetic inductive or Coriolis effect mass instruments shall be used for flow 
measurement. 
 
Wetted-parts shall be SS 316L, USP Class VI PTFE or Owner approved equal. 
 
The meter’s “straight run” piping lengths (before and after) must be in accordance with manufacturers 
specifications. 
 
End connections shall be Tri-Clamps.   
 
Where magnetic flow meters are used, device must be suitable for the minimum conductivity of the fluids to be 
measured. 
 
Non-Sterile Liquid Flow Applications: Vortex, Magnetic, Turbine, or Differential-pressure instruments may be 
used.  
 
The meter’s “straight run” piping lengths (before and after) must be in accordance with manufacturers 
specifications. 
 
End connections for non-sanitary service shall use flanges. 
 
Non-Sterile Gas Flow Applications: Thermal dispersion mass flow instruments shall be used for gas flow 
measurement. 
 
Wetted parts shall be SS 316L or Owner approved equal. 
 
End connections for non-sanitary service shall use flanges or compression fittings as required by the line 
specification.   
 
2.8.2. 
Temperature Instruments 
 
Vessel Thermowells:  Thermowells connection in process vessels shall be tapered shank weld in.  
 
Line Thermowells:  Connections in sanitary piping shall be 316L SS instrument Tees using Tri-Clamp fittings.  
Thermowells shall be installed in such a manner so as not to constrict process flow.  
 
Bimetallic Thermometers:  Bimetallic dial type thermometers (4” dial diameter) shall be standardized to three (3) 
ranges:  steam applications (0 - 200°C), CIP applications (0 - 100°C), and low temperature process applications 
(0 - 50°C). 
 
Thermometers shall be “Everyangle”, case material 316 SS plastic window material. Glass stemmed 
thermometers shall not be used. All thermometers shall be inserted in thermowells. Elements inserted into 
 
thermowells shall be of sufficient length and spring-loaded to assure the element contacts the bottom of the 
thermowell. 
 
Resistance Temperature Detectors (RTDs):   RTDs shall be dual element, Platinum 100 Ohms +/- 0.06 Ohms, 
three-wires, Class A, DIN IEC 751, with an alpha coefficient of 0.00385 Ohms/Ohm/°C.  
 
RTDs shall be fitted with field mounted transmitters where specified as critical instruments. Remote mounted 
transmitters may be used where installation precludes the use of head mounted transmitters.  Remote mounted 
transmitters shall be mounted as close as possible to the RTD element to minimize lead length.  RTDs shall be 
installed to allow for ease of removal for calibration.  Exceptions may arise due to multi-instrument installations 
or per owner’s request. 
All RTD leads shall be terminated on a connection block mounted in a sanitary RTD head rated NEMA 4 or 
better.  RTD head enclosure shall be epoxy-coated aluminum or other Owner approved material. 
 
Thermocouples (TCs):  Type “K” (or Type “N”) TC shall be permitted if application exceeds 500°C. 
 
All thermocouples and RTDs shall be inserted in thermowells as detailed above unless otherwise noted and/or 
approved by owner. 
 
Thermocouples and RTDs inserted into thermowells shall be spring-loaded and of sufficient length to assure the 
RTD element contacts the bottom of the thermowell.   
 
Thermocouples and RTDs shall have nipple-union-nipple fittings for ease of removal. 
 
2.8.3. 
Pressure Instruments 
 
PRESSURE GAUGES 
 
Construction 
 
Case - 316 SS.  All non-sanitary gauges to have a solid front wall with a blowout back or disc and a removable 
dial cover. 
 
Movement - 316 SS, low friction co-efficient, vibration resistant, calibration adjustment and seal (or lock). 
 
Dial - dial size shall be determined by the application and shall be visible from normal operating locations.  Dial 
shall be laminated plastic or plastic coated metal with white face with black characters. 
 
Window - plastic (heat resistant acrylic or polycarbonate) with gasket separating dial cover and gauge ring.  
Optional glycerin filled case is permitted but not for high temperature applications (> 95°C). 
 
Pressure Element - "C" type bourdon tube, 316L SS with alloy socket and tip, welded at socket and tip and stress 
relieved. 
 
Process Connection:  Non-sanitary service: ¼” or ½” MNPT threaded connection provided with an isolation 
valve.  Provide coil siphon connecting tube for steam service gauges. 
 
 
Sanitary service: Integral 316L SS (or equal) diaphragm seal with Tri-Clamp fitting to sanitary fitting on vessels, 
or instrument tees on process lines. 
 
In sanitary services, diaphragm liquid fills shall be inert and suitable for use in FDA-regulated parenteral drug 
manufacturing, shall be suitable for Steam-In-Place applications without affecting accuracy. 
 
 
In the selection of scale range, the normal operating pressure should approximate 50 percent of the full-scale 
range; or the maximum operating pressure should approximate 75 percent of the full scale range, whichever 
dictates. All gauges for sanitary process or steam service shall be ranged to 30” Hg for vacuum service.  The 
range selected shall be determined by the process requirements. 
 
PRESSURE SWITCHES 
 
Pressure switches shall be capable of resetting themselves within approximately three (3) percent of their 
calibrated range.  Low-pressure applications may require smaller differentials. 
 
Pressure switches shall be provided with capability for readily readjusting the set point.  
 
No combination pressure switch and gauge units shall be allowed. 
 
Process connection 
 
Non-sanitary service: Flanged or NPT threaded connection. 
 
Sanitary service: Integral 316L SS (or equal) diaphragm seal with Tri-Clamp fitting to sanitary fitting on vessels, 
or instrument tees on process lines. 
 
In sanitary services, diaphragm liquid fills shall be suitable for use in FDA-regulated parenteral drug 
manufacturing and shall be suitable for Steam-In-Place applications without affecting accuracy. 
 
PRESSURE TRANSMITTERS 
 
Process connection:  Sanitary service: Integral 316L SS (or equal) diaphragm seal with Tri-Clamp fitting to 
sanitary fitting on vessels, or instrument tees on process lines. 
 
Non- sanitary service: Flanged or NPT threaded connection.  
 
Adjustable zero and span required. 
 
In sanitary services, diaphragm liquid fills shall be inert and suitable for use in FDA-regulated parenteral drug 
manufacturing and shall be suitable for Steam-In-Place applications without affecting accuracy. 
 
In the selection of scale range, the normal operating pressure should approximate 50 percent of the full-scale 
range; or the maximum operating pressure should approximate 75 percent of the full scale range. All transmitters 
for sanitary process or steam service must be capable of withstanding 30” Hg of vacuum.  The range selected 
shall be the manufacturers’ standard scale range. 
 
2.8.4. 
Level Instruments 
 
Level Switches:  In sanitary services, wetted parts shall be 316L SS.   Instrument shall be of sanitary design using 
Tri-Clamp connections.  
 
In non-sanitary service, probes shall use 150# flanges. 
 
Differential Pressure Transmitters for Level Measurement (Sanitary Services):  Where differential pressure is 
used to infer level for sanitary applications, the devices shall meet the following requirements. 
 
Pressure seals of sanitary design shall be mounted on top and bottom vessel nozzles.  All seals must use FDA 
approved gasket and fill fluid.  Bottom mounted seals in direct contact with process fluid must be “spud seal” 
type with no dead legs and minimal crevices.  Bottom seals shall be mounted in the dished end of the vessel, 
 
positioned to maximize the range of the level measurement.  Top mounting seal is preferred to be a sanitary “tank 
spud”, as well but can be a Tri-clamp type (if tank is not insulated) but must be self-draining and minimal length.   
 
The transmitter shall be mounted to minimize the length of capillary tubing required from the pressure seals to 
the sensor.  High and Low side capillary tube length and seal size shall be the same, or design shall minimize 
error due to temperature variations. 
 
Local non-interactive zero and span adjustments required.  
 
Differential Pressure Transmitters for Level Measurement (Non-Sanitary Services):  Where differential pressure 
is used to transmit level for non-sanitary applications, the devices shall meet the following requirements. 
 
Wetted parts construction material shall be 316L SS.  Block and Bleed valving configurations shall be provided 
for ease of calibration. 
 
End connections for non-sanitary service shall use flanges. 
 
Local non-interactive zero and span adjustments required. 
 
Radar Level Sensor (guided and unguided):  Radar level sensors may be considered for level monitoring with 
prior approval by Owner.  A determination must be made that the process material is not adversely affected when 
irradiated with microwave RF energy.   
 
Ultrasonic Level Sensor:  Ultrasonic level sensors may be used for level monitoring with prior approval by the 
Owner.   
 
Magnetostrictive Float Level Transmitters: Where magnetostrictive float level transmitters are used for sanitary 
applications, the devices shall meet the following requirements. 
 
In sanitary services, magnetostrictive float probes shall be 316L SS rods and floats with Tri-Clamp connections 
and sanitary end fitting for securing float to rod.  The magnetostrictive units shall be capable of withstanding SIP 
cycle sanitization temperature (minimum temperature of 121°C) for extended periods of hold times (> one (1) 
hour).   
 
Transmitters shall have built-in linearization tables. 
 
2.8.5. 
Automatic Valves 
 
Process valves shall be pneumatic actuated. 
Valve open and closed limit switches shall be provided.   
 
All valves trim shall be 316L SS or Owner approved equal. Sanitary applications require interior finish as stated 
in the attached piping specification. 
 
Valve bonnet shall be designed to meet the full range of temperatures that the valve may be exposed to during 
operation, including sanitization/sterilization temperatures. 
 
Clearance shall be provided in the piping arrangement to permit maintenance access to valve control components 
and removal of the plug and valve superstructure without removing the valve body from the piping. 
 
Control Valves:  Control valve noise shall not exceed 85 dBA at a level of one meter above grade or platform 
level whichever is appropriate and at a horizontal distance of one (1) meter.  Manufacturer shall guarantee all 
valves at both normal and maximum flow and pressure conditions to be within limits of noise level specifications 
for each valve.  Process control valves shall be pneumatic actuated. 
 
Construction:  Required seat tightness for soft seated valves shall be better than +/-0.0001% of Cv (ANSI Class 
VI).  Metal seated valves (i.e., steam applications) seat tightness shall be better than +/- 0.01 percent of Cv (ANSI 
Class IV). 
 
Accessories:  Valve positioners for modulating control valves shall be provided when required to meet application 
specification (i.e., accuracy of stem travel or process “holding” pressure).  Owner may require the use of a 
positioned (when not dictated by performance) to reduce size of the actuator’s bonnet and conserve space 
(minimize packaged equipment’s footprint). 
 
All modulating valves shall have stem travel indicators (vernier / pointer). 
 
Filter regulators and gauges (minimally, “supply” and “control signal”) shall be supplied. 
 
Open/Close Valves:  Open/Close valve actuators shall be single acting, pneumatic, spring return and have position 
indication (beacon).  
 
2.8.6. 
Analytical Instruments / Transmitters  
 
All sensors shall be of the “in-line” type such that no product must be diverted from the main product stream for 
sampling. 
 
In sanitary applications, sensor connections in process vessel shall be coordinated with the vessel connection.  
Sensor connections in sanitary piping shall be Tri-Clamps.   
 
Analytical instruments that require temperature compensation shall have the temperature element integral to the 
analytical sensor.  Exceptions shall require Owner approval. 
 
2.9. 
TAGS AND NAMEPLATES  
 
2.9.1. 
Electrical and Control Panels  
 
Provide nameplates for all panels per Section “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
2.9.2. 
Instrument Tags  
 
Provide tags for all instruments per Section “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
2.9.3. 
Abbreviations 
 
Use as indicated in Section “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
2.10. LOCAL INSTRUMENT / CONTROL PANELS   
 
Manufacturer shall provide local instrument / control panel(s) to accommodate as a minimum all terminations for 
instrument wiring and pneumatic tubing. 
 
All control panels shall be UL 508 labeled.   
 
The manufacture shall perform an “Arc Flash Hazard” and “Shock Hazard” analysis on each control panel and 
provide a label on each control panel per NFPA 70E. 
 
 
 
 
 
2.10.1. Construction 
 
Control panel enclosures shall be fabricated from 316L stainless steel, with a brushed finish. Enclosures shall 
have a NEMA 4X rating.  Enclosures in classified spaces shall have a sloped top appropriate for use in a clean 
room. 
 
The enclosure seams shall be continuously welded without leaks.  The welds shall be ground smooth and clean.  
All slag, scale, and spatter shall be removed.  All exterior corners shall be rounded and ground smooth to a 
nominal 1/16" radius to provide a neat appearance.  All interior edges shall be ground smooth to prevent damage
