to wiring, cables, and tubing.  
 
Panel and door stiffeners, as well as internal bracing, shall be provided to ensure adequate rigidity and support 
for door mounted equipment.  All bracings shall be on the panel's interior.  No evidence of fastening shall appear 
on the panel exterior.  
 
Internal bracing for lifting lugs shall be provided around the bolt holes suitable for supporting the panels. 
 
2.10.2. Wire, Cable and Tube Labels 
 
Each individual wire, cable, and pneumatic tube in power, control, indication, and instrumentation circuits shall 
be provided with identification markers at the point of termination.  Locate the label within 2" of the wire, cable, 
or tube termination.  Identification markers shall be labeled as indicated on drawings.  Where not indicated, 
markers shall be labeled by terminal block designation.  All wires originating from the same site shall have the 
same wire number. 
 
Provide wire and tube labels of the printable, shrink tube type.  Labels shall be computer or machine printed with 
the appropriate identification number.  Printing shall be permanent type and resist fading, smearing, water, and 
alcohol.  Hand marking shall not be acceptable.  Owner shall approve label manufacturer and series.  
 
2.10.3. Mounting Fasteners 
 
Devices:  All devices shall be rigidly attached with properly sized hex head or Phillips’ head stainless steel screws 
or bolts so they may be removed.  No standard square head screws are allowed. 
 
2.10.4. Power Supplies 
 
Vendor shall provide 24 Volt DC power supplies for powering instrument loops.  Power supply shall be linear, 
regulated and shall be sized to power all instruments and components associated with the control panel.  Power 
supplies shall have load-sensing circuits.  Power supplies shall be sized for a minimum of 50% spare capacity to 
service future needs. 
 
Redundant power supplies (with alarm function) for critical instruments / controls shall be provided. 
 
2.10.5. Ethernet I/O switch 
 
Vendor shall provide a local panel mounted managed Ethernet switch for connecting Ethernet I/O devices.  
Ethernet I/O devices may include VFDs, Solenoid manifolds, Weigh Controllers, etc. 
 
2.10.6. Terminals 
 
Provide fused terminals with blown fuse indication for all discrete input and output point power sources.  At a 
minimum, each I/O module shall be individually fused.  For analog loops, provide terminals with test lead 
connection for loop testing ability where test leads can be placed in series with the instrument loop without 
affecting the loop wiring.  Provide solderless, crimp, insulated, spade lug connectors at instrument, device, and 
 
terminal connections.  Bare wires and ring (or eyelet) terminal connectors are not permitted.  On screw clamp 
type terminal blocks provide insulated, crimp ferrules.  
 
All terminals and fuse blocks require UL approval.   
 
2.10.7. Line Filters 
 
Unless approved otherwise by the Owner, high-frequency noise filters (Islatrol or approved equal) shall be 
installed on the line side of the power feed for all control panels with a 120VAC UPS feed. 
 
2.10.8. Disconnect Switch 
 
Unless approved otherwise by the Owner, lockable, rotary style disconnect switch shall be provided for all control 
panels with one or more power feeds of voltage 120VAC or greater.   Disconnects shall be interlocked with all 
enclosure doors so that the either, the disconnect switch must be an open circuit for the enclosure door to open or 
the opening of the enclosure door trips the disconnect switch.  Where disconnects are used, they must be externally 
defeatable to allow for trouble shooting without interrupting panel power. 
 
2.10.9. Locks 
 
Doors or hinged panels for enclosures shall be able to be secured with a lock.  Doors equipped with mechanical 
locks are preferred.  Keys shall be removable in both the locked and unlocked positions. If multiple control panels 
are utilized, they shall all be keyed the same.  
 
Control panels with mechanical clamps in lieu of a keyed door shall provide a location for a future padlock (by 
others) or an alternate means of securing the door, such as a lockable disconnect.  The Vendor shall submit any 
alternate locking method to the Owner for approval. 
 
2.10.10. Space for Future Expansion 
 
Where future equipment is indicated in main equipment specifications, cutouts shall not be made unless 
specifically authorized by the Owner.  Future equipment areas shall be kept clear of the control panel stiffening 
members, rear-mounted equipment, wiring, and any other interference. 
 
2.10.11. Process Control System (PCS) Hardware 
 
Unless specifically instructed otherwise, the Manufacturer shall provide control products, components, and 
installation accessories as described below.   
 
Owner shall furnish all PCS hardware including controllers and HMIs   Controllers and HMIs will be mounted 
external from the manufacturer’s skid.  Configuration of the controller(s) and HMI(s) will be by Owner’s 
Integrator.   Field wiring for site installation to interconnect controller(s) and HMI(s) with skid will be by Owner. 
 
The manufacturer shall furnish all PCS I/O power supplies, PCS remote chassis and I/O modules.  The 
manufacturer shall provide redundant Ethernet communication cards at each remote chassis for connection to 
Owner provided PCS controller located elsewhere. Any additional Ethernet cards and switches needed to utilize 
Ethernet I/O devices shall be provided by the Manufacturer. 
 
The Manufacture shall provide PCS power supplies, I/O, and communications cards as required in the main 
equipment specification or in the design drawings to match the design of the owner’s PCS system from the 
following: 
 
 
Emerson Delta V S-Series/M-Series/CHARMS Series 
Rockwell Automation  
Stonel 
Turck 
 
Manufacturer shall coordinate with the Owners Integrator to provide documentation and configuration of the skid 
control system that follows the format and standards established for the Owner’s PCS.  Owner will provide 
controller and HMI hardware to support FAT.  Skid Manufacturer shall provide power and network cabling 
necessary to connect the controller panel(s) and HMI(s) to the skids for FAT.   
 
Manufacturer shall design and provide a control panel on the skid for installation and termination of all skid 
mounted instruments and controls.  Terminations and wiring for analog, 24 VDC discrete, and 120 VAC shall be 
segregated on terminal strips and in raceways to minimize interference.  Manufacturer shall provide wiring of all 
skid-mounted instruments to the control panel.  Network wiring from the control panel to the PCS system will be 
by owner.  120VAC power to each control panel local disconnect switch will be by the owner. 
 
All hardware documentation for the skid will be furnished by Manufacturer. Manufacturer shall provide, in 
conjunction with the Owner’s PCS integrator, Functional Requirement Specification and Control Sequence 
Description for the operation of the Vendor supplied system.  The documents shall be provided in sufficient detail 
to enable a qualified integrator to perform system integration work. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Sequence, coordinate, and integrate the various elements of instrumentation, control systems, materials, and 
equipment.  Comply with the following requirements: 
 
The successful bidder will be provided with design templates and sample drawings for Fieldbus segments to assist 
in design development and standardization with the project.  Drawing of sample panel layouts and suggested Bill 
of Material will also be provided.  Drawings will be available in AutoCAD file format.  The manufacturer is 
encouraged to utilize the designs and symbols to the greatest extent possible so that design and documentation 
appearance is consistent across the project.     
 
Install systems, materials, and equipment to conform with approved submittal data, including coordination 
drawings, to the greatest extent possible.  Conform to arrangements indicated by the Contract Documents, 
recognizing that portions of the Work are shown only in diagrammatic form.  Where coordination requirements 
conflict with individual system requirements, refer conflict to the Owner. 
 
3.2. 
WIRE AND CABLE 
 
Wire and cabling shall be installed in U.L. Listed electrical raceways.   
 
Wiring and cables shall not have any mechanical stress or strain at any place in the system.  
 
Continuously shield signal cables.  Shields shall be grounded as indicated on the wiring drawings, loop drawings, 
and installation details, or according to manufacturer's recommendations.  Pay particular attention to the 
requirement for maintaining contiguous shields through all intermediate termination points. Maintain single shield 
ground point (at receiving device), and insulate from ground at opposite end (field or sending device).  Indicate 
single ground point on the wiring drawings. 
 
Wiring design shall incorporate an Isolated Ground system for connecting Instrumentation DC Power Supply 
commons and instrument cable shield drains.  The isolated ground connection will be routed to the skid along 
 
with the owner provided 120 Volt UPS circuit for control power. Fieldbus cable shields shall be connected to the 
Isolated Ground in the Owner provided controller cabinet.  
 
Strands of stranded wire shall not be cut out to make the wiring fit an incorrectly sized terminal.  
 
Instrument/control wiring and cables shall not be spliced.  All connections shall be made in junction boxes using 
terminal blocks. 
 
3.3. 
PNEUMATIC INSTRUMENT TUBING 
 
3.3.1. 
Cutting, Bending, Shaping and Conditioning 
 
The tubing shall be checked for correct diameter and wall thickness. 
 
Bend tubing with a correctly sized tubing bender.  Hand bends and wrinkled, flattened or chinked bends will not 
be accepted.  The Vendor shall follow Manufacturer's recommendations for minimum bending radius. 
 
Cut all tubing with a tubing cutter.  Remove the cutting burr.  
 
Do not install pneumatic tubing in electrical raceways with wiring. 
 
Remove PVC jackets of PVC jacketed tubing at fittings in a manner such that the removal of the jacket does not 
cause damage or marking of the tubing.  
 
3.3.2. 
Tubing Channel 
 
All tubing shall be run in such a manner as to give the maximum protection against mechanical damage.  No pipe 
or tube shall be installed with a mechanical stress or strain on it.  Support tubing and tubing bundles in continuous 
track or channel.  
 
Tubing drops from the main raceway in process areas shall be supported in rigid stainless steel tubing.  Tubing 
fill limits shall not exceed 60 percent.  
 
Edges, ends, and protrusions in conduit, tubing track, tubing channel, or supports for tubing, shall be free of all 
burrs, sharp edges, and sharp corners to prevent injury to personnel and damage to tubing. 
 
Tubing shall be pulled into support channel in such manner as to prevent damage.  Use lubricant to pull tubing 
into raceways. Avoid use of lubricant in channel that will be located in ISO or “grade” areas.  
 
3.3.3. 
Routing 
 
Run channel, piping, tubing, and similar components in horizontal and vertical alignment with the building 
structure or in horizontal and vertical alignment with associated principal equipment. Minimize horizontal runs 
in classified areas.  Channel, piping and tubing mounts shall allow a minimum one-inch space between mounting 
surfaces/structures to allow for cleaning.  Sanitary style pipe clamps are recommended.   
 
3.3.4. 
Tubing Installation 
 
Prevent foreign material from entering the tubing lines during installation.  Shield all installed, but not connected, 
tubing ends using plugs.  ‘Blow clean’ all lines with instrument quality air or dry nitrogen prior to connection.  
Plastic tubing may be installed in multi-tube bundles. If these bundles are exposed, they shall be armored with 
PVC-coated flex.   
 
 
Plastic tubing and unarmored tubing bundles shall be protected inside metal conduit or raceway. Tubing, conduit 
and raceway shall be rigidly fastened to structural supports using tubing clips or fasteners designed for that 
purpose. It shall not be attached to process piping or electrical conduits nor be attached to any surface with cable 
ties or perforated strapping. 
 
Transition from a multi-tube bundle to single tube runs shall be made in a junction box using compression type 
bulkhead unions. 
 
Install all plastic tubing with sufficient slack in each straight run to assure that subsequent shrinkage will not 
cause the tubing to shrink into a state of stress.  It is strongly recommended that plastic tubing not be terminated 
the same day it is installed into the channel in order to avoid this.  
 
Wrap all tapered pipe threads with Teflon Tape to prevent thread galling upon disconnection.  Do not allow the 
tape to extend past the last thread on the connection end.  
 
Make tubing unions in channel, sheets, or groupings in boxes.  
 
All tubing shall be installed in continuous length from: 
 
1. The instrument to the instrument air supply valve 
2. The instrument to a pneumatic junction box fitting or bulk-head fitting 
3. The instrument to another instrument 
 
Provide inserts on 3/8 and larger plastic tubing.  
 
3.3.5. 
Testing 
 
Test pneumatic tubing system installations in accordance with ISA Standard ISA-S7.0.01, “Quality Standard for 
Instrument Air”, Annex C.   
 
Records of all tests shall be maintained by the Manufacturer and shall be submitted to the Owner. The Owner 
may witness any tests. 
 
The instrument at the outlet end of the tubing under test shall remain connected whenever possible.  Allowance 
in the duration of the test shall be made to compensate for the additional volume in the instrument.  
 
Reconnect all Instruments to the tubing system after successfully completing the test. Check the re-connections 
with a bubble test.  Apply a soap solution to the joint under test.  The joint is not properly sealed if bubbles form 
around the joint.  Reseal and recheck until the joint passes. 
 
3.4. 
INSTRUMENT CONDUIT 
 
3.4.1. 
Raceways 
 
Rigid Steel Conduit shall be used in non-clean room applications where flexibility is not required. 
 
Stainless Steel or gray PVC Coated Rigid Steel Conduit shall be used in clean room applications where flexibility 
is not required. 
 
Liquidtight Flexible Metal Conduit shall be used for flexible connections to equipment and devices. 
 
 
3.4.2. 
Routing 
 
Run conduit and similar components in horizontal and vertical alignment with the building structure or in 
horizontal and vertical alignment with associated principal equipment.  
Install conduit to avoid interference with normal operations and maintenance of equipment. 
 
3.4.3. 
Conduit Installation 
 
All conduit shall be run in such a manner as to give the maximum protection against mechanical damage.  No 
conduit shall be installed with a mechanical stress or strain on it.  All conduits shall be placed to avoid its use as 
a support or step. 
 
Conduit shall be installed per the locally enforced Code, i.e., NEC (installed location, NOT the fabrication site). 
Edges, ends, and protrusions in conduit or supports for conduit, shall be free of all burrs, sharp edges, and sharp 
corners to prevent injury to personnel and damage to conduit. 
 
Threading compound shall be used and shall not adversely affect the grounding continuity of the conduit system. 
 
Flexible conduits shall be of the same size as the rigid conduit it connects to. 
 
Flexible conduits shall not be relied upon to be a contiguous ground path (an internal ground conductor or external 
bonding jumper is required). 
 
Short radius elbows shall not be utilized to connect conduit runs. 
 
All bends shall exhibit true roundness and the full cross section shall be available throughout the bend. 
 
Parallel conduit runs shall be installed with concentric bends. 
 
Conduit fill shall not exceed 40% fill. 
 
3.5. 
CONTROL PANELS 
  
3.5.1. 
Control Panel Mounting 
 
Coordinate with owner on location of panel mounting to ensure code, installation, operational, and maintenance 
requirements are met. 
 
3.5.2. 
Device Mounting 
 
All interior devices, Instruments, and electrical equipment shall be rigidly mounted on panel back-plane or 
subpanel.  All mounted devices installed inside the enclosures and as panel features on the enclosures shall be 
located so connections can be easily made and ample room exists for servicing each item.  Every component in 
and on the enclosures shall be removable without affecting operation of the other components.  
 
Separate enclosures shall be used for devices that require a supply voltage greater than 120VAC or may produce 
harmonics.  These devices include but are not limited to motor controllers, VFDs, SCRs, and servo drives, etc. 
 
All components shall be installed according to the manufacturer's instructions.  
 
3.5.3. 
Cutouts 
 
Conduit/cable/tubing entries in the top surface of a panel or enclosure are not allowed.  Conduit/cable/tubing 
entries in the bottom of a panel are preferred. 
 
No distortion of panels is permitted as a result of machining cutouts or mounting Instruments and devices.  
 
Cutouts shall be smooth and shall not have any irregularity from the desired shape.  
 
Openings shall not be made by flame-cutting or arc-cutting.  
 
Cutouts, sub-panels, and drilling for mounting shall be aligned to keep the devices in a group in vertical and 
horizontal alignment.  
 
No field conduit knock-outs may be cut at the Vendor's panel shop.  
All devices shall be completely installed prior to terminating any wire or tubing. 
 
Rivets shall not be used for any fastening.  
 
3.5.4. 
Raceway 
 
Raceways shall be installed along vertical or horizontal runs to present a neat appearance. Angled runs are not 
acceptable.  
 
3.5.5. 
Wireway  
 
The wireway for internal wire routing shall be as indicated on drawings.  Where not indicated, wireway shall be 
white slotted plastic trough with snap-on cover.  Wireway for intrinsically safe (IS) wiring shall be blue slotted 
plastic trough with snap-on covers.  Maintain segregation between AC, DC, IS and communication system’s 
wiring.  A separate IS panel is preferred with clear delineation between “safe” and “non-safe” sides. 
 
All wireways shall be permanently fastened into the sub-panels using 10/32 screws. Double face adhesive tape 
shall never be used for any fastening. 
 
Wireway covers shall be labeled with the wiring type (e.g., 24VDC or 120VAC or IS) 
 
Plastic wire wraps and plastic adhesive anchors shall be used to bundle and secure wiring and cables.  
 
Flexible sleeves shall be used for protection of wire bundles that cross the door hinge.  
 
3.5.5.1. Electrical Wiring 
 
All wiring between devices and terminal blocks shall be in wireways except for dressing out to make terminations.  
Wireway fill shall not exceed 40 percent fill.  
 
Where wiring must be outside wireway, it shall be neatly arranged, supported, and bundled with nylon tie-wraps.  
Flexible sleeves for protection of each wire bundle that pass across the door hinge shall be provided.  Sufficient 
slack in wiring bundles shall be allowed so that the door can fully open.  
 
Low level DC signal wiring shall be routed separately from AC control (or power wiring, on exception, when 
permitted in the control cabinet – power components should be segregated into a dedicated power cabinet).  Where 
AC and low level DC wiring must intersect, they shall cross perpendicular to each other. 
 
Copper grounding lugs shall be provided for electrical grounding of all metal panels. Lugs are to be sized for the 
system requirements (NEC compliant ground conductor sizing) but in no case shall be less than #8.  
 
All stranded conductors shall be neatly landed and terminated in the terminal blocks.  Breakage or intentional 
strand removal (to reduce the conductor’s cross section) of stranded wire shall not be permitted.  (Solid conductors 
are NEVER permitted.)   
 
No more than two (2) conductors shall be connected under each terminal screw. 
 
Provide adequate safety shielding for terminations greater than 50 Volts. 
 
3.5.5.2. Pneumatic Tubing 
 
Tubing shall not be spliced within the panel.  Tubing extensions shall be made using bulkhead fittings. 
No tubing runs shall interfere with the removal of any component. 
 
All incoming and outgoing pneumatic tubing shall be terminated at the enclosure’s wall with bulkhead fittings.  
 
Tubing shall be installed along vertical or horizontal runs to present a neat appearance.  Angled runs are not 
acceptable. 
 
3.5.6. 
Nameplates 
 
Nameplates for devices and each panel mounted or sub-panel instrument shall be mounted next to or below the 
device in such a manner to minimize identification errors.  
 
3.6. 
PROCESS CONTROL SYSTEM SOFTWARE 
 
PCS software configuration shall be provided by Owner approved PCS integrator. The Manufacturer shall 
cooperate with the Owner and Owner’s PCS integrator during software configuration in order to provide a system 
compatible with other components of the Owner’s facility. 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide a Functional Requirement Specification (FRS) document to the Owner’s 
Integrator that clearly defines the operation of the skid.  The FRS shall also include any specific displays or 
functionality that the skid manufacturer provides to accommodate special skid setup or maintenance (i.e. 
maintenance, equipment characterization, calibration, etc.). This FRS shall be submitted to the Owner for review 
and approval prior to issue to the Integrator.  The official, approved version of the FRS will be the responsibility 
of the PCS Integrator; however, the intent is that the Manufacturer provides adequate process description via the 
FRS to allow the PCS integrator to successfully complete the control configuration for the skid.  The FRS shall 
be submitted to the Owner for review and approval. 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide support to accommodate the work of the Integrator while on site for the skid 
FAT.  Allowances for up to one week of time prior to the FAT should be made to allow the Integrator to set up 
and install software and check function of the controls.  This will require completed fabrication and wiring of the 
skid. 
 
3.7. 
TESTING 
 
3.7.1. 
Pre-Testing 
 
The Vendor shall test each fully assembled panel, console, or enclosure at the factory prior to shipment.  
 
Notify the Owner at least two weeks prior to testing and make arrangements for Owner observation and testing.  
 
Pre-testing in preparation for final testing and inspection shall include but not be limited to: 
 
 
 
All wiring and tubing shall be tested for continuity and tightness of connections. 
 
Energize all electrical circuits within the control panel. 
 
Pressurize all pneumatic circuits within the control panel. 
Verify that all components conform to the drawings, specification, and manufacturer’s instructions. 
Verify proper grounding. 
 
Verify that all components function as specified. 
Test power supplies for proper operation. 
Verify that all components are properly tagged and labeled per the drawings. 
Verify that the control panel has been labeled to show conformance to UL508A. 
Verify that the panel “Arc Flash Hazard” and “Shock Hazard” analysis has been completed and the panel 
is labeled per NFPA 70E. 
 
At the end of Pre-testing, the Vendor shall notify the Owner of test completion and that the control panel is ready 
for inspection.  Completed test reports shall be transmitted to Owner as a For Record Submittal. 
 
Test Failures:  If any equipment or system fails to test properly, the Vendor shall make necessary corrections, 
including replacement, at no additional cost to the Owner.  
 
3.7.2. 
Factory Acceptance Testing 
 
Where required by the Owner, control panels shall be factory-tested by the Owner prior to shipment. 
 
Devices 
 
Vendor shall check all devices to ensure complete conformance with the Bill of Materials. Non-conformances 
shall be corrected.  Vendor shall be responsible for compliance with their standard in-production test procedures, 
which should progressively check the assembly and wiring systems. 
 
Vendor shall test the contact configuration on all auxiliary relays having convertible contacts and verify 
conformance with the N/O and N/C positions. 
 
Vendor shall determine the contact configuration on all control and instrument switches, synchronizing switches, 
selector switches, and pushbuttons, and verify conformance with switch contact diagrams.  
 
Vendor shall verify that each contact operates in each switch position as indicated on the switch contact diagrams, 
and that all switches with spring return action do return to the intended positions freely and without binding. 
 
Wiring Check 
 
Vendor shall perform a point-to-point check with wiring drawings as defined in the project FAT procedures.  
 
All wiring terminations shall be connected to the specific device terminals as shown on the approved diagrams. 
The Vendor shall perform an electrical continuity test on each conductor. 
 
Non-conformances shall be corrected prior to functional testing by the Owner. The Vendor’s quality control 
checklist sheets shall be made available to the Owner during any inspection visit.  
 
Functional Testing 
 
A functional test shall be performed to ensure that the wiring checks previously performed are error free.  This 
functional test will be performed with power applied to the control panel, by the Owner or its authorized 
representative with appropriate support from the Vendor.  All discrete inputs and outputs will be cycled tested 
using 24VDC and 120VAC power supply.  All analog I/O points will be tested with the Vendor providing the 
appropriate test equipment to supply and measure variable 4-20mA signals.  
 
Vendor shall be responsible to protect all devices from exposure to overvoltage or other hazards during testing. 
 
 
Vendor shall submit a test procedure to the Owner prior to functional testing.  The test procedure shall identify 
the test hardware, Vendor personnel and schedule support and any special safety equipment required to perform 
the functional test.  
Functional testing will include a check of the variable speed drive configuration parameters and an operational 
test of the drive, where applicable.    
 
Any non-conformance shall be noted and corrected prior to the next day’s functional test.  Demonstration of all 
corrected non-conformances will be required. 
 
The Owner or Owner’s authorized representative will provide a technical sign-off procedure for each control 
panel.  This sign-off signifies the functional test is complete with all known non-conformities corrected.  The 
enclosure is to be immediately prepared for shipment and stored.  The actual release for the shipment of the 
equipment must be obtained in writing from the Owner prior to shipping. 
 
Test Failures:  In the event that the unit fails functional testing and requires re-testing at a later date, Vendor shall 
pay all costs associated with this re-testing.  No test shall require the control panel components to operate in a 
manner that voids or reduces the Vendors’ Warranty.  Responsibility for delays caused by damaged or unavailable 
equipment shall lie with the Vendor. 
 
3.8. 
CLEANING 
 
After completion of factory assembly and testing, the control panels and equipment mounted thereon shall be 
thoroughly cleaned internally and externally by wiping, vacuuming, and brushing.  All non-permanent marks and 
coatings shall be removed without damaging the exterior surface or the components. 
 
3.9. 
SHIPPING 
 
All control panels, equipment and materials shall be suitably crated, boxed, or otherwise prepared for shipment 
to prevent damage during handling and shipping.  Each box or crate shall contain a detailed packing list.  All 
openings shall be properly protected to prevent the entrance of dirt or debris. Suitable weatherproofing shall 
adequately protect all parts that, due to physical size or arrangement, may be exposed to the weather.  It shall be 
the responsibility of the Vendor to take any other precautions required to reasonably ensure jobsite arrival of the 
equipment in an undamaged and satisfactory working condition. 
 
Each separately shipped crate or box shall be plainly marked on the outside with the gross weight, shipping 
address, job number, Purchase Order number, and the identification of the items enclosed. 
 
Unless approved otherwise by the Owner, an air ride van shall be used to transport all control panels. 
 
Fabricator shall supply structural steel lifting beams or removable lifting eyes for lifting any shipping section of 
the control panels.  Fabricator shall supply control panel skin plugs for use when lifting eyes are provided.  The 
lifting beams shall be sufficiently rigid to distribute all strains evenly, which may be imposed in handling.  The 
Owner shall approve the method of preparation for shipment and shipping section lengths. 
 
Temporary braces or supports shall be provided to prevent twisting or bending of control panels and framework 
while uncrating, handling, and erecting the equipment in the field if necessary.  The braces/supports shall be 
located such that they may be left in place until the equipment is installed in its permanent position. 
 
Internally mounted components shall be protected with plastic shrink-wrap to prevent damage from metal 
shavings or other contaminants during transportation and installation. 
 
The equipment covered by this specification may be stored at the jobsite in a climate-controlled building prior to 
installation.  Any special storage requirements specified by the Vendor shall be forwarded to the jobsite at least 
1 week prior to delivery of each shipment to which they are applicable. 
 
The finish of control panels shall be protected in the best practical manner against abrasion or other damage during 
preparation for shipment and while in transit.  Sprayed-on coatings are not acceptable for this purpose.  Sheet 
plastic may be used for protection of paint and against entrance of moisture. The use of tight fitting polyethylene 
should be avoided unless internal moisture protection is provided. 
 
Matching ends of shipping splits shall be plainly identified on equipment and drawings.  Piping, tubing, and 
electrical connections at shipping splits shall be tagged for field identification. 
 
Relays and instruments shall, where appropriate, have moving parts firmly blocked, and glass or plastic doors and 
faces adequately padded, to prevent damage during shipment. 
 
Instrument doors and hinged covers shall be held closed with pressure sensitive tape.  Tape shall not be applied 
directly to plastic windows. 
 
Any documents, tags, or instructions necessary for proper unpacking and protection after unpacking shall be 
enclosed.  The location of these documents shall be indicated on outer covering of crate. 
 
Subject to the Owner's approval, any instruments or devices believed incapable of safely withstanding handling 
and shipment while mounted in the control panel shall be removed and shipped separately, preferably with the 
associated control panel. These instruments or devices shall be properly identified as to the control panel to which 
they are to be remounted. The Fabricator shall be responsible for remounting the equipment once it arrives on 
site. 
 
Owner reserves the right to reject any equipment that has sustained damage during shipment, or during preparation 
for shipment. 
 
All disassembled components shall be labeled to facilitate proper assembly.  Documentation provided shall clearly 
depict scope of supply for field installed interconnecting wiring or re-installation of components shipped loose.   
 
PART 4: PCS HARDWARE MATRIX:  APPENDIX A 
 
The PCS Hardware Matrix printed in Appendix A has select data fields necessary to define the scope of work and 
provide a general overview of the hardware for the project.  The hardcopy is to be considered the official project 
documentation.  An electronic file will be provided.  This electronic file is in PDF format and will be issued/re-
issued as a snapshot in time file for use as desired by the contactor.  When an updated specification and Matrix is 
reissued, it is the contractor’s responsibility to update any active and or customized previous version they may be 
using with new data issued. 
 
 
END OF SECTION

SECTION 409040 
INSTRUMENTATION AND CONTROLS DEMOLITION  
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and 
Division 01 Specification Sections, apply to this and the other Sections of Division 40.   
 
The requirements of this section apply to all other Division 40 Sections. 
 
Contract Drawings are in part schematic, intended to convey the scope of work and indicate the general layout, 
design, and arrangement.  
 
Follow Contract Drawings in laying out the work.  Check and be familiar with Shop Drawings and 
Coordination Drawings affecting spaces in which the work will be installed.  
 
Related Sections:  The following sections contain requirements that relate to this section: 
 
Section 409010 Basic Instrumentation and Controls Requirements 
Section 409050 Basic Instrumentation and Controls Materials and Methods 
 
1.2. 
SCOPE OF WORK 
 
The Contractor shall visit the site and inspect the installed instrumentation and/or control system(s) to determine 
the extent of the demolition work required.  
 
Coordinate all work with the Owner and/or Construction Manager. Schedule all work in advance with the 
Owner and/or Construction Manager.  
 
Perform such work and make such alterations to the existing WFI Control Panels as required to facilitate the 
installation of new work shown and called for on the Drawings and Specifications. 
 
Demolition shall consist of, but not be limited to the removal of instrumentation, wire, tubing, conduit, boxes, 
panels, support hardware, and other devices as shown on the plans or that is in the way of New Construction.  It 
is the Contractor’s responsibility to maintain instruments and control system(s) to keep areas in operation not 
included in the demolition work but affected by the demolition work. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
When new products are required to facilitate demolition work, they shall be new and as specified section 
409050. 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
Demolition shall be worked, according to the project schedule, in two Phases to maintain the facilities use of 
several processing rooms.  Demolition scope is identified on Demolition drawings and shall be followed by the 
Contractor.  
 
Coordinate control system shutdowns and power outages to facilitate reworking of existing system with the 
Owner.  Schedule necessary shutdowns / outages at least 72 hours in advance. 
 
Electrical and controls services may be turned off for only the shortest practicable periods of time, and then 
only by pre-arrangement between the owner and contractor for specific mutually agreeable intervals, after each 
of which the interruption shall cease and services shall be restored. 
 
3.1. 
DISPOSAL OF REMOVED EQUIPMENT AND MATERIAL 
 
Remove all devices shown on the demolition drawings except those noted "to remain" or "to be relocated." 
 
When an item is shown to be removed, also remove all wiring, conduit, boxes, tubing, and associated items 
back to its source junction box, termination panel or control panel. 
 
Where a pneumatic instrument is shown to be removed, remove pneumatic controls associated with that device 
back to an air system distribution panel, header valve or other appropriate isolation point. 
 
When wiring and/or cabling to be demolished is routed within conduit, wireway, cable tray, etc. with non-demo 
wiring and/or cabling, the contractor shall remove with minimal disturbance to the non-demo wiring and/or 
cabling. 
 
When pneumatic tubing to be demolished is routed within conduit, wireway, cable tray, etc. with non-demo 
pneumatic tubing, the contractor shall remove with minimal disturbance to the non-demo pneumatic tubing. 
 
All wiring, cabling and/or tubing shall be labeled “spare” where indicated on demolition drawings.  All new 
labeling shall match existing labeling within a panel or junction box. 
 
When a panel or junction box is to remain in service and demolition has created holes or openings by removal 
of conduits, the contractor shall cover openings with manufactured hole seals. 
 
When a panel or junction box is to remain in service and demolition has created bulkhead penetrations by 
removal of pneumatic tubing, the contractor shall cap bulkhead fittings. 
 
The Contractor shall verify that an instrument or other control system device does not serve an occupied area 
before he disconnects it. 
 
Disconnect and remove all line side power conduit and wiring, junction boxes and wireways associated with a 
field instrument as shown on the instrumentation & controls demolition drawings. 
 
Cut conduit flush with finished floor and seal where conduit is stubbed up above floor.  Abandon the rest of the 
conduit run in place in the floor.  Remove all wiring back to the source. 
Where the installation of new work interferes with the location of present work that is to remain in use, furnish 
and install all labor and materials necessary to relocate the present work as required to clear the new work. 
 
Instrumentation, control panels, terminal boxes, and other major equipment to be removed may, at the Owner's 
discretion, be delivered to the Owner at a location to be determined on site. 
 
 
Materials removed and not indicated by the Drawings to be reinstalled or stored shall be removed from the site 
at the Contractor's expense. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
SECTION 409050 
BASIC I&C MATERIALS AND METHODS 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and Division 
01 Specification Sections, apply to this and the other sections of Division 40.   
 
The requirements of this section apply to all other Division 40 Sections. 
 
1.2. 
JOB CONDITIONS 
 
General:  The following requirements apply: 
 
Protect work, materials, and equipment from damage before, during, and after installation.  Cap or plug temporary 
openings.  Protect system piping, ductwork, conduit, etc., from accumulation of unwanted debris.  Repair or 
restore rusted or otherwise damaged materials and equipment to "as new" condition as acceptable to the Owner.   
Coordinate routing of piping, tubing, cable tray, conduit, etc., with other trades to assure unobstructed installation 
 
Work not properly coordinated or installed out of proper sequence that causes conflict with the installation of 
other work, shall be removed, and reinstalled at Contractor’s expense. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Control Room and Field Instruments:  Provide all instruments as described in Section 409100, Instrument Index 
and Data Sheets, and in accordance with terms of the contract.  In some cases, certain instruments shall be 
furnished only and installed by others.  Coordinate these issues with the Owner or Owner’s representative. 
 
Calibration Instruments:  The Contractor shall furnish all calibration equipment, test equipment, and all special 
tools peculiar to an instrument required to complete the work.  Where required by the Owner, the Contractor shall 
provide all calibration certification information and documentation. 
 
Process Connections:  Provide all materials required to complete the instrument process connections, sensing 
lines, and sensor installations in accordance with current instrument installation practices, manufacturer’s 
recommendations, and/or the installation details where provided.  This shall include all required:  
 
 
Piping 
Tubing 
Fittings 
Isolation Manifolds 
Hardware and Supports 
Valves after the First Branch Valve 
 
All process wetted materials shall meet or exceed the corrosion, pressure, and temperature requirements of the 
process.  The Contractor shall be aware that the construction and design of some instruments requires better 
corrosion, pressure, and temperature ratings than is required by the piping or vessel and shall assure that these 
requirements are satisfied. 
 
2.2. 
INSTRUMENT MOUNTS 
 
Provide mounting and supports for remote mounted instruments in accordance with the drawings or 
manufacturer's recommended installation procedures.  All materials shall be in accordance with requirements of 
the area.  
 
2.3. 
CONTROL PANELS, ENCLOSURES, FIELD PANELS AND HOUSINGS 
 
Provide control panels, field panels, enclosures, and housings as indicated in the documents and which are not 
designated to be furnished by the Owner or others in accordance with Section 409350 - Control Panels.  
 
2.4. 
ELECTRICAL RACEWAYS 
 
General:  Provide complete raceways as required in accordance with Division 26 Section 260533 - Raceways. 
 
2.5. 
SUPPORTING DEVICES 
 
Raceway Supports:  Bolted conduit clamps, bolted beam clamps, riser clamps, ceiling trapeze hangers, wall 
brackets, and one-hole and two-hole straps shall be provided as required to complete the raceway installation. 
 
Fasteners:  Types, materials, and construction features as follows: 
 
 
Toggle Bolts:  All steel springhead type. 
 
Powder-Driven Threaded Studs:  Heat-treated steel, designed specifically for the intended service. 
 
Conduit Sealing Bushings:  Factory-fabricated watertight conduit sealing bushing assemblies suitable for sealing 
around conduit, or tubing passing through concrete floors and walls.  Construct seals with steel sleeve, malleable 
iron body, neoprene sealing grommets or rings, metal pressure rings, pressure clamps, and cap screws. 
 
Cable Supports for Vertical Conduit:  Factory-fabricated assembly consisting of threaded body and insulating 
wedging plug for non-armored control cables in riser conduits.  Provide plugs with number and size of conductor 
gripping holes as required to suit individual risers.  Construct body of malleable-iron casting with hot-dip 
galvanized finish. 
 
U-Channel Systems:  12 gauge minimum steel channels.  Provide fittings and accessories that mate and match 
with U-channel and are of the same manufacturer. 
 
2.6. 
INSTRUMENT POWER 
 
General:  Generally, the Electrical Contractor will provide isolated, RF noise free instrument power that is in 
accordance with the instrument manufacturer's recommendations, construction drawings, and with applicable 
articles of the NEC Code.  For instruments not designated to be powered by the Electrical Contractor, provide 
instrument power as specified above.  Coordinate these requirements with the Electrical Contractor. 
 
2.7. 
INSTRUMENT WIRE AND CABLE 
 
General:  Provide instrument wiring and instrument signal cable in raceway as required in accordance with Section 
409150 Instrument Wire and Cable.  Provide instrument specific cable (where required) for connecting sensors 
and converters/transmitters in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations or construction drawings.  
All voltage dropping resistors used to obtain a one (1) to five (5) volt input signal in 24 VDC powered loops shall 
be 250 ohms, 0.5 watts, with 1/10 of one (1) percent tolerance. 
 
Controller Communication Cable:  Provide transmission cable, cable taps, tap boxes, and components of 
controller communication cabling systems (i.e., DeviceNet). 
 
2.8. 
PIPING AND TUBING 
 
Provide instrument air supply piping from air headers to pneumatic instruments.  The piping/tubing system shall 
be provided in accordance with Section 409200 - Pneumatic Instrument Tubing. 
 
2.9. 
WIRE, CABLE, AND TUBE LABELS 
 
Provide wire and tube labels of the printable, self-laminating type.  Labels shall be vinyl with white printable area 
and machine laser-printed with the appropriate identification number using waterproof ink.  Hand marking shall 
not be acceptable.  Labels shall be Panduit, Brady, or equal. 
 
2.10. SEALANTS 
 
General:  Coordinate any special sealant conditions with Architectural specifications. 
 
Mildew-Resistant Silicone Sealants 
 
Silicone, mildew resistant, neutral-cure, non-sag, non-paintable single-component sealant complying with ASTM 
C920, Type S, Grade NS, Class 50, for uses in non-traffic areas, for sealing interior joints with nonporous 
substrates for plus 50 percent and minus 50 percent movement capability.   
 
Prime joint substrates where recommended by sealant manufacturer or as indicated by preconstruction joint-
sealant-substrate tests or prior experience.  Apply primer to comply with sealant manufacturer's written 
instructions.  
 
Acceptable Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide sealants of one of the following: 
 
 
"Pecora 898NST", Pecora Corp. 
 
Approved Equivalent 
 
Firestopping System Sealants 
 
Penetration Firestopping Systems:   Systems that resist spread of fire, passage of smoke and other gases, and 
maintain original fire-resistance rating of construction penetrated.  Penetration firestopping systems shall be 
compatible with one another, with the substrates forming openings, and with penetrating items if any.  
Firestopping systems shall have ratings determined per ASTM E814 or UL 1479 by Underwriters' Laboratories, 
Inc, or other testing and inspection agency acceptable to the Engineer and authorities having jurisdiction. 
 
Acceptable Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide products of one of the following: 
 
 
3M Fire Protection Products 
 
Hilti, Inc. 
Specified Technologies, Inc. 
 
2.11. FIELD MOUNTED INSTRUMENT TAGS 
 
See Section 200553 “Tagging and Identification”, Section 2.3.2 Instrument and Valve Tags. 
 
2.12. PROCESS WARNING SIGNS 
 
Sensors installed into process piping or vessels with no protective well shall have a hazard warning sign 
permanently affixed to the piping or vessel connection.  Signs shall be made of stainless steel, AISI 300series.  
Signs shall have a minimum size of 2" by 4" and be of 16 gauge minimum thickness.  Signs shall be stamped in 
1/4" high block characters.  The legend shall be:  
 
DANGER 
NO PROTECTIVE WELL 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
EXAMINATION OF WORK AREA 
 
Examine work area for suitability of conditions prior to installation of work.  Coordinate location of work with 
adjacent work.  Field verify location of work including dimensions and required clearances prior to proceeding 
with installation. 
 
Where unsatisfactory or unsuitable conditions are encountered, do not proceed until the appropriate persons have 
been notified and the conditions corrected. 
 
3.2. 
RECEIPT AND INSPECTION OF INSTRUMENT EQUIPMENT 
 
Receive and inspect all instruments and control equipment and inspect for conformance with the Specifications 
and in accordance with Division 1. 
 
 
Re-install components removed for shipment and inspect the completed assembly for compliance with the 
Documents and the manufacturer's recommended installation practice.  
 
Store instruments and equipment, including those furnished by Others, in accordance with the manufacturer's 
recommendations.  In no case shall the storage or transportation environment be colder than 0°F or hotter than 
120°F. 
 
3.3. 
ROUGH-IN 
 
Verify final locations for rough-ins with field measurements and with the requirements of the actual equipment 
to be connected. 
 
3.4. 
CUTTING AND PATCHING 
 
Protection of Installed Work:  During cutting and patching operations, protect adjacent installations. 
 
All openings in the roof, for electrical conduits, shall be made weather and watertight using seamless flashing 
assemblies for conduit through 2". 
 
Openings in fire rated assemblies, made during new construction or demolition, for conduit or nipples, for sleeves 
containing cable or wire, and for open conduits through rated assemblies shall be filled with fire resistant foam 
sealant as approved by the authority having jurisdiction. 
 
Patch existing or finished surfaces and building components using new materials matching existing materials, or 
original installation, utilizing experienced installers. 
 
3.5. 
INSTRUMENT AND PANEL INSTALLATION 
 
General:  Sequence, coordinate, and integrate the various elements of systems, materials, and equipment.  Comply 
with the following requirements: 
 
Install instruments per the instrument installation details.  If an installation detail is not provided for an 
instrument, manufacturer's recommendations shall be followed.  
 
Coordinate instrumentation, equipment, and materials installation with other building components. 
 
Verify all dimensions by field measurements. 
 
Coordinate the installation of required supporting devices and sleeves to be set in poured-in-place 
concrete and other structural components, as they are constructed. 
 
Sequence, coordinate, and integrate installations of instrumentation and equipment for efficient flow of 
the Work. 
 
Install systems, materials, and equipment level and plumb, parallel and perpendicular to other building 
systems and components. 
Install systems, materials, and equipment giving right-of-way priority to systems required to be installed 
at a specified slope. 
Ensure that proper connections are provided in process lines for instrument connections.  
 
Install instruments which could be damaged during line or vessel cleaning or pressure testing, e.g., orifice plates, 
turbine meters, vortex meters, positive displacement meters, pitot tubes, and pressure gauges, into the piping 
system or vessels only after cleaning and testing is complete.  
 
 
Instruments that must be regularly removed shall be installed with a conduit union or cable quick connect to 
facilitate removal.   
 
Sensors that must be regularly removed for calibration purposes shall include service loop of sufficient length (18 
inches min) with cabling neatly coiled and zip-tied at the element. 
 
All conduit entries to panels shall be made using hole punch or knockout.  Hole saws or drills shall not be used 
for conduit entries. 
 
All internal and external panel components shall be adequately protected from potential damage caused by 
accidental impact or the collection of debris during panel, conduit, and wiring installation. 
 
Install screened vents facing downward.  
 
Instrument capillary tubing shall be protected from stress and from contact with other equipment by installation 
in channel supports.  Excess capillary shall be neatly coiled into 6" to 9" coils and secured with nylon tie-wraps.  
 
All remote-mounted instruments shall be installed on pipe-stands or walls at four feet - six inches (4'-6") above 
grade level.  Deviations of more than twelve inches from this requirement must be approved by the Owner or 
Owner’s representative.  
 
Process Piping shall not be used to support instruments unless specifically indicated as such.  The only exception 
to this is inline components.  Where required, the Contractor shall provide additional support to minimize induced 
load on the process piping.  
 
Handrails shall not be used to support instruments or equipment unless specifically indicated as such.  Any use 
of handrails shall be reviewed by the appropriate discipline lead and done in a manner which meets local building 
codes.   
 
Mount and align all indicating instruments such that they are unobstructed and visible from normal operating 
positions.  Instruments not visible from said positions shall be removed and relocated at the contractor’s cost.  
Where indicating instruments cannot be relocated, the Contractor shall provide a remote indication device, wired 
and installed in a visible location.  If a remote indicator is not specified, Contractor shall consult Owner or 
Owner’s representative for appropriate device requirements.  
 
3.6. 
ELECTRICAL 
 
Install conduit, wire, cable, and connections as indicated, in accordance with equipment manufacturer's written 
instructions, the electrical hazard classification for the location, the location's housekeeping and corrosion 
requirements, recognized industry practices, and complying with applicable requirements of UL and NEC.   
 
Splicing any cable is unacceptable unless specifically called out on the drawings.  Where splices are required, it 
shall be made per design documentation.  
 
Route direct current (DC) signal conductors separately from alternating current (AC) conductors.  AC - DC route 
crossings shall be at 90° wherever feasible.  
Intrinsically safe wiring shall conform to the latest revision of ISA RP12.6 and NEC requirements.  Intrinsic safe 
conductors shall not be run with, nor cross, conductors of other NEC classifications and require a separating 
barrier if run in the same raceway with wiring of other classifications.  
 
Dress cables and wires, by cutting and stripping covering armor, jacket, and insulation properly to ensure uniform 
and neat appearance where cables and wires are terminated.  Exercise care to avoid cutting through tapes which 
will remain on conductors.  Also avoid "ringing" copper conductors while skinning wire. 
 
 
Instruments with cable quick connects shall have receptacle installed such that the stress on the molded 
connector/strain relief is minimized. 
 
Match wiring terminations to the terminals.  For connection to screw terminals, use spade-tongue crimping type 
insulated terminal connectors.  Terminations to tubular terminals shall be made using bare stripped wire.    Tighten 
connectors and terminals in accordance with manufacturers recommended torque tightening values. 
 
Install and connect instrumentation bus communication and/or wiring to I/O terminations inside motor control 
center (MCC) panels as defined in the design documents.  The MCC installation and power connections are not 
part of the instrumentation work. 
 
3.7. 
PIPING AND TUBING 
 
Inform the Mechanical Contractor of the required location of each air supply take-off drop point so the Mechanical 
Contractor may install a tee for the air supply take off valve.  Provide a dedicated pneumatic supply take off valve 
for each pneumatic drop to individually isolate each drop from the air supply.  Install the air take off valve within 
seven (7) feet of the floor or platform. 
 
3.8. 
INSTALLATION OF SUPPORTING DEVICES 
 
Install supporting devices to fasten conduit, tubing, and components securely and permanently.   
 
Raceway Supports 
 
Strength of each support shall be adequate to carry present and future load multiplied by a safety factor of at least 
four (4).  Where this determination results in a safety allowance of less than 200 lb., provide additional strength 
until there is a minimum of 200 lb. safety allowance in the strength of each support. 
 
Install individual and multiple (trapeze) raceway hangers and riser clamps as necessary to support raceways.  
Provide U-bolts, clamps, attachments, and other hardware necessary for hanger assembly and for securing hanger 
rods and conduits. 
 
Miscellaneous Supports:  Support miscellaneous components as required to produce the same structural safety 
factors as specified for raceway supports. 
 
Sleeves:  Install in concrete slabs and walls and all other fire-rated floors and walls for raceways and cable 
installations.  For sleeves through fire-rated wall or floor construction, apply UL listed firestopping sealant in 
gaps between sleeves and enclosed conduits and cables.  Plastic pipe shall not be used in fire-rated assemblies. 
 
Fastening:  Unless otherwise indicated, fasten items and their supporting hardware securely to the building 
structure, including but not limited to conduits, raceways, cables, enclosures, panels, and control components. 
 
3.9. 
APPLICATION OF SEALANTS 
 
Surface Cleaning for Sealants:  Clean surfaces of joints immediately before applying sealants to comply with 
recommendations of sealant manufacturer. 
 
Apply sealant primer to cleaned substrates as recommended by sealant manufacturer.  Protect adjacent areas from 
spillage and migration of primers, using masking tape.  Remove tape immediately after tooling without disturbing 
sealant. 
 
General:  Comply with sealant manufacturers' printed application instructions applicable to products and 
applications indicated, except where more stringent requirements apply. 
 
 
Environmental Conditions:  Apply joint sealers under temperature and humidity conditions within the limits 
permitted by the joint sealer manufacturer.  Do not apply joint sealers to wet substrates. 
 
Tooling:  Immediately after sealant application and prior to the time curing begins, tool sealants to form smooth, 
uniform beads; to eliminate air pockets; and to ensure contact and adhesion of sealant with sides of joint.  Remove 
excess sealants from surfaces adjacent to joint.  Do not use tooling agents that discolor sealants or adjacent 
surfaces or are not approved by sealant manufacturer. 
 
In cGMP production areas, seal around all wall mounted enclosures and mountings as to prevent ingress of 
contaminants behind the fixture. 
 
Installation of Fire-Stopping Sealant:  Install sealant, including forming, packing, and other accessory materials, 
to fill openings around controls services penetrating floors and walls, to provide firestops with fire-resistance 
ratings indicated for floor or wall assembly in which penetration occurs.  Comply with installation requirements 
established by testing and inspecting agency. 
 
3.10. TAGGING AND LABELING 
 
See Section 200553 “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
3.11. CALIBRATION, FUNCTIONAL CHECKS AND COMMISSIONING 
 
Calibrate all instruments in accordance with Section 409300 “Instrument Calibration”.  The Contractor shall 
check all calibrations and settings of all instruments and systems and re-calibrate and adjust as required to assure 
proper operation of each instrument, instrument loop, and the complete control system, except such items 
specifically identified as to be checked by Others.  
 
3.12. CHECK-OUT AND START-UP 
 
Provide labor, tools, and equipment required to commission and start up instrumentation and control systems.  
Test and inspect all wiring for proper connections, for correct polarity, for shorts, and for continuity to verify that 
items shall function properly.  Test and inspect all tubing for proper connections, for open lines, and for continuity 
to verify that items shall function properly.  Check all instruments requiring fill fluid to ensure the instrument is 
fully filled with the proper fluid and checked for gas bubbles per the manufacturer's recommendations.  All gas 
bubbles shall be removed.  Check-out all pneumatic instruments using the facility's air system.  Test all instrument 
loops and control loops to ensure response to input signals, output signals, alarms, interlocks, interconnections, 
and signal processing.  These tests shall be performed by teams of combined Owner personnel and Contractor 
personnel unless stated otherwise by the Documents.  Stroke all valves fully opened and fully closed.  All manual 
switches shall be operated to ensure correct function.  Record all calibrations performed during this phase in 
accordance with Section 409300 - Instrument Calibration.  Correct all errors or faulty workmanship discovered 
during testing to the satisfaction of the Owner. 
 
3.13. PAINTING 
 
Equipment and instruments shall be furnished with factory applied finish coats.  If the factory finish on any 
instrument furnished by the Contractor is damaged in shipment or during construction, the Contractor shall 
refinish the instrument to the satisfaction of the Owner. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
SECTION 409100 
INSTRUMENTATION 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
This section covers the procurement and installation of instrumentation and control components. 
 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409010 and 409050 and requirements of the 
Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 01 
General Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the components described in this section and the attached Instrument Index and Specification 
Datasheets must be pre-approved in writing by the Owner or Owner's Representative prior to purchase. 
 
Scope of Work Summary 
 
The process designed as part of this project is intended to support the installation of three automatic tear-down 
machines for plasma bottles and bags. The Instrumentation and Controls scope for the project include the 
procurement and installation of all the instrumentation designed as part of the equipment and utilities supporting 
those tear-down machines. All the process and process utilities instruments will be terminated on field 
instrumentation panels (FIPs) connected to new DeltaV controllers. All the HVAC and mechanical utilities will 
be connected to Siemen’s controllers installed as part of this project. Data sheets will be provided for process and 
process utilities instruments and for other critical instrumentation specified as part of the HVAC and/or 
mechanical systems. All the instrumentation will be listed on the instrument index. Some of the process 
instrumentation design has being deferred to a second phase of the Instrumentation and Controls design 
deliverables.    
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS, MATERIALS AND METHODS 
 
This specification consists of data and information necessary for procurement and installation of instrumentation 
and field or panel mounted control devices.  The data and information are contained in multiple documents in the 
referenced Appendices, outlined as follows.       
 
Approved Manufacturers/Model List:  Appendix A 
 
Manufacturers on the “approved” list marked with an ‘*’ preceding their name are the “preferred” manufacturer 
for that instrument type and shall be the manufacturer used to supply the item.  Alternate manufacturers listed 
shall not be used without prior approval by the Owner or Engineer.    
 
Where no preferred manufacturer is designated, the contactor shall provide instruments and components only by 
those approved manufacturers listed.  Alternates not on the list shall not be used without prior approval by the 
Owner or Engineer.    
 
Where specific instrument model number information is listed with the preferred or approved manufacturer, the 
contractor shall provide instrumentation and components as designated.   
 
 
Each instrument type is listed with the four digit ISA datasheet code.  This code is also listed on the footer of the 
instrument data sheet and may aid in matching up instruments to the appropriate approved/preferred manufacturer 
on the list.      
 
For instruments that do not have approved manufacturers listed, the contractor shall submit their proposed 
manufacturer for prior approval by Owner or Engineer. 
 
Instrument Index:  Appendix B  
 
The Instrument Index printed in Appendix B has select data fields necessary to define the scope of work and 
provide a general overview of the instrumentation for the project.  The hard copy is to be considered official 
project documentation.  An electronic file containing those fields printed as well as additional data fields for the 
instrumentation will be provided.  This electronic file is in Microsoft Excel format, and will be issued/re-issued 
as a snapshot in time file for use as desired by the contactor.  When an updated specification and Instrument Index 
is reissued, it is the contractor’s responsibility to update any active and or customized previous version they may 
be using with new data issued.   
 
The index is a comprehensive listing of all instrumentation for the project.  In addition to process instrumentation, 
it may also include instrumentation for utilities, building systems, etc.   Scope of supply and work related to each 
device is indicated in the index.  Refer to these fields in the Index as well as other contract documents and 
specifications for definition of what is included in your total scope of supply.      
 
The following is a list of data fields that will generally be included in the printed copy of the Instrument Index 
contained in this specification.  It is not an all-inclusive list, however all fields listed, in addition to other data 
fields, will be included in the electronic version of the Instrument Index data file provided with this specification.   
 
Instrument Index data fields: 
 
1. Revised:  Single character in the column to designate that the specific instrument has some 
information related to it that has been revised from the last issue.   This is not exclusive to the 
Instrument Index printed report.  Users should review all information relative to that instrument 
including the instrument data sheet.  All entries will be blank on the first formal issue of the 
Instrument Index.   
2. Tag Number:  The complete alpha-numeric instrument tag number for the instrument.  The printed 
Instrument Index will be sorted alpha-numerically by this field as the primary sort criteria. 
3. P&ID Number:  The drawing number for the P&ID diagram where the device is shown.  
4. Specification Number:  The ISA datasheet standard form number that is used for the instrument.  
This number can be found on the individual instrument data sheet footer and is also listed with its 
corresponding instrument type entry in the preferred manufacturer/model listing in Appendix A of 
this specification.   
5. Instrument Description:  Short description field for calling out the function and service of the 
instrument. 
6. Revision:  Single Alpha or Number that is the revision level code for the instrument data sheet.   
7. Specified By:  Letter designator that defines who is responsible for developing the specification data 
and data sheet for the instrument.  Typical codes are as follows:   
O = Owner  
E = Engineer 
S = Skid Vendor/Fabricator 
CM = Construction Manager 
EC = Electrical Contractor 
IC = Instrumentation Contractor 
GC = General Contractor 
MC = Mechanical Contractor (HVAC/BMS/BAS) 
PC = Piping Contractor 
 
8. Purchased By: Letter designation that defines who is responsible for purchasing (furnishing) the 
instrument.  Typical codes are the same as for ‘Specified By’ column.    
9. Installed By:  Letter designation that defines who is responsible for installing the main body of the 
device/sensor in the process line, on equipment nozzles or attached to mechanical devices.  Typical 
codes are the same as for ‘Specified By’ column.    
10. Wired by:  Letter designation that defines who is responsible for installing the signal and/or power 
wiring to the instrument.  Same would also be responsible for installing remote mounted transmitters 
and devices related to the instrument assemblies.   Typical codes are the same as for ‘Specified By’ 
column.    
11. Tubed By: Letter designation that defines who is responsible for installing pneumatic air supply, 
pneumatic control signal, or process impulse/sensing tubing.   Typical codes are the same as for 
‘Specified By’ column.    
12. Calibrated By:  Letter designation that defines who is responsible for calibration of the instrument 
subsequent to the vendor shipping the instrument to the construction or fabrication site.  
Vendor/factory calibration is designated on the instrument data sheet.  Typical codes are the same 
as for ‘Specified By’ column.   Column is left blank if factory calibration is to be maintained. 
13. Manufacturer:  Name of Instrument manufacturer 
14. Model Number:  Partial or complete model number of instruments.  This should be used for 
reference only.  Please refer to instrument datasheet for Model Number.   
 
Instrument Data Sheets:  Appendix C 
 
Completed ISA type data sheets for instruments are in Appendix C.  It may not be an all-inclusive set depending 
on the phase of the project and the scope of supply for the datasheets.  
 
The datasheets are sorted into sections based on the ‘Purchased By’ designation in the Instrument Index.  Each 
section will have a printout of the Instrument Index filtered to show the contents of that section only.   
 
NOTE:  This grouping only applies to who is purchasing the instruments.   Your Scope of Supply for installation 
services may apply to other groups of instruments that are not purchased by you. Lack of data sheets being 
included in this section shall not be grounds for excluding installation services if the instrument is listed in the 
Instrument Index and installation services are designated.       
 
The order of the groups of data sheets will follow the same order of the listing for the ‘Purchased By’ codes in 
the Instrument Index.   
 
O = Owner  
E = Engineer 
S = Skid Vendor/Fabricator 
CM = Construction Manager 
EC = Electrical Contractor 
IC = Instrumentation Contractor 
GC = General Contractor 
MC = Mechanical Contractor (HVAC/BMS/BAS) 
PC = Piping Contractor 
 
I/O List:  Appendix D 
 
The I/O List printed in Appendix D has select data fields necessary to define the scope of work and provide a 
general overview of the controls for the project.  The hard copy is to be considered official project documentation.  
An electronic file will be provided.  This electronic file is in Microsoft Excel format, and will be issued/re-issued 
as a snapshot in time file for use as desired by the contactor.  When an updated specification and Instrument Index 
is reissued, it is the contractor’s responsibility to update any active and or customized previous version they may 
be using with new data issued. 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
Contractor shall comply with all submittal requirements of Section 409010, prior to purchase of specified devices.  
Inspect all instruments as specified in Section 409050 upon receipt for correct model number, damage, and proper 
operations.  If any equipment is found to be defective, Contractor shall replace item with correct and functional 
item at no additional expense to the Owner. 
 
 
 
END OF SECTION

5. See line 15 for body size to fill "X" in Model.

3. Provide permanent SS tag with the following information engraved: Tag No.,  Mfr's name, Model No. and Serial No..
4. Manufacturer shall verify provided data sheet and model with application requirements and field conditions.
5. See line 15 for body size to fill "X" in Model.

Burns (RTD) ; Rosemount (Transmitter)
200L05AN2D075TS1506/WF05E04E06; 3144PD1F2NAM5Q4
Paper Tag by Manufacturer , Stainless Steel Tag by Contractor
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
N/A
1. VS = Vendor Standard
2. Provide permanent SS tag with the following information engraved: Tag No.,  Mfr's name, Model No. and Serial No..
3. Manufacturer shall verify provided data sheet and model with application requirements and field conditions.
4. Final thermowell and RTD configuration to be coordinated with piping contractor.
5. Instrument supplier shall include the FF receptacle.

SECTION 409150 
INSTRUMENT WIRE AND CABLE 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
SCOPE 
 
This section covers the procurement and installation of instrument wire and cable. 
 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Section 409050 Basic Materials and Methods 
requirements of the Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and 
sections under Division 01 General Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the equipment components, or installation procedures described in this section must be pre-
approved by the Owner or Owner's Representative prior to installation. 
 
1.2. 
DEFINITIONS 
 
AWG 
American Wire Gauge 
CAN 
Controller Area Network 
CCW 
Continuously Welded Corrugated 
CL3 
NEC Article 725 type Class 3 cable, commercial installation 
CM 
NEC Article 800 type Communications cable, commercial installation 
CMG 
NEC Article 800 type Communications cable, commercial installation 
CMP 
NEC Article 800 type Communications cable, plenum rated installation 
CMR 
NEC Article 800 type Communications cable, riser rated installation 
EIA 
Electronic Industries Association 
FEP 
Fluorinated ethylene propylene 
HDPE 
High-Density Polyethylene 
ODVA 
Open DeviceNet Vendors Association 
PE 
Polyethylene 
PLTC 
NEC Article 725 type Power Limited Tray Cable, commercial installation 
PP (PPE) 
Poly propylene 
PUR 
Poly urethane 
PVC 
Poly vinyl chloride 
TC 
Tray Cable 
THHN 
90°C, 600 volt, nylon jacketing building wire for dry locations 
THWN 
75°C, 600 volt, nylon jacketed building wire for wet and dry locations 
UL 
Underwriters Laboratories 
 
1.3. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and Division 
01 Specification Sections, apply to this and the other Sections of Division 40.   
 
The requirements of this section apply to all other Division 40 Sections. 
 
Contract Drawings are in part schematic, intended to convey the scope of work and indicate the general layout, 
design, and arrangement.  
 
Follow Contract Drawings in laying out the work.  Check and be familiar with Shop Drawings and Coordination 
Drawings affecting spaces in which the work will be installed.

PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
All wire and cable shall be UL listed. 
 
2.1. 
WIRE 
 
Power wiring (dedicated power enclosures) shall be sized for the load with #12 AWG being minimum size. 
Control wiring (dedicated control enclosures) shall be #14 AWG.  Power and control wire shall be stranded copper 
wire type THWN or THHN, as an alternate, wiring inside of control panels can be type MTW.   
 
Stranded copper #16 AWG wire type THHN with PVC insulation shall be used for discrete signal wiring external 
to control panels unless otherwise stated on the drawings.  
 
Stranded, tinned copper #18 AWG, twisted, shielded pair (or three-conductor), with PVC insulation shall be used 
for instrument signal wiring. 
 
Thermocouple couple extension wire shall be of the appropriate type as determined by the thermocouple type. 
 
The wire color code for single-conductor wire insulation shall be as follows: 
 
Type 
Color 
120VAC hot 
Black 
120 VAC neutral 
White 
24 / 120VAC control signal hot 
Red 
24 / 120VAC control signal neutral 
White 
Ground (Equipment) 
Green, Green w/Yellow stripe 
24+ VDC 
Blue 
24- VDC 
Blue w/White Stripe 
24 VDC Analog (shielded) 
Red (+), Black (-) 
RTD (excitation) 
Black, Red, or White 
RTD (compensation) 
(matches excitation color) 
Intrinsically safe 
Light Blue (shall be segregated from non-IS) 
Interlocks (Safety Interlocks) 
Yellow (Safety Instrumented Systems -SIS– wiring shall be 
segregated from non-SIS dictated by Safety Integrity Level - 
SIL) 
 
2.2. 
CABLE 
 
All communications cable shall have a minimum insulation rating of 300V. 
 
All communications and control cables placed in cable tray shall have an insulation rating at least equal to the 
highest voltage present in the tray. 
 
All intrinsically safe cables shall have (intrinsic safety) light blue color insulation jacket. 
 
Cables with a PLTC rating may be used in Class I, Div 2 environments. 
 
Cables explicitly listed on drawings override this section of the specification. 
 
Due to the variety of cable offerings and installation requirements, the cables listed below do not comprise an 
exhaustive list and should be used as suggested cables.  The use of cables not listed below require a submittal to 
the Engineer for review/acceptance. 
 
 
 
Instrument Analog Cables: 
 
 
2-Conductor, Twisted, Shielded 
Plenum: 18 AWG stranded (19x30) tinned copper conductors (black, red), FEP insulation, twisted pairs, 
overall foil (100% coverage), 20 AWG stranded tinned copper drain wire, Low Smoke PVC jacket., 
300V, 75°C, 1-pr., NEC/(UL) Type CMP  Belden #82760. 
Non-plenum: 16 AWG stranded (19x29) tinned copper conductors (black, red), PVC insulation, twisted pairs, 
overall foil (100% coverage), 18 AWG stranded tinned copper drain wire, PVC jacket, 300V tray cable, 
105°C, 1-pr., NEC/(UL) Type CMG/PLTC  Belden #9316. 
Non-plenum: 18 AWG stranded (19x30) tinned copper conductors (black, red), PVC insulation, twisted pairs, 
overall foil (100% coverage), 20 AWG stranded tinned copper drain wire, PVC jacket, 300V tray cable, 
105°C, 1-pr., NEC/(UL) Type CMG/PLTC  Belden #9318.

twisted triad, unshielded, PVC jacket, 300V tray cable, 105°C, 1-triad., NEC/(UL) Type CMG/PLTC

twisted, unshielded, PVC/Nylon jacket, 600V, 90°C, NEC/(UL) Type TC.  Alpha #M3829. 
 
Communications Cables:

and PVC jacket.  Number of conductors dependent upon application.
