PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
WIRE AND CABLE INSTALLATION 
 
When installing in areas above fire protection, use plenum rated cable. 
 
Wiring and cables shall not have any mechanical stress or strain at any place in the system.  
 
Continuously shield signal cables.  Shields shall be grounded as indicated on the wiring drawings, loop drawings, 
and installation details, or according to manufacturer's recommendations.  Pay particular attention to the 
requirement for contiguous shields through intermediate termination points, maintaining only one single 
grounding point, and insulating from ground at all other points.  Refer to the wiring drawings to determine the 
single grounding point (at “receiving” device). 
 
Strands of stranded wire shall not be cut out to make the wiring fit an incorrectly sized terminal.  
 
Instrument/control wiring and cables shall not be spliced.  All connections shall be made in junction boxes using 
terminal blocks. 
 
All Ethernet cables defined in this section are limited to cabling lengths of 100 meters (328 feet).  The minimum 
bend radius shall be 4-times the cable diameter. 
 
Power (120 VAC) and control (24 VDC) wiring will be segregated to prevent noise on the control wiring. 
 
Refer to Section 409175 Instrument Bus for additional installation requirements for Instrument Bus systems. 
 
Install wiring in conduit or cable tray per Division 26 specifications. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
SECTION 409175 
INSTRUMENT BUS 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
 
1.1. 
SCOPE 
 
The purpose of this specification is to establish basic requirements and guidelines for the wiring and installation 
of conventional, device-level, fieldbus networks.  The installation of these networks shall be in strict accordance 
with this specification, as well as the respective standards and accepted guidelines governing the installation, 
configuration, and commissioning of these networks.  The Owner or the Owner’s representative must approve 
any deviations from this specification prior to proceeding. 
 
The project standard bus networks are DeviceNet and Foundation Fieldbus.  Any other busses allowed only with 
approval by Owner. 
 
For Stick-Built Applications 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409010 and 409050 and requirements of the 
Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 01 
General Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the equipment components, or installation procedures described in this section must be pre-
approved by the Owner or Owner's Representative prior to installation. 
 
Refer to Section 409150 Instrument Wire and Cable for cable Specification. 
 
For Packaged Equipment Skid Applications 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409021 Basic I&C Reqs for PCS Controlled 
Packaged Equipment, and the requirements of the main equipment specification, the Contract Documents 
including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 01 General 
Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the equipment components, or installation procedures described in this section must be pre-
approved by the Owner or Owner's Representative prior to installation. 
 
Refer to Section 409020 Basic I&C Reqs for PCS Controlled Packaged Equipment, as was issued with the main 
equipment specification. 
 
 
 
1.2. 
DEFINITIONS 
 
Where mentioned in this document, the following definitions apply: 
 
Owner: 
Takeda Pharmaceutical Company Limited 
Engineer: 
CRB Consulting Engineers 
Fabricator: 
The Company responsible for delivering a packaged mechanical system. 
Connector: 
Provide one or several points of connection to a fieldbus segment. 
Repeater: 
A device used to extend the range over which signals can be correctly transmitted and received 
for a given medium. 
Segment: 
Contains active devices, power supply (for bus powered devices), and terminators connected 
by a channel consisting of trunk lines and spurs. 
Terminator: An impedance matching module placed at each end of the trunk which has the same 
characteristic impedance of the trunk.  It is used to minimize signal distortion in the form of 
reflected waves which can cause data errors. 
Trunk: 
Longest cable path between any two devices on a network. 
Spur: 
Any cable connection to a network that is not the trunk line.  A spur is a branch line that is a 
final circuit. 
 
1.3. 
RELATED DOCUMENTS 
 
Drawings and general provisions of the Contract, including General and Supplementary Conditions and Division 
01 Specification Sections, apply to this and the other Sections of Division 40.   
 
The requirements of this section apply to all other Division 40 Sections. 
 
Contract Drawings are in part schematic, intended to convey the scope of work and indicate the general layout, 
design, and arrangement.  
 
Follow Contract Drawings in laying out the work.  Check and be familiar with Shop Drawings and Coordination 
Drawings affecting spaces in which the work will be installed.  
 
1.4. 
QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
Applicable Standards and Codes shall be as defined in the mechanical equipment specification unless noted in 
this document. 
 
National Electrical Manufacturer’s Association (NEMA) 
National Electrical Code (NEC) NFPA-70 
Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) 
Underwriter’s Laboratories (UL) 
International Society of Automation (ISA) 
Federal Occupational Safety Health Act (OSHA) 
Factory Mutual (FM)

IEC 61158 & EN 50254, PROFIBUS Standards  
FF AG-140 Revision 1, Foundation Fieldbus Application Guide  
PROFIBUS Guideline, Order No. 2.092, Technical Guideline for Profibus-PA, User, and Installation 
Guideline Ver 2.2, Feb 2003 
PROFIBUS Guideline, Order No. 2.112, Installation Guideline for Profibus-DP/FMS 
IEC 62026 & EN 50325 DeviceNet Standards 
IEC 62026-2 & CENELEC EN 50295, AS-Interface Standards 
 
 
 
PART 2. - HARDWARE 
 
2.1. 
FOUNDATION FIELDBUS COMPONENTS  
 
All assembled components shall be rated NEMA 4 and IEC IP67 that are not in enclosures.  This includes 
Cordsets, Connectors, Glands, Couplers, Terminators, Bricks, and Tees.  Foundation Fieldbus segments will use 
components manufactured by Turck or Stonel unless indicated otherwise on design documents, this specification 
or approved by Owner/Engineer. 
 
Allowable Devices: 
 
Only devices rated for Foundation Fieldbus shall be allowed to be connected to a Foundation Fieldbus network.   
The maximum number of devices allowable on a fieldbus segment depends on the type of devices. 
 
DEVICE TYPE 
MAXIMUM DEVICES PER SEGMENT 
Bus Powered and Intrinsically Safe (110mA max) 
5 
Bus / Non-Bus Powered and Non-Intrinsically safe 
16 
 
The maximum number of field devices per segment is 16. Per design constrains, no more than 4 of these devices 
may be control valves. 
 
All control valves and any associated analytical devices used for valve control must be connected to the same 
segment. 
 
Distance Limitations:   
 
Maximum available segment length is limited to 1,900 M (1.18 miles).  This is the summation of the trunk line 
and all spurs.  Individual spurs can measure from 1M (3.28ft.) to 120M (394ft.) depending on the number of 
devices on the segment. 
 
Foundation Fieldbus and cables are shielded to minimize noise due to inductive coupling.  Installation of cables 
shall maintain suitable separation from cables and equipment emitting noise.  Cables shall be physically separated 
from power cables, transformers, variable frequency drives and drive cables, rotating equipment, and other high-
power machinery.  The minimum separation distance between signal cables and power lines shall be as follows: 
 
 
VOLTAGE 
CURRENT 
MINIMUM SEPARATION 
DISTANCE (INCHES) 
0 – 125 VOLTS 
0 – 10 A 
12 INCHES 
125 – 250 VOLTS 
1 – 50 A 
15 INCHES 
250 – 440 VOLTS 
0 – 200 A 
18 INCHES 
 
Signal wiring and AC power cable separated by the recommended distances should not run parallel for more than 
20 ft.  If longer parallel runs are needed, increase the separation distance by 12 inches for each additional 30 ft in 
length. 
 
Signal cable shall be separated from devices that generate magnetic fields (motors, variable frequency drives, 
power cables, etc.) by a minimum of five (5) feet; ten (10) to fifteen (15) feet separation is recommended. 
 
2.1.1. 
Cables 
 
Cables shall be specific to the fieldbus type selected and conform to related standards regarding cable types, 
routing, and distance.   Bulk cable for Foundation Fieldbus shall be Belden 3076F or approved equivalent. 
 
 
For services installed above fire protection use black-jacketed plenum cable containing 2/20 AWG White 
TC/White BC data conductors with an overall braid and foil shield.  (Belden 89207) Cable shall meet ISA-SP50 
Standard for Type B and shall be UL-910 and CMP rated. 
 
Receptacles and Glands 
 
All male gland receptacles specified come with external threaded connections.  Male gland receptacles shall be 
installed in all Foundation Fieldbus field instruments such as transmitters and valve positioners.  In general, they 
shall be factory installed.  However, these may also be field installed by the I&C Contractor or Skid Vendor if 
not supplied with the instrument.    Glands shall be installed in a ½ inch – 14 NPT conduit connections.    
 
The use of female gland receptacles for instrument connections shall be prohibited. 
 
Terminators 
 
Termination of the Foundation Fieldbus Cable in the field requires a 100 ΩRC network-terminating resistor with 
a male Minifast connector.  Two terminators are required for each segment and are to be located at the beginning 
and end of the segment trunk line.  The I&C Sub-Contractor or Equipment/Skid Vendor will provide the 
terminator at the end of each field segment as indicated on the project drawings.    
 
Termination of the Foundation Fieldbus Cable in the DCS control cabinet shall be through the built-in terminating 
resistor of the fieldbus power supply.  The unit shall be approved for IEC 61158-2 and ISA-SP50.2 installations. 
 
Multi-port Junctions 
 
Multi-Port Junctions shall be the primary connection for Foundation Fieldbus devices.  Multi-port shall have a 
female Minifast spur connector and a Grounding Lug.  The brick shall provide short circuit protection on each 
spur connection. 
 
The use of DIN-rail mount junctions, for installation within instrument panels shall be allowed, subject to approval 
by the Owner/Engineer. 
 
Power Supplies 
 
Foundation Fieldbus are powered bus networks requiring a power supply for the devices on the segment and to 
carry the Manchester Encoded Signal.  The power supply shall be rated at least 420mA at 24 VDC and have a 
built-in terminating resistor.  The power supply shall have a FM approval rating for Class 1, Div 2, in an 
appropriate enclosure and be approved for IEC 61158-2 and ISA-SP50.02 installations.  Redundant power 
supplies shall meet IEC/ISA physical layer standards.  Paralleling two power supplies to obtain redundancy shall 
not be permitted if stated standards are not adhered to.   Power supplies shall provide diagnostic capability unless 
specifically approved otherwise by the Owner. 
 
Polarity 
 
Foundation Fieldbus signals are polarized.  Connecting the fieldbus cables with reverse polarity will cause the 
device to not communicate properly with the fieldbus interface module.  Fieldbus signals shall be connected so 
they all see the proper polarity.  
 
Voltage Drop 
 
Voltage drop shall be considered when installing a fieldbus network.  Refer to project documents for estimated 
distances and voltage available at each fieldbus device.  Verify trunk and spur lengths prior to installation and 
adjust cable route accordingly.  Minimum voltage allowable at the terminals of a fieldbus device is nine (9) VDC. 
If device locations cannot meet voltage requirements, notify owner or owners representative immediately. 
 
Repeaters 
 
None required.  Distance limitations shall be adhered to. 
 
Intrinsic Safety 
 
Fieldbus segments used in a potentially flammable atmosphere shall meet the applicable requirements of the 
National Electric Code.  Refer to project drawings for definition of electrical area classification.  Special fieldbus 
barriers and terminators are required for intrinsically safe installations.  Separation and identification requirements 
for IS wiring shall be adhered to. 
 
Connection to High-Speed Networks 
 
31.25kbit/s fieldbus networks cannot be directly connected to a higher speed fieldbus network.  When connecting 
to a higher speed network, a special bridge or linking device must be used.  The bridge will be counted as one of 
the 32 field devices on the network. 
 
2.2. 
DEVICENET 
 
Allowable Devices 
 
Only devices with DeviceNet interface shall be allowed to be connected to the DeviceNet network.  The maximum 
number of nodes per network is 64. 
 
Distance Limitations 
 
Data Rate (Kbits/s) 
Trunk Distance 
Max. Drop Length 
Cumulative Drop Length 
125 
500M (1,640 ft) 
6M (20 ft) 
156M (512 ft) 
250 
250M (820 ft) 
6M (20 ft) 
78M (256 ft) 
500 
100M (327 ft) 
6M (20 ft) 
39M (128 ft) 
 
Trunk Distance is the length of the trunk line between terminating resistors.  Cumulative drop length is the sum 
of all the drops from the trunk tee to the end device.   
 
Project documentation will list all devices and calculated distances.  If distances are found to exceed allowed 
limits, contractor is to notify owner or owner’s representative immediately.  
 
Connectors 
 
All male connectors specified come with external threaded connectors.  All female connectors specified come 
with internal threaded connections. 
 
Sealed connectors can be either mini or micro style depending on project documentation.  Sealed connectors are 
only to be used with thick, thin, or mid-sized round cable. 
 
Open connectors can be plug-in or fixed screw terminals depending on project documentation. 
 
Tees 
 
T-ports are the primary way to establish a drop from the trunk line.  Tees should be the sealed type that are keyed 
and connect via mini style quick connectors.  However, if project drawings call for an open style, they are 
permitted.  
 
 
 
Multi-Port Taps 
 
Multi-Port Taps or Bricks shall be the primary connection for DeviceNet devices.  Bricks shall have a female 
quick connect spur connectors and a Grounding Lug.  The brick shall provide short circuit protection on each 
device connection.  Multi-port taps come in two, four, or eight device ports.   
 
Terminators 
 
Termination of the DeviceNet trunk in the field shall be a resistor that is sealed into a T-port tap when round cable 
is used.  If flat cable is used, the terminating resistor shall be a snap-on cap for the flat cable connector base and 
be sealed.  The terminating resistor shall be UL and FM certified. 
 
Power Supplies 
 
DeviceNet devices require a 24 VDC power supply for the devices to operate.    The power supply shall have a 
UL approval rating of UL-508.  Power supplies shall have current limiting protection per NEC Article 725.  Power 
supplies shall comply with the Open DeviceNet Vendor Association (ODVA) power supply specifications and 
NEC/CE Code Class 2 characteristics. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
INSTALLATION 
 
General:  Sequence, coordinate, and integrate the various elements of network systems, materials, and equipment.  
Comply with the following requirements: 
 
• 
Install components and devices per the installation details.  If an installation detail is not provided, 
manufacturer's recommendations shall be followed.  
• 
For temperature, pressure, flow, and analytical instruments, the installation contractor/manufacture shall 
add a minimum of 6 feet at the instrument end, coiled neatly and secured from touching process line or 
vessel.  The contractor shall verify and add if needed, additional length based on instrument location 
relative to floor or platform level. 
• 
Coordinate device, component, and cable installation with other building components. 
• 
Verify all dimensions by field measurements.  Notify owner or owner’s representative if distances are 
not as stated on project drawings. 
• 
Coordinate the installation of required supporting devices and sleeves to be set in poured-in-place 
concrete and other structural components, as they are constructed. 
• 
Sequence, coordinate, and integrate installations for efficient flow of the Work. 
 
Cordset and Cable Support 
 
It is the intent of the project to utilize an open wiring system from local devices to multiport communication 
blocks in lieu of installing wire in conduit.  
 
Cordsets and cables in clean rooms shall be supported and protected with stainless steel rail or angle and fastened 
with sanitary supports.  Supports may be stainless steel hangers with BUNA inserts, Triclover models A24FCF, 
B24FCF, C24FCF or Waukesha equivalents; Universal suspension systems (Sanitech or Behringer); or modular 
clamping system or equivalent by Swagelok. 
 
Cordsets and cables in technical spaces galvanized steel tube track shall be permitted to support quick disconnect 
cords or cable ties may be used to fasten cords to the rail or angle, subject to approval by the Owner. 
 
 
 
If cord sets are approved to be routed within conduit or wireway, refer to the appropriate Division 26 electrical 
specifications for conduit and wireway requirements.  
 
3.2. 
START-UP AND CHECK-OUT 
 
Contractor shall provide start-up and checkout of the system after installation within the facility.  All costs for 
this work shall be included in the Contractor’s base bid.  The Owner is aware that the Contractor may require 
assistance/coordination with Owner’s personnel or others to complete start-up and checkout of the system.  
Contractor shall provide a schedule to the Owner a minimum of 2 weeks in advance of when personnel are 
required to allow the Owner to schedule personnel.   
 
Foundation Fieldbus System 
 
The Foundation Fieldbus system shall be tested, as a minimum, for the following: 
 
• 
Confirm end of terminating resistor is set properly. 
• 
Measure resistance between each wire and the shield. 
• 
Measure resistance between each wire and the ground. 
• 
Measure the resistance between the two twisted pair wires. 
• 
Measure the resistance between the shield and ground. 
• 
Measure capacitance between each wire and the shield. 
• 
Measure capacitance between each wire and the ground. 
• 
Measure the capacitance between the two twisted pair wires. 
• 
Measure the capacitance between the shield and ground. 
 
Owner shall specify the minimum parameters for the test requirements. 
 
These tests should occur with all instruments connected and the final terminator connected. 
 
The contractor or skid fabricator shall provide sufficient documentation to indicate completion of these tests. 
 
DeviceNet System 
 
The DeviceNet system shall be tested, as a minimum, for the following: 
 
• 
Confirm end of terminating resistor is set properly. 
• 
Measure the resistance between the positive communications wire and negative communications wire. 
• 
Measure resistance between each power wire and the shield. 
• 
Measure the resistance the shield and ground. 
 
The Owner shall specify the minimum parameters for the test requirements.   
 
These tests should occur with all instruments connected and the final terminator connected. 
 
The contractor or skid fabricator shall provide sufficient documentation to indicate completion of these tests. 
 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
SECTION 409200 
PNEUMATIC INSTRUMENT TUBING 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
This section covers the procurement of pneumatic instrument tubing and associated installation hardware. 
 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409010 and 409050 and requirements of the 
Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 01 
General Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the equipment components described in this section must be pre-approved by the Owner or 
Owner's Representative prior to purchase. 
 
Instrument air supplies shall be designed so as to operate between 60 psig minimum and 100 psig maximum 
instrument air supply. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT: Provide control products, components, and installation accessories as 
required for complete operational installation.   
 
The following definition of exposed and non-exposed shall be used to determine the type of tubing that will be 
used for a particular installation:  All tubing installed outside wall cavities in production spaces shall be considered 
exposed.  Non-exposed tubing shall include all tubing installed in spaces other than production spaces and tubing 
installed in wall cavities of production spaces.  If tubing inside wall cavities is to be routed through wall into 
production space, tubing material shall change to match specification for the space being entered. 
 
2.1. 
INSTRUMENT TUBING 
 
2.1.1. 
Stainless Steel Tubing 
 
Control air tubing in clean production areas shall be ASTM A269 seamless, annealed 316L stainless steel tubing 
(without manufacturer’s printed information).  Minimize fittings and joints in all spaces to conform to all 
applicable sanitization requirements. 
 
1/4" O.D., 0.035" wall; 
3/8" O.D., 0.035" wall; 
 
2.1.2. 
Copper Tubing 
 
Control air tubing in other areas shall be rigid, hard drawn, copper tubing, Type L, ASTM B-88; with cast bronze 
solder joint fittings, ANSI B16.18; or wrought-copper solder-joint fittings, ANSI B16.22; except brass 
compression type fittings at connections to equipment.  Tubing shall have minimum 500 PSIG pressure rating. 
 
1/4" O.D., 0.030" wall 
3/8" O.D., 0.035" wall 
1/2" O.D., 0.040" wall 
 
Control air tubing in other areas shall be rigid, hard drawn, copper tubing, Type L, ASTM B-75; with cast bronze 
solder joint fittings, ANSI B16.18; or wrought-copper solder-joint fittings, ANSI B16.22; except brass 
compression type fittings at connections to equipment.  Tubing shall have minimum 500 PSIG pressure rating. 
 
For HVAC & Refrigeration applications, seamless soft-annealed coiled copper, Type L, ASTM B-75 may be used 
with approval by the Owner. 
 
2.1.3. 
Plastic Tubing 
 
Provide plastic tubing where required for flexible connections to equipment or in process areas if contained in 
stainless tubing.  Exposed flexible connections in process areas shall be limited to less than or equal to three (3) 
feet.   
 
Plastic tubing shall be UV-resistant seamless extrusion molded high density polyethylene (HDPE) tubing.   HDPE 
tubing shall have a minimum working pressure of 300 PSIG and a minimum burst pressure of 1200 PSIG, with 
an operating temperature range of -80°F to 175°F or better at rated pressures.   
 
1/4" O.D., 0.040" wall, black   Parker HDPE-43 series or approved equal 
3/8" O.D., 0.062" wall, black   Parker HDPE-64 series or approved equal 
 
2.2. 
FITTINGS 
 
Provide correctly sized tubing fittings at all tubing connections.  Stainless steel tubing shall be fitted with stainless 
steel fittings.  Copper tubing shall be fitted with brass fittings.  Plastic tubing shall be fitted with polyethylene 
fittings of same rating as tubing.  As an alternate, brass or stainless fittings, designed for use with polyethylene 
tubing and equipped with tubing inserts, may be used. 
 
All fittings shall have NPT screwed threads according to ANSI B1 20.1, unless equipment connections require 
otherwise. 
 
2.3. 
THREAD SEALANT 
 
Provide PTFE Teflon tape, 0.0035" thickness Mil Spec A-A-58092, tape for fitting thread sealant.  Liquid or paste 
type thread sealants are prohibited. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
CUTTING, BENDING, SHAPING AND CONDITIONING 
 
The tubing shall be checked for correct diameter and wall thickness. 
 
Bend tubing with a correctly sized tubing bender.  Hand bends and wrinkled, flattened or chinked bends will not 
be accepted.  The installer shall follow Manufacturer's recommendations for minimum bending radius. 
 
Cut all tubing with a tubing cutter.  Remove the cutting burr.  
 
Remove PVC jackets of PVC jacketed tubing at fittings in a manner such that the removal of the jacket does not 
cause damage, or marking of the tubing.  
 
3.2. 
RACEWAYS 
 
Do not install pneumatic tubing in electrical raceways with wiring. 
 
All tubing shall be run in such a manner as to give the maximum protection against mechanical damage.  No pipe 
or tube shall be installed with a mechanical stress or strain on it.  Support tubing and tubing bundles in continuous 
track, channel, or conduit.  
 
Tubing drops from the main raceway in process areas shall be supported in rigid metal conduit.  Conduit fill limits 
shall not exceed 40 percent.  
 
Edges, ends, and protrusions in conduit, tubing track, tubing channel, or supports for tubing, shall be free of all 
burrs, sharp edges, and sharp corners to prevent injury to personnel and damage to tubing. 
 
Tubing shall be pulled into raceway in such manner as to prevent damage.  Use lubricant to pull tubing into 
raceways. 
 
3.3. 
ROUTING 
 
Run conduit, piping, tubing, and similar components in horizontal and vertical alignment with the building 
structure or in horizontal and vertical alignment with associated principal equipment.  
 
3.4. 
TUBING INSTALLATION 
 
All metal and plastic tubing connections shall be made with flareless compression type fittings as specified. 
Installation shall be made in strict accordance with the fitting Manufacturer’s recommendations. 
 
Prevent foreign material from entering the tubing lines during installation.  Shield all installed, but not connected, 
tubing ends using plugs.  Blow clean all lines with instrument quality air or dry nitrogen prior to connection.  
 
Short tubing runs shall be installed with at least one 90-degree bend to provide a relief for thermal expansion. 
 
Plastic tubing may be installed in multi-tube bundles. If these bundles are exposed, they shall be armored with 
PVC-coated flex.   
 
Plastic tubing and unarmored tubing bundles shall be protected inside metal conduit or raceway. Tubing, conduit 
and raceway shall be rigidly fastened to structural supports using tubing clips or fasteners designed for that 
purpose. It shall not be attached to process piping or electrical conduits nor be attached to any surface with cable 
ties or perforated strapping. 
 
Transition from a multi-tube bundle to single tube runs shall be made in a junction box using compression type 
bulkhead unions. 
 
Plastic tubing should not be used at all where high or low (cryogenic) temperatures are encountered.   Exposed 
plastic tubing shall not be run near high temperature sources such as uninsulated steam pipe. 
 
Install all plastic tubing with sufficient slack in each straight run to assure that subsequent shrinkage will not 
cause the tubing to shrink into a state of stress.  It is strongly recommended that plastic tubing not be terminated 
the same day it is installed into the raceway in order to avoid this.  
 
Fittings shall not be installed near a tubing bend.  A length of straight tube, not deformed by bending, shall be 
required.  When a tubing section that contains a bend is being connected, the end section shall be in proper 
alignment with the fitting.  Springing the tube into position with the fitting shall not be permitted, as it may result 
in excessive stress and possible leakage. 
 
Instrument piping and tubing shall be as short as practicable between the source connection and the instrument 
location with the minimum number of fittings in order to minimize the potential for leakage. 
 
Wrap all tapered pipe threads with Teflon tape to prevent thread galling upon disconnection.  Do not allow the 
tape to extend past the last thread on the connection end.  
 
All tubing shall be installed in continuous length from: 
 
1. The instrument to the instrument air supply valve 
2. The instrument to a pneumatic junction box fitting or bulk head fitting 
3. The instrument to another instrument 
 
Make tubing unions in raceways, sheets, or groupings in junction boxes.  
 
Provide inserts on 3/8” OD and larger plastic tubing.  
 
3.5. 
TESTING 
 
Test pneumatic tubing system installations in accordance with ISA Standard ISA-7.0.01 “Quality Standard for 
Instrument Air”, Annex C.   
 
Records of all tests shall be maintained by the installer and shall be submitted to the Owner. The Owner may 
witness any tests. 
 
The instrument at the outlet end of the tubing under test shall remain connected whenever possible.  Allowance 
in the duration of the test shall be made to compensate for the additional volume in the instrument.  
 
Reconnect all instruments to the tubing system after successfully completing the test. Check the re-connections 
with a bubble test.  Apply a soap solution to the joint under test.  The joint is not properly sealed if bubbles form 
around the joint.  Reseal and recheck until the joint passes. 
 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
 
SECTION 409300 
INSTRUMENT CALIBRATION AND COMMISSIONING 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
Extent of the controls and instrumentation work is indicated on drawings and schedules and by requirements of 
this section.  This section covers the calibration and commissioning of the electronic and pneumatic 
instrumentation and controls. 
 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409010, 409050, 409100 and requirements of 
the Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 
01 General Requirements. 
 
Any deviations from the equipment components described in this section must be pre-approved by the Owner or 
Owner's Representative prior to purchase. 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Calibrate all instruments furnished or installed under Section 409100 which have functions that can be confirmed 
to operate correctly by testing. 
 
All functions of all instruments shall be tested for full and correct operation.  
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
CALIBRATION EQUIPMENT 
 
All calibration equipment shall be current, up-to-date models, of industrial instrumentation quality, and 
manufactured by a company regularly engaged in the production of industrial instrumentation calibration 
equipment.  
 
All calibration equipment shall have a readout resolution and accuracy that meets or exceeds (one order greater 
where possible) that of the instrument to be calibrated.  
 
All calibration equipment shall have a current verification of calibration certificate traceable to the National 
Institute of Standards and Technology.  A copy of this document shall be furnished to the Owner before this 
equipment is used for calibration and for all subsequent verification of calibration.  This documentation shall 
include an error report of the calibration.  
 
The error report of the calibration equipment shall be to an accuracy that meets or exceeds (one order greater 
where possible) the accuracy of the calibration equipment.  
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Instruments shall be calibrated before the required time of installation.  Instruments that have long lead times for 
delivery shall be calibrated in time to obtain and calibrate a replacement if necessary before the instrument is 
required for installation.  Instruments that have a replacement lead time greater than the time left before 
installation shall be calibrated as soon as possible.  The Owner shall be informed immediately of instruments in 
this category with which problems are encountered.  
 
All instruments shall be calibrated to within the manufacturer's stated accuracy.  
 
All components of an assembly shall be calibrated individually and then the assembly calibrated.  
 
On electronic instruments, simply using the internal simulation of the process output is not considered an 
acceptable calibration method. 
 
All flow and pressure measuring instruments shall be calibrated to indicate zero flow or pressure at the zero flow 
or pressure input value and to within the manufacturer's stated accuracy at the remaining points. 
 
All flow instruments designated key or critical will require comparative flowing with the use of a flow cart and 
traceable transfer flow device.   
 
The Contractor shall inform the Owner of all instruments requiring excessive calibration or which cannot be 
calibrated to within the specified accuracy limits.  The Owner will take appropriate action as required. 
 
3.2. 
CALIBRATION RECORDS 
 
Record all calibrations, checks, and tests made onto calibration sheets as the calibration is being performed.  The 
first calibration of the instrument shall be marked calibration number 1 (one) and subsequent re-calibrations shall 
be numbered sequentially.  
 
One of three (3) types of calibration sheets shall be used:  
 
Analog Instrument. 
Discrete Instrument (On/Off). 
Orifice Inspection. 
 
Some instruments will require more than one calibration sheet.  A modulating valve with a transducer, a 
positioner, and a position switch, for example, will require four (4) sheets; one each of analog calibration sheets 
for the transducer, the positioner, and the actuator; and one discrete calibration sheet for the position switch.  
When more than one calibration sheet is used, enter the sheet number as part of the total.  The entry for component 
tested shall show which component part is recorded on each sheet.  
 
All calibrations shall be recorded on a separate calibration sheet for each instrument or loop.  
All entries on calibration sheets shall be handwritten into the correct location for these entries and shall be made 
using blue water-proof ink by the person performing the calibration.  
 
Date of calibration shall be recorded on each calibration sheet for each instrument on the date the calibration is 
performed.  
 
Calibration sheets shall have all entries completed, except where noted otherwise on the calibration sheet.  The 
entry "N/A" can only be used for those entries that are non-applicable.  Any applicable test that was not performed 
shall have a notation entered that clearly indicates the test was not made.  The entry "N/P" will not be accepted.  
Not performing an applicable test must have Owner approval and the reason for not performing the test shall be 
recorded in the remarks section of the calibration sheet.  
 
The actual values of all data shall be entered.  Entries of "OK", a check mark, or similar is unacceptable.  
 
Manufacturer name, model, and serial number of the calibration equipment used for the calibration shall be 
recorded on the calibration sheet for each instrument. 
 
The calibration date of the calibration equipment and the calibration certificate number for the calibration 
equipment shall be recorded on the calibration sheet for each instrument.  
 
The name of the person performing the calibration and the date shall be recorded on the bottom of each calibration 
sheet.  
 
Instruments that are re-calibrated shall require a new calibration sheet, in which, after completed, shall be 
permanently filed with prior sheets and other associated design, installation, and maintenance records.  Copies of 
the calibration sheets shall be submitted to the Owner daily for inspection, with the originals collated for 
submission to the Owner immediately following project completion.  Calibration sheets and all other associated 
records pertaining to a particular instrument and subject to Owner-specified retention periods shall be made 
available to the Owner for maintenance.   
 
Each instrument shall have a small, pressure-sensitive adhesive sticker affixed when calibrated.  This shall have 
the date of calibration and the Calibrator's initials written on it in black, waterproof ink.  This sticker shall be 
placed upon an internal structure of the instrument where it shall be visible with the cover removed.  It shall not 
be placed on the cover exterior or interior.  Reasonable judgment shall be used for instruments for which this is 
impractical, e.g.; liquid filled pressure gauges, and items of like nature. 
 
Interlock relays, hand switches, pilot lights, and like items do not require formal calibration and shall be tested 
during check- out.  
 
3.3. 
CALIBRATION EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE 
 
All calibration equipment shall be maintained under the supervision of qualified personnel to prevent 
compromising the integrity of the equipment.  
 
Equipment Abuse: The following actions shall constitute abuse of the calibration equipment: 
1. Equipment storage in a space that does not meet the storage environment specifications of the 
manufacturer; 
2. Failure to acclimate equipment to an environment meeting the specifications of the manufacturer 
before use and used in these conditions; 
3. Failure to ship calibration equipment properly.  Equipment shall be shipped crated, marked 
'Scientific Instrument', and shipped with special handling service via a commercial courier, e.g.; 
Purolator, Federal Express, United Parcel Service. 
4. Transporting un-crated calibration equipment in the trunk of an automobile or in the bed of a truck. 
 
Any calibration equipment which has been tampered with, over-ranged, or abused shall have all damage repaired 
and shall have its calibration re-certified before being used again. 
 
3.4. 
GENERAL CALIBRATION PROCEDURES FOR ANALOG INSTRUMENTS 
 
All analog instruments (to include modulating valves) shall be given a three-point calibration check of the 
 
instrument after calibration (as left).  This shall be accomplished by applying an input signal equivalent to 0, 50 
and 100 percent of the input range of the instrument.  This check shall be made with both an increasing signal 
from below zero percent to one hundred percent and a decreasing signal from above one hundred percent to zero 
percent with no overshoot or back up. The percentage test points may be changed in cases where it is more 
reasonable to do so; i.e.; it may be more practical to test a square root extraction module at other points to obtain 
a more meaningful test.  
 
The calibration may be made at less than three points for instruments that are not normally checked at this many 
points.  This includes pressure gauges and thermometers.  Other instruments, such as pH meters, conductivity 
meters, vapor fractionating analyzers, infra-red absorption analyzers, and the like are normally calibrated using a 
set of known samples. 
  
All analog instruments with digital communication shall be read and recorded at the first (nearest to the sending 
device) accessible point of raw data.  The data register should not be scaled or in engineering units but merely an 
A/D conversion of the proportional magnitude respective to the device’s range and bit resolution.  Scaling and 
engineering units of same are checked (verified or validated) elsewhere.  
 
3.5. 
GENERAL CALIBRATION PROCEDURES FOR DISCRETE INSTRUMENTS 
 
All discrete instruments, pressure switches, temperature switches, on/off valves, position switches, flow switches, 
and like items, shall be tested at the operation point for proper functioning and adjusted as required.  Adjustments 
made shall be recorded on the calibration sheet.  The actual operating point shall be recorded on the calibration 
sheet.  
 
This check shall be made with an increasing signal from below the trip point until the point of actuation for high 
condition switches and with a decreasing signal from above the trip point until the point of actuation for low 
condition switches.  
 
3.6. 
SPECIFIC CALIBRATION REQUIREMENTS 
 
Mass Flow Instruments: These shall be calibrated by the manufacturer.  An appropriate calibration certificate with 
full details of the calibration including as-found and as-left conditions these shall be obtained from the 
manufacturer for each element/transmitter.  Requirements of manufacturer’s calibration shall be no less stringent 
than this specification. 
 
TOC/Conductivity analyzers: These shall be calibrated by the manufacturer.  An appropriate calibration 
certificate with full details of the calibration including as-found and as-left conditions shall be obtained from the 
manufacturer for each element/transmitter.  Requirements of manufacturer’s calibration shall be no less stringent 
than this specification. 
 
Level Instruments: Level probe type instruments using capacitance, conductivity, or RF shall be calibrated in 
accordance with the manufacturer's procedure.  Float or displacer type instruments shall be calibrated by one of 
the following methods: 1) By using calibration weights to shop calibrate and confirm in service, 2) By using a 
well to hold liquid of a known height and of a specific gravity which matches the process.  
 
Pressure and Differential Pressure Instruments: Calibrate using a pressure source.  Pressure instruments with 
remote seals shall be calibrated using a flange jig fitted to the diaphragm face.  The calibration of instruments 
with remote seals shall correctly simulate the different field elevations of the installed transmitter and seal.  The 
calibration of pressure instruments connected with filled impulse lines shall correctly simulate the effect of the 
fill fluid.  
 
Resistance Temperature Detectors (RTD) These shall be checked with an ohmmeter for continuity, and, for 
ungrounded RTDs, shorts to the sheath.  RTDs shall be checked using a temperature bath, or baths, capable of 
temperature variations as required by the span of the instrument.    
 
Analog Temperature Transmitters having RTD inputs shall be calibrated first using a decade box, and then finally 
using the actual temperature element that will be used with the transmitter in the aforementioned temperature 
bath(s).  
 
Discrete Temperature Instruments shall be checked using a temperature bath, or baths, capable of temperature 
variations as required by the span of the instrument.  
 
Valves: All valves shall be leak-tested in the closed position and shall meet the specified leak rating.  It is 
recommended this check be made initially.  Valves, modulating and on/off, shall be fully closed with an input 
signal corresponding to fully closed.  Valves, modulating and on/off, which are fail closed shall be fully closed 
with the design conditions for full closed in effect.  
 
Modulating Valves: These valves shall be calibrated to obtain a fully closed valve prior to the signal reaching the 
closed valve value of the signal to ensure the valve closes with the control signal.  This shall be between one (1) 
percent and two (2) percent for air-to-open and between 98 percent and 99 percent for air-to-close.  Check the 
actuator and trim for the amount of hysteresis.  Actuators with properly adjusted stem packing are expected to 
have less than 0.2-PSI hysteresis.  Inform the Owner of valves with sticky actuators.  Actuator and trim shall be 
checked for full travel as specified by the manufacturer.  Set the travel indicator to indicate closed at the fully 
closed position.  Set the actuator to the manufacturer's stated bench setting as a separate calibration from the 
positioner calibration.  Calibrate the positioner to obtain full travel proportional to the positioner input signal.  
Calibrate the transducer.  Calibrate the assembly to obtain a fully closed valve at the required signal for fully 
closed.  
 
On/off valves: Check the valve for correctly installed pneumatic connections and solenoid valves.  Check the 
valve for proper direction of operation and fail position.  Check the valve for full travel.  Check that the valve 
closes fully.  Set the speed controls to Owner's requirements.  
 
Valve Position Switches: These switches, on modulating and on/off valves, shall be checked using a slowly 
changing input signal to approach and reach the point of switch actuation.  On/off valves will require a restriction 
in the air line to do this.  This will allow checking that an on/off valve position switch does not indicate closed 
should the valve stick open a small amount.  Valves, with the exception of manual valves with position switches, 
shall not be manually operated to accomplish this calibration.  Valves shall have all other components of the 
assembly calibrated before the position switches are calibrated.  
 
The Analog signal being brought to the modulating valve shall be the signal used to position the valve for 
calibration of the position switches.  The value of this signal shall be the value entered onto the Calibration Sheet 
for the switch.  The pneumatic signal to the valve shall be used for those valves having remote transducers, i.e.; 
the transducer is not mounted directly onto the valve assembly.  
 
The position of on/off valves upon switch actuation shall be the entry entered for these and shall be the Calibrator's 
visual interpretation of the position of the trim.  Fully-closed, fully-opened, and not-closed position switches on 
valves shall be calibrated to actuate as close to the valve mechanical stop as is practical.  
 
Small gauges on valve positioners and air-set regulators require no testing.  These shall be replaced if considered 
defective.  
 
pH Analytical Systems: Remove the probe and insert into buffer solutions having pH levels of the process at the 
process extremes and the process midpoint.  
 
Other Ion Specific Analytical Systems: Remove the probe and insert into a container of fluid having similar 
characteristics as the process fluid.  Check for proper analyzer operation.  Remove the probe and recheck zero.  
 
Electrical Power Measuring Instruments: Watt transmitters shall be shop calibrated and confirmed in operation.  
Shop calibrate current transmitters to the anticipated current flow from the current transformer.  Confirm this 
 
Orifice Plates: Concentric, square-edged, beveled-relief; record the results of this check on the orifice inspection 
sheet.  These shall be checked for conformity to the specifications for pipe size, ANSI rating, material, bore size, 
bore configuration, specified vent/drain, and correct upstream side tang stamping of plates with tangs.  The orifice 
plate shall be inspected for bowing and warping.  The orifice plate shall be flat to within 0.02 (two hundredths) 
inch per inch of the inside diameter of pipe size and schedule into which the orifice plate will be installed.  The 
dam bore shall be inspected for correct configuration: The straight bore of the dam shall not be more than 1/50 
(one fiftieth) of the dam height.  The bevel shall not be less than 45 degrees measured from the piping centerline.  
The orifice plate shall be inspected for nicks and scratches.  There shall be none on the upstream or on the 
downstream face.  The upstream edge of the dam shall be inspected for burrs and sharpness.  There shall be no 
burrs or ridging on this edge and there shall be no reflected light from this edge when viewed from any angle with 
normal vision in a shaded north light.  Orifice plates, integral orifices, flow nozzles, and head-producers other 
than concentric, square-edged, beveled-relief orifice plates shall be inspected for conformity with the 
specifications and the manufacturer's information.  Record the results of this check on the orifice inspection sheet.  
 
Items Which the Owner May Approve for Minimal Calibration and Records: Thermometers and pressure gauges 
shall be checked at a point near the operating point, unless the Owner has agreed to accept the vendor's calibration 
check.  These shall have a pressure adhesive sticker applied showing the date of test and the Calibrator's initials.  
With Owner approval, the vendor's sticker, if present, shall suffice on these items.  
 
Sight glasses, level gauges, and like items need no testing or checking other than the receiving check that these 
items are actually as specified.  No sticker is required, unless the instrumentation Contractor wishes to do such 
for his own record purposes.  
 
Small gauges on valve positioners and air-set regulators require no testing.  These shall be replaced if considered 
defective.  
 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
SECTION 409350 
CONTROL PANELS
