This section covers the procurement of control panels. 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
REFERENCE 
 
This section covers the procurement of control panels. 
 
The Work under this section is subject to requirements of Sections 409010 and 409050 and requirements of the 
Contract Documents including the general documents, supplementary conditions, and sections under Division 01 
General Requirements.  
 
Any deviations from the equipment components described in this section must be pre-approved by the Owner or 
Owner's Representative prior to purchase. 
 
1.2. 
DEFINITIONS 
 
The contractor responsible for control panel fabrication will be referred to as the Vendor in this specification.  
 
The Owner or the Owner's appointed representative shall be referred to as the Owner in this Specification.  
 
Control and instrument panels shall be collectively referred to as control panels within this specification.   
 
1.3. 
SCOPE OF WORK 
 
The Vendor shall furnish all materials, supplies, labor, tools and equipment, transportation, and incidentals 
required to make each control panel complete, fully equipped, fully functional, and fully outfitted in all respects, 
in accordance with the best industry standards and practice and complying with all applicable codes.   The NFPA 
79 and 70 (NEC Article 409) standards shall be followed unless otherwise noted.   All required material and work 
to completely execute the intent of the work shall be incidental to and included.  All discrepancies in the 
description or the omission of any material, equipment, device, or parts which would be detrimental to operation, 
or serviceability of the control system or control panel and the inclusion of which is generally accepted good 
industry practice shall be brought to the attention of the Owner.  All devices included in this scope of work should 
be 120 VAC / VDC or under.  Power devices should not be placed in control panels.  Separate enclosures would 
be used for power devices and their associated controllers (e.g., motor controllers, VFDs, SCRs, servo drives, 
etc.) but not limited to these devices. 
 
This document shall address the minimum requirements for control panel design.   This specification shall 
describe the technical and quality assurance requirements for the design, fabrication, testing, and delivery of 
control panels. The control panels shall form a part of the control, protection, and instrumentation systems of the 
project, which shall control operation of, provide protection for, and monitor the performance of project 
equipment, respectively. 
 
It is not the intent of this specification to completely specify all details of design and construction.  Suggested 
changes to these specifications that improve the installation, operation, or effect economy of fabrication at no 
sacrifice in performance or quality will be considered, provided suitable notification is made.  This specification 
shall not eliminate consideration of the Vendor’s factory practice, which may receive approval if found equivalent 
or superior to the requirements covered in this specification. 
 
All control panels shall be UL 508A labeled unless approved otherwise by the Owner.  Components shall be UL-
listed in instances where the Owner approves a deviation from the UL508A label requirement.  CE marking is 
not an acceptable alternative to UL listing or UL labeling. 
 
 
 
 
 
1.4. 
REFERENCE SPECIFICATIONS 
 
The publications listed below form part of this specification.  Each publication shall be the latest revision and 
addendum in effect on the date this specification is issued for construction unless noted otherwise.  Work included 
in this specification shall conform to the applicable provisions of these publications, except as modified by the 
requirements specified herein or the details of the drawings. 
 
A. UL 508 - Standard for Industrial Control Equipment 
B. UL 508 A – UL standard for Safety Industrial Control Enclosures  
C. UL 698A - Standard for Industrial Control Panels Relating to Hazardous (Classified) Locations 
D. ANSI/ISA S5.1, Instrument Symbols, and Identification 
E. ANSI/ISA S5.4, Instrument Loop Diagrams 
F. ASME B31.1, Power Piping 
G. ASTM - American Society for Testing & Materials, 1248, 1974, standard specific for 
polyethylene plastics 
H. NEC - National Electrical Code 
I. 
NEMA - National Electrical Manufacturer's Association  
J. 
NFPA 79 and NFPA 70 Article 409. 
K. NFPA – National Fire Protection Association 
L. OSHA - Occupational Safety and Health Administration 
M. ISA - International Society of Automation 
• 
ISA RP60.2 - Control Center Design Guide and Terminology 
• 
ISA RP60.4 - Documentation for Control Centers 
• 
ISA RP60.6 - Nameplates, Labels and Tags for Control Centers 
• 
ISA RP60.8 - Electrical Guide for Control Centers 
• 
ISA RP60.9 - Piping Guide for Control Centers 
• 
ISA RP60.11 - Crating, Shipping and Handling for Control Centers 
In the event of conflict between the requirements of this specification and an above referenced standard, the above 
standards will govern.  Such conflicts shall be brought to the attention of the Owner. 
 
1.5. 
PHOTOGRAPHS 
 
The Owner shall be allowed to photograph the panels at any stage of production with a one (1) normal business 
day advance notice to the Vendor.  
 
1.6. 
INSPECTION AND TESTING 
 
The Owner shall be allowed to visit the Vendor's shop at any time for inspection of the panel(s) to determine if 
the work conforms to the required dimensions, tolerances, wiring, and assembly in compliance with the contract 
terms.  
 
The Owner shall be notified two weeks in advance of scheduled tests and completion of fabrication.  
 
The inspections or any waivers of inspection do not release the Vendor from compliance with any part of this 
Specification.  
 
1.7. 
DEVIATIONS FROM SPECIFICATIONS OR DRAWINGS 
 
Any deviations from the Drawings or Specifications which the Vendor wishes to implement shall have written 
authorization from the Owner before work on that deviation begins.  
 
 
1.8. 
SHIPPING 
 
Two (2) normal business days’ notice shall be provided to the Owner before shipment.  
 
Two packing lists shall be packed with the shipment and duplicates shall be mailed to the Owner.  Packing lists 
shall include all items shipped and reference the Owner's purchase order number.  
 
1.9. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
The Vendor shall submit a written control panel test procedure to the Owner for review and approval prior to 
executing the tests.  The procedures shall detail installation inspection procedures, operation inspection 
procedures, and execution of these procedures.  
 
The Owner reserves the right to reproduce any drawing or print received from the Vendor, as may be required 
during the design and construction of this project and the preparation of the plant manual, despite any notice 
prohibiting the same appearing on the drawing or print. 
 
After the order is placed, the Vendor shall submit all data and drawings listed in the governing scope specification 
as issued with the Request for Quotation. 
 
The Owner job order number, purchase order number, project name, control panel name, and control panel 
identification number shall be shown on each drawing. 
 
The drawings submitted shall show the following as a minimum: 
• 
General Arrangement drawings of the external and internal layouts, with Bill of Materials detailing 
responsibility of supply. 
• 
Cross sections and details, as required, to satisfy the Owner that all components are in conformance 
with the intent of the specification and are satisfactory from the standpoint of design and physical 
arrangement. 
• 
Internal control panel wiring diagrams showing terminal numbers, wire and cable labels, wire colors 
and gauge, and component labels. 
• 
Pneumatic tubing layout, showing tubing labels and component labels. 
• 
All information required by the Owner for design and location of all connecting furnished structural, 
mechanical, or electrical items such as foundations, steel supports, piping, ducts, cables, conduit, 
and so forth. 
• 
Dimensions and weight of the equipment. 
• 
120 VAC power requirements, including FLA. 
 
After review by the Owner, a copy marked APPROVED, or REJECTED, REVISE AND RESUBMIT will be 
returned to the Vendor.  If marked APPROVED, the Vendor may be directed to incorporate any changes per 
document mark-ups and/or attachments and resubmit to for record.   If marked REVISE AND RESUBMIT, the 
required changes shall be incorporated by the Vendor and clearly identified, and the drawings shall again be 
submitted to the Owner for approval.  If the Vendor elects not to incorporate the revisions, the Vendor shall inform 
the Owner that the suggested revisions cannot be made without prejudice to the Vendor’s responsibility under 
warranty. 
 
Arrangements for production scheduling shall not be deferred pending approval of drawings. 
 
1.10. QUALITY ASSURANCE 
 
General 
 
Vendor shall have in effect at all times a Quality Assurance (QA) program that clearly establishes the authority 
and responsibility of those responsible for the QA program.  Persons performing quality functions shall have 
 
sufficient and well-defined responsibility and authority to enforce quality requirements, to identify, initiate, 
recommend, and provide solutions to quality problems, and to verify the effectiveness of the solutions. 
 
Vendor shall ensure that all control panels are designed and delivered in agreement with this specification.  
Assemblies and subassemblies shall be factory tested in accordance with the Vendor’s standard quality assurance 
program. 
 
Notification 
 
Prior to the start of any fabrication, the Vendor shall notify the Owner and obtain a written release from the Owner 
to proceed with fabrication of the material covered by this specification.  This fabrication shall be based on the 
drawings reviewed and approved by the Owner. 
 
The Vendor is subject to audits, inspections, and witnessing by the Owner or its authorized representative to 
ensure compliance with the requirements of the specification, codes, drawings, and the Owner-approved 
submittals. Any exercise of, or failure to exercise, the Owner’s rights to inspect, witness, or audit, and any 
subsequent approval, shall not relieve the Vendor of the obligation to comply with terms/conditions of Purchase 
Order/Contract. 
 
The Owner may authorize the Vendor to proceed without the Owner or its authorized representative present to 
witness the event.  However, the Owner may require that the Vendor repeat any activity performed without proper 
notification. 
 
Storage and Handling 
 
Items of equipment shipped to the Vendor for mounting and wiring shall be received, inspected, stored, and 
protected against loss or damage before, during, and after installation in the control panels. Receiving inspection 
shall include checking for shortage or damage and for conformance with the description of each item on the 
equipment list. 
 
Vendor shall promptly submit to the Owner copies of receiving records, including written reports of damage, 
shortages, or nonconformity of description. 
 
Environmental Requirements 
 
Control panels shall be designed to withstand damage and protect their contents from suspended dust particles.  
Specific attention shall be paid to all openings of the control panel to ensure a dust tight connection.  Unless 
approved by the Owner, all openings are to be gasketed and sealed to achieve an overall NEMA rating as follows:  
enclosures located in production areas shall be NEMA 4X, brushed 304 stainless steel; enclosures located in 
mechanical areas/chases shall be NEMA 12; and enclosures located in mechanical areas/chases where humid or 
wet conditions are expected shall be NEMA 4.  Deviations for these NEMA ratings must be approved by the 
Owner.  All panels shall include manufacturer’s recommended keyed locking handle, back panel and grounding 
bar. The back panel shall be powder-coated steel and installed per manufacturer’s recommendations.  Panel 
penetrations are to be made through the bottom and sides of the panel.  Penetrations through the top are prohibited. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
ENCLOSURES 
 
Panels shall be fabricated as detailed on drawings.  Purged panels (where applicable) shall be built to conform 
with NFPA 70 (NEC) and NFPA 496 requirements for Purged and Pressurized Enclosures in Hazardous Areas.     
All control panels shall be UL 508, or UL 698A, labeled, depending on electrical classification or use.  All 
control panels shall be labeled per NFPA 70E to indicate “Arc Flash Hazard” and “Shock Hazard” analysis has 
 
All electrical materials shall be UL approved, or meet UL specifications where approval has not been obtained, 
unless written permission is received from the Owner for the use of non-approved devices.  
 
Lifting Lugs:  All floor mounted control panels shall be provided with two (2) removable lifting lugs. 
 
2.2. 
PAINT 
 
The control panel exterior shall be finished with the panel manufacturer’s standard paint.  (This does not apply to 
stainless steel or fiberglass panels). 
 
Supplier must provide touch-up paint to repair any damage during the installation of the panels. The Owner shall 
be allowed to specify the paint color or approve the manufacturer’s standard paint color. 
 
2.3. 
WIRE AND CABLE 
 
Wire and cable shall be as specified in Section 409150 Instrument Wire and Cable. 
 
Cable and connectors for instrument bus systems shall be as specified in 409175 Instrument Bus. 
 
Panel wiring shall maintain segregation between 120VAC, 24VDC, and Intrinsically Safe. 
 
2.4. 
TERMINAL BLOCKS AND BREAKERS 
 
Terminal Blocks shall be as specified on drawings. 
 
All terminal blocks shall be provided with appropriate spacers, end barriers, end anchors, jumpers, bridge bars 
and DIN rail.  Size circuit breaker and fuse terminal blocks as indicated on drawings.  Provide a minimum of five 
(5) spare fuses for each fuse size and type. 
 
All enclosures shall have a minimum of 20% spare terminal blocks and DIN rail space.   
 
2.5. 
CONTROL PANEL FACE MOUNTED NAMEPLATES 
 
See Section 200553“Tagging and Identification”. 
 
2.6. 
CONTROL PANEL INTERIOR MOUNTED NAMEPLATES 
 
See Section 200553 “Tagging and Identification”. 
 
Provide power source nameplates for all panels listing the power source(s) feeding a panel.  Indicate the source 
panel name and circuit number(s).  Information on power source shall be provided to the Vendor by the Owner 
and/or Engineer. 
 
2.7. 
WIRE, CABLE, AND TUBE LABELS 
 
Each individual wire, cable and pneumatic tube in power, control, indication, and instrumentation circuits shall 
be provided with identification markers at the point of termination.  Locate the label within 2" of the wire, cable, 
or tube termination.  Identification markers shall be labeled as indicated on drawings.  Where not indicated, 
markers shall be labeled by terminal block designation. 
 
Provide wire and tube labels of the printable, self-laminating type.  Labels shall be vinyl with white printable area 
and machine laser-printed with the appropriate identification number using waterproof ink.  Hand marking shall 
not be acceptable.  Labels shall be Panduit, Brady, or equal. 
 
 
2.8. 
MOUNTING FASTENERS 
 
Devices:  All devices shall be rigidly attached with properly sized stainless steel screws or bolts so they may be 
removed.  
 
2.9. 
GROUND BUS 
 
Earth Ground:  A copper ground bus shall be installed at the bottom of each control panel.  A minimum size of 
1/4 inch by 1 inch by 12 inches is preferred; a smaller size can be used if approved by the Owner.  The bus shall 
be drilled at each end for extension and shall have a suitable indent/compression-type lug bolted to it near each 
end for the field-installed ground cable.  Panels shall have an 8 AWG ground cable.  The ground bus shall be 
connected to all control panel steel. 
 
Isolated Ground:  Where required by the Owner, a second similar ground bus shall be installed and shall be 
insulated from all control panel steel. Typically, this requirement is for control panels that are associated with the 
site Process Control System. 120 UPS power ground and instrumentation requiring 24 VDC power shall have the 
DC common connected to this isolated bus system.  When instruments require signal points or cable shields to be 
grounded, this bus shall be used.  All other grounds shall be connected to the uninsulated ground bus. 
 
Ground bonding jumpers will be placed between enclosure doors and internal panels (having mounted electrical 
devices) and the main body of the enclosure.  
 
Ground wires, if used, shall be installed so as to be visible and accessible after all other wiring has been completed. 
 
2.10. EMERGENCY STOP (E-STOP) 
 
Where required by the Owner, E-Stops shall be provided.  E-Stops shall be a hard-wired interrupt of the skid or 
equipment functioning that will stop all pumps and motors and return all valves and outputs to their failsafe 
condition.   E-Stops shall be a red mushroom head type with a guard to prevent accidental contact.   
 
E-Stop buttons shall be provided with normally closed contacts for power interruption and an additional set of 
contacts for wiring to the PCS for monitoring purposes.  E-Stop buttons shall be maintained type. 
 
E-Stops shall be located on the control panel for convenient access and shall be appropriately labeled with a 
yellow legend plate. 
 
E-Stops shall be wired to terminal blocks and be jumpered in series to a minimum or two (2) additional terminal 
blocks as to allow addition of other interlock device wiring from the field. 
 
An appropriate safety relay shall be used to provide E-Stop to additional equipment. 
 
2.11. COOLING 
 
The manufacturer shall calculate internal panel maximum temperature based on 150% heat load, factoring 
maximum environmental conditions for temperature.  The vendor shall utilize this calculation and the maximum 
area humidity, to determine if enclosure cooling is required.  The vendor will specify, at time of bid, the method 
of cooling required in order to bring all installed components within manufacture’s environmental specifications.   
 
Where indicated by the Owner, or thru heat load calculations, control panels shall be provided with 
thermostatically controlled cooling fans or an air conditioner to keep the contained electronic components below 
the maximum recommended temperature.  If an air conditioning unit is required, it shall be provided with integral 
controls, be UL rated, and come equipped with a fully integrated condensate evaporation system.  All panel 
cooling apparatus must maintain the NEMA rating of the panel.  In clean, production spaces, any exhausted air 
must be filtered to minimize particulates to the area. 
 
2.12. POWER SUPPLIES 
 
Vendor shall provide 24 Volt DC power supplies for powering instrument loops.  Power supply shall be switch 
mode and shall be sized to power all instruments and components associated with the control panel.  Power 
supplies shall have load-sensing circuits.  Power supplies shall be sized for a minimum of 50% spare capacity to 
service future needs. 
 
Redundant power supplies (with alarm function) for critical instruments / controls shall be provided. 
 
2.13. TERMINALS, BREAKERS, AND FUSE BLOCKS 
 
Provide fused terminals with blown fuse indication for all discrete input and output points.  For analog loops, 
provide terminals with test lead connection for loop testing ability where test leads can be placed in series with 
the instrument loop without affecting the loop wiring.  Provide solderless, crimp, insulated spade lug connectors 
at instrument, device, and terminal connections.  Bare wires and ring connector connectors are not allowed at 
instrument and device connections.  On screw clamp type terminal blocks, provide insulated, crimp ferrules.  
 
Provide din rail mounted, thermal magnetic breakers, sized for 150% of total load for all 120VAC external power 
feed connections. 
 
All terminals, breakers, and fuse blocks require UL approval. 
 
2.14. WIREWAY 
 
All wire routing within a panel shall be routed in plastic wireway trough.  Refer to Sections 3.4 and 3.5 for 
additional information regarding wireways. 
 
2.15. PNEUMATIC ACCESSORIES 
 
All pneumatic accessories required for conditioning and routing of instrument air supply shall be provided with 
the control panel. 
 
When equipment requires both process (product contact) and instrument air, they shall be supplied to the 
equipment by separate systems and connections and shall be routed in dedicated systems. 
 
Air Preparation 
 
An integral air preparation system shall be used to set individual instrument air feeds to a control panel.  The 
system, at a minimum shall consist of the following components: 
 
• 
Self-Contained Coalescing Filter Regulator w/ pressure gauge 
• 
Isolation Valve 
 
A self-contained pressure regulator with integral coalescing filter shall be used to set instrument air pressure to 
that required for normal operation of downstream pneumatic valve actuators.  It shall be rated for 125 psig supply 
air and be capable of regulating downstream air pressure to as low as 5 psig.  A manual hand operator shall be 
employed for downstream pressure adjustment and shall have an integral locking ring.  The body material shall 
be plastic with plastic and stainless steel internals.  Pneumatic and gauge connections shall be ¼” FPT or larger. 
 
Each regulator shall be provided with an integral pressure gauge that will display downstream pressure.  The 
range of the gauge shall be 0-100 psig.  A pressure gauge shall also be supplied and installed upstream of the 
regulator to measure supply pressure and shall have a range of 0-150 psig. 
 
 
Integral coalescing filters shall be 5 microns with a clear polycarbonate debris bowl to remove particulates that 
may be in the air stream.  The debris bowl shall be provided with a bottom mounted drain valve to blow down 
debris. 
 
An inline shutoff valve shall be upstream of the regulator.  The valve shall be plastic body with a knife gate 
operator and downstream relief capability. 
 
If air pressure is critical to the operation of the equipment, a pressure switch must be provided which will interlock 
the equipment operation. 
 
Air preparation systems for panels installed in clean process areas shall be installed inside of control panels with 
a breather vent installed in panel for exhaust. 
 
Air Distribution Manifolds 
 
Air distribution within a control panel shall be made with aluminum pre-manufactured blocks.  Each individual 
air feed from a distribution block shall have a quarter-turn plug valve for isolation. 
 
Pneumatic Tubing 
 
Refer to Section 409200 Pneumatic Instrument Tubing, for requirements. 
  
2.16. DISCONNECTS 
 
Unless approved otherwise by the Owner, lockable, disconnect switch shall be provided for all control panels 
with one or more power feeds of voltage 480VAC or greater.   Disconnect switches shall be interlocked with all 
enclosure doors so that the either the disconnect switch must be an open circuit for the enclosure door to open, or 
the opening of the enclosure door trips the disconnect switch.  Where disconnect switches are used, they must be 
externally defeatable to allow for trouble shooting without interrupting panel power. 
 
The panel manufacturer shall provide power source nameplates for all panels listing the power source(s) feeding 
a panel.  Indicate the source panel name and circuit number(s).  Information on power source shall be provided 
to the Vendor by the Owner and/or Engineer. 
 
2.17. LOCKS 
 
Doors or hinged panels for enclosures shall be able to be secured with a lock.  Doors equipped with mechanical 
locks are preferred.  Keys shall be removable in both the locked and unlocked positions. All control panels shall 
be keyed the same.  
 
Control panels with mechanical clamps in lieu of a keyed door shall provide a location for a future padlock (by 
others) or an alternate means of securing the door, such as a lockable disconnect.  The Vendor shall submit any 
alternate locking method to the Owner for approval. 
 
2.18. SPACE FOR FUTURE EXPANSION 
 
Where future equipment is indicated on project sketches or drawings, cutouts shall not be made unless specifically 
authorized by the Owner.  Future equipment areas shall be kept clear of the control panel stiffening members, 
rear-mounted equipment, wiring, and any other interference. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
The following are mandatory hold points for which prior notification to the Owner is required: 
 
• 
Approval of Vendor drawings by Owner 
• 
Functional testing (by the Owner or its authorized representative). 
• 
Release for shipment. 
 
3.1. 
PANEL CONSTRUCTION 
 
All enclosures shall be purchased as standard, out of the catalog.  Custom-fabricated enclosures require approval 
of the Owner.  Particular care shall be used to ensure that all enclosures are smooth, flat, and free from dents, 
cracks, or other imperfections; and that cutting, and fabrication do not result in warping, buckling, or other 
distortion. 
 
The enclosure seams shall be continuously welded without leaks.  The welds shall be ground smooth and clean.  
All slag, scale, and spatter shall be removed.  All exterior corners shall be rounded and ground smooth to a 
nominal 1/16" radius to provide a neat appearance.  All interior edges shall be ground smooth to prevent damage 
to wiring, cables, and tubing.  
 
Panel and door stiffeners, as well as internal bracing, shall be provided to ensure adequate rigidity and support 
for door-mounted equipment.  All bracings shall be on the panel's interior.  No evidence of fastening shall appear 
on the panel exterior.  
 
Internal bracing for lifting lugs shall be provided around the bolt holes suitable for supporting the panels.  
 
Enclosures shall be painted steel and have a minimum rating of NEMA 12 for dry non-production areas, NEMA 
4 for damp non-production areas, NEMA 4X (304/316L Stainless Steel) for all production areas.  Additional 
NEMA requirements may be specified in project design documents.  Custom built enclosures shall not be 
allowed unless approved in advance by the Owner or the Owner’s representative. 
 
Complete panel design shall provide space for cable and conduit entries on side or bottom.  Plinth bases can only 
be used with prior approval by the Owner or the Owner’s representative. 
 
3.2. 
DEVICE MOUNTING 
 
All interior devices, Instruments, and electrical equipment shall be rigidly mounted on panel back plane or 
subpanel.   All mounted devices installed inside the enclosures and as panel features on the enclosures shall be 
located so connections can be easily made and ample room exists for servicing each item.  Every component in 
and on the enclosures shall be removable without affecting operation of the other components.  
 
Separate enclosures shall be used for devices that require a supply voltage greater than 120VAC or may produce 
harmonics.  These devices include but are not limited to motor controllers, VFDs, SCRs, and servo drives, etc. 
 
Maintain device segregation based on “type” (AC, DC, IS and communication) in order to facilitate the 
segregation of the device’s wiring. 
 
All components shall be installed according to the manufacturer's instructions.  
 
Rivets or double face adhesive tape shall not be used for any fastening. 
 
All devices shall be DIN rail mounted where possible. 
 
All devices shall be completely installed prior to terminating any wire or tubing. 
 
Pre-punch all holes and verify alignment before drilling subpanel.  Provide protection (or remove) for all the 
mounted devices from drippings (cutting oil), drillings or filings.  Collect and remove all oil, drillings and filings.   
 
All devices shall be labeled per fabrication design drawings. 
 
Cutouts  
 
No distortion of panels is permitted because of machining cutouts or mounting Instruments and devices.  
 
Cutouts shall be smooth and shall not have any irregularity from the desired shape.  
 
Openings shall not be made by flame cutting or arc-cutting.  
 
Cutouts, sub-panels, and drilling for mounting shall be aligned to keep the devices in a group in vertical and 
horizontal alignment.  
 
No field conduit knock-outs may be cut at the Vendor's panel shop.  External conduit entries will be field punched 
not drilled.  
 
3.3. 
RACEWAY 
 
Raceways shall be installed along vertical or horizontal runs to present a neat appearance. Angled runs are not 
acceptable.  
 
Wireway  
 
The wireway for internal wire routing shall be as indicated on drawings.  Where not indicated, wireway shall be 
white slotted plastic trough with snap-on cover.  Wireway for intrinsically safe (IS) wiring shall be blue slotted 
plastic trough with snap-on covers.  Maintain segregation between AC, DC, IS and communication system’s 
wiring.  A separate IS panel is preferred with clear delineation between “safe” and “non-safe” sides. 
 
All wireways shall be permanently fastened into the sub-panels using 10/32 screws. Double face adhesive tape 
shall never be used for any fastening. 
 
Wireway covers shall be labeled with the wiring type (e.g., 24VDC or 120VAC or IS) 
 
Plastic wire wraps and plastic adhesive anchors shall be used to bundle and secure wiring and cables.  
 
Flexible sleeves shall be used for protection of wire bundles that cross the door hinge. 
 
3.4. 
ELECTRICAL 
 
Wiring 
 
All wiring between devices and terminal blocks shall be in wireways except for dressing out to make terminations.  
Wireway fill shall not exceed 40% fill.  
 
Where wiring must be outside wireway, it shall be neatly arranged, supported, and bundled with nylon tie-wraps.  
Flexible sleeves for protection of each wire bundle that pass across the door hinge shall be provided sufficient 
slack in wiring bundles shall be allowed so that the door can fully open. Wiring shall be arranged so as to be 
readily accessible for inspection and maintenance, and in no case shall wiring arrangement impede access to 
control panel mounted devices or spaces for future equipment. 
 
Low-level DC signal wiring shall be routed separately from AC wiring.   
 
Two or more wires run together shall be clamped or tied in straight lay bundles at no more than 12-inch intervals.  
Ties or clamps shall be nonmetallic. 
 
Copper grounding lugs shall be provided for electrical grounding of all metal panels. Lugs are to be sized for the 
system requirements but in no case shall be less than #8.  
 
Terminations 
 
All stranded conductors shall be neatly landed and terminated in the terminal blocks.  Breakage or intentional 
strand removal (to reduce the conductor’s cross section) of stranded wire shall not be permitted.  (Solid conductors 
are NEVER permitted.) 
 
Terminal strips shall have marking strips with terminal block number and point identification indelibly marked 
for all terminations from the terminal block manufacturer. Identification shall be the terminal block numbers and 
point numbers shown on Vendor’s wiring diagrams as approved by the Owner.   
 
All connections to control panel-mounted equipment shall be made on one side of the blocks with no more than 
two (2) wires connected under a single terminal screw.  All stranded conductors shall be neatly landed and 
terminated in the terminal blocks.  Where two wires are landed under a single terminal screw, an appropriately 
sized lug that accepts two wires must be used. 
 
Wire lugs must be used for all terminal connections, and the wires shall be terminated with indent/compression 
type lugs with spade tongues.  Proper crimping tools shall be used, and the Vendor shall maintain them in a 
properly calibrated condition.  Each wire shall be continuous between terminations.  No intermediate splices shall 
be used. 
 
Each control panel will be supplied with 20% spare terminal blocks. This percentage will be calculated as a 
percentage of and added on to the amount of I/O terminated in the control panel.  
 
Provide adequate safety shielding for terminations greater than 50 Volts. 
 
3.5. 
PNEUMATIC 
 
Tubing 
 
Tubing shall not be spliced within the panel.  Tubing extensions shall be made using bulkhead fittings. 
 
No tubing runs shall interfere with the removal of any component. 
 
All interior pneumatic components that interface to devices outside of the panel shall be terminated to bulkhead 
fittings.  The incoming tubing shall be terminated to these bulkheads. 
 
Tubing shall be installed along vertical or horizontal runs to present a neat appearance.  Angled runs are not 
acceptable. 
 
Tubing shall not be run in the same wireway with wiring. 
 
3.6. 
NAMEPLATES 
 
Nameplates for devices and each panel mounted or sub-panel instrument shall be mounted next to or below the 
device in a manner to minimize identity association errors.  See Section 200553 “Tagging and Identification” for 
additional requirements. 
 
 
 
3.7. 
TESTING 
 
3.7.1. 
PRE-TESTING 
 
The Vendor shall test each fully assembled panel, console, or enclosure at the factory prior to shipment.  
 
Notify the Owner at least two weeks prior to testing and make arrangements for Owner observation and testing.  
 
Pre-testing in preparation for final testing and inspection shall include but not be limited to: 
 
 
 
All wiring and tubing shall be tested for continuity and tightness of connections. 
 
Energize all electrical circuits within the control panel. 
 
Pressurize all pneumatic circuits within the control panel. 
Verify that all components conform to the drawings, specification, and manufacturer’s instructions. 
Verify proper grounding. 
Verify that all components function as specified. 
Test power supplies for proper operation. 
Verify that all components are properly tagged and labeled per the drawings. 
Verify that the control panel has been labeled to show conformance to UL508A. 
Verify that the panel “Arc Flash Hazard” and “Shock Hazard” analysis has been completed and the panel 
is labeled per NFPA 70E. 
 
At the end of Pre-testing, the Vendor shall notify the Owner of test completion and that the control panel is ready 
for inspection.  Completed test reports shall be transmitted to Owner as a For Record Submittal. 
 
Test Failures:  If any equipment or system fails to test properly, the Vendor shall make necessary corrections, 
including replacement, at no additional cost to the Owner.  
 
3.7.2. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING 
 
Where required by the Owner, control panels shall be factory-tested by the Owner prior to shipment. 
 
Devices 
 
Vendor shall check all devices to ensure complete conformance with the Bill of Materials. Non-conformances 
shall be corrected.  Vendor shall be responsible for compliance with their standard in-production test procedures, 
which should progressively check the assembly and wiring systems. 
 
Vendor shall test the contact configuration on all auxiliary relays having convertible contacts and verify 
conformance with the N/O and N/C positions. 
 
Vendor shall determine the contact configuration on all control and instrument switches, synchronizing switches, 
selector switches, and pushbuttons, and verify conformance with switch contact diagrams.  
 
Vendor shall verify that each contact operates in each switch position as indicated on the switch contact diagrams, 
and that all switches with spring return action do return to the intended positions freely and without binding. 
 
Wiring Check 
 
Vendor shall perform a point-to-point check with wiring drawings as defined in the project FAT procedures.  
 
All wiring terminations shall be connected to the specific device terminals as shown on the approved diagrams. 
The Vendor shall perform an electrical continuity test on each conductor. 
 
 
Non-conformances shall be corrected prior to functional testing by the Owner. The Vendor’s quality control 
checklist sheets shall be made available to the Owner during any inspection visit.  
 
Functional Testing 
 
A functional test shall be performed to ensure that the wiring checks previously performed are error free.  This 
functional test will be performed with power applied to the control panel, by the Owner or its authorized 
representative with appropriate support from the Vendor.  All discrete inputs and outputs will be cycled tested 
using 24VDC and 120VAC power supply.  All analog I/O points will be tested with the Vendor providing the 
appropriate test equipment to supply and measure variable 4-20mA signals. All application software shall be fully 
tested operationally for both normal and upset conditions. 
 
Vendor shall be responsible to protect all devices from exposure to overvoltage or other hazards during testing. 
 
Vendor shall submit a test procedure to the Owner prior to functional testing.  The test procedure shall identify 
the test hardware, Vendor personnel and schedule support and any special safety equipment required to perform 
the functional test.  
 
Functional testing will include a check of the variable speed drive configuration parameters and an operational 
test of the drive, where applicable.    
 
Any non-conformance shall be noted and corrected prior to the next day’s functional test.  Demonstration of all 
corrected non-conformances will be required. 
 
The Owner or Owner’s authorized representative will provide a technical sign-off procedure for each control 
panel.  This sign-off signifies the functional test is complete with all known non-conformities corrected.  The 
enclosure is to be immediately prepared for shipment and stored.  The actual release for the shipment of the 
equipment must be obtained in writing from the Owner prior to shipping. 
 
Test Failures:  In the event that the unit fails functional testing and requires re-testing at a later date, Vendor shall 
pay all costs associated with this re-testing.  No test shall require the control panel components to operate in a 
manner that voids or reduces the Vendors’ Warranty.  Responsibility for delays caused by damaged or unavailable 
equipment shall lie with the Vendor. 
 
3.8. 
CLEANING 
 
After completion of factory assembly and testing, the control panels and equipment mounted thereon shall be 
thoroughly cleaned internally and externally by wiping, vacuuming, and brushing.  All non-permanent marks and 
coatings shall be removed without damaging the exterior surface or the components. 
 
3.9. 
SHIPPING 
 
All control panels, equipment and materials shall be suitably crated, boxed, or otherwise prepared for shipment 
to prevent damage during handling and shipping.  Each box or crate shall contain a detailed packing list.  All 
openings shall be properly protected to prevent the entrance of dirt or debris. Suitable weatherproofing shall 
adequately protect all parts that, due to physical size or arrangement, may be exposed to the weather.  It shall be 
the responsibility of the Vendor to take any other precautions required to reasonably ensure jobsite arrival of the 
equipment in an undamaged and satisfactory working condition. 
 
Each separately shipped crate or box shall be plainly marked on the outside with the gross weight, shipping 
address, job number, Purchase Order number, and the identification of the items enclosed. 
 
Temporary braces or supports shall be provided to prevent twisting or bending of control panels and framework 
while uncrating, handling, and erecting the equipment in the field if necessary.  The braces/supports shall be 
 
Internally mounted components shall be protected with plastic shrink-wrap to prevent damage from metal 
shavings or other contaminants during transportation and installation. 
 
The equipment covered by this specification may be stored at the jobsite in a climate-controlled building prior to 
installation.  Any special storage requirements specified by the Vendor shall be forwarded to the jobsite at least 
1 week prior to delivery of each shipment to which they are applicable. 
 
The finish of control panels shall be protected in the best practical manner against abrasion or other damage during 
preparation for shipment and while in transit.  Sprayed-on coatings are not acceptable for this purpose.  Sheet 
plastic may be used for protection of paint and against entrance of moisture. The use of tight fitting polyethylene 
should be avoided unless internal moisture protection is provided. 
 
Matching ends of shipping splits shall be plainly identified on equipment and drawings.  Piping, tubing, and 
electrical connections at shipping splits shall be tagged for field identification. 
 
Relays and instruments shall, where appropriate, have moving parts firmly blocked, and glass or plastic doors and 
faces adequately padded, to prevent damage during shipment. 
 
Instrument doors and hinged covers shall be held closed with pressure sensitive tape.  Tape shall not be applied 
directly to plastic windows. 
 
Any documents, tags, or instructions necessary for proper unpacking and protection after unpacking shall be 
enclosed.  The location of these documents shall be indicated on outer covering of crate. 
 
Subject to the Owner's approval, any instruments or devices believed incapable of safely withstanding handling 
and shipment while mounted in the control panel shall be removed and shipped separately, preferably with the 
associated control panel. These instruments or devices shall be properly identified as to the control panel to which 
they are to be remounted. The Fabricator shall be responsible for remounting the equipment once it arrives on 
site. 
 
Owner reserves the right to reject any equipment that has sustained damage during shipment, or during preparation 
for shipment. 
 
3.10. INSTALLATION 
 
Location:  Install all control panels in the locations as indicated on the drawings. 
 
Wall Mounted Panels:  All wall mounted panel shall have one anchor for every four (4) feet of outside wall 
perimeter; the minimum anchors for any wall mounted panel shall be four (4).  Anchor spacing shall be decreased 
for heavy panels as required.  
 
Removable Lifting Lugs shall be removed after the panels are set and short, full-thread, hex-head machine screws 
shall be used to fill the lug holes.  
 
 
END OF SECTION 
 
 
 
 
Division 42 
Process   
 
SECTION 424113 
TEMPERATURE CONTROL UNIT

PART 1.- GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
This specification describes the minimum requirements for design, materials, fabrication, cleaning, testing, and 
inspection of Temperature Control Units utilized for the distribution of a heat transfer fluid.  The Temperature 
Control Units (TCU’s) shall be designed, manufactured, and otherwise provided in accordance with the attached 
specifications and drawings. 
 
Components shall be sized and provided as specified in this document.  Where such specification is not included, 
sizing shall be supplied by the Manufacturer to be consistent with the intended use of the equipment.  The 
Manufacturer shall be responsible for meeting the intended operation and performance of the system.  In many 
cases a specific supplier and model for components of the skid will be specified.  Use of other suppliers must be 
listed as a deviation to this specification. 
 
This specification is not intended to otherwise limit the Manufacturer in design or details of construction.  The 
Manufacturer may submit any proposed deviations that would improve design, decrease delivery, or decrease 
cost.  Any deviation, along with its schedule and cost impact, shall be submitted in writing to the Owner or 
Owner's representative for approval.  If no such deviations are submitted, it shall be understood that the 
Manufacturer's proposal complies in full with this specification.  Substitutions after contract award shall only be 
allowed with due cause (such as decreasing lead time, improving quality, or Owner preference), and only with 
approval of Owner or Owner's representative.  Any requested modification to contract amount due to substitution 
shall be provided with a written Substitution Proposal.  
 
The Manufacturer shall provide functional, assembled units that incorporate the specific equipment and 
components as indicated in this specification.  The bid proposal shall add to the project definition provided herein, 
 
but in no way replaces any conditions of the specification, unless specific written exceptions are approved by the 
Owner or Owner's representative. 
 
Attached to and part of this specification are other specifications and data sheets for mechanical, electrical, and 
instrumentation components that will be required on the skids. 
 
1.2. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
The following table outlines the required submittals for compliance with this specification.  These submittals are 
defined in specification section 110010.  This does not relieve the manufacturer from supplying any additional 
documentation as specified by the applicable codes and standards, or other submittal requirements as indicated in 
attached specifications.   
 
Provide a review set of documents at FAT.  Documents may change as a result of the FAT.  Final revisions are 
to be shipped with the equipment and shall arrive no later than the equipment. 
 
* Denotes submittals that shall be submitted both electronically and as hard copy. 
 
1.3. 
AVAILABLE UTILITIES 
 
The utilities listed on the data sheet are available at the proposed installation site.  The Manufacturer’s equipment 
shall operate utilizing these connections unless otherwise stated and agreed upon by Owner.  The manufacturer 
shall provide utility usage, including peak and run load in standard American units for equipment specified.  
Manufacturer shall provide suitable piping terminations for utilities to a single point of connection. 
 
 
PART 2 - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
BASIC SYSTEM DESCRIPTION 
 
The TCU shall be provided with the following components as a minimum: 
 
• 
Heat Exchanger 
• 
Circulation Pump 
• 
Expansion Tank 
• 
Instrumentation 
• 
Piping 
• 
Skid Frame 
 
The skids shall be provided as a packaged unit, fully assembled; skid mounted with motors and instruments intact.  
The expansion tank may be shipped loose for high point installation when included.  The unit shall be provided 
with suitable piping terminations for all utilities, to a single point of connection at the equipment edge.  The skids 
shall be so constructed (simple and compact) to enable ease of disassembly for maintenance, servicing, and 
cleaning.  The skids shall be designed for full drain-ability.   
 
Materials of construction for equipment, components, piping systems and specialties shall be in accordance with 
the associated data sheets.      
 
The skid shall be capable of meeting the performance requirements (i.e., flow rates, temperature, and pressure) 
as specified within the attached data sheets, at all times during routine operating conditions.    
 
All pressure containing parts shall de designed, fabricated, and tested in accordance with ASME Boiler and 
Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, and stamped with the ASME “U” symbol and be register with the 
National Board, or applicable country codes if project outside of US. 
 
Welder qualifications and welding shall meet the requirements of ASME Section IX.   
 
The Manufacturer shall clearly state service and maintenance access requirements within the Manufacturer’s 
submittal 
 
2.2. 
BASIC FUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION 
 
Each Temperature Control Unit (TCU101, V101TCU01, V102TCU01, and V103TCU01) shall be an open loop 
system consisting of an inline centrifugal distributing pump, heat exchanger (depending on the P&ID supplied) 
and valves, instruments, and controls as indicated to provide a working system.  Each TCU skid shall distribute 
and control temperature of the fluid loop for its respective tank or jacketed pipe.  The TCU loop will provide 
heating or cooling to process tank jackets or jacketed pipe to maintain the correct temperature in the tank or line.  
 
Temperature Control 
 
The TCU skids shall be controlled from a DCS control system (furnished by others) to maintain jacket water 
temperatures at the temperatures listed on the TCU data sheets.   
The TCU will operate only when required by the manufacturing unit DCS.  All required settings will be controlled 
by the DCS. 
 
Drainability 
 
The TCU skids shall be completely drainable for system maintenance. 
 
Distribution System 
 
The TCU skid shall be capable of mechanically performing all the required functions of the skid as described in 
this specification.   
 
The skid shall be supplied with all necessary terminations, solenoids, and remote I/O blocks for control of 
components located on the skid.   
 
2.3. 
PUMPS 
 
Pumps shall be factory-assembled and tested.  Fabricate casings to allow removal and replacement of impellers 
without necessity of disconnecting piping.  Select pump for operation at center of performance curve, near “Best 
Operating Efficiency Point.”   
 
Vibration dampening shall be included between the bases of pumps, motors and gearboxes and the frames for 
vibration dampening and mechanical protection. 
 
Pump installations shall allow sufficient access to service pump casing and motors. Pumps shall be provided with 
casing drain and drain valve. 
 
2.3.1. 
Pump Motors 
 
Provide motors that are non-overloading within the full range of the pump performance curve. 
 
2.3.2. 
Centrifugal Pumps 
 
Centrifugal pumps shall be sized and specified to operate as close as possible to their “maximum efficiency point” 
while meeting the operating conditions indicated on the data sheets.  Selection shall allow impeller replacement 
with both larger and smaller within same casing.  Pump impellers shall be statically and dynamically balanced. 
 
 
2.4. 
HEAT EXCHANGERS 
 
Heat exchangers shall comply with the requirements indicated on the attached data sheets.   
 
The Manufacturer shall check the design and guarantee mechanical, thermal, and hydraulic performance per 
TEMA for all heat exchangers.  Orientation and installation shall assure drainability.  Whenever possible, each 
heat exchanger and connected process piping shall be configured and oriented so that the flow of cooling solutions 
is up through the unit (against gravity), as opposed to down (with gravity).   
 
Heat exchangers shall be oriented and installed on the skid so that they can be serviced without the requirement 
to completely remove them from the skid or to remove other components from the skid.  This shall include 
adequate pull space for shells on shell-and-tube and plates on plate-and-frame style heat exchangers.  All ASME 
rated heat exchangers shall be provided with the appropriate pressure safety relief devices. 
 
Steam and condensate piping for any heat exchanger shall be configured to prevent stall conditions at low load.   
 
2.5. 
PRESSURE SAFETY VALVES 
 
Provide pressure safety valves as indicated on drawings.  Vendor shall provide sizing calculations for each valve.  
Valves shall have a permanently mounted tag, indicating manufacturer, model number, and serial number.  Valves 
shall be tested for proper operation, prior to installation, and provided with a certification form indicating 
conformance to test and to applicable ASME standard. 
 
2.6. 
HYDRONIC SPECIALTIES 
 
2.6.1. 
Y-Strainers 
 
Class150, cast iron body, grade 18-8 stainless steel screen (20 mesh for 2" and smaller, and manufacturer 
recommended perforations for 2-1/2" and larger), ball valve, and blow down nipple.  End connections:  2" and 
smaller, threaded; 2-1/2" and larger, flanged.  (Steam Strainers discussed in section 2.8.4) 
 
2.6.2. 
Manual Air Vent 
 
Rated working pressure of 150 psig, and temperature of 225°F.  Bronze or brass body, nonferrous internal parts, 
discharge connection copper tube pig-tail, and manually operated with screwdriver or thumbscrew.  1/2" ball 
valves may be used in lieu of manual air vents.   
 
2.6.3. 
Automatic Air Vent 
 
Non-modulating, float type for automatic venting of air.  Rated working pressure of 150 psig, and temperature of 
240°F.  Cast iron, bronze or brass body, nonferrous internal parts, discharge connection copper tube pig-tail, and 
1/2" inlet connection. 
 
2.6.4. 
Air Separator 
 
Sized for full system flow.  Rated working pressure of 125 psig, and temperature of 350°F.  Constructed, tested, 
and labeled in accordance with ASME Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1.  Welded black steel, 
perforated stainless steel air collector tube, tangential inlet and outlet connections, and threaded blowdown 
connection.  Provide blowdown connection with ball valve, and short threaded nipple with cap.  End connections: 
2" and smaller, threaded; 2-1/2" and larger, flanged. 
Acceptable Manufacturers 
Amtrol 
Armstrong 
Bell & Gossett ITT; Fluid Handling Division 
 
2.6.5. 
Pressure Reducing Valves 
 
Size and operating pressure as indicated on drawings.  Diaphragm operated, bronze body valve, stainless steel 
valve seat, stainless steel/bronze trim, and removable spring cage assembly for disc replacement, or inspection of 
internals without removing body from piping.  Factory-set at operating pressure and capable of field adjustment.   
 
End Connections:  2” and smaller, threaded; 2-1/2” and larger, flanged. 
 
2.7. 
AIR REGULATORS 
 
Copper line valves:  Provide compressed air line pressure control valves where indicated on the drawings.  Valves 
shall have a brass body, hand-operated tamper resistant pressure adjusting handwheel, pressure gauge, and NPT 
female end connections.  Select valves for a maximum outlet pressure of approximately twice the outlet pressure 
indicated on the drawings. 
 
2.8. 
PLANT STEAM SPECIALTIES 
 
2.8.1. 
Steam Traps 
 
Thermo-Dynamic Traps: Stainless steel body, with integral seat design with hardened disc and seating surfaces, 
and oxidation resistant finish.  Trap shall contain inlet Y strainer and insulating cover. 
 
Float and Thermostatic Traps: Cast-iron body and bolted cap conforming to one of the following:  ASTM A126 
Class B, A278 Class 30, or A48 Class 30.  Renewable, stainless steel float mechanism, with renewable stainless 
steel valve and seat; balanced pressure thermostatic air vent made of renewable stainless steel or bronze element 
with renewable stainless steel valve and seat. 
 
Pressure Powered Float and Thermostatic Pumping Trap: SG Iron body conforming to ASTM A395 with a swing 
type inlet check valve and ball type outlet check valve.  Trap to be operated by steam.  The internal trap mechanism 
shall contain a stainless steel float connected to an internal trap.  The pumping trap shall be vented to the shell 
side of the heat exchanger to provide for proper operation, and otherwise installed per the trap manufacturer’s 
recommendations.   
 
2.8.2. 
Air Vents 
 
Thermostatic Air Vents: Manufacturer’s standard body material, with balanced pressure beryllium copper, 
phosphor bronze, stainless steel, or monel thermostatic bellows, and stainless steel heads and seats. 
Float-Thermostatic Air Vents: Cast-iron or brass body; balance pressure thermostatic bellows; replaceable 
stainless steel seat, float, and head. 
Acceptable Manufacturers 
 
2.8.3. 
Vacuum Breakers 
 
Vacuum Breakers: Brass or stainless steel body, brass or stainless steel ball or stem type valve, and minimum ½” 
threaded system connection. 
 
2.8.4. 
Strainers 
 
Y-Pattern Strainers: Minimum 250 psig steam working pressure; cast-iron body conforming to ASTM A278 Class 
30 or A126 Class B, type 304 stainless steel screen (maximum 30 mesh for 2" and smaller, and manufacturer 
recommended for sizes 2-1/2" and larger); tapped blow-off for ball valve, and threaded nipple.   End connections; 
2" and smaller threaded, 2-1/2" and larger flanged. 
Basket Strainers: Minimum 250 psig steam working pressure; cast carbon steel body and bolted cover conforming 
to ASTM A216B, type 304 stainless steel screen.  Flanged connections. 
 
2.9. 
CONTROLS 
 
This skid is to be controlled via the site DCS (DeltaV), refer to Division 40 Specifications for complete 
instrumentation and control system details.  The automated process control system shall include the following 
items as a minimum: 
• 
FIP (Field Instrument Panel) 
• 
Transmitters 
• 
Solenoids (for open-closed pneumatic valves) and I/P Converters (for pneumatic modulating valves) 
• 
Analyzers 
• 
Electrical Wiring (power and communication) 
• 
E-Stop button. 
 
The process control system shall be designed to minimize operator input requirements. 
The control system shall activate automatic valves, electric motors and instruments as required by programmed 
steps or phases.  The unit shall be programmed to alarm deviations from selected procedures and to indicate 
problem areas via diagnostic indicators and the control panel.   The Manufacturer shall provide all necessary 
instrumentation for fully automatic sequence of operations.  The control system shall be capable of performing 
the indicated automation on the P&ID and the following: 
• 
See section Basic Functional Description for process valve sequencing. 
• 
Alarm Detection (audible and visual) 
• 
Manual and automatic system control method editing routines. 
• 
Process data logging 
• 
Manual operation of each automated valve through OIT. 
 
Alarms and Diagnostics 
 
The control system shall generate alarms for, at a minimum, the conditions as stated in the datasheet.  Upon 
generation of an alarm, the control system shall initiate the following steps: 
• 
Shut down the supply pump. 
• 
Close the steam control valve. 
• 
Close all valves on the skid. 
 
2.10. INSTRUMENTATION 
 
Instrumentation shall be provided that will be capable of monitoring and/or controlling the following process 
conditions: 
 
• 
Temperatures of the heat transfer solution in the “supply Line” exiting the skid. 
• 
Pressure (downstream of pump) 
• 
Control valve positions 
 
2.10.1. Temperature 
 
Temperatures shall be measured using direct immersion RTDs.  
 
2.10.2. Flow Switch 
 
A flow switch shall be installed on the skid if indicated on the P&ID.   
 
2.10.3. Pressure 
 
A pressure indicating transmitter shall be installed on the line downstream of the pump if indicated on the P&ID.   
 
 
2.10.4. Pump Speed 
 
The pump speed shall be constant. 
 
2.10.5. SAFETY 
 
Pressure Relief – Each pressure vessel shall be equipped with a suitably sized relief valve(s) to protect the unit 
from over pressurization.  
  
Guards. - Machine guarding shall meet applicable OSHA requirements. 
 
Noise. - The unit shall have a noise level of less than 80 dBa as measured no more than 3 feet from the unit. 
 
The manufacturer shall document all safety features and shall provide a detailed list of safety interlocks in English. 
 
2.11. ELECTRICAL 
 
Refer to specification 260660 (Electrical Requirements for Packaged Equipment) for details about the electrical 
system.  Power to each piece of equipment shall be provided by the facility to a single point of connection per 
power type as listed on the data sheet.  The Manufacturer shall provide a lockable disconnect for each connection 
point.   
 
The Manufacturer shall warrant that all wiring and electrical components shall comply with the NEC, as well as 
all applicable local electrical codes.  All wiring and components shall be rated appropriately and suitable for the 
environment in which the equipment is installed.   
 
2.12. EMERGENCY STOP 
 
Manufacturer shall provide a hard-wired emergency stop button on the control panel for shutdown of the system 
in the event of emergency.  Emergency stop shall disable all outputs and reset the valves, agitator and pumps to 
a fail-safe position, while maintaining inputs for monitoring capability.  The Owner or Owner’s representative 
shall approve the location of the emergency stop switch location on the equipment panel. 
 
2.13. STRUCTURAL SKID 
 
All physical parts of the skid, including but not limited to equipment, components, piping, conduit, 
instrumentation, and enclosures, shall be supported by a structural skid.  The structural skid shall be designed and 
constructed in accordance with the requirements listed in 110010 and of the materials as indicated within the 
attached data sheets. 
 
 
PART 3 – EXECUTION 
 
3.2. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is outlined in section 110010.  .  Attached 
specifications may have additional FAT requirements.  The following items shall be the required tests to be 
performed at FAT. 
 
3.2.1. 
General Verifications 
 
• 
Verify adherence to specifications and datasheets. 
• 
Verify adherence to approved drawings, including P&IDs. (order of take-off, order of 
instrumentation, slopes, tagging, etc.) 
 
• 
Loop/instrument checks:  Verify the signal returns to the control system, not just continuity. 
• 
Instrument Calibration:  Vendor to calibrate instruments and control valves.   
• 
Internal and external surface finish testing using a profilometer. 
• 
Random check of piping and fitting heat numbers. 
• 
Sanitary clamp connections should be disassembled and reassembled to ensure correct “fit-up”. 
• 
Verify adequate support of all lines. 
• 
Valve angles should meet minimum tolerances. 
• 
Verify the system dimensions – tie-in points, footprint, slope, dimensional tolerances and height. 
• 
Review of Turnover package for accuracy and completeness 
 
3.2.2. 
Discharge Temperature 
 
The discharge temperature shall be measured to verify that the skid provides the specified discharge temperature. 
 
3.2.3. 
Pump Performance 
 
The pressure and flow rate of the TCU skid shall be measured to verify that the skid provides the specified flow 
rate and pressure at the temperatures specified.   
 
3.3. 
SITE ACCEPTANCE TESTING (SAT)   
 
SAT will cover FAT items that were not addressed as well as making sure the new system is adequately integrated 
into the facility. 
 
3.3.1. 
Basic Testing/General Verification 
 
Basic testing will typically include an inspection of the system using the Issued for Construction Drawings to 
verify their accuracy including flow paths and sloping.  This testing will also include an inspection of the system 
to verify correct installation to specification.  This testing will also include finish verification both on the inside 
and outside of the equipment to ensure no damage was incurred during transport.  Testing may include some or 
all items from the FAT described under General Verification. 
3.3.2. 
Discharge Temperature 
 
The discharge temperature shall be measured to verify that the skid provides the specified discharge temperature. 
 
3.3.3. 
Pump Performance 
 
The pressure and flow rate of the TCU skid shall be measured to verify that the skid provides the specified flow 
rate and pressure at the temperatures specified. 
   
END OF SECTION
