SECTION 426013 
GMP PARTS WASHER 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1.- GENERAL ............................................................................................................................................. 1 
1.1. GENERAL .......................................................................................................................................... 1 
1.2. EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE ................................................................................................................ 1 
1.3. ATTACHMENTS ............................................................................................................................... 1 
1.4 SUBMITTALS ................................................................................................................................... 2 
1.5. AVAILABLE UTILITIES .................................................................................................................. 2 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS .......................................................................................................................................... 2 
2.1. BASIC SYSTEM DESCRIPTION ..................................................................................................... 2 
2.2. BASIC FUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION ........................................................................................... 3 
2.3. RECIRCULATION PUMP................................................................................................................. 3 
2.4. HEAT EXCHANGERS ...................................................................................................................... 3 
2.5. FILTERS ............................................................................................................................................. 4 
2.6. SANITARY RUPTURE DISKS ......................................................................................................... 4 
2.7. INSTRUMENTATION AND CONTROLS ....................................................................................... 4 
2.8. SAFETY ............................................................................................................................................. 6 
2.9. ELECTRICAL .................................................................................................................................... 7 
PART 3. - EXECUTION ........................................................................................................................................ 7 
3.1. FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) .................................................................................. 7 
 
 
PART 1.- GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
This specification describes the minimum requirements for the design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and delivery of 
a GMP washer/dryer unit with stand-alone control for cleaning of production glassware, components and equipment.   
 
1.2. 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide equipment as indicated in the associated Equipment Data Sheet.   
 
1.3. 
ATTACHMENTS 
 
The following specifications, drawings, and documents are attached to and comprise part of this specification: 
 
Description 
Specification or 
Datasheet No. 
Specifications 
Equipment General Requirements 
110010 
Piping 
230500 
Basic Instrument and Controls for Packaged Equipment 
409020 
  
  
Data Sheets 
COP Washer 
426013 
 
 
Drawings 
COP Washer P&ID 
34-0200-111 
 
 
 
1.4 
SUBMITTALS 
 
The associated Vendor Documentation Requirements (VDR) Specification outlines the required submittals for 
compliance with this specification. These submittals are defined in specification section 110010. This does not relieve 
the manufacturer from supplying any additional documentation as specified by the applicable codes and standards, or 
other submittal requirements as indicated in attached specifications.   
 
The manufacturer shall certify--in writing--design, fabrication and testing compliance with listed requirements.  
The manufacturer shall provide a review set of documents at FAT.  Documents may change as a result of the FAT.  
Final revisions are to be shipped with the equipment and shall arrive no later than the equipment. 
 
1.4. 
AVAILABLE UTILITIES 
 
The utilities listed on the data sheet are available at the proposed installation site.  The Manufacturer’s equipment shall 
operate utilizing these connections unless otherwise stated and agreed upon by Owner.  The manufacturer shall provide 
utility usage, including peak and run load in standard American units for the equipment specified.  Manufacturer shall 
provide suitable piping terminations for utilities to a single point of connection. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
BASIC SYSTEM DESCRIPTION 
 
Manufacturer shall submit based on the standard size that is equal to, or larger than, the listed nominal chamber 
dimensions. 
 
The GMP Washer shall be capable of producing chemically clean glassware, components or equipment without 
presoaking, scraping or other pretreatment.  The washer shall be designed for internal water recirculation or once-
through flow through appropriately designed rotary spray arms on top and bottom and load rack spindles, during all 
phases of the cycle. The equipment shall be supplied with a forced air-drying system.  
 
The washer furnished under this specification shall include washing chamber, control panel, filters, instrumentation, 
piping, wiring, insulation, water heater, drying air heater, air circulation blower(s), circulation water pump, air exhaust 
blower, supply and return connections to allow for internal hose washing and/or cleaning of product piping spool pieces, 
and all necessary appurtenances as required for a complete package. Vendor shall provide mobile carts, and loading racks 
as specified in the data sheets. 
 
 
The washer shall be capable of washing and drying items identified on the Equipment Data Sheet(s).   
 
The washer shall have flexible control to allow for programming of cycles that may include detergent wash, acid wash, 
rinses, once-through final rinse (e.g., WFI), exhaust and air drying of various cycle lengths. As indicated on the data 
sheet, the equipment shall be capable of connecting to multiple water quality supplies. 
 
The washer shall use filtered air propelled by blowers as the air source for the drying cycle, as indicated on the 
datasheet.  Duct connection size, air flow rate and whether or not the air flow is a constant shall be included in the 
proposal.  Test ports shall be provided for testing of the filters. 
 
Manufacturer shall provide all the component operating systems necessary to obtain a complete and operable unit, 
factory-tested and ready for connection to the building utility service lines. 
 
The system shall be identified with permanently mounted tags showing equipment numbers and description.   
 
Manufacturer shall provide suitable pipe and duct terminations for utilities to a single point of connection at each skid.  
Owner will provide appropriate roughing filters, let down regulators, and pressure relief valves.  The utilities as 
 
designed are listed on the attached data sheet.  Manufacturer shall verify equipment operation based on utility design 
specified in the data sheet. 
 
2.2. 
BASIC FUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION 
 
The control system controls shall be capable of not progressing to the next sequence step until the set point 
temperature, and conductivity (during detergent additions) requirements have been reached.  Operation shall be fully 
automatic, with the minimum control requirements described in the equipment data sheet.  Control panel shall be 
permanently mounted on the unit skid and positioned for ease of monitoring.  OITs shall be positioned on the load 
and unload sides, if specified. 
 
The equipment shall be provided with a minimum of one (1) controlling RTD for temperature control of the wash/rinse 
fluid.  The temperature sensor(s) shall be fast response RTDs. The RTDs shall be rigidly mounted & shall be 
removable for calibration outside the unit. 
 
During the washing and drying cycles, the control temperature shall remain within ± 2°C of set point temperature.  
The temperature controller shall be equipped with variable “high” and “low” temperature audible alarms adjustable 
for a deviation of 0 – 9.9°C from a set point. 
 
Two conductivity sensors shall be provided – one for cleaning solution prior to circulation, and one for final WFI 
rinse. The location shall be stated for the Owner’s review and approval. 
 
The washer shall be equipped with a sanitary rinse sample valve accessible from the within the process space, not in 
the mechanical space. 
 
2.3. 
RECIRCULATION PUMP 
 
The pump(s) shall be factory-assembled and tested. The pump(s) shall be installed so that they can be serviced without 
the requirement to completely remove from the skid and installed to provide drain-ability per ASME BPE.   Fabricate 
casings to allow removal and replacement of impellers without necessity of disconnecting piping.  Select pump for 
operation at center of performance curve, near “Best Operating Efficiency Point.” 
   
Isolation material shall be used between the bases of pumps, motors and gearboxes and the frames for vibration 
dampening and mechanical protection. 
 
Pump Motors  
 
Provide motors that are non-overloading within the full range of the pump performance curve. 
 
Centrifugal Pumps 
 
Centrifugal pumps shall be sized and specified to operate as close as possible to their “maximum efficiency point” 
while meeting the operating conditions indicated on the data sheets.  Selection shall allow impeller replacement with 
both larger and smaller within same casing.  Pump impellers shall be statically and dynamically balanced. 
  
2.4. 
HEAT EXCHANGERS 
 
The type of heat exchanger for the recirculated washes/rinses shall be the manufacturers standard unless otherwise 
indicated on the datasheet.   
 
Heat exchangers shall be oriented and installed on the skid so that they can be serviced without the requirement to 
completely remove them from the skid or to remove other components from the skid.  This shall include adequate pull 
space for shells on shell-and-tube and plates on plate-and-frame style heat exchangers.   
 
 
All ASME rated heat exchangers shall be provided with the appropriate pressure safety relief devices.  All heat 
exchangers are subject to ASME and municipal pressure vessel codes. 
 
Steam and condensate piping for any heat exchanger shall be configured to prevent stall conditions at low load.   
 
Sanitary Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers 
 
If indicated as required, shell and tube heat exchangers for product contact shall be installed to assure complete drain-
ability per ASME BPE on the product (tube) side.  Whenever possible, each heat exchanger and connected process 
piping shall be configured and oriented so that the flow of product solutions is up through the unit (against gravity).  
Shell and tube heat exchangers are to be fabricated such that the tube attachment is expanded and welded. 
 
If indicated as required on the datasheet, a drain cooler shall be provided with the equipment. 
 
2.5. 
FILTERS 
 
Pre-filters and HEPA filters shall be provided for the drying phase of the cycle.  The filters shall be easily accessible. 
If indicated on the datasheet, extra filters shall be provided within the quote.   Filter efficiency and HEPA class shall 
be indicated on the datasheet. 
 
If process or vent filters are provided, the housings shall be free draining.  Each filter housing shall be oriented and 
installed so that the housing dome can be easily removed, with a filter installed in the housing, with no other 
disassembly required on the skid.  Filter cartridges shall be provided for use at the FAT and for start-up and 
commissioning activities.   
 
2.6. 
SANITARY RUPTURE DISKS 
 
If required by the design, a rupture disk housing/body shall be 316L stainless steel with sanitary clamp end 
connections.  Disk shall be of non-fragmenting type with Teflon gasket.  Maximum burst tolerance range shall be ±5% 
of the requested burst pressure.  Supply disks with a 0% Manufacturing range.  
 
A disk burst sensor and monitor shall be provided where indicated on drawings.  Sensor shall be suitable for operation 
at temperatures through 250°F.  Sensor shall be designed for normally closed output. Monitor shall be designed for 
120VAC supply power, provide +5 VDC loop power to the sensor, contain 1- SPDT 10-amp contact, and provide 
local alarm annunciation and indication.  Burst sensor lead length shall be 25 feet minimum or as coordinated with 
the controls’ contractor. 
 
2.7. 
INSTRUMENTATION AND CONTROLS 
 
The design for each piece of equipment shall meet the requirements identified in specification 409020. 
 
The automated process control system shall include the following items as a minimum: 
 
• 
Process Controller (PLC)   
• 
Operator Interface Terminal (OIT) 
• 
Transmitters 
• 
Solenoids 
• 
Analyzers 
• 
Electrical Wiring 
 
The process control system shall be PLC based and designed to minimize operator input requirements. 
The control system shall activate automatic valves, electric motors and instruments as required by programmed steps 
or phases. 
 
 
The unit shall be programmed to alarm deviations from selected parameters and to indicate problem areas via 
diagnostic indicators and the control panel.  
 
The Manufacturer shall provide all necessary instrumentation for fully automatic sequence of operations.  The control 
system shall be capable of performing the indicated automation on the P&ID and the following: 
 
• 
Valve sequencing 
• 
Alarm Detection 
• 
Manual and automatic system control method editing routines. 
• 
Process data logging and transmission to Owner’s Historian 
• 
Manual operation of each automated valve through OIT 
• 
Communication protocol support 
 
2.7.1. 
Process Controller 
 
Subject to compliance with conditions outlined in design documents, a programmable logic controller (PLC) shall be 
utilized for the sequential and analytical control of the specified system. The PLC processor shall be: 
 
 
Allen-Bradley Control Logix Family or approved equivalent.    
 
The supplier OIT shall be: 
 
Allen-Bradley Rockwell PanelView Plus or approved equivalent.    
 
The control system, including all wiring and terminations, shall be protected against corrosion and heat.  Memory 
shall be non-volatile. 
 
• 
Alternate: The Manufacture may quote their standard control system as an option to the Allen-Bradley 
system described in this specification.  The Manufacturer must indicate the functional discrepancies 
between their standard unit and the unit indicated in this specification.   
 
2.7.2. 
CPU 
 
CPU shall be supplied such that 25% of memory capacity remains for future expansion after all programming and 
documentation is complete.  CPU shall be able to execute PID, Math, Logic and Subroutine functions along with all 
basic digital control functions as a minimum.  Lithium battery backup and EEPROM memory (if it is a manufacturer’s 
option) shall be provided with CPU.  Shutdown and startup control shall conform to all industry standard procedures 
and practices. 
 
2.7.3. 
I / O Subsystem 
 
Input and output modules shall be supplied such that the following amount of spare inputs and outputs exist: 
 
 
15% Digital inputs and outputs 
 
10% Analog inputs and outputs 
 
15-20% Spare slots available 
 
2.7.4. 
Programming Software: 
The PLC ladder logic program shall be structured in modular form using subroutines.  I/O, status register and coils 
and data registers shall be blocked in contiguous series to allow interface to a DCS system.  The manufacturer shall 
be responsible to coordinate this requirement with the owner.  The program must not contain any unused "Dead" code 
and must be well annotated. 
 
 
 
2.7.5. 
Power Failure 
If required to do so as per the Equipment Datasheet, the Manufacturer shall provide an Un-interruptible Power System 
(UPS) with ample capacity in order to facilitate a controlled shutdown of the system upon power loss.  Upon 
restoration of electrical power to the unit, the cycle will be placed in hold and will provide the operator the ability to 
continue, abort or restart the desired cycle. 
 
2.7.6. 
Security 
 
The system will utilize a two level (user/password) security algorithm for access to all system functions.  On a user 
level basis (i.e., all users shall have unique passwords) and shall have a unique profile of access rights.  The system 
shall allow for the creation of user groups with similar access privileges to simplify creation of new users.  Once a 
user profile is created individual user accounts can be modified as needed. 
 
As a minimum, the following security groups shall be provided: 
 
• 
System Administrator / configuration 
• 
Supervisor  
• 
Operator 
• 
Maintenance 
 
2.7.7. 
Remote Monitoring 
 
Provide signals to allow for remote monitoring and/or recording of the following parameters. 
 
1. Cycle ID 
2. Cycle Start/Stop Date and Time 
3. Caustic and Acid Conductivity 
4. Dry Time / Temperature 
5. Final Rinse Conductivity 
6. Rinse Time / Temperature 
7. Wash Time / Temperature 
8. Wash (recirculation) pump discharge pressure 
 
2.7.8.    Alarms and Diagnostics 
 
The following alarm and diagnostic indicators shall be provided: 
 
1. Date and time stamp of alarm occurrence. 
2. Date and time alarm acknowledged. 
3. Control system status. 
 
The alarm shall be operated through the microprocessor controller.  Upon sensing an alarm condition, the controller 
shall cause the audible alarm to sound and the visual indicator light to flash. 
 
After the operator has acknowledged the alarm by pushing the “acknowledged alarm” button, the audible alarm shall 
be silenced but the diagnostic light shall remain lit until the condition is corrected. 
When the condition causing the alarm has been cleared, the alarm light shall be turned off automatically. 
 
2.8. 
SAFETY 
 
The manufacturer shall document all safety features and shall provide a detailed list of safety interlocks in English. 
 
All moving parts that can form pinch points, trap or cause injury to personnel must be adequately guarded with either 
fixed or interlocked guards. It is not sufficient to display written warnings. Use table 10 in OSHA Standard 29 CFR 
 
1910.217 for maximum width openings. Non-compliance must be reviewed with the Owner or Owner’s 
representative. 
 
All components including faceplates, motors, controls, piping and all electrical components shall have installed all 
appropriate hazard and warning signs in accordance with OSHA, NEC, NFPA, state and local code standards.  Refer 
to Section 200553 Tagging and Identification for additional details. 
 
The safety interlock system (E-stops, electrical interlocks) shall be hardwired.  The system must pass through a safety 
relay, which removes all output voltages and causes an “air dump” in power down, E-stop and guard open conditions. 
 
An Emergency Stop (E-stop) button shall be provided on each unit and located next to the OIT on the same enclosure.    
E-stop switches must be red, of mushroom design and latch when depressed.  They must be capable of bringing the 
machine to a “zero energy” state.  Zero energy means that all machine motion must come to a controlled stop and all 
residual energy must be dissipated from the system where the removal of such energy shall not cause additional 
machine movement.  The Manufacturer shall provide a description of the actions the washer takes when the e-stop is 
activated. 
 
The installation or operation of the system will not affect the safety devices already in place in the area. 
 
2.9. 
ELECTRICAL 
 
Power to each piece of equipment shall be provided by the facility to a single point of connection.  The Manufacturer 
shall provide a lockable stainless steel NEMA 4X disconnect for this connection point.  The manufacturer shall provide 
a control power transformer for all 120 VAC power required on the equipment. 
 
The Manufacturer shall warrant that all wiring and electrical components shall comply with the NEC, as well as all 
applicable local electrical codes.  All wiring and components shall be rated appropriately and suitable for the 
environment in which the equipment is installed.   
 
All wire colors shall be per UL standards.  No more than two wires shall be connected to a single terminal connection.  
Each wire end connected to a terminal strip is identified with an individual number. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and specified in section 110010.  
The tests listed in 110010 shall be performed in addition to the test(s) listed below: 
 
• 
Sequence of Operation verification for each cycle 
 
Empty chamber test run acceptance criteria: 
 
• 
For Empty Chamber Test, HEPA filters or HEPA simulators shall be used. 
• 
Washer wash and rinse water heaters shall be capable of heating from 20 ºC to set point temperature.  
• 
Cooling of the chamber and its contents from 60 ºC to specified exit temperature shall be accomplished 
prior to allowing the doors to be opened.   
 
All of the above test results, process variables, and test protocols shall be fully documented and recorded in a written 
report to be submitted to the Owner.   A responsible and qualified person shall certify all reports. The reports shall 
include instrumentation calibration data. 
 
END OF SECTION

PART 1.- GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
This specification covers the detailed requirements for design, fabrication, assembly, and delivery of agitators for 
installation on and operation within vessels for pharmaceutical and biotech operations. The agitators shall be of a 
size and capacity as specified herein and on the attached data sheets. This specification is used as an attachment 
for stainless steel process vessel specification 434113. 
 
1.2. 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide equipment as indicated in the Equipment Schedule below.  
 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
EQUIPMENT 
NUMBER 
P&ID 
NUMBER 
CAPACITY 
NAME 
LA5V101AG01 
34-0200-031 
0-80 RPM 
Pooling Vessel 1 Agitator 
LA5V102AG01 
34-0200-032 
0-80 RPM 
Pooling Vessel 2 Agitator 
LA5V103AG01 
34-0200-033 
0-80 RPM 
Pooling Vessel 3 Agitator 
 
1.3. 
AVAILABLE UTILITIES 
 
The utilities listed on the data sheet are available at the proposed installation site. The Manufacturer’s equipment 
shall operate utilizing these connections unless otherwise stated and agreed upon by Owner. The manufacturer 
shall provide utility usage, including peak and run load in standard American Customary units for equipment 
specified.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
1.4. 
COORDINATION 
 
The agitator manufacturer is fully responsible for the coordination of the agitators with the vessel manufacturer 
regarding all details of mounting methods, shaft and impeller removal, flange bore clearance dimensions, seal 
compatibility, mounting location, insertion angles, dimensions, materials of construction, surface finish, weights 
and other necessary items.  
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Agitators will be operated in a sanitary manner (except where noted otherwise on the Data Sheets) in a low bio-
burden operation. Agitators shall be provided with magnetic drive, single mechanical seal or double mechanical 
seal as noted on the agitator data sheet. The manufacturer shall determine optimal X-Y mounting angles for angled 
top mounted mixers that are based on vessel geometry and fluid properties.  
 
Process requirements may include mild liquid blending, solids dissolution, mild gas sparging, gas/liquid mass 
transfer, and / or heat transfer. Accompanying Data Sheets provide information relative to agitator operating 
conditions, design requirements, and materials of construction.  
 
The Manufacturer shall recommend agitator speeds and impeller diameters suitable for the type of agitation and 
the process fluid characteristics. The manufacturer shall recommend fluid discharge direction relative to the 
impeller, i.e., up-pumping or down-pumping, based on the application. 
 
Agitators shall be Manufacturer's standard, except as modified herein.  
 
Any vibration observed in factory testing and site testing at the Owner's location shall be within industry 
standards. The Manufacturer's proposal shall state first critical speed of each agitator. that falls within the 
operational speed range of the agitator as indicated on the data sheet. A tag or nameplate stating the first critical 
speed shall be provided and attached to the agitator gear drive with a warning against routine operation at critical 
speeds ± 20%.  Each agitator shall come up to full speed smoothly throughout its operating range (except for 
passing through the first critical speed). 
 
2.2. 
MATERIALS 
 
All critical materials and finishes shall be as indicated on the data sheets. Motors, gearboxes, VFDs, shrouds, 
couplings, junction boxes and all other exposed components exterior to the vessel shall be stainless steel unless 
indicated otherwise on the data sheets. Electroless Electrolysis nickel-plated components may be quoted for non-
wetted components as an alternative to stainless steel. 
 
2.2.1. 
Surface Finish 
 
All critical surfaces shall be mechanically polished to a final finish as indicated on the data sheets. Surface finish 
shall be measured by a profilometer. All welds shall be ground smooth and successively polished to the same 
finish as the adjoining surfaces.  
 
Surfaces in contact with product shall be free from visible scratches, burrs, pits, flash, folds, nicks, inclusions, 
crevices, and other defects as judged by the Owner or the Owner's representative. 
 
2.3. 
SHAFT 
 
Provide cantilever shaft without steady bearing. Hollow or stepped shafts are not acceptable without prior 
approval by Owner. 
 
After impellers are welded to the shaft (see Data Sheets to determine which units are applicable), the shaft shall 
be true and straight such that the Total Indicator Run-out is less than 0.005" per inch of shaft length when the 
shaft is rotated 360° by hand.  
Segmented shafts shall feature BPE In-tank couplings as detailed in ASME BPE section SD-3.5.2, “In-Tank 
Couplings”. O-rings shall be USP Class VI material unless noted otherwise on datasheets. 
 
2.4. 
IMPELLERS 
 
Provide impeller type as indicated on the Data Sheet.  
 
No split hubs will be allowed. Impeller components shall be machined or forged, not cast. One-piece welded 
construction of impeller is preferred whenever practical. Underside cavities in the hub, mechanical connections 
and crevices in the assembled wetted parts shall be minimized to facilitate cleaning-in-place. Hubs shall be welded 
to the shaft unless noted otherwise on the Data Sheets. Welds shall be ground smooth to surface finish listed on 
data sheet. 
 
2.5. 
SEALS 
 
Provide each agitator with the seal type indicated on its data sheet. Seal designs shall be approved by the client 
prior to purchase to ensure compliance with site or corporate standards. Low noise combinations of stationary 
and rotating face materials shall be identified where seal noise is a criterion on the datasheet. Seal flush 
requirements, flushing fluids and conditions are noted on the datasheets. 
 
2.6. 
MOTORS AND GEAR DRIVES 
 
All electrical components shall be UL labeled and tagged. 
 
Provide each agitator complete with motor, gear drive, seal, shaft, and impeller(s) as required and indicated on 
the data sheets. Whenever possible, the gear drive shall be close coupled to the agitator and the motor shall be 
mounted integral to the gear drive unit. Guards shall be provided in accordance with OSHA requirements, and 
couplings shall be accessible. Each agitator assembly shall be suitable for an on/off cycle frequency of greater 
than 10 times daily. 
 
The agitator motor shall be a unit supplied by a top-quality U.S. motor manufacturer listed below. All motors 
shall be UL or CSA listed or recognized. Motors driven by variable frequency drives shall be premium efficiency 
rated. If indicated on the datasheet, a variable frequency drive shall be provided having a speed adjustment 
capability of 20:1 or better.  
 
Gearing type shall be helical or spiral bevel and have permanently attached direction of rotation arrows. 
Manufacturer shall provide a list of lubricated parts (including type of lubricant used and lubrication schedule) 
and all lubricants shall be food grade per FDA. Maximum shaft speed and motor sizing shall be per 
Manufacturer’s recommendation, to be provided in the bid proposal. 
 
Acceptable Motor Manufacturers  
 
 
Reliance 
 
Baldor 
 
Approved Equal 
 
If indicated on data sheet, agitator motors shall be compatible with variable frequency drives (VFDs). Each 
agitator motor shall be sized to pull no more than 80% of FLA when installed on the vessel for which it was 
specified, operating at maximum speed, with the vessel full of the process liquid indicated on the data sheet. 
 
 
2.7. 
GEAR REDUCERS 
 
Gear design shall conform to AGMA standards for continuous service and shall be enclosed in dust-proof, 
watertight casings, fully protected against lubricant leakage. Gear box design, configuration and orientation shall 
provide for ease of maintenance and equipment change-out. 
 
2.8. 
ELECTRICAL 
 
The Manufacturer shall warrant that all wiring and electrical components shall comply with the NEC, as well as 
all applicable local electrical codes. All wiring and components shall be rated appropriately and suitable for the 
environment in which the equipment is installed.  
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is outlined in section 110010. The 
following tests shall also be performed at FAT: 
 
3.1.1. 
General Verifications – Associated with Specification 434113 
 
3.1.2. 
Surface Finish 
 
Each agitator shall be visually inspected in its entirety with areas of concern noted with tape flags or post it notes. 
These points shall then be inspected using the following procedure: 
 
• 
The area to be inspected shall be cleaned using acetone and a clean, lint free rag. 
• 
The surface area being checked shall be recorded. 
• 
Use an averaging Profilometer to measure surface finish at three points, two of which shall be 90° apart. 
• 
All readings shall be recorded. 
 
A minimum of four places shall be checked on agitator shaft and impeller. Failure of two or more points may 
require additional testing. 
 
3.1.3. 
Interference with Vessel or Internals 
 
Agitator shall be completely installed in vessel and rotated by hand to note any interference with the vessel or 
other vessel internals.  
 
3.1.4. 
Agitator Performance 
 
Agitator shall be operated at top speed with minimum recommended amount of water in vessel. At this speed, 
there shall be no noticeable shaft run-out or assembly vibration. Agitator shall come up to full speed smoothly 
through its operating range (except passing through the first critical speed). 
 
Agitator shall be operated at design speed(s) with vessel full of water to working volume. A minimum of three 
operating points shall be tested for agitators using a VFD. Agitation performance may be ensured by CFD studies, 
mixing tests combined with visual determination of fluid surface movement and objectionable vortexing at given 
speeds. The Pass/Fail criteria shall be stated in a pre-approved FAT testing protocol prior to factory or site testing. 
Manufacturer shall verify and document that the motor current does not exceed 80% of FLA and that there is no 
noticeable shaft run-out or assembly vibration through the complete range of the specified operating conditions. 
 
Total Indicator Run-out shall be less than 0.005" per inch of shaft length when the shaft is rotated 360° by hand.  
 
3.1.5. 
Cleanability 
 
A fluorescing riboflavin shall be applied to all wetted surfaces of the agitator and magnetic drive bearing, if 
applicable. The spray device test of the vessel shall be completed and the agitator, including the bearing, shall be 
completely inspected with a UV light to determine if ANY residual riboflavin remains after the test. The test shall 
be successful after two complete cycles of application and spray device testing show that no riboflavin remains 
either time. 
 
3.1.6. 
Testing Responsibility Matrix 
 
  
X=Primary 
Responsibility for 
Developing Protocol

END OF SECTION

Process Fluids Data

Class of Agitation

 FILTER HOUSING

GENERAL 
 
 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
 
 
This specification covers the detailed requirements for design, fabrication, assembly, testing and delivery of 
 
cartridge filter housings. 
 
 
 
Division 23 - Basic Mechanical Requirements and Basic Mechanical Materials and Methods Sections apply to 
 
work of this section. For packaged equipment, provide submittal documents in compliance with requirements 
 
indicated in Section 110010 Equipment General Requirements. For all other equipment and materials, provide 
 
submittal documents in compliance with requirements indicated in Section 230010 Basic Mechanical 
 
Requirements. 
 
 
 
1.2. 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
 
 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide equipment as indicated in the Equipment Schedule below.   
 
 
 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
EQUIPMENT 
NUMBER 
P&ID NUMBER 
CAPACITY 
NAME

1.4. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
 
 
Product Data:  Submit manufacturer's technical product data for filter housings including dimensions, weights, 
 
material certifications and U-Forms for code stamped housings. 
 
 
 
The following table outlines the required submittals for compliance with this specification.  These submittals are 
 
defined in Section 110010 Equipment General Requirements for packaged (skidded) equipment and Section 
 
230010 Basic Mechanical Requirements for all other equipment.  This does not relieve the manufacturer from 
 
supplying any additional documentation as specified by the applicable codes and standards, or other submittal 
 
requirements as indicated in attached specifications.   
 
 
 
Provide a review set of documents at FAT.  Documents may change as a result of the FAT.  Final revisions are 
 
to be shipped with the equipment and shall arrive no later than the equipment. 
 
 
 
* Denotes submittals that shall be submitted both electronically and as hard copy.

PRODUCTS 
 
 
 
2.1. 
GENERAL 
 
 
 
Provide filter housings as indicated on the attached data sheet(s).   All filter housings shall be free draining for 
 
CIP and/or SIP as indicated on the datasheet(s).  Filter housing domes shall be constructed to minimize volumes 
 
required for process operations.  The filter base shall be designed such that no projected sections are protruding 
 
above the flush base.  The base of the filter-housing unit shall be fully drainable from both inlet and outlet ports, 
 
with sloped design for drainability towards the effluent port.   
 
 
 
Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide filter housings from one of the following: 
 
 
 
Allegheny Bradford 
 
Filterite 
 
FSI 
 
Graver Technologies 
 
Meissner 
 
Millipore 
 
Pall 
 
Parker Hannifin 
 
Ronningen-Petter 
 
Sartorius 
 
 
 
 
 
 
2.2. 
CARTRIDGE FILTER HOUSINGS 
 
 
 
Filter housings shall have a fully drainable machined base.  Filter housings cleaning philosophy shall be defined 
 
by Owner. 
 
 
 
Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide filter housings from one of the following: 
 
 
 
Allegheny Bradford 
 
Millipore 
 
Pall 
 
Sartorius 
 
 
 
2.3. 
MULTI-ROUND CARTRIDGE FILTER HOUSINGS 
 
 
 
Multi-round filter housings shall be capable of being cleaned by a top or bottom adapter spray ball for cleaning 
 
in place, as noted on the datasheet.   
 
 
 
If a split dome is specified, a sanitary clamp shall secure the sections of the split dome.   
 
 
 
Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide filter housings from one of the following: 
 
 
 
Allegheny Bradford 
 
Millipore 
 
Pall 
 
Sartorius 
 
 
 
2.4. 
DEPTH FILTER HOUSING 
 
 
 
Depth filter housings shall have a fully drainable machined base. The tie-rod adapters shall be of spring and screw 
 
design within the depth filter base.  Each depth filter shall be provided with the correct adapter assembly, 
 
dependent on what depth filter element the Owner may utilize.  In applications where the center adapter is 
 
required, it shall be removable with an O-ring elastomeric material. 
 
 
 
Any required depth filter element tie-rod base adapter or Code 226/227 filter element shall be capable of locking 
 
into the base below the housing base elevation to help promote process and cleaning fluid drainability.  
 
Specifically, the depth filter base shall be interchangeable with either the center post adapter, or Code 226/227 
 
filter element. Depth filter housings shall be capable of being cleaned by a top or bottom adapter spray ball for 
 
cleaning in place.   
 
 
 
If a split dome is specified, a sanitary clamp shall secure the sections of the split dome.  All depth filter housings 
 
with a specified depth filter element size above a two high stack shall be of split dome design, in which an operator 
 
of normal height can reach into the bottom section and be able to remove the bottom depth filter stack.  The 
 
Manufacturer shall ensure that removal and addition of the top split section of the depth filter housing will not 
 
compromise the elements in any way. 
 
 
 
Filter cartridges shall be supported by a center post of a sanitary design that incorporates a sealing system 
 
sufficient to maintain cartridge position during process operations.   Adapters shall be supplied as indicated on 
 
the referenced data sheet(s) to accommodate varying number of cartridges within each housing. 
 
 
 
 
 
Manufacturers:  Subject to compliance with requirements, provide filter housings from one of the following: 
 
 
 
Allegheny Bradford 
 
GE 
 
Millipore 
 
Seitz (Pall) 
 
Cuno (3M) Sartorius 
 
 
 
2.5. 
SURFACE FINISH 
 
 
 
When indicated as required on the data sheets, all surfaces, including accessories, in contact with process fluids 
 
shall be mechanically polished to a final finish as indicated on the data sheets.  Surface finish shall be measured 
 
by a calibrated profilometer, after a successively built up mechanical polish is completed, and after 
 
electropolishing if required.  All interior welds shall be ground smooth and successively polished and 
 
electropolished to the same finish as the adjoining surfaces. 
 
 
 
Each polishing operation shall completely remove the polishing marks from the previous polishing operation; the 
 
Owner or the Owner's representative reserves the right to inspection.  Surfaces in contact with product shall be 
 
free from visible scratches, burrs, pits, flash, folds, nicks, inclusions, crevices, and the Owner or the Owner's 
 
representative reserves the right to inspection. 
 
 
 
2.6. 
CLEANING AND PASSIVATION 
 
 
 
After the filter housing has been completely fabricated and pressure tested, all interior and wetted surfaces shall 
 
be detergent cleaned, then passivated (if required on data sheet) prior to inspection by the Owner or Owner's 
 
representative.  Gas filter housings shall be cleaned for oxygen service (CFOS) per CGA4.1, if stated on the 
 
datasheet. 
 
 
 
2.7. 
HOUSING ACCESSORIES 
 
 
 
Refer to the referenced data sheet(s) for the specific accessories required for each filter housing as indicated in 
 
the Table of Contents.  Specifications for each accessory type that will be supplied by the housing Manufacturer 
 
are described below.   
 
 
 
2.7.1. Spray Device 
 
 
 
Filter housings with an 8” internal diameter and larger shall be provided with spray devices.  For diameters less 
 
than 8” the Manufacturer shall determine if spray devices are required to ensure full cleaning of the housing 
 
 
 
All spray devices shall be constructed of the same material, and finished (internally and externally) to the same 
 
polish specification as for the internal, wetted areas of the housing to which the device is intended.  They shall 
 
mount to the housing and to CIP supply and process lines using sanitary tri-clamp type connections.  The housing 
 
Manufacturer shall be responsible for the complete coverage of the wetted internals of the housing for which the 
 
spray device(s) will service.  If more flow, pressure, or spray devices will be required, as determined by the 
 
housing Manufacturer, in order to meet the wetting requirements above, as well as pass the FAT spray tests 
 
indicated elsewhere in this specification, then the Manufacturer shall notify the Owner and Engineer in writing 
 
of the proposed changes.  The changes will be reviewed, and approval shall be required prior to making changes 
 
to the specified design as indicated in the data sheet(s). 
 
 
 
In addition, the hole pattern on the spray device(s) shall be such that all nozzles exposed to the inside of the 
 
housing are completely wetted.  The spray balls shall be welded to the upstream supply tubing, and the entire ball 
 
and tube assembly shall be removable from the housing through the nozzle in which it will be mounted.  All spray 
 
balls shall have a drain hole at their low points when the balls are installed in their operational orientation.  Two 
 
 
 
holes shall also be drilled 180° apart on the supply tube for each spray ball at a location that is inside the housing 
 
nozzle in which it will be inserted, to enhance the cleaning of these nozzles.  Once the position of each spray ball 
 
is determined and drill patterns have been set, they shall be configured with an external locating pin that shall be 
 
mated with a locating bracket and hole that will prevent the spray ball from being installed in any other position.   
 
 
 
Each spray ball assembly shall be permanently marked with the equipment tag number of the housing to which it 
 
belongs. 
 
 
 
2.7.2. Legs, Casters, and Supports 
 
 
 
All supports for filter housings shall be sized and installed by the Manufacturer to safely support the housing(s) 
 
in the seismic zone specified in Section 110010 Equipment General Requirements, when completely filled with 
 
product solution, and under the operating conditions indicated on the referenced data sheet(s). 
 
 
 
All filter housings shall also be configured for portability as indicated as necessary on the referenced data sheet(s).  
 
The housing can be mounted on a portable cart or with casters on the housing legs.   
 
 
 
If casters are required, each leg shall be fitted with a stainless steel caster with a non-marking polyurethane wheel.  
 
Each housing shall be configured with non-swivel casters on one side of the unit, and lockable swivel casters on 
 
the other side of the unit.  The castor mounting plates and corresponding leg plates shall have radiused corners.  
 
The legs shall be configured in such a manner that the casters are no closer to the centerline of the housing than 
 
the housing sidewall and shall be sufficiently splayed to provide safe movement of the housing containing wetted 
 
membranes.  If necessary, there shall be a stiffening support between each leg and its adjacent leg, no higher than 
 
four inches above the caster mounting height, constructed of round stainless steel pipe or stock.  Stiffening support 
 
shall be placed as to not restrict access to housing nozzles. 
 
 
 
If required, the filter housing(s) shall be provided with a minimum of one push handle located on the housing at 
 
40-42 inches off the floor.    
 
 
 
2.7.3. Nameplate 
 
 
 
Provide each filter housing with a permanently attached, exterior nameplate positioned in an accessible location.  
 
This nameplate is in addition to the ASME nameplate and does not replace the ASME nameplate that is required 
 
and defined in the ASME code.  Nameplate shall be in accordance with the requirements listed in Section 200553 
 
Tagging and Identification. 
 
 
 
2.7.4. Jackets 
 
 
 
Filter housing jackets, where necessary, shall be pressure rated for the same pressure as the filter to full vacuum 
 
as indicated on the data sheet.  Jackets for steam service shall have the inlet at the top and outlet at the bottom of 
 
the jacket. 
 
 
 
2.7.5. Heat Tracing 
 
 
 
Filter housings which require electric heat tracing are indicated on the data sheet. 
 
 
 
 
 
EXECUTION 
 
 
 
3.1. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
 
 
The following shall be done when an FAT is part of the purchase agreement. The Manufacturer shall assist Factory 
 
Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and indicated below.  FAT is in addition to the ASME pressure tests 
 
 
 
and other tests as required by code. The Manufacturer shall submit the schedule for FAT to the Owner and 
 
Engineer.  FAT shall be conducted at the Manufacturer's facility with the Owner or Owner's representative 
 
present, who shall be notified at least two weeks prior to the anticipated test date.   
 
 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and specified in Section 
 
110010 Equipment General Requirements.  See attached specifications for additional FAT requirements.  The 
 
following items shall be the required tests to be performed at the FAT. 
 
 
 
General Verifications: 
 
 
 
• 
Verify the filter housing adherence to specifications, datasheets and project documentation. 
 
• 
Verify compliance with approval drawings, including P&IDs. 
 
• 
Verify the system dimensions – footprint, height, and nozzle arrangement. 
 
• 
Review of turnover package for accuracy and completeness. 
 
• 
Verify the calibration reports for instruments used during FAT. 
 
 
 
Spray Device Coverage:  If spray devices are required in the data sheets, then a spray device coverage test shall 
 
be performed. The Manufacturer shall provide a surge vessel, hoses and circulating pump capable of the required 
 
flow rate and pressure (not to exceed housing pressure) for the proper operation of the spray device(s) of each 
 
housing to be tested.  All wetted components of the test equipment shall be either stainless steel or plastic, and 
 
shall leave no residue other than the test indicator solution on the housing(s) to be tested.  This test shall be for 
 
the purpose of evaluating the spray device(s) for coverage and shadowing.  The test indicator solution shall be an 
 
aqueous riboflavin solution at a nominal concentration of 100 ppm of Eastman Kodak #EK117712 Reagent Grade 
 
Riboflavin Orange powder (1 gram of powder per 10 liters of water) or approved equivalent. 
 
 
 
All internal, wetted accessories that are indicated on each housing data sheet shall be installed on that housing as 
 
part of the spray coverage testing of that housing.  The test indicator solution shall be applied to all the interior 
 
surfaces of the housing (including the inside of all nozzles and their associated caps) by some method other than 
 
using the actual spray devices and the test equipment (e.g., a spray bottle and/or by filling the housing completely 
 
with the test indicator solution, then draining it completely).   
 
 
 
The test indicator solution shall be allowed to completely drain from the housing, and the interior of the housing, 
 
including internal accessories, shall be inspected for complete coverage with the test indicator solution prior to 
 
beginning the spray coverage testing.  The inspection shall be conducted with a UV "black" light, and more test 
 
indicator solution shall be re-applied to any areas that are not covered. Test water flow shall be initiated at the 
 
flow rate and pressure required for the correct operation of the spray device(s), and shall flow for 30 seconds with 
 
the bottom outlet of the housing wide open to drain (no re-circulation back to the surge housing).   
 
 
 
The initiation of flow shall mark the beginning of the spray coverage test.  After the test has ended, allow the 
 
housing to drain. The interior of the housing, including accessories, shall be completely inspected with a UV light 
 
to determine if any residual test indicator solution remains after the test.  If any residual test indicator solution is 
 
detected, another 30 second rinse burst shall be applied, and the interior of the housing re-inspected.  If any 
 
residual test indicator solution is detected, the spray device(s) shall be adjusted and/or modified (e.g., more or 
 
larger holes in spray balls, re-positioning of spray device(s), increased flow rate and/or pressure), and the entire 
 
test repeated, including a fresh application of test indicator solution.   
 
 
 
Once a satisfactory test has been completed (no residual test indicator solution detected), it shall be repeated to 
 
verify the successful results.  The test will be considered successful only when two successful test runs have been 
 
completed in series.  The Manufacturer shall document each and every test, and shall include the time and date 
 
of each test, rinse (spray) time, modifications made (if any), and the areas that failed the visual inspection (if any) 
 
in every test. 
 
 
 
 
 
Drainability Testing:  Water shall be introduced and allowed to pool in the housing base with the bottom port 
 
capped.  The bottom port cap shall then be removed and the liquid allowed to drain into a catch container.  No 
 
liquid shall remain pooled at any location in the housing base. 
 
 
 
Surface Finish Testing:  The Manufacturer shall make available an averaging profilometer along with a sample 
 
that can be agreed to be “acceptable” (retain duplicate of original sample submitted; i.e., original sample to be 
 
provided to Owner for record keeping purposes) for establishing accuracy.  Each housing shall be visually 
 
inspected in its entirety with areas of concern noted with tape flags or Post-it notes.  These points shall then be 
 
inspected using the following procedure: 
 
 
 
• 
The area to be inspected shall be cleaned using acetone and a clean, lint free rag. 
 
• 
The surface area being checked shall be recorded. 
 
• 
Readings shall be taken in three directions, two of which shall be 90° apart. 
 
• 
All readings shall be recorded. 
 
 
 
A minimum of four and a maximum of six points shall be checked on the interior of each housing with the top 
 
and bottom head each being checked.  The exterior of the housing shall also be inspected in this manner with a 
 
maximum of five points measured.  Failure of two or more points may require additional testing.  The 
 
Manufacturer shall provide access to all surfaces.  The housing(s) will be evaluated to determine compliance with 
 
the specifications.  The Manufacturer shall rework any areas not meeting the specification.   
 
 
 
3.1.1. Testing Responsibility Matrix

STAINLESS STEEL PROCESS VESSEL

2.7. SURFACE FINISH ........................................................................................................................... 4 
2.8. INSULATION .................................................................................................................................. 4
