3.2. FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) ................................................................................ 8 
3.3. SITE ACCEPTANCE TESTING (SAT) ........................................................................................ 11 
3.4. ASSEMBLY, DELIVERY, STORAGE AND HANDLING .......................................................... 12 
 
 
PART 1.- GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
This specification covers the detailed requirements for design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and delivery of 
stainless steel vessels.  
 
1.2. 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide equipment as indicated in the Equipment Schedule below.  
 
EQUIPMENT SCHEDULE 
EQUIPMENT 
NUMBER 
P&ID NUMBER 
CAPACITY 
NAME 
LA5V101 
34-0200-031 
9,000 Liters 
Pooling Vessel 1 
LA5V102 
34-0200-032 
9,000 Liters 
Pooling Vessel 2 
LA5V103 
34-0200-033 
9,000 Liters 
Pooling Vessel 3 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1.3. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
Refer to specification section 110010 and the Vendor Documentation Requirements (VDR) list for submittal 
requirements and definitions. This does not relieve the manufacturer from supplying any additional 
documentation as specified by the applicable codes and standards, or other submittal requirements as indicated in 
attached specifications. 
 
Provide a review set of documents at FAT. Documents may change as a result of the FAT. Final revisions are to 
be shipped with the equipment and shall arrive no later than the equipment. 
 
1.4. 
AVAILABLE UTILITIES     
 
The utilities listed on the data sheet are available at the proposed installation site. The Manufacturer’s equipment 
shall operate utilizing these connections unless otherwise stated and agreed upon by Owner. The manufacturer 
shall provide utility usage, including peak and run load in standard American units for equipment specified.  
 
1.5. 
COORDINATION 
 
The vessel Manufacturer shall be responsible for coordinating with manufacturers of accessory components that 
are indicated to be installed on the vessel. This includes agitators, sight and light glasses, spray devices, load cells, 
mechanical seals, pressure and temperature indicators, and valves that will be welded to the vessel. Unless 
indicated otherwise elsewhere in this specification or on the attached data sheets, the vessel Manufacturer shall 
purchase and install all accessories indicated as required on the attached data sheets. 
 
If the Owner provides the agitator, the Owner or Engineer will supply the vessel Manufacturer with information 
on the agitator, including model, weight, size, and torque load. The agitator will be shipped to the vessel 
Manufacturer for installation prior to FAT, unless indicated otherwise. Whether the agitator will be provided by 
the Owner or by the vessel Manufacturer, the vessel Manufacturer shall be responsible for all other coordination 
activities with the agitator manufacturer, including connection type and size, impeller quantity and size, 
interference with vessel internals and agitator dimensions. 
 
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
GENERAL 
 
Vessels shall be designed, fabricated, and stamped in accordance with applicable ASME codes to the maximum 
allowable working pressure (vessel design pressure rating) as indicated on the data sheets. Vessels shall be tested 
and code-stamped after installation of all welded nozzles and valves, but prior to mounting and attachment of all 
vessel accessories.  
 
Each vessel shall be adequately supported to carry the weight of the vessel and all attached equipment, including 
agitators (including dynamic load), vent filters, spray devices, etc., when completely filled with the process fluid 
indicated on the data sheets. Supports shall be designed for the seismic requirements indicated in Specification 
110010 and 230241. The vessel shall be completely supported by the support structure indicated on the data sheet 
and not by any connected piping or components.  
 
2.2. 
MATERIALS 
 
Materials used for fabrication shall be new and free from defects. 
 
Product vessel, all fittings used for fittings or other wetted components, all metals in contact with product, all 
metal accessories, and sheathing shall be constructed of stainless steel of type indicated on the data sheets. 
Manufacturer shall supply complete documentation to support Material Requirements. 
 
All gasket material shall be as per elastomer material specified on data sheet. Gaskets shall meet current USP 
Sections 87 and 88 Class VI requirements. Manufacturer shall supply complete documentation to support USP 
Class VI compliance. 
 
2.3. 
WELDING 
 
All welding shall be done by certified welders in accordance with the applicable requirements of the latest revision 
of the following codes: 
 
ASME Code - "Standard Qualification for Welding Procedure and Welding Operator". 
ASME Code - Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code, Section VIII, Division 1. 
 
Vessel welding of product contact weld surfaces shall be by the Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW) process. 
Welds can be filled with Gas Metal Arc Welding (GMAW) process if and only if the first pass or root weld has 
been done with GTAW process. Non-product contact welds may be by GMAW process. All seam welds shall be 
full penetration per ASME Code, Table UW12, Type Number 1. Nozzles and other appurtenances shall be located 
away from any weld seams. Otherwise, plate layout shall minimize the amount of welding. 
 
Welds on the interior of vessels shall be ground smooth and flush with adjoining surfaces, to the same finish as 
the vessel interior before the vessel is tested. Interior surfaces in contact with process fluids shall be free from 
visible scratches, burrs, pits, flash, folds, nicks, inclusions, crevices, and other defects discernible by profilometer 
or magnification inspection. No visible heat tint is permissible.  
 
2.4. 
NOZZLES 
 
All nozzles shall have the same surface finish as the adjacent surfaces, including electropolish as required. All 
nozzles shall have traceable heat numbers and documentation to prove material of construction. Ferrule 
connections shall project a minimum distance from the surface of the vessel. The manufacturer shall assure 
sufficient distance is provided to easily operate the sanitary clamps.  
 
Insulation and sheathing shall be cut back around all vessel nozzles. Vessel nozzles shall not be extended to allow 
placement of insulation without cutouts at the fittings. Group vessel nozzles together where practical to minimize 
insulation cut-backs. 
 
2.5. 
MANWAYS AND REMOVABLE TOP HEADS 
 
Provide a sanitary pressure manway of size indicated on data sheet. Each manway shall be provided with a spring 
assist hinge, a lifting handle and sanitary clamp and lugs on swivel studs for closure. Gasket sealing design shall 
assure cleanability of closure surfaces.  
 
Each vessel specified or configured with a removable top head shall incorporate a gasket and sealing design 
similar to that of the manway indicated above.  
 
Acceptable Vendors 
A&B Process 
DCI PharmAssist 
Holloway 
OLSA 
Paul Mueller Company 
 
 
 
 
 
2.6. 
HEAT TRANSFER JACKET 
 
Heat transfer jackets shall be of type and coverage as indicated on data sheet with adequate heat transfer surface 
to achieve the heating and cooling requirements as indicated on the data sheet. If the jacket is dimpled style, it 
shall be spot welded to the exterior wall of the vessel at all inward dimple locations to promote higher and more 
even heat transfer rates. The heat transfer jacket shall be cut back around any vessel nozzles and completely seal 
welded to the vessel wall around the cut back.  
 
The upper nozzle on any jacket shall be located as high as possible to allow the jacket to fully vent and fill without 
air-locking. The lower nozzle on any jacket shall be located so that the entire jacket can be completely drained of 
heat transfer fluid. 
 
2.7. 
SURFACE FINISH 
 
When indicated as required on the data sheets, all surfaces, including accessories, in contact with process fluids 
shall be mechanically polished to a final finish as indicated on the data sheets. Surface finish shall be measured 
by a profilometer, after a successively built-up mechanical polish is completed, and after electropolishing if 
required. All interior welds shall be ground smooth and successively polished and electropolished to the same 
finish as the adjoining surfaces. 
 
Each polishing operation shall completely remove the polishing marks from the previous polishing operation, as 
judged by visual inspection by the Owner or the Owner's representative. Surfaces in contact with product shall be 
free from visible scratches, burrs, pits, flash, folds, nicks, inclusions, crevices, and other defects as judged by the 
Owner or the Owner's representative. 
 
2.8. 
INSULATION 
 
Insulation shall be non-asbestos, chloride free type indicated on data sheet. Insulation shall be completely covered 
with stainless steel sheathing and shall include a weep hole. Stainless steel in contact with the insulation shall be 
primed with a Thurmalox mastic coating prior to insulating. Sheathing shall be seam welded, blended and ground 
smooth. Insulation supports welded to the vessel shall be 316 L stainless steel. 
 
2.9. 
VESSEL ACCESSORIES 
 
Refer to the attached vessel data sheet(s) for the specific accessories required for each vessel indicated in the 
Equipment Schedule above.  
 
2.9.1. 
Agitators 
 
The Manufacturer shall supply the agitator if indicated on the data sheet. The agitator is fully specified in 
specification 432216 and associated data sheets. 
 
Acceptable Vendors 
Lightnin 
Chemineer 
Approved Equivalent 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
2.9.2. 
Spray Devices 
 
No threaded connections shall be allowed. Spray assemblies shall have a hole in the length of the down tube 
located inside the mounting nozzle to facilitate cleaning of the mounting nozzle. Each spray device assembly shall 
be permanently marked with the following: equipment tag number of the vessel to which it belongs, unique 
identifier of the spray device, and nozzle tag for the spray device installation. Spray device nozzles shall be 
permanently marked with the unique identifier of the corresponding spray device. 
 
Static spray devices shall be sized and drilled to provide a total flow rate that corresponds to 3 gpm per linear foot 
of internal circumference of the vessel, unless indicated otherwise on the data sheet. The pressure drop across the 
spray device shall be limited to the greatest extent possible. In constant flow installations, such as WFI storage 
vessels, the pressure drop across the spray device shall not exceed 15 psig. Flow directed from the spray device 
towards the vessel drain shall be minimized. In addition, the pattern of holes shall be directed to ensure all vessel 
nozzles are completely wetted, as well as all surfaces of all items inserted in the vessel during CIP cycles. The 
spray device shall be fully welded to the down tube. The spray device and tube assembly shall be removable 
through the nozzle in which it is mounted. All spray devices shall have a drain hole at their low points when the 
devices are installed in their operational orientation. Once the position of each spray device is determined and 
drill patterns have been set, each spray device shall be configured with an external locating pin that shall be mated 
with a locating bracket and hole.  
 
Rotating spray devices shall completely wet, by direct impingement, all internal surfaces of the vessel, including 
all nozzles and inserted accessories. The duration of the complete spray pattern shall be less than four minutes. 
The rotating action shall be powered by the CIP solution flow, and all machinery required for operation shall be 
located externally to the vessel.  
 
The vessel Manufacturer must state an exception in the bid and provide revised numbers if he believes CIP flow 
rates, pressures and volumes indicated in this specification will not achieve successful coverage of the vessel and 
all internals. 
 
2.9.3. 
Baffles 
 
Internal baffles shall be installed on the straight side wall of the vessel(s) of the quantity and size indicated on the 
data sheet(s). Each baffle shall be oriented perpendicular to the vessel wall. All corners of each baffle shall be 
rounded to a minimum ½" radius, and all edges shall be rounded and smooth. The use of bolts to secure the baffles 
to the vessel is unacceptable. 
 
2.9.4. 
Dip Tubes and J-tubes 
 
Dip tubes and J-tubes shall be welded to a sanitary cap and mounted to the ferrule of the size indicated on the data 
sheet and shall terminate outside the vessel at a sanitary tri-clamp style fitting for process connection. Final dip 
tube length shall be determined during shop drawing review. J-tubes shall direct flow to the sidewall of the vessel 
using a no-foam design and shall have a locator pin to ensure proper orientation when installed.  
 
2.9.5. 
Bottom Outlet Valves 
 
Bottom outlet valves shall be of the flush-mounted welded body radial diaphragm type. The body shall be a two 
piece design held together with a sanitary clamp connection. The vessel side of the valve body shall be 
continuously welded to the low point of the bottom head of the vessel. Material shall not be added to the bottom 
head of the vessel to create a “well” in which to weld the valve. If the vessel is insulated, the insulation and 
sheathing shall be cut back to allow for the un-hindered connection of process piping and/or integral satellite 
valve and actuator if designated on data sheet. The valve(s) shall be supplied with the type and style of actuator 
indicated on the data sheet. 
 
 
Valves shall have the same surface finish as the adjacent surfaces, including electropolish as required. The vessel 
Manufacturer shall weld the valve bodies to the vessel, polish the weld seams to meet the requirement of the 
vessels, and then, if indicated on the corresponding data sheet, electropolish the vessel and valve together to meet 
the vessel’s surface specification. 
 
Acceptable Vendors 
Asepco 
Millipore/NovAseptic 
Approved Equivalent 
 
2.9.6. 
Sampling Assembly Enclosure 
 
Sampling will occur in an enclosure, which shall be provided by the vessel manufacturer as specified on the 
datasheet. Disposable sampling assembly is provided by the Owner.  
 
Enclosure shall be fixed to the vessel and constructed of materials as listed on the datasheet with a sloped basin 
to drain with drain valve. This enclosure is intended to be like a sink basin, large enough for manipulations of the 
sampling assembly and holding sample collection containers, with enough depth to capture and direct fluid from 
manipulating assemblies to drain instead of spilling to the floor. 
 
Piping from the drain valve to a floor drain or other collection area shall be field-routed and provided by Others. 
 
2.9.7. 
Vortex Breakers 
 
Where indicated on the attached data sheets, vessels shall be equipped with a vortex breaker centered and located 
directly over the center of the bottom outlet port or valve of the vessel. The vortex breaker shall be of the cross 
design which shall be welded directly to the interior of the bottom head of the vessel. It shall be constructed of 
three (3) inch wide, 1/8" flat bar, with each leg of the cross extending a minimum of two (2) inches beyond the 
edge of the opening made by the bottom outlet. The vortex breaker shall be continuously welded to the bottom 
head of the vessel and to itself at its intersection. The corners of the flat bar not welded to the vessel shall be 
configured with a minimum ½" radius, and all edges shall be rounded and smooth. 
 
2.9.8. 
Sight and Light Glasses 
 
Sight and light glasses shall be constructed of a duplex stainless steel frame fused to a chemical and scratch 
resistant pre-stressed borosilicate glass viewing window. Each unit shall mount to the vessel using a sanitary 
connection and shall provide a flush surface after mounting. The pressure rating of each unit shall be equal to or 
greater than the vessel pressure rating.  
 
Acceptable Vendors  
LJ Star 
Canty 
Approved Equivalent 
 
2.9.9. 
Lights 
 
Lights shall consist of a 24VDC/120VAC power source and an encapsulated LED lamp with a built-in reflector 
to provide glare-free, cool-light illumination. . Lights shall meet NEMA 4X electrical enclosure requirements. 
Lights shall be supplied with push button on/off switch and a minimum of 6’ of power cord. The lights shall be 
constructed of a corrosion-resistant alloy and shall be moisture-proof. The lights shall be mounted to direct a wide 
dispersion angle of light inside the tank. Each light shall be mounted over a sight glass, of the size indicated on 
the vessel data sheet. When indicated on the data sheets, the unit shall be intrinsically safe or have an explosion 
proof design. 
 
 
Acceptable Vendors  
LJ Star 
Canty 
Approved Equivalent 
 
2.9.10. Legs, Casters, and Supports 
 
All fixed vessels that are indicated as having legs shall be equipped with adjustable legs that will allow for 1" of 
adjustment. Any required leg bracing shall be designed to allow access to the nozzle and instruments at the bottom 
heat of the vessel. An 1/8” weep hole shall be provided near the base of each leg, facing to the inside of the vessel. 
 
Sidewall supports (lugs) shall be welded directly to the vessel wall and reinforcing steel shall be used when 
required. Lugs shall extend a minimum of eight (8) inches beyond the insulation sheathing, or beyond the vessel 
sidewall if no insulation is required. 
 
2.9.11. Grounding Lugs 
 
Provide a grounding lug on each vessel that will be located on either the lower sidewall or bottom head, with final 
location to be determined during review of shop drawings. Lugs shall be at least 1/4" thick with a 3/8" diameter 
hole, of the same material and finish as the exterior of the vessel. The lug shall be attached in a manner that will 
allow for complete grounding of the vessel via the lug. 
 
2.9.12. Platforms 
 
When required, provide platforming for each vessel as specified on the datasheets. Platforming shall provide 
accessibility to routinely maintained nozzles on the top head and view into all sight glasses on the vessel. 
Continuous platforming is not required. Instead, sections should be constructed to provide access to priority areas. 
 
Construct platforming from closed steel members and “diamond” plate   
 
Any required platforms shall conform with applicable building codes and standards and shall be designed and 
stamped by a licensed structural engineer registered in California. 
 
See Specification 230241 for additional Structural Requirements. 
 
2.10. ELECTRICAL 
 
Power to each vessel shall be provided by the facility to a single point of connection per power type as listed on 
the data sheet. 
 
The Manufacturer shall warrant that all wiring and electrical components shall comply with the NEC, as well as 
all applicable local electrical codes. All wiring and components shall be rated appropriately and suitable for the 
environment in which the equipment is installed.  
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
SPARE COMPONENTS 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide the following items: 
• 
One complete set of unused gaskets for all nozzles, including manway, with the vessel, in addition 
to the set installed on the vessel. 
• 
Provide two extra rupture disks for each rupture disk assembly.  
• 
Provide end cap, sanitary clamp and gasket for all free sanitary connections on the vessel. 
 
• 
Provide one spare agitator mechanical seal. 
 
3.1.1. 
Cleaning and Passivation 
 
After the vessel has been completely fabricated and pressure tested, all interior and wetted surfaces shall be 
detergent cleaned, then passivated (if required on data sheet) prior to inspection by the Owner or Owner's 
representative. The cleaning and passivation procedure shall be that which was reviewed and approved under the 
Submittals section.  
 
3.2. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and specified in Section 
110010. See attached specifications for additional FAT requirements. The following items shall be the required 
tests to be performed at FAT. 
 
3.2.1. 
General Verifications 
 
• 
Verify the vessel adherence to specifications, datasheets and project documentation. 
• 
Verify compliance with approval drawings, including P&IDs   
• 
Verify the system dimensions –footprint, height, and nozzle arrangement. 
• 
Review of Turnover package for accuracy and completeness 
 
3.2.2. 
Pressure Hold Test 
 
Fill vessel with DI water or owner-approved purified water to the maximum working volume. Pressurize vessel 
with clean compressed, oil free and filtered air (or nitrogen) to 1.5 times the operating pressure indicated on the 
data sheet and hold for at least 4 hours. Vessel should be rejected if leaks across gasketed surfaces cannot not be 
stopped when closures have been tightened to the required torque (no sealants shall be used). 
 
The agitator(s) (if so equipped and installed by the vessel Manufacturer) will be operated at minimum speed for 
at least 1 hour of the hold period, and at maximum speed for at least 1 hour. The maximum allowable pressure 
drop over the test period shall be 2 psi. 
 
3.2.3. 
Hydrostatic Pressure Test 
 
Hydrotest water shall be DI water or owner-approved purified water. The hydrotest will be performed at rated 
pressures for the vessel. 
 
3.2.4. 
Spray Device Coverage Test – Top Head 
 
Vessel top heads shall be tested, with all appurtenances installed, separate from and prior to attachment to the 
shell, in order to facilitate the inspection process. The head shall be retested as part of the overall vessel test after 
it has been attached to the shell.  This test shall evaluate the spray devices for coverage and shadowing.  
 
The test indicator solution shall be an aqueous riboflavin solution at a nominal concentration of 100 ppm. The 
test indicator solution shall be applied to all the interior surfaces of the top head by some method other than using 
the actual spray devices and the test equipment. The vessel shall be inspected with a UV "black" light for complete 
coverage of the test indicator solution. More test indicator solution shall be re-applied to any areas that are not 
covered. 
 
Water flow shall be initiated at the flow rate and pressure required of the spray devices, as indicated on the 
approved shop drawings. Water shall flow for 30 seconds for static spray devices or one complete cycle for 
rotating devices, with the bottom outlet of the vessel open to drain. The 30-second bursts shall be repeated 3 times 
per static spray device, or two complete cycles for rotating devices.  
 
After the test has ended, allow top head to drain. The interior of the top head, including accessories, shall be 
completely inspected with a UV light to determine if ANY residual riboflavin remains after the test. If any residual 
riboflavin is detected, the spray devices shall be adjusted and/or modified, and the entire test repeated, including 
a fresh application of riboflavin. Once a satisfactory test has been completed, it shall be repeated to verify the 
successful results. The test shall be considered successful only when two successful test runs have been completed 
in series.  
 
The Manufacturer shall document each and every test and shall include the time and date of each test, spray 
duration, number of sprays, modifications made, flowrate and pressure, and the areas that failed the visual 
inspection, in every test. 
 
3.2.5. 
Spray Device Coverage Test – Fully Assembled Vessel 
 
The Manufacturer shall provide a surge vessel, hoses, and circulating pump capable of the required flow rate and 
pressure (not to exceed vessel Maximum Allowable Working Pressure, MAWP) for the proper operation of the 
spray devices of each vessel to be tested. The test shall include flow rate ranges to meet the minimum and 
maximum pressures required to ensure proper spray coverage. All wetted components of the test equipment shall 
be either stainless steel or plastic and shall leave no residue other than the test indicator solution on the vessel to 
be tested. The test indicator solution shall be an aqueous riboflavin solution at a nominal concentration of 100 
ppm.  
 
Install all internal, wetted accessories indicated on each vessel datasheet 434113 for testing. 
 
The test indicator solution shall be applied to all the interior surfaces of the vessel by some method other than 
using the actual spray devices and the test equipment. Internal surface of the vessel includes the top head. The 
vessel shall be inspected with a UV "black" light for complete coverage of the test indicator solution. More test 
indicator solution shall be re-applied to any areas that are not covered. 
 
Water flow shall be initiated at the flow rate and pressure required of the spray devices, as indicated on the 
approved shop drawings. Water shall flow for 30 seconds for static spray devices or one complete cycle for 
rotating devices, with the bottom outlet of the vessel open to drain. The 30-second bursts shall be repeated three 
(3) times per static spray device, or two (2) complete cycles for rotating devices.  
 
After the test has ended, allow vessel to drain. The interior of the vessel, including accessories, shall be completely 
inspected with a UV light to determine if ANY residual riboflavin remains after the test. If any residual riboflavin 
is detected, the spray devices shall be adjusted and/or modified, and the entire test repeated, including a fresh 
application of riboflavin. Once a satisfactory test has been completed, it shall be repeated to verify the successful 
results. The test shall be considered successful only when two (2) successful test runs have been completed in 
series.  
 
The Manufacturer shall document each and every test and shall include the time and date of each test, spray 
duration, number of sprays, modifications made, flowrate and pressure, and the areas that failed the visual 
inspection, in every test. Any spray device that was modified (drilled) during testing shall be re-passivated. 
 
3.2.6. 
Drainability Test 
 
The vessel shall be leveled prior to testing. Water shall be introduced into the vessel, up to the bottom tangent 
line with the bottom valve closed (or bottom port capped if the vessel is not specified with an integral bottom 
valve). The bottom outlet valve shall then be opened (or cap removed) to gravity drain the vessel. There shall be 
no puddles of water left on the bottom of the vessel greater than five (5) mm in diameter. If there are any puddles 
larger than five (5) mm in diameter, a thumb or soft rubber dowel is to be pushed into the center of the puddle, 
displacing the water. If water returns to the puddle, that area shall be repaired to the satisfaction of the Owner. 
 
 
3.2.7. 
Surface Finish Test 
 
The Manufacturer shall make available an averaging profilometer calibrated with NIST traceable certifications, 
along with a sample that can be agreed to be “acceptable” (retain duplicate of original sample submitted) for 
establishing accuracy. Each vessel shall be visually inspected in its entirety with areas of concern noted with tape 
flags or post it notes. These points shall then be inspected using the following procedure: 
 
• 
The area to be inspected shall be cleaned using acetone and a clean, lint free rag. 
• 
The surface area being checked shall be recorded. 
• 
Readings shall be taken in three (3) directions, two (2) of which shall be 90° apart. 
• 
All readings shall be recorded. 
• 
A minimum of six (6) points shall be checked on the interior of each vessel with the top and bottom 
head each being checked. The exterior of the vessel shall also be inspected in this manner and with 
a minimum of four (4) points measured. Data points shall not be averaged together. Failure of two 
or more points may require additional testing. The Manufacturer shall provide access to all surfaces. 
The vessel will be evaluated to determine compliance with the specifications. The Manufacturer 
shall rework any areas not meeting the specification. 
• 
At completion of this testing a determination will be made as to any re-inspection of any vessels or 
the need for the Manufacturer to provide a representative at the job site to participate in Site 
Acceptance testing. 
 
3.2.8. 
Jacket Pressure Drop Test 
 
Connect vessel jacket to a recirculating pump system and fill with DI or owner-approved water. Recirculating 
pump should supply pressure approximately equal to the building jacket services supply pressure. After the jacket 
has been vented to remove air, circulate flow through the vessel jacket at the design flowrate. Measure and 
document jacket inlet pressure, outlet pressure and flowrate. After test is complete, vessel jacket should be 
completely drained and blown dry.  
 
3.2.9. 
Functional Test 
 
Movable and portable vessels shall be tested to verify that they safely resist overturn during movement of the 
vessel. Movement of the vessel shall be performed at the manufacturers shop. 
 
3.2.10. Agitator Tests  
 
The agitator shall be installed for the FAT test. Agitators will be inspected for surface finish, shaft run out (test 
indicator provided by manufacturer), stability, interference, and shadowing during spray device coverage test. 
See Specification 432216 for additional requirements.

3.3. 
SITE ACCEPTANCE TESTING (SAT)  
 
SAT will cover FAT items that were not addressed as well as making sure the new system is adequately integrated 
into the facility. 
 
3.3.1. 
Basic Testing/General Verification 
 
Basic testing will typically include an inspection of the system using the Issued for Construction Drawings to 
verify their accuracy. This testing will also include an inspection of the system to verify correct installation to 
specification. This testing will also include finish verification both on the inside and outside of the equipment to 
ensure no damage was incurred during transport. Testing may include some or all items from the FAT described 
under General Verification. 
 
3.3.2. 
CIP Testing 
 
Verification of the cleaning effectiveness of the CIP/cleaning cycle for the vessel. This could include on-site 
riboflavin testing using the plant provided CIP rinse system.  
 
 
3.4. 
ASSEMBLY, DELIVERY, STORAGE AND HANDLING 
 
The Manufacturer shall clean and dry each vessel prior to shipping. The cleaning shall be performed after the 
successful completion of the FAT. The vessel shall be cleaned with an alkaline detergent cleaning step, rinsed 
with DI water and then dried with documented oil-free, clean compressed air or filtered nitrogen prior to capping. 
 
After testing, cleaning and drying of the vessel and accessories, the entire assembly shall be dismantled and 
packed separately and securely prior to shipping. All accessories supplied by others shall be shipped in the original 
packing containers. No components shall be shipped loose. All sanitary connections shall be capped with gaskets, 
clamps, and stainless steel blind caps for shipment. All Ingold fittings shall be equipped with plugs for shipping. 
The exterior of the tank shall be wrapped in protective plastic wrap for shipment. 
 
Under no circumstances shall any vessel be shipped with an agitator installed in the vessel. With the exception of 
the weld stub for a bottom mounted magnetic drive agitator, all agitator components shall be removed from each 
vessel prior to shipment and shall be shipped in dedicated crates and packaging. 
 
 
END OF SECTION 
 
VS * - Vendor/Manufacturer to Supply Information

Division 45 
Process   
SECTION 458050 
CIP SKID 
 
 
INDEX 
PAGE 
 
PART 1. - GENERAL 
 
1.1. 
GENERAL 
 
This specification covers the detailed requirements for design, fabrication, assembly and testing of Clean-In-Place 
(CIP) skids that will be used to clean cGMP piping and equipment in an FDA licensed biotech facility.  This 
specification does not apply to equipment and components that are cleaned by hand.  The manufacturer shall 
provide equipment as indicated in the Table of Contents. 
 
Attached to and part of this specification are other specifications and data sheets for mechanical, electrical, 
instrumentation and control system components that will be required on the skids.  This specification covers items 
that are relevant specifically to CIP skids.  For items that are applicable to multiple types of process equipment 
(e.g. interior surface finish of sanitary pressure vessels), this specification does not give specific guidance but will 
discuss the issues as they relate to CIP design.  These items will be covered more specifically in the attachments. 
 
1.2. 
SUBMITTALS 
 
Reference specification section 110010 – Equipment General Requirements for submittal requirements.  This 
does not relieve the manufacturer from supplying any additional documentation as specified by the applicable 
codes and standards, or other submittal requirements as indicated in attached specifications.  
 
Provide a review set of documents at FAT.  Documents may change as a result of the FAT.  Final revisions are 
to be shipped with the equipment and shall arrive no later than the equipment. 
 
 
1.3. 
AVAILABLE UTILITIES     
 
The utilities listed on the data sheet are available at the proposed installation site.  The Manufacturer’s equipment 
shall operate utilizing these connections unless otherwise stated and agreed upon by the Owner.  The manufacturer 
shall provide utility usage, including peak and run load in standard US Customary Units for equipment specified.  
Manufacturer shall provide suitable piping terminations for utilities to a single point of connection. 
 
1.4. 
EXTRA MATERIAL  
 
Manufacturer shall provide extra materials as listed below: 
• 
Provide three extra rupture disks for each rupture disk assembly.  
• 
Provide two (2) complete sets of gaskets and O-ring seals for the complete system, including O-
rings for the heat exchanger. 
• 
Provide end cap, sanitary clamp and gasket for all free sanitary connections, both on the vessel and 
on the piping. 
• 
The Manufacturer shall provide a minimum of two (2) filter cartridges for each filter indicated on 
the PIDs or data sheets; one (1) of use during FAT, and one to be installed in the field during start-
up and commissioning activities. 
 
1.5. 
SPECIAL CONDITIONS 
 
Manufacturer shall include time in their bid proposal to review the specifications in detail with the Owner and the 
Owner’s Representative via teleconference prior to beginning engineering for the project.   
 
PART 2. - PRODUCTS 
 
2.1. 
BASIC SYSTEM DESCRIPTION 
 
The CIP skid shall be of the same operational design as indicated in the following paragraphs, as well as on the 
attached data sheets.  Where differences apply, they will be noted. 
 
The CIP skid shall be provided with the following components as a minimum: 
• 
One (1) Rinse/surge tank 
• 
Two (2) Wash/circulation tanks 
• 
CIP supply pump, variable frequency drive (VFD) compatible (VFD provided by others) 
• 
CIP supply heat exchanger 
• 
CIP return strainer 
• 
Air blow filter 
• 
Piping (w/single point connections for utilities where applicable) 
• 
Automated and manual valves 
• 
Instrumentation 
• 
Skid framing and support for all components. 
• 
Local Disconnect 
 
The CIP skid shall be capable of cleaning process equipment with integral air gaps (e.g., tanks), as well as closed 
pipe circuits.  Each unit shall be capable of operating in either a circulation (washes and circulated rinses) or once-
through mode (pre- and final rinses). 
 
 
2.1.1. 
Rinse and Wash Solutions 
 
Ambient WFI will be delivered directly from a WFI loop point-of-use valve (by others) to the rinse/surge tank on 
the skid, via a static spray ball.  At no time will water be returned to the rinse/surge tank, except during rinse/surge 
tank cleaning procedures (i.e., rinses will be to drain, via the CIP return piping on each skid, or circulated back to 
the wash/circulation tank). 
 
RO water will be delivered directly from a RO loop point-of-use valve (by others) to the wash/circulation tanks.  
Wash solutions shall be created in the wash/circulation tanks using a circulation loop that will return water directly 
to this tank via a j-tube in a separated top mounted nozzle with no spray ball.  Once created, wash solutions shall 
be delivered to the connected distribution system via the CIP supply pump and returned to the wash/circulation 
tank via a j-tube.  Circulated rinses shall be handled in the same manner, if pre-heating is required. 
 
Cleaning chemicals (detergents, caustics and acids) for the make-up of wash solutions will be supplied 
automatically to each system from the facility chemical distribution system operating at a constant pressure. Each 
CIP skid shall be capable of dosing the required volume of chemical solutions into the system in order to reach 
the desired conductivity.  The amount of chemical added for the wash solution should be based on a total volume 
set-point as determined during startup and commissioning.  The chemicals shall be supplied to the 
wash/circulation tank.  Water and chemicals shall be circulated on the skid via the wash/circulation tank until the 
desired (based on pre-programmed recipes) conductivity and/or time set point is reached, after which the solution 
shall be ready for delivery to the distribution system. 
 
A divert valve assembly shall be located downstream of all components on each CIP skid supply line and shall 
divert flow either directly to drain, to the distribution system or to the wash/circulation tank.  The CIP return line 
on each skid shall be configured with a divert valve assembly that will divert flow either directly to drain or into 
the wash/circulation tank via a top mounted nozzle with no spray device. 
 
2.1.2. 
Flow Control 
 
Each CIP skid will be required to provide different flow rates to the connected distribution system depending on 
the particular circuit piping or equipment to be cleaned.   
 
Flow control shall be accomplished using both a Variable Frequency Drive (VFD) (by others) on the CIP supply 
pump and a Coriolis flow meter on pump discharge line for analog flow control.  The control system shall set the 
CIP supply pump to a pre-set speed for each cycle, via the VFD, based on the maximum flow rate plus 15% that 
will be required for that cycle.   
 
The flow meter shall be used to provide feedback to adjust the VFD and shall vary depending on a particular 
phase of the cycle (e.g., solution make-up and corresponding direct circulation to the wash/circulation tank, supply 
to the distribution system, and diversion to drain).   
 
2.1.3. 
Temperature Control 
 
Each CIP skid shall be capable of maintaining required solution and rinse temperatures listed on the data sheet 
for all required flow rates using a heat exchanger.  Reference the attached heat exchanger data sheet for each CIP 
skid for more information regarding each unit.  The steam supply line on each skid shall be trapped and provided 
with a drip leg. 
 
2.1.4. 
Level Control 
 
The level in the rinse and wash tanks need to be controlled. All tanks will need to control level by opening or 
closing the water point of use valve on the water loop.  Level will be monitored in the tanks to make sure an 
adequate level is maintained. 
   
 
2.1.5. 
Drainability 
 
Each CIP skid shall be completely drainable, requiring at a minimum an automated casing drain (true low-point 
of skid) and automatic drain valve on the supply pump suction line.  At the end of each circulation cycle, the 
valves are opened until the tank is empty (level = 0), plus additional time afforded for piping. 
 
2.1.6. 
Air Blows 
 
Each CIP skid shall be capable of providing air blows using clean compressed air as indicated in the Available 
Utilities, at the pressure indicated.  The air shall be supplied to the system via an automated diaphragm valve.  
Upstream components on the air line shall include, at a minimum, a check valve and a 0.2 micron filter. 
 
2.1.7. 
Return of CIP Solution to CIP Skid 
 
If it is determined that additional motive force is required to move the CIP solution from its intended destination 
back to the CIP skid, a separate CIP return pump will be installed near the equipment and general cleaning area.  
CIP return pumps will be provided by others. 
 
2.2. 
BASIC FUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION  
 
Each CIP skid shall be fully automated.  The CIP skid will be controlled by the site DeltaV control system.  The 
control system shall also be capable of controlling valves on the supply and return distribution systems to which 
each skid will be connected.  Refer to the Instrumentation and Controls section in this specification and the 
Division 40 Specifications for more information on the control system. 
 
A typical CIP cycle will be as follows: 
1. Once through rinse to CIP waste system of piping/equipment circuit from 2nd wash tank using RO 
2. Fill wash/circulation tank from RO supply drop 
3. Charge caustic cleaning chemical into CIP system while heating solution 
4. Circulate caustic CIP wash solution through piping/equipment circuit and back to tank while 
simultaneously filling 2nd wash tank 
5. Discharge cleaning solution to CIP waste system 
6. Once through rinse to CIP waste system of piping/equipment circuit from 2nd wash tank using RO 
7. Air blow of piping/equipment circuit to drain followed by system vent 
8. Fill wash/circulation tank from rinse tank 
9. Charge acidic cleaning chemical into CIP system 
10. Circulate acidic CIP wash solution through piping/equipment circuit and back to tank while 
simultaneously filling 2nd wash tank 
11. Discharge cleaning solution to CIP waste system 
12. Rinse of piping/equipment circuit to CIP waste system from 2nd was tank using RO 
13. Air blow of piping/equipment circuit to drain followed by system vent 
14. Final WFI rinse of piping/equipment circuit to CIP waste system 
15. Air blow of piping/equipment circuit to drain followed by system vent 
16. Cleaning of the CIP skid (if required) 
 
2.3. 
SANITARY VESSELS 
 
All tanks on each CIP skid shall comply with the attached specification section 434113 – Stainless Steel Process 
Vessels, as well as the attached data sheets that comprise part of that specification.  Nozzles shall be arranged so 
that they can be easily accessed from outside the skid boundaries and allow for the normal operational service 
and removal of components mounted on each tank.  If a tank is to be mounted on load cells, the Manufacturer 
shall connect piping and wiring to the tank with flexible hoses and conduit, respectively, in such a manner as to 
not interfere with the normal operation of the load cells. 
 
 
2.4. 
PUMPS 
 
Refer to attached pump data sheets (specification 230540) for type, size, capacity, efficiency, and materials of 
construction.  Each CIP supply pump should be sized to handle the minimum and maximum flow rates at the 
required pump discharge pressures.  These flow conditions must occur at operational points on the pump curve 
in order to allow adequate control (i.e., not on a flat portion of the curve or near the operational extremes of dead 
heading or full run out).     
 
Pumps (and their corresponding gear boxes and motors) shall be secured to the skid framing with stainless steel 
hardware.  Delrin plastic, or approved equivalent, shall be used between the bases of pumps, motors and gear 
boxes and the frames in order to provide vibration dampening and mechanical protection.     
 
2.4.1. 
Centrifugal Pumps 
 
Centrifugal pumps shall be sized and specified to operate as close as possible to their “maximum efficiency point” 
while meeting the operating conditions indicated on the data sheets.  The impellers for centrifugal pumps shall be 
sized and selected to meet these requirements, but the pump models shall be selected so that the impeller that 
meets these requirements is neither the largest nor smallest available for the particular pump model for which it 
is installed.  Pump impellers shall be statically and dynamically balanced. 
 
2.4.2. 
Pump Motors   
 
Provide motors that are non-overloading within the full range of the pump performance curve. 
 
2.5. 
HEAT EXCHANGERS 
 
Heat exchangers shall comply with the requirements indicated on the attached data sheets (specification 230755).  
They shall be oriented and installed on the skid so that they can be serviced without the requirement to completely 
remove them from the skid or to remove other components from the skid.  This shall include adequate pull space 
for shell and / or tube bundle for shell-and-tube exchangers.  All ASME-rated heat exchangers shall be provided 
with the appropriate pressure safety relief devices, which shall be constructed of stainless steel.  For heat 
exchangers specified as requiring insulation, the insulation shall be factory installed by the heat exchanger 
manufacturer. 
 
Steam and condensate piping for each heat exchanger shall be configured to prevent stall conditions at low load.  
No vacuum breakers shall be installed on the shell (steam) side of the unit, but each unit shall be provided with 
an automatic air vent. 
 
2.5.1. 
Sanitary Shell and Tube Heat Exchangers 
 
Sanitary shell and tube heat exchangers shall be used on critical systems with CIP solution flow through the tubes 
and utility flow through the shell.  The heat exchanger shall be installed with a 5° tilt for drainability when installed 
horizontally.  Assuming the heat exchanger is a U-tube design, the tilt shall have the tubeside head or bonnet at 
the low end.  Final orientation and installation shall assure complete drainability on the sanitary (tube) side with 
no crevices or dead legs.  Bypass drain channels shall be provided on the tube side heads where necessary to 
facilitate drainability.  Whenever possible, each heat exchanger and connected process piping shall be configured 
and oriented so that the flow of CIP fluid is upward through the unit in order to displace air from the tube side.  
The heat exchanger should be a double tube sheet design to prevent contamination of the CIP stream with the 
utility flow.  The shell side should be baffled as necessary to ensure turbulent flow and increased heat transfer 
coefficient.   
 
 
 
 
 
2.6. 
PROCESS AND VENT FILTERS 
 
Sanitary cartridge style filter housings for gas filtration and tank vent filtration shall comply with the requirements 
indicated on the attached data sheets (specification 433113).  Provide the housing with the appropriate fittings 
and valves to allow for complete drainability during process and cleaning operations.  Each filter housing shall 
be oriented and installed so that the housing dome can be easily removed, with a filter installed in the housing, 
with no other disassembly required on the skid.    
 
2.6.1. 
Air Filter 
 
This filter housing is for air (or inert gas) used for pressure testing and / or air blow phases.  It will be installed in 
such a manner that air flow is from the outside of the element in.   
 
2.6.2. 
Vent Filter 
 
The final rinse tank should have a hydrophobic sterilizing grade vent filter on the tank headspace.  This filter 
should be sized appropriately to vent air from the vessel during filling and pull air during tank draining.      
 
2.7. 
NON-SANITARY STEAM TRAPS 
 
Provide a pressure powered pumping trap for the heat exchanger according to the P&ID. 
 
2.7.1. 
Pressure Powered Pumping Trap 
 
Provide a Spirax Sarco, or approved equivalent, pressure powered pumping trap which will use the supply steam 
as the motive force.  The pumping trap shall be vented to the shell side of the heat exchanger to provide for proper 
operation, and otherwise installed per the trap manufacturer’s recommendations.   
 
2.8. 
SANITARY RUPTURE DISKS 
 
Rupture disks will be BS&B GCR-SMS.  Rupture disk housing/body shall be 316L stainless steel with sanitary 
clamp end connections.  Disk shall be of non-fragmenting type with Teflon gasket.  Maximum burst tolerance 
range shall be ±5% of the requested burst pressure.  Supply disks with a 0% Manufacturing range. 
 
A disk burst sensor and monitor shall be provided where indicated on drawings.  Sensor shall be suitable for 
operation at temperatures of 250°F.  Sensor shall be designed for normally closed output. Burst sensor lead length 
shall be 25 feet minimum or as coordinated with the control’s contractor. 
 
2.9. 
CONTROLS 
 
This skid is to be controlled via the site DCS (DeltaV), refer to Division 40 Specifications for complete 
instrumentation and control system details.  The automated process control system shall include the following 
items as a minimum: 
• 
FIP (Field Instrument Panel) 
• 
Transmitters 
• 
Solenoids (for open-closed pneumatic valves) and I/P Converters (for pneumatic modulating valves) 
• 
Analyzers 
• 
Electrical Wiring (power and communication) 
• 
E-Stop button. 
 
The process control system shall be designed to minimize operator input requirements. 
 
The control system shall activate automatic valves, electric motors and instruments as required by programmed 
steps or phases.  The unit shall be programmed to alarm deviations from selected procedures and to indicate 
problem areas via diagnostic indicators and the control panel.   The Manufacturer shall provide all necessary 
instrumentation for fully automatic sequence of operations.  The control system shall be capable of performing 
the indicated automation on the P&ID and the following: 
• 
See section Basic Functional Description for process valve sequencing. 
• 
Alarm Detection (audible and visual) 
• 
Manual and automatic system control method editing routines. 
• 
Process data logging 
• 
Manual operation of each automated valve through OIT. 
 
2.9.1. 
Alarms and Diagnostics 
 
The control system shall generate alarms for, at a minimum, the conditions as stated in the datasheet.  Upon 
generation of an alarm, the control system shall initiate the following steps: 
• 
Shut down the supply pump 
• 
Close the steam control valve 
• 
Close all valves on the skid. 
 
2.10. INSTRUMENTATION 
 
All instrumentation shall conform the attached list, 458050, CIP Skid Appendix A.  Instrumentation shall be 
provided that will be capable of monitoring and/or controlling the following process conditions: 
 
• 
Conductivities of the CIP supply and return streams 
• 
Temperatures of the CIP supply and return streams 
• 
CIP supply flow rate (downstream of pump discharge, prior to any diversion of flow) 
• 
Water quantity used per cycle step (can be determined by integration (totalization) of CIP supply flow 
rate for each cycle step) 
• 
Flow verification on the CIP return line (flow switch) 
• 
CIP supply pressure (downstream of pump discharge, prior to any diversion of flow) 
• 
Liquid level in each CIP tank 
• 
Pump speed 
• 
Differential pressure across CIP return strainer 
 
2.10.1. Conductivity 
 
The CIP piping on each skid shall be equipped with three (3) conductivity meters: two (2) mounted on the CIP 
supply piping system and one (1) on the return piping system.  The CIP return conductivity meter should be 
capable of measuring accurately at the conductivity limits per the attached datasheet.  Each meter shall have tri-
clamp process connections. 
 
2.10.2. Temperature 
 
CIP supply and return stream temperatures shall be measured using direct immersion RTDs with tri-clamp 
connections.  The CIP supply RTD shall be located just downstream of the heat exchanger and shall be used to 
control the steam supply valve on the steam supply line to the heat exchanger.  The return line RTD shall be 
located on the skid return line just upstream of the divert valve assembly and will be used for verification that 
entire CIP circuit was exposed to adequate temperature CIP fluid, and this signal MAY be used for cascade control 
of CIP supply temperature set-point (within limits).    
 
 
2.10.3. Flow Rate/Cycle Water Quantities 
 
The CIP supply flow rate shall be measured with a mass flow meter.  Magnetic flow meters should not be used 
because they cannot properly read the flow rate of high purity water.  Each flow meter shall be supplied and 
installed with an integral indicating transmitter, with its display oriented for ease of readability.  Each transmitter 
shall have totalizing functions to allow for monitoring water quantities used per cycle. 
 
2.10.4. Flow Switch 
 
A sanitary flow switch shall be installed on the skid return line just upstream of the divert valve assembly to verify 
flow back to the CIP skid.  The switch shall be direct immersion with tri-clamp connections. 
 
2.10.5. Pressure 
 
A sanitary diaphragm pressure indicating transmitter shall be installed on the CIP supply line downstream of the 
supply pump, prior to any diversion of flow.  The pressure range should be determined based on the maximum 
system operating pressure which is usually based on the dead-headed CIP supply pump pressure and is 
proportional to the impeller size.  If a flow control valve is used on the CIP supply line, the pressure should be 
measured upstream and downstream of the valve. 
 
Sanitary diaphragm pressure indicating transmitters shall be installed upstream and downstream of the sanitary 
strainer located on the CIP return line to allow differential pressure monitoring across the strainer.  
 
2.10.6. Liquid Level 
 
The liquid level in each tank shall be monitored with sanitary, guided wave radar level elements with integral, 
indicating transmitters.  The elements shall mount to the tanks with tri-clamp process connections. 
 
2.10.7. Pump Speed 
 
The CIP supply pump speed shall be varied to meet different cleaning cycle requirements using a constant torque 
Variable Frequency Drive (VFD), which shall be preset and fixed per cycle.  Where utilized, dynamic flow control 
will be accomplished with a flow control valve.  Pump speed shall be indicated at the OIT via an output from the 
VFD (an algorithm shall map speed to frequency). 
 
2.11. SAFETY 
 
The manufacturer shall document all safety features and shall provide a detailed list of safety interlocks in English. 
 
2.12. ELECTRICAL 
 
Refer to specification 260660 (Electrical Requirements for Packaged Equipment) for details about the electrical 
system.  Power to each piece of equipment shall be provided by the facility to a single point of connection per 
power type as listed on the data sheet.  The Manufacturer shall provide a lockable disconnect for each connection 
point.   
 
The Manufacturer shall warrant that all wiring and electrical components shall comply with the NEC, as well as 
all applicable local electrical codes.  All wiring and components shall be rated appropriately and suitable for the 
environment in which the equipment is installed.   
 
2.12.1. Emergency Stop 
 
Manufacturer shall provide a hard-wired lockable emergency stop button on the control panel for shutdown of 
the system in the event of emergency.  Emergency stop shall disable all outputs and reset the valves, agitator and 
 
pumps to a fail-safe position, while maintaining inputs for monitoring capability.  The Owner or Owner’s 
Representative shall approve the location of the emergency stop switch location on the equipment panel. 
 
2.13. STRUCTURAL 
 
The skid support structure shall consist of box beams, “diamond plate”, railing, etc of the material stated on the 
datasheet.  All surfaces must be mechanically polished to the polish indicated on the datasheet.  
 
All skid components, including tanks, piping, flow meters, valves, filter housings, pumps, in-line monitoring 
instruments, etc., must be fully supported without interfering with disassembly for regular maintenance.  All tri-
clamp ferrules must mate-up without using force to move piping into the correct position.  Similarly, un-clamped 
ferrules may not “spring apart” upon release of the tri-clamp. 
 
Any required platforms shall conform with applicable building codes and standards and shall be designed and 
stamped by a licensed structural engineer registered in California. 
 
See Specification 230241 for additional Structural Requirements. 
 
 
PART 3. - EXECUTION 
 
3.1. 
FACTORY ACCEPTANCE TESTING (FAT) 
 
The Manufacturer shall perform Factory Acceptance Testing (FAT) as it is defined and specified in section 
110010. See attached specifications for additional FAT requirements.  The following items shall be required tests 
to be performed at FAT. 
 
 
3.1.1. 
General Verifications 
• 
Verify adherence to specifications and datasheets. 
• 
Verify adherence to approved drawings, including P&IDs. (order of take-off, order of instrumentation, 
slopes, tagging, etc.) 
• 
Verify compliance with project documentation. 
• 
Loop/instrument checks:  Verify the signal returns to the control system, not just continuity. 
• 
Instrument Calibration:  Vendor to calibrate instruments and control valves.   
• 
Internal and external surface finish testing using a profilometer. 
• 
Random check of piping and fitting heat numbers. 
• 
Sanitary clamp connections should be disassembled and reassembled to ensure correct “fit-up”. 
• 
Verify adequate support of all lines. 
• 
Valve angles (for drainability) should meet minimum tolerances. 
• 
Verify the system dimensions – tie-in points, footprint, slope, dimensional tolerances and height. 
• 
Review of Turnover package for accuracy and completeness 
 
3.1.2. 
Discharge Temperature 
 
The discharge temperature shall be measured to verify that the skid provides the specified discharge temperature.   
 
3.1.3. 
Pump Performance 
 
Test the pump to verify performance at the lowest and highest flow rates and corresponding discharge pressures.   
 
3.1.4. 
Spray Device Coverage 
 
See Specification 434113 for details. 
 
 
3.1.5. 
Drainability Testing of Vessel    
 
See Specification 434113 for details. 
 
3.1.6. 
Surface Finish Testing of Vessel   
 
See Specification 434113 for details. 
 
3.1.7. 
Heat Exchanger 
 
Test the ability to provide maximum heat transfer capacity.  Verify that the pressure drop across the heat 
exchanger is below the maximum allowable pressure drop.  Verify the drainability of the heat exchanger. 
 
3.1.8. 
Testing Responsibility Matrix 
 
  
X=Primary Responsibility 
for Developing Protocol 
O = Primary Responsibility 
for Executing Protocol 
 
S=Support

Consulting Engineer 
Construction Manager 
Client

3.2. 
SITE ACCEPTANCE TESTING (SAT) / COMMISSIONING AND STARTUP 
 
SAT will cover FAT items that were not addressed at Factory / Fab Shop, as well as ensure that the new system 
is adequately integrated into the facility. 
 
3.2.1. 
Basic Testing/General Verification 
 
Basic testing will typically include an inspection of the system using the Issued for Construction Drawings to 
verify their accuracy including flow paths and sloping.  This testing will also include an inspection of the system 
to verify correct installation to specification.  This testing will also include finish verification both on the inside 
and outside of the equipment to ensure no damage was incurred during transport.  Testing may include some or 
all items from the FAT described under General Verification. 
 
 
3.2.2. 
Flow Rate 
 
The specific flow rate for each individual CIP cycle and circuit should be tested to ensure the pressure drop for 
that system is being taken into account. 
 
3.2.3. 
Drainability 
 
The drainability of the CIP and process systems combined should be tested to verify that the system as one is 
drainable.   
 
3.2.4. 
Temperature Control 
 
Test the temperature control at the lowest and highest required set points.  Test the ability of the control valve to 
work together with the discharge temperature transmitter to attain the necessary temperature.  Test the ability of 
the CIP skid to overcome the thermal load of the CIP and process system for each circuit and supply solutions at 
the proper temperature. 
 
3.2.5. 
Chemical Injection Control 
 
CIP wash solutions should be prepared to verify that the system is capable of injecting chemicals into the skid or 
circuit and control the conductivity of the wash solution. 
 
 
END OF SECTION

NOTES: 
 
1. Control system components should provide the ability to control within these stated tolerances 
listed above. 
Description: CIP SKID 
Equipment No.: LA5CIP101 
 
2. VFD to be available for pump test at skid vendor’s site for FAT testing. 
3. CIP skid will be brought into the building through a 10 foot tall by 10 foot wide opening.  Any 
components that extend beyond this opening must be able to be removed during shipment and 
rigging.  
4. Client will provide a portable controller for the FAT for loop testing and run cycle testing.  
Manufacturer shall provide time to accommodate client engineering staff to setup and commission 
devices on control system.  
5. CIP Return filter strainer to be Angle-Line, 4" body, 25 Ra max ID, 35 Ra OD, EPDM gaskets, 3" 
x 15" element with 1/4" perforations, 20 mesh 316SS overlay 
6. Skid will be provided with a single E-stop on the control panel. Additional input required for 
remote-mounted E-stop, provided by others. 
7. Vendor to confirm if any parts such as vent filter exceed 8’ height maximum. 
8. Skid shall be provided with automatic pumping trap for condensate return. Pumping trap will be a 
Spirax Sarco APT-14 or approved equivalent. 
9. Insulation will be installed in the field by the owner/contractor.  CIP skid vendor shall design for 
insulation thicknesses specified on attached P&ID.
